webTitle: Round-up  Jim Bruce-Ball

fields.headline: Round-up  Jim Bruce-Ball
fields.trailText: While Birmingham City improved their chances of a play-off place with a 1-0 victory at Fulham, Graham Taylor's Watford suffered a setback in their bid to secure one of those spots with a 2-1 defeat at Norwich .
fields.body:
While Birmingham City improved their chances of a play-off place with a 1-0 victory at Fulham, Graham Taylor's Watford suffered a setback in their bid to secure one of those spots with a 2-1 defeat at Norwich .

The dismissal of the Watford striker Gifton Noel-Williams, just after the Hornets had taken the lead through Heidar Helguson, altered the course of the game according to Taylor, whose side went down to two late strikes from Steen Nedergaard and Lee Marshall.

"A red card doesn't always change the face of a game," Taylor said, "but in this instance it most certainly did."

He blamed Norwich's Chris Llewellyn for bringing on Noel-Williams's second booking and subsequent dismissal by play-acting after a challenge by the young forward.

"It often helps the referee if a player who has been fouled gets up straight away after a challenge. If a player doesn't roll about after a challenge it makes it much, much easier for officials to keep their cards in their pocket," he said.

In the only other First Division game Grimsby aided their survival hopes with a 2-1 home win over Portsmouth .

The Grimsby manager Lennie Lawrence said afterwards that his side needed six more wins to be safe. "We have taken a big step but we are under no illusions because we have been in a relegation battle since the day I came here," he said.

Grimsby dominated the first half with goals from Kevin Donovan and Steve Livingstone but Portsmouth pulled one back after the break.

The Portsmouth manager Steve Claridge afterwards accused some of his players of thinking "they are better than they are".

Walsall went top of the Second Division as the Portugese striker Jorge Leitao struck his 14th goal of the season in a 1-0 win at Cambridge .

Millwall , the previous leaders, were beaten 1-0 at the New Den by Bournemouth . However it was Claus Jorgensen who was on target and not the prolific Jermaine Defoe whose run of scoring in 10 successive games came to an end.

Wigan lost 2-0 at Stoke , who are now unbeaten in eight games and fifth in the table, while Rotherham kept up with the leading pack after a last-gasp win over Port Vale at Millmoor. Paul Warne scored in injury time to make it 3-2 to the home side.

Mark Allott hit two goals for Oldham in their 3-0 win over Brentford while Oxford remain rooted to the foot of the table after Joe Dunne's 45th-minute strike gave Colchester a 1-0 victory at the Manor Ground. It was the Us' fourth win in their last six matches.

Swindon eased out of the bottom three with a 3-0 win over Bury , who suffered their fourth consecutive defeat.

Peterborough , who are without a win in six games, earned a point from a goalless draw with Northampton .

webTitle: Chelsea facing tough test at Highbury

fields.headline: Chelsea facing tough test at Highbury
fields.standfirst: Full fifth round draw
fields.trailText: Arsenal and Chelsea may have exploited First Division defences to reach the last 16 of the FA Cup, but only one of the capital's aristocrats will make it to the quarter-finals after yesterday's draw.
fields.body:
Arsenal and Chelsea may have exploited First Division defences to reach the last 16 of the FA Cup, but only one of the capital's aristocrats will make it to the quarter-finals after yesterday's draw.

The Gunners, fresh from hitting QPR for six, welcome Chelsea to Highbury, though Claudio Ranieri's players will take heart from their 1-1 Premiership draw in north London this month.

Kingstonian, the only non-league survivors, will finally have an opportunity to test themselves against Premiership opposition if they overcome Bristol City in their replay. The Conference side, denied in the last seconds at Ashton Gate, have a visit to Leicester City as incentive.

Wycombe, who had never before reached the fifth round, have another home tie against either Middlesbrough or Wimbledon, for whom their manager Lawrie Sanchez scored the winning goal in the 1988 final.

West Ham's reward for their shock win at Old Trafford is a trip to another formidable fortress, Sunderland. Peter Reid's side, second in the Premiership, have not lost on Wearside since April.

Southampton have also been handed a third successive home draw and welcome Tranmere to the Dell; Rovers have won on the south coast already this season, knocking out Portsmouth in the third round.

Shaun Goater's late winner for Manchester City against Coventry has set up a tie at Liverpool, the 11-4 favourites, where City have failed to win since 1981. Bolton, who crushed Scunthorpe 5-1, will face their neighbours Blackburn if Rovers win at Derby in their replay.

Stockport County, through to the fifth round for only the third time in their history - the previous one was 51 years ago - will travel to either Charlton or Tottenham.

webTitle: Holdsworth's trio lays Cup jinx to rest

fields.headline: Holdsworth's trio lays Cup jinx to rest
fields.trailText: Dean Holdsworth's previous two outings in the Cup had ended in tears, for contrasting reasons, but he made it third time lucky yesterday with a hat-trick of headed goals that kept Bolton Wanderers on course for success on two fronts.
fields.byline: Ian Winrow at the Reebok stadium
fields.body:
Dean Holdsworth's previous two outings in the Cup had ended in tears, for contrasting reasons, but he made it third time lucky yesterday with a hat-trick of headed goals that kept Bolton Wanderers on course for success on two fronts.

The forward made an instant connection with the winger Nicky Summerbee, making his first full appearance after spending the first five months of the season in Sunderland's reserves, to banish the painful memories of Cup appearances past.

Holdsworth was the villain of the piece when he missed an open goal in the semi-final defeat by Aston Villa at Wembley last season and more recently, in the third-round victory over Yeovil Town this month, left the field with a horrific facial injury that required plastic surgery.

"The surgeon was here to watch and he was a bit worried when he heard that I was playing," the forward said. "But no way was I going to let that affect my performance. It was just one of those days when everything went right. Nicky Summerbee was brought to the club to deliver crosses like that and it's nice as a centre-forward to be able to attack balls of that quality."

Holdsworth rose unchallenged twice in two minutes before half an hour had gone to meet Summerbee crosses for the first two goals before Alex Calvo-Garcia's scrambled goal rekindled Scunthorpe's hopes of adding Bolton to their list of cup conquests. But Bolton made sure of their 10th win in 11 matches through a third Holdsworth header, this time from an Anthony Barness cross, and two well-taken goals from the young midfielder Kevin Nolan.

webTitle: Daggers blunted by sand and mud

fields.headline: Daggers blunted by sand and mud
fields.trailText: The defiant message from the Dagenham striker Junior McDougald afterwards was a familiar one from the have-nots to the rich. It was on the lines of "just because Charlton's team are in the Premiership and earn bucketloads of money, it doesn't make them better players than us".
fields.body:
The defiant message from the Dagenham striker Junior McDougald afterwards was a familiar one from the have-nots to the rich. It was on the lines of "just because Charlton's team are in the Premiership and earn bucketloads of money, it doesn't make them better players than us".

Warming to his theme, McDougald went on to suggest that Premiership managers could recruit more players from outside the league. But one can not imagine Arsène Wenger abandoning his penchant for French World Cup winners to trawl the Conference or the Dr Martens League in search of the new Thierry Henry.

McDougald, with his experience at Chesterfield, Millwall, Rotherham and Brighton, might be correct in his assertion that the gap between league and non-league is closing. But the fright his team gave Charlton was less to do with a shrinking class gap than a levelling of the playing field, or in this case, the un-levelling of it.

The pitch had a thicker covering of sand than Southend beach and the only places you could not see the bumps were on the parts so deep in mud that players were asking not what size stud it would take but which size boot. A welly might have been the answer.

On the sort of going more familiar at Leopardstown, it was remarkable that Dagenham could match the energy levels of their Premiership rivals, still forcing chances in the final seconds of the game. Charlton's manager Alan Curbishley remarked almost resentfully: "They never played as well as that when I watched them before the first match."

The Daggers, as their nickname suggests, also have a skilful cutting edge, personified by McDougald and Danny Shipp, formerly with West Ham and Coleraine, who fashioned the moment when the giantkilling trap might have snapped 12 minutes from the end of normal time, if there was anything normal about this match.

McDougald appeared to have lost possession when a ball played out to him wide on the left slipped under his foot. But he recovered it and cleverly turned back towards his own goal to shield the ball from two defenders before angling it delightfully into Shipp's path.

In one movement Shipp rolled his defender and shot, and Charlton's fans released an audible sigh of relief as the ball slapped the side netting.

That was the last outstanding chance for Dagenham, who discovered that if there is one difference between them and the Premiership, it is mental concentration. They were still trying to refresh theirs at the start of extra-time when Charlton swept forward for Shaun Newton to score the winner from John Salako's cross.

Furious at themselves and the injustice of it all, Dagenham forced the ball in themselves a few minutes later through Tim Cole, only for the goal to be disallowed for a foul. The Charlton goalkeeper Dean Kiely said: "I think the forearm smash in my face might have had something to do with it."

Charlton's players were upset before the game by the alliterative insult by some Dagenham players that they were pampered Premiership primadonnas, particularly as they consider themselves small fry in the top division.

Kiely said: "I've never been called pampered before in my life and I don't even recognise that term. I was at York City when we played Manchester United so I understand what it's like to be a small club taking on a big one. When we play Manchester United or Arsenal, we get in their faces and try to stop them performing. So it was no surprise Dagenham tried to do that to us."

webTitle: Chelsea calm jangling nerves

fields.headline: Chelsea calm jangling nerves
fields.trailText: The tone had been set by the Tannoy man before kick-off. "Have Chelsea got the fight for it," he asked as the teams took the field. "Have they got the bottle?" In the end Claudio Ranieri's side showed just enough of those qualities but it was nerve-janglingly tight.
fields.body:
The tone had been set by the Tannoy man before kick-off. "Have Chelsea got the fight for it," he asked as the teams took the field. "Have they got the bottle?" In the end Claudio Ranieri's side showed just enough of those qualities but it was nerve-janglingly tight.

Three goals ahead after 25 minutes, Chelsea tottered in typical away fashion to inject drama into a tie that had been heading for anti-climax. Not until Eidur Gudjohnsen scored their fourth deep into injury-time was Gillingham's stirring recovery killed off.

The First Division team deserved their ovation at the finish but it Chelsea who can look forward to a fifth-round tie at Arsenal. Their wait of almost 10 months for an away win is over but the stern look on Ranieri's face proved that relief rather than celebration was the overriding emotion.

"I have heard a lot about the FA Cup and everything I have heard was true," reflected Jesper Gronkjaer, scorer of two goals on an impressive first start for Chelsea. "It was very difficult. You saw what happened in the second half.

"I have played in many stadiums in front of many people but this crowd was amazing. I have a lot of respect for them. You have it in the back of your mind that maybe they will get it to 3-3 and then it would be difficult."

Such a close finish had seemed impossible at half-time. The pace and movement of Chelsea's attacks had been too much for Gillingham.

Those who wondered whether Chelsea had thrown away £7.8m on Gronkjaer after the long, injury-laden wait that followed his move from Ajax were treated to a fine performance as the 23-year-old flitted from flank to flank and scored twice.

With Eidur Gudjohnsen bustling menacingly around him, the holders looked in little danger. If there was no doubting Gillingham's fight, it seemed they had lost their bottle on the big occasion.

Yet led by their indefatigable captain Paul Smith, and helped by the introduction of the muscular Iffy Onuora at the interval, they produced a memorable fightback. First Paul Shaw and then Onuora pounced, and for the last 25 minutes Chelsea held out nervously as the decibel levels rose among an excited crowd.

"We believed perhaps we could nick another but it wasn't to be," said Gillingham's player-manager Andy Hessenthaler. "We made it hard for ourselves with our performance in the first half. You could see the difference in the leagues then and their class but we're disappointed with the way we defended."

Chelsea's pleasure at progressing will have been tempered by the sight of Jody Morris departing on a stretcher with ankle ligament damage, the full extent of which should be known today after a scan.

Frank Leboeuf, too, was carried off with a dead leg. His future, as well as his fitness, is in doubt after the Monaco president Jean-Louis Campora said he had no intention of signing the 33-year-old. Other reports last night suggested Monaco were simply looking to find the fee of around £2.5m.

Leboeuf had played a role in Chelsea's opener, his long ball culminating in Barry Ashby misdirecting a header back to Vince Bartram, which allowed Gudjohnsen to nod the ball into an empty net.

When Gronkjaer scored twice in 10 minutes after a spell of Gillingham pressure, first running on to Gudjohnsen's pass and cutting in to score with his right foot and then latching on to a Gianfranco Zola pass that caught out Chris Hope and scoring with his left, it seemed game over. But nothing is straightforward on Chelsea's travels. Shaw slid in the loose ball after Onuora's run had been stopped and 15 minutes later Onuora headed in after Carlo Cudicini had parried Nicky Southall's free-kick to give Gillingham hope.

But the chance they craved never arrived and Chelsea, who hit the post and bar in the second half, could finally relax when Gudjohnsen volleyed in Graeme le Saux's cross to put those questions about fight and bottle to rest.

webTitle: Celtic quick to brush off the cobwebs

fields.headline: Celtic quick to brush off the cobwebs
fields.trailText: Celtic won themselves a fourth-round trip to St Johnstone or Dunfermline after this routine victory at a cold and frosty Stranraer last night, the Premier League leaders quickly taking the initiative and defiantly holding it throughout.
fields.body:
Celtic won themselves a fourth-round trip to St Johnstone or Dunfermline after this routine victory at a cold and frosty Stranraer last night, the Premier League leaders quickly taking the initiative and defiantly holding it throughout.

Martin O'Neill's side, back on competitive duty after their winter break, created two openings inside two minutes. Ramon Vega's cross was headed goalward by Henrik Larsson but Mark McGeown was down low to his left to turn the ball around the post. And from the resulting corner Vega fired Bobby Petta's cross over the bar from six yards.

Stranraer were under intense pressure from the start and the referee Stuart Dougal added to it when he awarded Celtic a free-kick after deciding that Keith Knox had brought down Petta. Neil Lennon angled the ball to the far post and Vega again got on the end of it but headed over.

However, the Celtic defence was opened in the 15th minute and Stranraer could have taken a sensational lead. Ian Harty played Paul Walker clean through and he cut inside Joos Valgaeren before unleashing a right-foot effort which Robert Douglas saved low to his right.

Celtic, however, were always in control and took the lead in the 23th minute. Lennon's cross was headed goalward by Vega and, though it was destined for the back of the net, the Belgium international Valgaeren made sure with a header at the back post.

McGeown was being kept busy and in the 28th minute he prevented a second when he saved Larsson's header from Lennon's cross. And three minutes before the interval the visitors again went within inches after Paul Blair was booked for sending the impressive Petta sprawling. Lennon floated in the free-kick and Larsson watched his close-range volley rebound from the bar.

Stranraer's hopes of making a name for themselves were shattered in the 51st minute when Celtic produced a classy move to double their lead. Chris Sutton played the ball inside to Larsson, who squared the ball for Jackie McNamara to blast home a right-foot shot.

They scored another four minutes later. Petta's dangerous cross was fired into his own net by Knox, who was sporting a bandaged head after a collision with Vega.

Shortly after the hour O'Neill sent on Lubo Moravcik and Paul Lambert, for whom it was a first appearance in Scotland since being injured in November. McNamara looked certain to score his second goal of the game after an inch-perfect through-ball from Moravcik but McGeown was quickly off his line to deny him.

Stranraer did find the net in the 84th minute when Harty took advantage of some sloppy defending on the Celtic left, but within a minute Moravcik restored the three-goal margin when his shot squeezed under McGeown's body and over the line.

Fourth-round draw: Berwick or Hearts v Dundee or Falkirk; Motherwell v Dundee United; Queen of the South or Airdrie v Peterhead; St Johnstone or Dunfermline v Celtic; Stirling Albion v Hibernian; Inverness Caledonian Thistle v Kilmarnock; Ross County v Rangers; Livingston v Aberdeen.

Ramon Vega's cross was headed goalward by Henrik Larsson but Mark McGeown was down low to his left to turn the ball around the post. And from the resulting corner Vega fired Bobby Petta's cross over the bar from six yards. Stranraer were under intense pressure from the start and the referee Stuart Dougal added to it when he awarded Celtic a free-kick after deciding that Keith Knox had brought down Petta. Neil Lennon angled the ball to the far post and Vega again got on the end of it but headed over. However, the Celtic defence was opened in the 15th minute and Stranraer could have taken a sensational lead. Ian Harty played Paul Walker clean through and he cut inside Joos Valgaeren before unleashing a right-foot effort which Robert Douglas saved low to his right. Celtic, however, were always in control and took the lead in the 23th minute. Lennon's cross was headed goalward by Vega and, though it was destined for the back of the net, the Belgium international Valgaeren made sure with a header at the back post. McGeown was being kept busy and in the 28th minute he prevented a second when he saved Larsson's header from Lennon's cross. And three minutes before the interval the visitors again went within inches after Paul Blair was booked for sending the impressive Petta sprawling. Lennon floated in the free-kick and Larsson watched his close-range volley rebound from the bar. Stranraer's hopes of making a name for themselves were shattered in the 51st minute when Celtic produced a classy move to double their lead. Chris Sutton played the ball inside to Larsson, who squared the ball for Jackie McNamara to blast home a right-foot shot. They scored another four minutes later. Petta's dangerous cross was fired into his own net by Knox, who was sporting a bandaged head after a collision with Vega. Shortly after the hour O'Neill sent on Lubo Moravcik and Paul Lambert, for whom it was a first appearance in Scotland since being injured in November. McNamara looked certain to score his second goal of the game after an inch-perfect through-ball from Moravcik but McGeown was quickly off his line to deny him. Stranraer did find the net in the 84th minute when Harty took advantage of some sloppy defending on the Celtic left, but within a minute Moravcik restored the three-goal margin when his shot squeezed under McGeown's body and over the line. Fourth-round draw: Berwick or Hearts v Dundee or Falkirk; Motherwell v Dundee United; Queen of the South or Airdrie v Peterhead; St Johnstone or Dunfermline v Celtic; Stirling Albion v Hibernian; Inverness Caledonian Thistle v Kilmarnock; Ross County v Rangers; Livingston v Aberdeen.

webTitle: Andersen thrives as a Norwegian would

fields.headline: Andersen thrives as a Norwegian would
fields.trailText: As legacies go it is hardly up there with John Lennon's back catalogue, but when Trond Andersen scored from the edge of the area Wimbledon were in receipt of a welcome payback from the disastrous nine months Egil Olsen spent as their manager last season.
fields.body:
As legacies go it is hardly up there with John Lennon's back catalogue, but when Trond Andersen scored from the edge of the area Wimbledon were in receipt of a welcome payback from the disastrous nine months Egil Olsen spent as their manager last season.

Andersen was the only Don on show to have been brought to the club by the maverick Norwegian, and when the midfielder met Marcus Gayle's cross at the edge of the box and beat two defenders before powering a header into the corner to settle this scrappiest of matches it was instant karma all round.

Strange then that the winner came with County in a rare moment of ascendancy after the visitors had Chris Willmott sent off for two bookable offences and with his manager Terry Burton expecting his team to take their chance on penalties. Mind you had the otherwise impressive Patrick Agyemang, Jason Euell or Damien Francis been more incisive, it would have been over long before 90 minutes.

"That's the third time this season we've been down to 10 men and we've won them all," Burton said later. "We also beat Middlesbrough 1-0 at home in the League Cup earlier this season but they are a stronger side now, very difficult to beat."

So were Notts County, who had their moments, not least when a free-kick from Gary Owers found Anders Jacobsen only for the unmarked defender to sky his close-range effort. Danny Allsopp also dragged a chance wide and Mark Stallard had a 20-yard drive deflected for a corner.

But they never came to terms with an injury to their central defender Ian Richardson, which forced the manager Jocky Scott to reshuffle after 20 minutes and withdraw Adam Newton to right-back. With that the midfield lost much of its attacking threat.

"I was disappointed with myself," said the loanee from West Ham who along with Joe Cole and Michael Carrick played a distinguished part in the 1999 Youth Cup-winning team. "I had a job to do but I kept giving the ball away. I've been brought up to pass to feet, pass and move, and I've got to get used to Notts County's style.

"I've been here two months and am still not quite on the same wavelength, but when it all clicks it goes quite smoothly."

Newton keeps in touch with Carrick and Cole and was on the phone to congratulate Jermain Defoe last week. "But all I'm really thinking about is helping County to promotion or into a play-off spot," he said. "I'm very grateful to them for giving me this opportunity and I wish to take it."

The Dons will be thinking along similar lines when they get to the Riverside on Tuesday week.

webTitle: Villa's season blows up in their face

fields.headline: Villa's season blows up in their face
fields.trailText: It is not known whether David Ginola looked back in anger as he drove off an hour before kick-off, feeling unused and unwanted. Around 2 hours later John Gregory left, with Aston Villa still in the Cup, to watch the £6m-rated Alaves striker Javi Moreno. Perhaps the manager, too, will be feeling the same sense of emptiness.
fields.body:
It is not known whether David Ginola looked back in anger as he drove off an hour before kick-off, feeling unused and unwanted. Around 2 hours later John Gregory left, with Aston Villa still in the Cup, to watch the £6m-rated Alaves striker Javi Moreno. Perhaps the manager, too, will be feeling the same sense of emptiness.

It is safe to say that the mood of the airport-bound Gregory darkened as much as that at the stadium when he heard that Arnar Gunnlaugsson's devastating shot six minutes from the end of a torrid rancorous tie had knocked the stuffing out of their season.

This was a bitter defeat that saw Villa's goalkeeping coach Paul Barron remonstrating with the referee Uriah Rennie at the final whistle before being pulled away by Leicester's manager Peter Taylor as the home fans took it out on the man in black rather than those in claret and blue who had made far more mistakes.

Later the noises were conciliatory but hardly convincing. Villa's coach Steve Harrison emerged to heighten the air of unreality. "It's too soon to say the season is in tatters," he insisted. "Obviously we're very disappointed with our run of results. [But] they've got everything to play for, including a place in Europe."

The realistic view is that Villa's only European mission this year will be Gregory's current trip, during which he saw Moreno get the only goal of the game against Las Palmas.

And after last week's public criticism of the strikers by Doug Ellis, the chairman's many detractors will accuse him of speaking and, even worse, acting too late because the team's principal weakness was glaring long before the £9.5m Juan Pablo Angel was hired. But whoever is at fault, it is now clear that Villa have problems all over the pitch.

Ginola would simply like to have been out there and on Saturday evening the Frenchman was in philosophical mode. "I'm backing Aston Villa and I'm not here to cause any problems for them," he said. "I want to stay and I'll fight for my place." The words did not match the picture shortly before 2pm when he was told he was not on the bench. He soon sped away, albeit having been given permission to go home.

For all the Frenchman's faults it is difficult to imagine how he could have failed to add something to a fitful Villa performance that demonstrated that chronic forward failings are now being mirrored in defence, previously an area of strength.

It hardly helped that Darius Vassell, preferred to Dion Dublin, was sent off for his second needless late tackle. The numbers were levelled up seconds before half-time when Leicester's Callum Davidson received a second booking, for a reckless jump at Steve Staunton that prompted a mass brawl.

Amid all the fury, studded by unwanted advice by protesting players on both sides, Rennie calmly and correctly administered justice.

The major misjudgments were Villa's. Gareth Barry embarrassingly failed to cut out Matt Elliott's pass that sent Ade Akinbiyi to shoot against David James and roll the rebound home. Then the home defence was out-manoeuvred as the impressive 19-year-old Damien Delaney scooped a pass from which Elliott's beautifully volleyed touch set up Gunnlaugsson's thunderous left-foot finish.

It was a move of imagination and precision mocking the barrenness of the football before. Even if Villa improved in the second half their goal stemmed from a seeming miscue by Staunton and a clumsy Taggart challenge before Julian Joachim scored in his first appearance for nine weeks.

Ellis must be noting Villa's forthcoming fixtures. Like those at Bradford City and Derby, sandwiching the visit of Middlesbrough, next month. And his club's fall from fourth place to 13th in the space of two months. The chairman will also have noted the fact that Leicester, currently the Midlands' top team, have largely prospered under a new manager who has fashioned the sort of rapid overhaul needed at Villa Park. Taylor's team contained no fewer than seven signings since last summer. Perhaps no one is irreplaceable, not even Martin O'Neill.

webTitle: Rangers' stitching comes undone exposing the scars below

fields.headline: Rangers' stitching comes undone exposing the scars below
fields.trailText: Gerry Francis got mugged down memory lane and it was sad to see. A likeable bloke and talented manager, he and his beloved Queens Park Rangers were brutally reminded how far they have both fallen since beating Arsenal was as common as a top-10 finish.
fields.body:
Gerry Francis got mugged down memory lane and it was sad to see. A likeable bloke and talented manager, he and his beloved Queens Park Rangers were brutally reminded how far they have both fallen since beating Arsenal was as common as a top-10 finish.

A combination of poor managerial appointments and lack of cash have turned the club into a candidate for one of those tabloid before-and-after pictures that show the effects of a bad face-lift.

The contrast must have been particularly galling not just for Francis but Rangers' former Gunners Chris Kiwomya, Matthew Rose, Steve Morrow and Lee Harper. Theirs was the only cup upset on view at Loftus Road on Saturday.

There is one way of looking at this game from which Rangers emerge in a better light. They spurned two great chances before Arsenal went 3-0 ahead, and that was only thanks to two own goals and a deflection.

This was Francis's line of defence afterwards and with games against Fulham and Bolton coming up one can understand him trying to strain positive thoughts from the dregs of defeat.

But even he privately cannot have been blind to the gulf in class, invention, touch, movement and ideas separating the sides. The threat even from this injury-hit Arsenal was evident from the start even if they did need help to cure their recent scoring sickness.

Admittedly, Rangers' policy of pumping high balls into the area did cause early problems and Peter Crouch missed from four yards and then saw his header smuggled off the line.

But having failed to comply with the first law of cup upsets (take your chances) Rangers then forgot the second: keep your concentration and shape.

From the clearance, Arsenal raced to the other end, caught Rangers short at the back and Chris Plummer panicked enough to divert Lee Dixon's cross into his own net. A minute later Sylvain Wiltord's strike hit Ian Baraclough to wrong-foot Ludek Miklosko and the game was all but over.

That Rangers had now been failed by the third law of cup upsets (the need for luck) was rubbed in five minutes into the second half when Rose deflected an Ashley Cole cross past his own keeper.

By then Francis had thrown on a third forward in a gallant attempt to play catch-up. It proved suicidal. Wiltord volleyed in No4 Pires clinically dispatched No5 and Dennis Bergkamp's cool finish completed the rout.

webTitle: Punters following County have their Wiss come true

fields.headline: Punters following County have their Wiss come true
fields.trailText: Tenuous they may be, but the signs are that Stockport may emerge as the punter's friend in this year's FA Cup. That view would certainly find favour in Finland, where a select few benefited from Jarko Wiss's inside knowledge.
fields.body:
Tenuous they may be, but the signs are that Stockport may emerge as the punter's friend in this year's FA Cup. That view would certainly find favour in Finland, where a select few benefited from Jarko Wiss's inside knowledge.

The Finnish international midfielder claimed his first goal in the competition four minutes from time, much to the relief of family and friends who had taken his advice on the result.

"I gave everyone back home a tip that they should back us to win and I know a lot of my friends will have made some money," said Wiss, who should line up against Sven-Goran Eriksson's England in March's World Cup qualifier.

It would be generous to describe County's cup pedigree even as modest, but more desperate followers of fate would be advised to pay attention to the club's progress. Their two previous fifth-round appearances both ended in defeat at the hands of eventual losing finalists, West Brom in 1935 and Liverpool in 1950.

Of more relevance to the Stockport manager Andy Kilner is that his side remain unbeaten this year with only one goal conceded. That record would have been more seriously challenged had Crewe's Rodney Jack not fluffed a tap-in from two yards.

County's captain Mike Flynn could not believe Jack's blunder. "There were two of them inside the six-yard box and they could have played keepy-up before scoring," the centre back said. "I think he was trying to be a bit flash and it looked as though he was taking the mickey.

"All we want now is a little bit of luck in the draw. We've been drawn away in our last 10 cup ties." They did not get it; a trip to Tottenham or Charlton awaits.

Mug punters take note.

webTitle: No charity for masked Chapple

fields.headline: No charity for masked Chapple
fields.trailText: It would be impossible to create a more perverse or cruel commentary on Cup heroics. Kingstonian, mocking their lowly status near the bottom of the Conference, were on their way to the fifth round - until the fourth minute of injury time.
fields.body:
It would be impossible to create a more perverse or cruel commentary on Cup heroics. Kingstonian, mocking their lowly status near the bottom of the Conference, were on their way to the fifth round - until the fourth minute of injury time.

In their dug-out, the occupants were shouting for the referee to blow for time. Their supporters were poised for the celebratory yells. It seemed certain that Bristol City were about to become the Surrey club's eighth Cup victims from the Football League.

The Ks packed the penalty area as Scott Murray's out-swinging corner came over. Lee Peacock nudged it on to Tony Thorpe, the leading scorer who had remained on the bench until after the interval. He, awkwardly positioned, stabbed the ball past Gavin Kelly, the talented 19-year-old on loan from Spurs and Kingstonian's seventh keeper of the season.

It was the last kick of the match. What followed gave the lie to the idea that soccer long ago lost its soul. The collective dejection was almost tangible. Half the visiting team sprawled on the ground in despair, not hearing the warmth of the ovation that the west country crowd were giving them.

The Kingstonian manager Geoff Chapple masked his own feelings as he walked on to the field to console the tearful. In his long blue overcoat he did not look much like the archetypal team manager. Through the game he had stood on the edge of the dug-out, offering advice with a minimum of emotion. Now at the end he actually smiled, a gentle reaction that implied they could still rise again on Tuesday week, at Brentford's Griffin Park.

"I told the players before this tie that we could go to Old Trafford in the next round. We still can," said the 55-year-old one-time insurance agent after the game - though, unlike Kingstonian, Manchester United did not make it to the fifth-round draw. "I think we did non-league football proud," said Chapple. "This was a game when we made a lot of friends."

Overall Kingstonian probably defended better than City. Mark Harris, Eddie Saunders, a former basketball pro, and Derek Allan blocked the middle with unfussy skills. In midfield Geoff Pitcher is clearly misplaced in the Conference and could soon be returning to higher status; like City's Brian Tinnion, he passes the ball with intuitive precision. Maybe family relations help: he had his brother-in-law Mark Beard prompting away on his right.

Bristol were not too often allowed to settle and find the space and rhythm that has taken them up the Second Division table. There was a slightly frantic, nervous element to their play after they conceded a needless goal.

Louis Carey blundered with a back-pass in the 57th minute, allowing the busy Phil Wingfield, his Saturday football a therapy from carpet cleaning, to weave round Steve Phillips and score with the perfect angled shot.

Just before that Ian Duerden, a newcomer from Doncaster, had a better chance and fluffed it, though City - and Peacock in particular - might have put the tie outside Kingstonian range. Keith Millen, the Bristol captain who used to play with Pitcher at Watford, said: "We never made the mistake of underestimating them. And that goes for the replay."

webTitle: Late drama but nothing to phone home about

fields.headline: Late drama but nothing to phone home about
fields.trailText: The mobile phone has even intruded into the mindset of the football supporter. It is now no longer enough to debate the highlights of a match with fellow spectators while scurrying back to the car. The need now is to identify a friend who was not there, and provide an instant appraisal. Match reports on the whistle, whether you like it or not.
fields.body:
The mobile phone has even intruded into the mindset of the football supporter. It is now no longer enough to debate the highlights of a match with fellow spectators while scurrying back to the car. The need now is to identify a friend who was not there, and provide an instant appraisal. Match reports on the whistle, whether you like it or not.

While the inimitable football bard, Stuart Hall, was delivering his Five Live rhapsody, Jaz's breathless mobile call possessed an earthier but equally arresting theme. "Last minute, yeah, Goater's header, bang, straight in, fights broke out, the police were called in, amazing finish. The rest of it was crap, though, mate."

It was, too. Shaun Goater, brought on with 19 minutes remaining, salvaged a desperately poor Manchester City display when he headed in Tony Grant's corner in the second minute of injury-time. Coventry were out of the Cup and out of luck, but at least they seem the likelier of these two sides to preserve their Premiership status.

The goal sparked outbreaks of fighting in the main stand, when Coventry supporters invaded a home section, and more than 10 minutes elapsed before police and stewards restored order. It was never frightening, but it was a disturbing throwback to English football's wretched hooligan years, and will inevitably require an FA inquiry.

Manchester City's midfield was overstocked with defenders with barely a creative bone in their body. Their best prospects seemed to rest with the uncertainty of Magnus Hedman in Coventry's goal and it was Hedman, indeed, whose confusion with Paul Williams first conceded the corner and then allowed Goater a free header.

Paulo Wanchope stalked angrily down the tunnel upon being substituted. Goater's goal vindicated Joe Royle's decision, and Wanchope had made no valuable contribution. His anger should have been directed at himself.

Williams spent half the after noon trying to calm him down; a less honest and more calculating defender might have imagined he could goad Huckerby into getting himself sent off.

Coventry's liveliest moments came through Craig Bellamy, who led the line sparkily, and who deserves better fortune. John Eustace struck the post in the first half from Bellamy's pass, and Bellamy headed narrowly wide from Eustace's driven cross.

That apart, there was little worth telling. Mobiles have long become the accepted method of disseminating totally worthless information. This was a match that belonged on the end of a mobile phone call.

webTitle: Cut jail population to minimum, Blair told

fields.headline: Cut jail population to minimum, Blair told
fields.trailText: Lord Woolf, the lord chief justice, is expected this week to call on the government to end prison overcrowding, arguing that it is time the jail population was reduced to "an unavoidable minimum".
fields.body:
Lord Woolf, the lord chief justice, is expected this week to call on the government to end prison overcrowding, arguing that it is time the jail population was reduced to "an unavoidable minimum". This week sees the 10th anniversary of the publication of Lord Woolf's report into prison conditions in the wake of the Strangeways riot and he is expected to use the annual Prison Reform Trust lecture on Wednesday to argue that its reform agenda is as relevant today as it was a decade ago.
The prison population stood at only 45,600 when Lord Woolf first called for prison numbers to be reduced to the "unavoidable minimum" but it now stands at more than 62,000 and is projected to rise to 70,800 in the next two years. Lord Woolf is expected to revive his recommendations that prisoners should be held nearer their homes. Some 26,000 in mates are still held more than 50 miles from home, and 11,000 more than 100 miles.
The former Conservative home secretary, Lord Hurd of Westwell, in an interview with the Guardian, also warns of the corrosive impact of overcrowding. He says that it is time for inmates to be given the vote and for a prime minister to visit a prison.
"If prisoners had the vote then MPs would take a good deal more interest in conditions in prison," he said. Lord Hurd also says no serving prime minister has ever visited a prison and discloses that a plan for Tony Blair to do so was shelved because of public relations fears .
"It is one of our public services and prisons are important institutions. Prisons are not a series of wastepaper baskets into which you can simply toss somebody and not hear from them again."

webTitle: Hot-wired Sanchez gives Wolves an electric shock

fields.headline: Hot-wired Sanchez gives Wolves an electric shock
fields.trailText: Wycombe Wanderers are known as the Chairboys after the furniture-making industry in Buckinghamshire but they are going to have to change their nickname if they carry on like this. The Electric Chairboys might be more appropriate after they shocked Wolverhampton Wanderers with a late goal and sent them back to the black country looking completely frazzled, their season as good as over.
fields.body:
Wycombe Wanderers are known as the Chairboys after the furniture-making industry in Buckinghamshire but they are going to have to change their nickname if they carry on like this. The Electric Chairboys might be more appropriate after they shocked Wolverhampton Wanderers with a late goal and sent them back to the black country looking completely frazzled, their season as good as over.

"We got caught with a sucker punch," said the Wolves manager Dave Jones after only his third game in charge. "Everybody's disappointed because we feel that we shouldn't have come away with nothing."

Try telling that to Wycombe. Harrow Borough, Millwall and Grimsby Town have all fallen in a run that had taken Wycombe to the fourth round for the first time in their history and a ground that had never sold out before was packed to its near-10,000 capacity to see Wolves receive similar shock treatment.

Wycombe did not disappoint. This was the Cup tie that had everything, including appeals on local radio for volunteers to clear the pitch after the Chilterns awoke under a smattering of snow. Most of all it had an unlikely hero in Sam Parkin. 19 years old, on loan from Chelsea, never had a whiff of the Premiership first team - he came on as a late substitute and scored the winning goal.

"He put himself on the stage," said Wycombe's manager Lawrie Sanchez, holding court in the Second Division club's tiny gym. "I said to the players before the game that it was a day for heroes: if you score the winner today and we go through in the Cup people will be speaking about you and you'll be written about on the back pages tomorrow."

He should know, having scored the only goal in the 1988 final for Wimbledon against Liverpool, and so it came to pass for Parkin. "I was confident I could do it if I was given the chance to play and I feel I've repaid Lawrie's faith in me," he said.

When Parkin entered the action in the 66th minute Wycombe were on the ropes. Throughout the first half they had harried Wolves relentlessly, taking the lead shortly before half-time when Andy Rammell was first to a loose ball at a corner, but now they were exhaustedly trying to protect their goal.

Wolves equalised through a Carl Robinson header and another goal was on the cards. No one, however, expected it to be at the Wolves end, but then Steve Brown escaped down the left, whipped in a wicked cross and there was Parkin peeling away to meet the ball with a decisive header.

The teenager was most surprised of all. "Heading's not one of my strong points," he admitted. No one was complaining, though, and at least his mother was there to see it. The rest of the family had gone to Queens Park Rangers.

webTitle: Gloating Grainger sours success for City

fields.headline: Gloating Grainger sours success for City
fields.trailText: Wins do not come much more satisfying than this. Birmingham, constant cravers for the Premiership, beat a team whose thirst for the top flight will soon be quenched. In addition, City's own promotion hopes have been boosted and they will go into the second leg of their Worthington Cup semi-final against Ipswich at St Andrews on Wednesday full of belief that the Suffolk side can be overhauled.
fields.body:
Wins do not come much more satisfying than this. Birmingham, constant cravers for the Premiership, beat a team whose thirst for the top flight will soon be quenched. In addition, City's own promotion hopes have been boosted and they will go into the second leg of their Worthington Cup semi-final against Ipswich at St Andrews on Wednesday full of belief that the Suffolk side can be overhauled.

While this was a minor blip for Fulham, it was the perfect fillip for Birmingham. Ipswich have a 1-0 lead from the first leg, but City will be far more confident of reaching their first major cup final for 38 years after Martin Grainger's free-kick, combined with some resolute defending, dealt Fulham only their third league defeat of the season.

It was a shame, then, that the game was soured by an unseemly spat between Grainger and a section of Fulham supporters. As the second half began, the fans baited Grainger with some light-hearted abuse. As the chants became more offensive so Grainger's response hardened. He celebrated his goal with gusto in front of his tormentors and included the tiresome gesture of holding his hand to his ear.

The home fans took out their frustration at Fulham's inability to equalise on Grainger, booing his every touch. On the final whistle he was able to gloat again and his offensive hand gesture provoked fury in the stands.

Afterwards a Fulham spokesman said the club had received a "large number of complaints" about Grainger's actions and that some had been passed on to the police.

The left-back, who had come close with a free-kick on the stroke of half-time, provided a more appropriate response to the taunts with an effort three minutes into the second half that found its target and left Maik Taylor stranded.

Birmingham's win was sweet revenge for the televised hammering they received from Fulham in their first home game of the season.

Jean Tigana's side indicated immediately at St Andrews that day the hold they would exert on the division with a 3-1 win and, despite this defeat, the teams below them should not get too excited. Fulham were without their three main strikers, Luis Boa Morte and Louis Saha who were suspended and Barry Hayles who was injured. Between them they have scored all but 20 of Fulham's 65 league goals.

They, and Fulham, will soon be back and a trip to Queens Park Rangers on Wednesday night should allow them to extend their lead at the top to 10 points.

At the same time Birmingham will be playing for the right to play Liverpool at the Millennium stadium next month. After Saturday's success Cardiff will not seem quite so far away.

webTitle: Everton blacked out by Yates

fields.headline: Everton blacked out by Yates
fields.trailText: When Steve Yates rose highest in a crowded penalty area to head home a Jason Koumas corner, the 7,000-odd Tranmere fans inside Goodison Park plunged headlong into noisy delirium.
fields.body:
When Steve Yates rose highest in a crowded penalty area to head home a Jason Koumas corner, the 7,000-odd Tranmere fans inside Goodison Park plunged headlong into noisy delirium.

It was the postscript to a quite marvellous Tranmere performance. Their third goal, Yates's second, reiterated that a team of honest triers who crave victory will often eclipse a team of seasoned pros.

The second noise was altogether more curious, the sound of seats being turned up as thousands of Evertonians headed for the exits. Those who stayed to the bitter end did so only to register their disapproval in the traditional manner.

Yates, 31 today, who has been plying his trade around the lower divisions all his career, admitted: "I've never scored two in a game; I've hardly scored them in ones. It's nice to get a couple because I have waited 14 years to be a hero for once instead of being a villain."

Of Koumas, who scored Rovers' other goal with an angled chip from 20 yards, Yates said: "Jason's was a great finish and he played ever so well. Everybody did, but Jason just took the chance to show off his ability. He's a Premiership player and I'm sure there are a lot of clubs interested in him. He proved what a great player he is already by the way he took on Everton on their own ground."

Tranmere make a habit of upsetting Premiership sides, adding Everton to West Ham, Coventry, Middlesbrough, Sunderland and Leeds in the past 16 months. But Yates said: "This was the best of our cup giant-killings over the past couple of seasons. This time we not only had to face one of the biggest clubs around us but we had to do it on their ground. People expected us to get beaten so it was great to get ourselves into the next round with a performance like that."

Everton have had many, many dark days of late but this was a total blackout in terms of thought, reason, logic and, most significantly, pride.

It was almost impossible not to feel some sympathy for Walter Smith afterwards. As the cries of the disenchanted drifted up from the street below, he attempted to explain away the unexplainable, attempted without success to find some way of excusing the inexcusable. He simply pointed out that Tranmere took their goals well.

Having dominated the opening 10 or so minutes, Everton gave up. Tranmere isolated the weakest link in Everton's chain of many weak links, David Unsworth, and funnelled everything down the right flank. It was a clever ploy and Unsworth obliged with a series of errors. Unable to deal with the sprinting speed of the excellent Andy Parkinson, the former England international defender fell to pieces before being hauled off at half-time.

For Smith the damage had already been done. After 22 minutes Yates climbed well at the far post to send a looping header over the strangely leaden-footed Thomas Myhre, and 13 minutes on Koumas swept in gloriously.

Thereafter Tranmere, currently 21st in the First Division, began to swagger and but for some decidedly dodgy finishing - Yates's second goal apart - the final margin of victory would have been enormous rather than merely generous.

"My players are driving me mad," said Tranmere's manager John Aldridge. "They play so well in the cup games yet we are marooned near the foot of the First Division table. It's very confusing."

As those Everton supporters who applauded Aldridge's men off the pitch headed home, Goodison's public address system crackled into life. "We look forward to seeing you all again on Wednesday night when Middlesbrough are the visitors," said the disembodied voice without a hint of irony. No chance.

webTitle: Dichio makes hay to scythe down Tractor Boys

fields.headline: Dichio makes hay to scythe down Tractor Boys
fields.trailText: It was billed as the showdown between two of England's most potent sharpshooters, both on the verge of Sven-Goran Eriksson's first national squad after seven goals in their last seven appearances. Instead, emerging from the shadows of Kevin Phillips and Marcus Stewart came a lolloping Italian stallion to earn Sunderland their first fifth-round tie since they went all the way to the final in 1992.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
It was billed as the showdown between two of England's most potent sharpshooters, both on the verge of Sven-Goran Eriksson's first national squad after seven goals in their last seven appearances. Instead, emerging from the shadows of Kevin Phillips and Marcus Stewart came a lolloping Italian stallion to earn Sunderland their first fifth-round tie since they went all the way to the final in 1992.

Daniele Dichio, a perennial understudy to Niall Quinn, was given a rare start and, just as he had on New Year's Day in the Premiership, popped up with a well-deserved goal to stall the Tractor Boys. In contrast, Phillips, feeling "leggy" according to his manager, was substituted with Wednesday's visit of Manchester United in mind. Ipswich's Stewart, who had a 16th-minute shot saved but was too often forced to vacate the six-yard box and seek the ball nearer the half-way line, may as well have followed suit so anonymous was he in the second half.

With Stewart so withdrawn, the onus was on Alun Armstrong to excel, but the former Middlesbrough striker fluffed his lines. running on to Jim Magilton's pass, Armstrong shot weakly from just outside the area when he could have advanced further on to the exposed Thomas Sorensen, who gratefully caught the ball.

Three minutes later, Stanislav Varga's wonderful long pass was cushioned by Don Hutchison on the right wing and the Scottish international crossed smartly for Dichio, evading the lumbering Titus Bramble, to dive and head beyond Richard Wright.

Dichio has started only 35 matches since joining Sunderland from Sampdoria in 1998 for £750,000. There have been 56 substitute appearances, almost exclusively to replace Niall Quinn, and 18 goals along the way, but this was the former Queens Park Rangers striker's first-ever FA Cup goal.

"My Dad phoned me up last night and told me it was about time I got one in the Cup," he said on Saturday. "It was a good time to score because they were creating chances and we needed to stop their rhythm."

Dichio should have doubled his tally three minutes later, side footing Michael Gray's punt wide of the post, while his prodded effort from Hutchison's 57th-minute lob dribbled on to an upright. "Danny was superb, outstanding," said his manager Peter Reid.

"It's been difficult waiting in the wings, but it's a case of staying mentally strong," added Dichio. "I'm learning a lot from Quinny even when I'm not in the team - he encourages me to be confident in my ability and at half-time just urged me to keep battling away at their centre-halves. Even I'm asking just how long he's going to keep on playing, but at least the competition for a place gives me something to aim at. If I can achieve even half of what Niall's done for this club, I'll be pleased."

For Ipswich - whose slick passing lacked incision despite a switch to 4-4-2 at half-time - there was little consolation other than the second leg of their Worthington Cup semi-final against Birmingham. Bramble, who hobbled off with a calf strain, is unlikely to feature on Wednesday night.

webTitle: Derby bring back only pain from Spain

fields.headline: Derby bring back only pain from Spain
fields.trailText: There is nothing new about Brits returning from the Costa del Sol feeling slightly the worse for wear but for Jim Smith the after-effects of Derby's mid-season break in Spain were as unexpected as they were unwelcome.
fields.body:
There is nothing new about Brits returning from the Costa del Sol feeling slightly the worse for wear but for Jim Smith the after-effects of Derby's mid-season break in Spain were as unexpected as they were unwelcome.

His players spent most of last week on a club trip to Marbella; Smith could be excused for opting for a few nights in the Derbyshire foothills next time as they returned from Iberia with more than they had bargained for.

"I was about to bollock Malcolm Christie and Rory Delap and then I found out they had been up all night with bad stomachs. It turns out that six of them had been up from 2am but they hadn't dared tell me before the game," said Smith.

Sometimes things are not quite as they seem and though Derby stood accused of displaying a lack of ambition, there were obvious mitigating circumstances. "I don't know where this bug has come from but we've had to send two staff home as well," Smith added. "I wasn't in Spain and that might explain why I'm all right."

Given that his side already had eight senior players unavailable, Derby's manager could be excused a smile of satisfaction for extending the hosts to a replay. Yet Blackburn showed enough in the few moments of excitement to suggest that this tie is still finely poised, and Derby's home form over the past two seasons indicates they would be foolish to think anything else.

For long spells they were reduced to the smothering tactics more often employed by visiting teams to Old Trafford than Ewood Park, but Blackburn lacked the guile to break through and television replays refuted their complaints that Alan Mahon should have won a penalty from Bjorn Otto Bragstad's challenge.

Derby's only FA Cup triumph came in 1946 after their captain Jack Nicholas paid gypsies to lift a curse their ancestors had placed on the club when they were forced to move so the old Baseball Ground could be built. That 4-1 defeat of Charlton is now remembered as the burst-ball final. Saturday, alas, was another deflating experience.

webTitle: Booth has a hand in Saints' sloppy win

fields.headline: Booth has a hand in Saints' sloppy win
fields.trailText: This was "a bonus" for Wednesday, said their manager Paul Jewell, a chance for his mostly young side to test themselves against a team with whom they shared status last season. With bonuses like this, who can stand setbacks?
fields.body:
This was "a bonus" for Wednesday, said their manager Paul Jewell, a chance for his mostly young side to test themselves against a team with whom they shared status last season. With bonuses like this, who can stand setbacks?

Last week Howard Wilkinson, a predecessor at Hillsborough, called for a winter break. Wednesday, in place for their second drop running, could do with one from mid-November to mid-October. Outside 21 days last autumn, when they won four league games out of six, they have continued in last season's downward spiral.

Jewell insisted there was "no use feeling sorry for ourselves". He has just put Jimmy Shoulder, fresh from duties with Wales, in charge of the academy, joining his other Welsh discards, Terry Yorath and Peter Shreeves. Wales stand 109th in the world, two behind Oman.

Jewell said there was "nothing to lose", referring to the match. With luck his side may have gained what they most need - belief. Southampton, after scoring early, went sloppy and Wednesday, with a midfield four aged 20 to 22, came out from behind harassment and hope to show training-ground tricks, skill and poise after the interval. Behind them, Des Walker guided and covered with evergreen assurance.

Andy Booth's header crept in like an action replay and suddenly the match that never was came to life. Southampton, for the second round running, needed a late penalty by Jason Dodd to nail their Sheffield. Booth was the culprit. "He held his hand up afterwards," said Jewell. "I just wish he'd kept it down on the field."

The first and final goals were prefaced by superb blocking saves from Kevin Pressman. There were others too. One on one and 15 stone at the last weigh-in, he is a good spread bet.

Glenn Hoddle, a year in office at the Dell, said: "We're progressing but we've got to be more ruthless; goalscoring is the missing link in our play, rather like getting stuck on the last piece of a jigsaw." The dimmest child can put the last piece of a jigsaw in place. Hoddle may have been in safer territory when he added: "Until we learn to kill teams off, we'll keep bobbing around in the limbo area."

Kevin Davies ran with purpose and converted with emphasis for the first goal but James Beattie's injury-time nod-in could not hide the loss of touch that has led to his barren month after 10 goals in 10 games. Between times they bobbed in limbo - as Jewell might admit, a bonus missed. And what will they do with no more Sheffields to kill off?

webTitle: Sean Connery

fields.headline: Sean Connery
fields.standfirst: The very first Monsieur Bond has been voted the greatest British film actor of all time. Here's our guide to the best sites on the silver-bearded septuagenarian sex symbol
fields.trailText: The very first Monsieur Bond has been voted the greatest British film actor of all time. Here's our guide to the best sites on the silver-bearded septuagenarian sex symbol.
fields.body:
1. Beating such illustrious rivals as Anthony Hopkins and dear Larry, Sir Sean has been voted Britain's No 1 film thesp ever by 10,000 participants of the Orange Film Survey.

2. He's best known, of course, for playing that suave chap in the tux. It's accepted wisdom that Connery's rough'n'ready interpretation is the classic (Jamesh) Bond.

3. Connery, though, actually came to hate the association with 007, leaving the franchise in 1967 after You Only Live Twice and only returning for 1971's Diamonds Are Forever after executives offered him a massive pay-off to save them from George Lazenby.

4. And introducing the world to the concept of portly, balding Bond, he had one last crack of the whip in 1983's unofficial spin-off Never Say Never Again . Quite.

5. Large amounts of money were again the incentive, though Connery's attachment to cash perhaps isn't surprising considering that earlier occupations included milkman, bricklayer, lifeguard and, erm, Mr Universe competitor (in 1953 - fourth from left).

6. But happily for the movie world, acting proved to be his true vocation. Early in his career, he grappled with such demanding roles as "Extra", "2nd welder" and "Mountaine McClintock".

7. Bond made him a star though and later Connery highlights include a Franciscan monk (The Name of the Rose), Spanish swordsman (Highlander) and an Irish copper (The Untouchables). All with the same Scots brogue.

8. Perhaps his other best-known role is as Indiana Jones' dad in the third film. Sean's probably glad that most people's memories don't stretch back much further than that.

9. Despite having lived in Marbella for some time now, Sean fondly remembers his native Scotland and is a vocal supporter of the SNP.

10. He may be 70 now, but the ladies still love him and he finds the time, between rounds of golf, to bang out a film or two a year. See him next in Finding Forrester, in which he fine-tunes his Indiana Jones Sr act as a tetchy bookish mentor.

webTitle: From: Ben (28  Jan)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Ben
fields.trailText: One thing to remember if you have a bad experience is the power of perspective - is this something that I am going to worry about in a year's time or five years' time? Is it something that I am going to let spoil my trip? Nope is the answer in most cases!
fields.body:
Milly,

Watch out! I did what you are doing now when I was 19 visiting Australia and the Philippines and never looked back - I've now spent most of the last 10 years working or travelling overseas - the last five in Singapore. Don't spend too much time there - you are better off in Bangkok - but you should spend some time checking out the nightlife with the locals who love to party!

One thing to remember if you have a bad experience is the power of perspective - is this something that I am going to worry about in a year's time or five years' time? Is it something that I am going to let spoil my trip? Nope is the answer in most cases!

Have a great time!

webTitle: After the shock, new horrors

fields.headline: After the shock, new horrors
fields.standfirst:
As aid pours into Gujarat, former India correspondent Derek Brown takes a closer look at the quake's impact on the nation

Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: As aid pours into Gujarat, former India correspondent Derek Brown takes a closer look at the quake's impact on the nation.
fields.body:
Time is fast running out for any earthquake survivors still buried within the oceans of rubble which used to be the towns and villages of Gujarat. But even for those who escaped the horrors of entombment, new perils lie ahead.

The authorities are warning of more aftershocks and say they could be severe. They have warned people in the earthquake area to be "vigilant" - though what they can do to protect themselves, except avoid the tottering remains of shattered buildings, is doubtful.

Apart from the rescue workers and the distraught families of the missing, most people have left the main areas of devastation. At first, they streamed away from danger. Now, they are desperate to find food and shelter.

Relief convoys have been mobbed and looted by hungry earthquake victims. Food and other supplies are in desperately short supply, mainly because the road and rail systems have been badly damaged by the quake.

The next obvious danger is disease, with thousands of bodies of animals as well as human beings rotting in the rubble. Water supplies have also been badly disrupted, and hospitals and clinics are overwhelming with the injured and dying.

Inevitably, but unfairly, there has been criticism of the Indian central and state governments for failing to respond quickly enough to the calamity.

It's inevitable, because in all such catastrophes passions are raised and tempers are frayed. It's unfair, because India has, alas, long experience of natural disasters and on the whole has coped with them with commendable skill and speed.

The country may have limited resources, but it does have some priceless assets in these circumstances - primarily a vast army and air force which can be deployed quickly to aid the civil authorities.

Foreign aid is streaming into the earthquake area, and it says much for the Indian government that it has apparently swallowed its pride and encouraged outside help.

Soon it will need much, much more. For clearing the bodies and healing the wounded is only a scratch on the surface of what needs to be done in Gujarat.

The state is the second most prosperous in India, next to its southern neighbour Maharashtra. Its fast growing industries are vital to the national economy.

Remarkably, one of the region's most precious assets, a 900-mile oil pipeline running to the northern state of Punjab, was undamaged by the quake. It was put out of action by power failure, but officials of the state run Indian Oil Corporation say it will be up and running by the end of this week. But that is one of the few bright spots in a ruinous picture.

Rebuilding the smashed infrastructure and factories is going to require monumental effort and investment. The Indian papers are guesstimating the cost at £1bn or more, but nobody truly knows.

A tragic irony of the quake is that it could well throw out of gear the long needed economic reforms which the government had been poised to introduce in next month's budget.

India has been gingerly opening up its economy for several years, dismantling the old state sector and encouraging the burgeoning business class. The economics minister, Yashwant Sinha, had been expected to boost that trend with a tax-cutting budget.

Now, it is widely anticipated, he will have to impose tough new taxation get Gujarat back on its feet.

webTitle: Neville charged with misconduct

fields.headline: Neville charged with misconduct
fields.trailText: Gary Neville has been charged with misconduct by the FA for allegedly using foul and abusive language to a match official after Manchester United's FA Cup match against West Ham yesterday.
fields.body:
Gary Neville has been charged with misconduct by the FA for allegedly using foul and abusive language to a match official after Manchester United's FA Cup match against West Ham yesterday.

After the final whistle had been blown Neville ran across to berate an assistant referee over the amount of injury time that was played.

Referee Paul Durkin added on four minutes but Neville and his manager Sir Alex Ferguson claimed there should have been much more due to time being wasted by Stuart Pearce taking all of West Ham's goal kicks.

Pearce took all West Ham's kicks throughout the game, as goalkeeper Shaka Hislop was suffering from a knee injury.

Having received the report of referee Durkin, the FA have decided to bring the charge which, if proven, is likely to lead to a three-match ban.

"The FA can confirm that Gary Neville has been charged with misconduct following an incident after the Manchester United-West Ham United FA Cup tie," said an FA spokesman. "He is alleged to have used foul and abusive language towards a match official.

"He has 14 days in which to respond to the charge."

webTitle: Tennis: Capriati's comeback

fields.headline: Capriati the renaissance princess
fields.trailText: A few minutes after defending his Australian Open title, Andre Agassi turned his thoughts to his fellow American Jennifer Capriati, winner of the women's title. "I guess," he said, "that it's a story a lot of people can identify with, and one that is a credit to tennis and a credit to the human spirit."
fields.body:
A few minutes after defending his Australian Open title, Andre Agassi turned his thoughts to his fellow American Jennifer Capriati, winner of the women's title. "I guess," he said, "that it's a story a lot of people can identify with, and one that is a credit to tennis and a credit to the human spirit." There is no doubting that.

Capriati was a professional at the age of 13 and hailed as a prodigy a year later, in 1990, when she reached the semi-finals at Roland Garros. Two further semi-finals, at Wimbledon and Flushing Meadows, came the next year and then in the 1992 Barcelona Olympics she startled the world by defeating Germany's Steffi Graf for the gold medal on red clay. It appeared there was nothing she might not achieve, but with a suddenness that shocked everybody involved her world fell apart.

She experienced depression, became unable to motivate herself and then suffered further problems in her private life, such as it was, being charged with shoplifting and later being found in possession of drugs.

Distraught, mixed up and unable to cope with the pressures of the sport and the expectations of her father Stefano, she turned her back on tennis for two years, before eventually making the first of a series of comebacks that were frequently painful, tearful and abortive.

She wanted to be back in the tennis limelight, and she also wanted to be left alone. It seemed, despite her best intentions and the continued support of many, that she was finished as a player. Then, in 1999 and still only 23, the first signs of the renaissance appeared with tournament wins in Strasbourg and Quebec City. That same year, in the US Open, she read a carefully prepared statement saying that all her problems had been her own fault and that she now hoped everybody would draw a line under the past and help her to move forward. It was both brave and cathartic, though even then it appeared the game had moved on too quickly for her to play catch-up.

And this is what made her 6-4, 6-3 victory over Switzerland's Martina Hingis on Saturday so very special, for it was a triumph of spirit over self-doubt and exemplified the enduring bond between father and daughter. Stefano Capriati, born in the Italian city of Brindisi, has been blamed for pushing his daughter too hard and too soon. His punishment, if such it was, was to lose control of the person he loved the most and watch in horror and sadness as she all but self-destructed. Now, as in those early and traumatic days, he is coaching her again, but this time the relationship is much different. For a start he cannot tell her when to go to bed.

Capriati was asked if she could compare her first grand slam win with the Olympic title. "That actually seems like another life. This is a new life, a different life. It's like winning something for the first time again."

This was Hingis's fourth successive grand slam final defeat and once again she was overpowered, wins over the Williams sisters taking their toll, perhaps mentally as much as physically. There was no doubting her fitness but Capriati was in equally good shape. Having raced to a 5-1 first-set lead, the American took only two points from the next two games and went on to miss two set points on the Hingis serve. The match appeared to be swinging in favour of the world No1 but these setbacks stiffened rather than weakened Capriati's resolve. In this respect it mirrored her recent life.
