webTitle: Vivendi puts Sky stake in trust

fields.headline: Vivendi puts Sky stake in trust
fields.trailText:
3.30pm:French media giant Vivendi Universal has started the scramble for a stake in BSkyB after quitting the board of the satellite broadcaster.
A HREF="http://www.mediaguardian.co.uk/city/story/0,7497,430398,00.html">Cable giant John Malone holds key
A HREF="http://www.mediaguardian.co.uk/city/story/0,7497,430525,00.html">Print-out-and-keep guide to Vivendi and Liberty
fields.body:
French media giant Vivendi Universal has started the scramble for a stake in BSkyB after quitting the board of the satellite broadcaster.

Vivendi chairman Jean Marie Messier said the 22.7% holding will be placed with a trustee during negotiations, in order to protect BSkyB's share price.

The early favourite for the BSkyB stake is US cable operator Liberty Media, which already owns 20% of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, the parent company of BSkyB.

Liberty Media boss John Malone is a renowned deal maker, and he will be keen to increase his holding in Mr Murdoch's media empire.

"I don't think anyone expected the stake to come into the open market because of capital gains tax issues, and the deal is likely to involve something with John Malone. Messier says he is in o rush, but I imagine it will be done very quickly," said Nicola Stewart, media analyst at Commerzbank.

A quick deal may increase the chances of Mr Murdoch and Mr Malone teaming up to bid for US satellite TV operator DirecTV, which would complete News Corporation's plans for the float of its Sky Global Networks subsidiary.

Mr Messier made his remarks at the World Economic Summit in Davos, Switzerland.

webTitle: Flying visit places rescue project under scrutiny

fields.headline: Flying visit places rescue project under scrutiny
fields.standfirst: Rachel Stabb continues her diary from the earthquake-striken region of El Salvador with an account of the challenges of restoring water supplies and an inspection from an EU ambassador
fields.trailText: Rachel Stabb continues her diary from the earthquake-striken region of El Salvador with an account of the challenges of restoring water supplies and an inspection from an EU ambassador
fields.body:
A tall, thin grey-haired man strode across the football field with the din of helicopter engines still echoing in our ears. The man from the EU was in town and he was making a swift tour of some of the emergency projects Brussels is funding.

It had meant an early start for the Oxfam team. Some of the main roads are still closed because of massive landslides. A 15-minute journey along the Pan-American highway to the west of San Salvador turned into a 110-minute detour back into the city, then north via the Santa Ana volcano, rejoining the highway a few kilometres further on.

We made up time and were soon climbing into the hills north of Sonsonate, the provincial capital. Our destination was the coffee-growing area of Santa Catarina Masahuat, where we'd identified nine communities that had been without water for more than a week.

Steve Abbott, our Canadian water engineer, had begun putting up a 10,000 litre tank in each place. Dos Puertas was the first, then San Miguelito. He was hoping his newly trained team of volunteers would pass the test by putting up tanks on their own today, leaving him free to explain the niceties of "'positioning the offtake flange" to the ambassador!

As in other mountain villages I'd visited in the past ten days, the scenery was stunning. Our progamme manager, Enrique, pointed out the cacao trees with their subtle purple hue in among the green vegetation. They're mainly for shade and fertilising the ground.

In Santa Catarina Masahuat we stopped to check arrangements. While we were phoning, a crowd gathered. Women were complaining that they hadn't received any help. Nothing. Enrique told them they needed to organise themselves, draw up lists with identity card numbers and take that to the Red Cross, who'd evaluate their needs.

It was at that moment we heard the drone of the helicopters approaching. We ran to the field to see two of them land and the EU delegation alight. Then, we drove to the Oxfam site. Children were already collecting water in bright, multi-coloured, urn-like plastic containers. They laughed as four photographers took their pictures.

Ambassador Mamberto listened attentively to our account of how these tanks will bridge the gap until a permanent water supply is restored in two months' time. He was impressed at their speed, simplicity and effectiveness in providing a basic, life-sustaining need.

But, after a quick tour of the hamlet, it was time to leave. With a wave he was gone, in a cloud of dust, surely satisfied that his money's been well spent.

webTitle: Comment: radicalism in the Labour manifesto

fields.headline: Little radicalisms
fields.standfirst:
Don't expect promises of sweeping change in the Labour manifesto

Special report: New Labour in power
 Special report: Fabian Society conference
fields.trailText: Don't expect promises of sweeping change in the Labour manifesto, writes Michael Jacobs.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has famously said that a second-term Labour government would be more radical than the first. Public services are going to be the heart of the manifesto and the central issue of the election campaign. Labour will set out its various reform programmes and it will remind voters of the increased spending due to come on stream in April. But will any of this count as radical?

Well, it depends what you mean. The government will almost certainly talk a radical game, speaking of the "challenge" of delivering "world-class services". It will contrast its commitment to improving services with the Conservatives' commitment to tax cuts.

If you compare this kind of rhetoric - and the spending that goes with it - with that of the Conservative governments of the past 20 years it is certainly a huge change. But this is hardly a standard for radicalism. Compared with the quality of public services enjoyed by our European partners, and with what Labour has always believed in, it is no more than trying to protect the status quo.

Yet of course there is something the government could do in this field which would count as radical. This would be to promise higher taxes. If UK public spending was raised closer to the European average (the shortfall is currently around £45bn a year, the equivalent of our entire education budget) the achievement of world class services might become rather more likely. But this idea, you will not be surprised to hear, won't be appearing in the manifesto.

So, for all the talk of radicalism, it seems unlikely - for good or ill - that the headline policies in Labour's election platform will merit that term. Yet we shouldn't dismiss the idea of a radical manifesto altogether. Tucked away in the small print there may well be hints of genuine innovation.

Labour is likely to promise, for example, a small but significant policy of wealth-redistribution. Detailed research is now being done into the idea of giving all young people capital grants - probably in the form of "baby bonds", which accumulate over a child's lifetime and can be realised at 18.

The manifesto seems likely to promise various "work-life balance" measures, such as paid parental and paternity leave. Meanwhile there are interesting ideas being worked out on making towns and cities more liveable - enlarging pedestrian areas, improving parks, cutting traffic, enhancing safety. New environmental policies are also on the table, including a major programme of investment in renewable energy and other sustainable technologies.

None of these initiatives is likely to attract the headlines during the election. But it may yet be such "little radicalisms" that actually determine the character of Labour's second term.

For the point about policy ideas such as these is that they embody new kinds of thinking about the relationship between the government, society and the individual. They concern the ways in which the state can redistribute opportunity directly to individuals; how it can help protect the quality of our personal lives against the growing time demands of the economy; how public spaces and the sense of community can be enhanced; how the economy might be restructured to achieve a dramatic reduction in environmental damage.

These are not yet the dominant themes of progressive politics. But they could well become so. Look out for them in the manifesto: from little radicalisms big ideologies grow. During the first government of the 21st century they might even force us to rethink what "radical" means.

 Michael Jacobs is general secretary of the Fabian Society, whose LSE conference at the weekend, Prospects for a Second Term, was sponsored by the Guardian.

webTitle: The Mandelson row - inside New Labour

fields.headline: The Mandelson row - inside New Labour
fields.standfirst: The past week has been a horrific one for the key players in New Labour and a sensation for every politician, official and journalist in Westminster. Julian Glover explains where they stand today
fields.trailText: The past week has been a horrific one for the key players in New Labour and a sensation for every politician, official and journalist in Westminster. Julian Glover explains where they stand today.
fields.body:
Tony Blair, prime minister
The prime minister has been appalled by recent events. He has seen Peter Mandelson and Alastair Campbell, his two closest allies, turn on each other in public. He has had to defend the minister for Europe, Keith Vaz, from attacks over his integrity and stave off a call in today's Sun for Mr Vaz to resign. He has also been left politically exposed, while the chancellor, Gordon Brown, looks stronger than ever.

In the week ahead, the prime minister's aim will be to refocus New Labour on the coming election campaign - it would be a disaster for him if he were forced to delay polling day because of internal rows within the government. The good news for Mr Blair - and it's not that good - is that the opposition is in an even greater state of disarray, and has failed to exploit the crisis for their own ends.

Alistair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman
Alastair Campbell is not just a civil servant; he is a key New Labour player who is been both angered and alarmed by the events of the last week.

A week ago, Mr Campbell was forced to retract a briefing to journalists which implied that Peter Mandelson had not dealt with the Indian businessmen at the heart of the passports affair. That need to retract was the reason Mr Mandelson had to resign.

Now Alastair Campbell has tried to backtrack on a second briefing, given last Friday to Sunday political journalists. That briefing led to lurid headlines in the Sunday press, quoting Mr Campbell as describing that Mr Mandelson had been "slightly detached".

Journalists took his comments to mean Mr Blair's two biggest allies were now at war. But Mr Campbell is adamant that did not mean this, merely that Mr Mandelson had been busy with events in Northern Ireland - a version of events that has been denied journalists in the room at the time.

He will be as shocked as his boss at the way the story has spun out of control and will no doubt be planning a series of major policy announcements to take attention away from the feud.

Peter Mandelson, former Northern Ireland minister
Numbed by the speed and unexpectedness of his resignation last Wednesday, Peter Mandelson has had time to reflect on what went on, apparently leaving him feeling very hard done by.

He consequently wrote an article for the Sunday Times, setting out what he saw as the facts of the case. He hoped the article would clear the air and establish that at no point did he lie. Instead, it has fuelled claims that he is on the verge of a breakdown - claims greatly assisted by Mr Campbell's decision to stick the knife into him in front of a pack of hungry Sunday journalists.

The best that Mandelson can hope for now is that tempers will cool and the official inquiry led by Anthony Hammond QC will go some way to verifying Mr Mandelson's assertions. A return to government is not on the cards - though re-election to his Hartlepool seat is - but any positive outcome from the inquiry may provide a route back to some sort of public life.

The civil service
It seems clear that senior civil servants, notably Sir Richard Wilson, the Cabinet secretary, played a key role in convincing Mr Blair that Mr Mandelson had told an untruth about a phone call to the then immigration minister Mike O'Brien and should resign. However Mr Mandelson's junior civil servants still maintain that they have no recollection of the call. Only one side can be right.

The trouble for Mr Mandelson is that he talked about the phone call on television last week, and Mr O'Brien maintains he is sure it took place. If (and it's a big if) Hammond establishes that this is a case of cock-up, not conspiracy, then the senior civil servants involved will do all they can to deflect the blame and preserve their reputation.

Jack Straw, home secretary
The home secretary has ultimate responsibility for the issuing of passports, and will be under pressure to explain why SP Hinduja's application was processed so quickly.

Mr Straw will also want to clear up the confusion surrounding Peter Mandelson's phone call with Mike O'Brien two years ago. Jack Straw discussed this call with Mandelson just days before he resigned - yet Mandelson then expressed doubts as to whether this call ever took place. Why?

The official opposition
It is one of the ironies of this case that the interests of the Conservative party and Peter Mandelson are now closely aligned. Michael Ancram, the Tory chairman, says he wants all of the details of the case to be established.

He also wants the enquiry to be extended to look into the relationship between the Hinduja brothers and the government. None of this will worry Peter Mandelson, who now thinks a fair inquiry will clear him - though the hope may prove a vain one.

The Tories will also want to tag Tony Blair with accusations of bad judgement and sleaze. This will prove tricky - not least because many senior Conservatives have also had dealings with the Hinduja brothers.

webTitle: Government races to complete Hinduja inquiry

fields.headline: Government races to complete Hinduja inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Mandelson resigns

Sir Anthony Hammond says his report into the Hinduja passport affair will be completed by the end of February
fields.trailText:
 Passport row inquiry ready in weeks  Mandelson's author friend attacks Campbell
Special reports
New Labour in power
Peter Mandelson
fields.body:
The inquiry into the Hinduja passport affair should be completed by the end of February, Downing Street said today.

Sir Anthony Hammond has told the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, that he hopes to complete his report within the next few weeks.

In a statement released through No 10, Sir Anthony said: "On the information currently available to me I would hope to conclude the inquiry by the end of February."

The prime minister, Tony Blair, has promised that the report will be published.

Mr Blair's official spokesman said today that Sir Anthony's terms of reference were wide enough to allow him to look into any aspect of the affair, which has so far led to the resignation of Peter Mandelson as Northern Ireland secretary and embroiled the Europe minister, Keith Vaz.

Mr Blair's spokesman today again tried to draw a line under the issue, telling reporters: "The prime minister set out the background to Peter's resignation in the Commons last week and I think it's pretty clear from today's press and broadcasts that you may not want to move on, but the government's got a lot to do.

"There's an inquiry into the facts of the application by SP Hinduja for his passport, which is being conducted by Sir Anthony Hammond. The background to Peter's resignation was set out by the prime minister last week.

"The prime minister made that statement based on his own judgment and knowledge.

"I don't intend to get into the position where every single little line that appears here, and line that appears there, we have to suspend the business of government so you can go out and talk about it.

"We are the government, the prime minister is the prime minister, we have a government to run and a country to run."

The spokesman said neither he nor cabinet ministers had been ordered to be more circumspect in future in their comments on the affair.

"Headlines come and headlines go. Governments get on governing."

Asked if he still regarded Mr Mandelson as a friend, the spokesman replied: "I do. Yes."

On Mr Mandelson's Sunday newspaper article which sought to vindicate his own position, the spokesman said simply: "Peter wrote that article, and I know he's not around at the moment, but it's for him to explain it."

Mr Mandelson is believed to have gone abroad, leaving the furore behind him.

Earlier today, the bitter war of words between Downing Street and Mr Mandelson rumbled on amid claims that he was driven from government to meet a media deadline.

Best-selling author Robert Harris, who is a close friend of the former cabinet minister, said that Mr Mandelson was standing by his account of his role in the so-called "passport-for-favours" affair.

Mr Harris attacked the prime minister's press secretary, Alastair Campbell, for briefing Sunday lobby journalists for 10 minutes last week about Mr Mandelson's "mental stability".

Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, Mr Harris alleged that Mr Mandelson had been "browbeaten" into resigning without the full facts having been made available.

Mr Mandelson was sticking to his original account that officials in his private office had handled the query to the Home Office as to whether a change in government policy would affect Mr Hinduja's chances of getting a passport, he said.

Mr Harris said that Mr Mandelson still had no recollection of making a telephone call to Home Office minister Mike O'Brien.

The author said there was no official transcript of the "alleged" conversation and the Home Office note simply had the three words "Mandelson, Hinduja, naturalisation."

"He is absolutely confident that what he originally thought and said that the contact between his office and the Home Office on this matter was handled by his private secretary," Mr Harris said.

"He cannot still recall this conversation that he is alleged to have had with Mike O'Brien.

"He doesn't think Mike O'Brien is a liar so obviously there could have been a conversation. He just cannot remember it."

Mr Harris also criticised the way that Downing Street handled the resignation and said that if Mr Mandelson had been given more time he would have been able to produce the evidence from his former officials in the cabinet office to support his version of events.

"I think certainly it was unfortunate, to put it mildly, that the whole of this affair seems to have turned on having the news ready to give to the morning lobby meeting at 11 o'clock in Downing Street on Wednesday," he said.

"If that briefing had been postponed by maybe only an hour, then the information that Peter Mandelson's private secretary handled this whole thing would have been in the prime minister's hands.

"To the extent that the whole thing was being driven by a media deadline - that is a very bad thing."

Mr Harris also criticised reported remarks by Mr Campbell to journalists that Mr Mandelson had become "slightly detached" - a comment that Downing Street insisted was taken out of context.

"I think it is a pretty poor thing to have a civil servant ruminating for 10 minutes about the mental stability of a former government minister. That seems strange to put it mildly."

fields.bodyText: The inquiry into the Hinduja passport affair should be completed by the end of February, Downing Street said today. Sir Anthony Hammond has told the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, that he hopes to complete his report within the next few weeks. In a statement released through No 10, Sir Anthony said: "On the information currently available to me I would hope to conclude the inquiry by the end of February." The prime minister, Tony Blair, has promised that the report will be published. Mr Blair's official spokesman said today that Sir Anthony's terms of reference were wide enough to allow him to look into any aspect of the affair, which has so far led to the resignation of Peter Mandelson as Northern Ireland secretary and embroiled the Europe minister, Keith Vaz. Mr Blair's spokesman today again tried to draw a line under the issue, telling reporters: "The prime minister set out the background to Peter's resignation in the Commons last week and I think it's pretty clear from today's press and broadcasts that you may not want to move on, but the government's got a lot to do. "There's an inquiry into the facts of the application by SP Hinduja for his passport, which is being conducted by Sir Anthony Hammond. The background to Peter's resignation was set out by the prime minister last week. "The prime minister made that statement based on his own judgment and knowledge. "I don't intend to get into the position where every single little line that appears here, and line that appears there, we have to suspend the business of government so you can go out and talk about it. "We are the government, the prime minister is the prime minister, we have a government to run and a country to run." The spokesman said neither he nor cabinet ministers had been ordered to be more circumspect in future in their comments on the affair. "Headlines come and headlines go. Governments get on governing." Asked if he still regarded Mr Mandelson as a friend, the spokesman replied: "I do. Yes." On Mr Mandelson's Sunday newspaper article which sought to vindicate his own position, the spokesman said simply: "Peter wrote that article, and I know he's not around at the moment, but it's for him to explain it." Mr Mandelson is believed to have gone abroad, leaving the furore behind him. Earlier today, the bitter war of words between Downing Street and Mr Mandelson rumbled on amid claims that he was driven from government to meet a media deadline. Best-selling author Robert Harris, who is a close friend of the former cabinet minister, said that Mr Mandelson was standing by his account of his role in the so-called "passport-for-favours" affair. Mr Harris attacked the prime minister's press secretary, Alastair Campbell, for briefing Sunday lobby journalists for 10 minutes last week about Mr Mandelson's "mental stability". Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, Mr Harris alleged that Mr Mandelson had been "browbeaten" into resigning without the full facts having been made available. Mr Mandelson was sticking to his original account that officials in his private office had handled the query to the Home Office as to whether a change in government policy would affect Mr Hinduja's chances of getting a passport, he said. Mr Harris said that Mr Mandelson still had no recollection of making a telephone call to Home Office minister Mike O'Brien. The author said there was no official transcript of the "alleged" conversation and the Home Office note simply had the three words "Mandelson, Hinduja, naturalisation." "He is absolutely confident that what he originally thought and said that the contact between his office and the Home Office on this matter was handled by his private secretary," Mr Harris said. "He cannot still recall this conversation that he is alleged to have had with Mike O'Brien. "He doesn't think Mike O'Brien is a liar so obviously there could have been a conversation. He just cannot remember it." Mr Harris also criticised the way that Downing Street handled the resignation and said that if Mr Mandelson had been given more time he would have been able to produce the evidence from his former officials in the cabinet office to support his version of events. "I think certainly it was unfortunate, to put it mildly, that the whole of this affair seems to have turned on having the news ready to give to the morning lobby meeting at 11 o'clock in Downing Street on Wednesday," he said. "If that briefing had been postponed by maybe only an hour, then the information that Peter Mandelson's private secretary handled this whole thing would have been in the prime minister's hands. "To the extent that the whole thing was being driven by a media deadline - that is a very bad thing." Mr Harris also criticised reported remarks by Mr Campbell to journalists that Mr Mandelson had become "slightly detached" - a comment that Downing Street insisted was taken out of context. "I think it is a pretty poor thing to have a civil servant ruminating for 10 minutes about the mental stability of a former government minister. That seems strange to put it mildly." webTitle: Case study: Simon Shore's experience of independent living

fields.headline: Case study: Simon Shore's experience of independent living
fields.standfirst: The first time Simon Shore applied to join an independent living scheme, he was turned down. Judy Hirst finds out why he's glad he was eventually accepted
fields.trailText: The first time Simon Shore applied to join an independent living scheme, he was turned down. Judy Hirst finds out why he's glad he was eventually accepted
fields.body:
Simon Shore has had more than 100 volunteer "personal assistants" since a car crash left him paralysed from the neck down 16 years ago. Not that he's complaining. Having made a decision early on that he was going to live as normally as possible, the last thing he wants is a know-it-all professional taking over his life.

"This way, the relationship's on my terms. I get to interview the volunteers before they come, and I've never had a bad experience yet. Someone who chooses to do this kind of work is usually pretty genuine, and willing to work flexibly with you." Mr Shore, who is 32, relies on Lambeth support and housing assistance for people with disabilities (Shad) to supply him with a regular flow of volunteers. They work in teams of three, on a rota basis, doing 24-hour shifts. Once every six weeks, a district nurse comes to check things over but otherwise the assistants are responsible for all of Simon's personal care.

One of Mr Shore's helpers, 20-year-old Helena, is typical of many Shad volunteers. She has come from Germany to improve her English, spend time in London, and see whether she is interested in caring as a career. She is really enjoying the work: "It's a good atmosphere, and we get on well. It's nice to be doing this, to be caring for someone. Simon needs everything doing for him, but he is not at all bitter. He's busy developing his computer graphics skills, and he's got his family for support." Mr Shore and his able-bodied partner have recently had a baby boy, Nile.

Mr Shore describes his daily routine as incredibly complex: "It takes me most of the morning just to get up, get to the bathroom, dress and have breakfast." To help with all this, Shad volunteers receive some basic training in correct procedures for lifting and manual handling, and other health and safety rules. Beyond that, they're pretty much on their own.

Another volunteer, 18-year-old Harriet Lamborn, does not see this as a problem. For the last three months, she has been working with a service-user who has severe multiple sclerosis, a woman in her mid-30s. "She's in a powered wheelchair and needs a hoist for the bathroom, so I'm her arms and legs - shopping, cooking, cleaning and helping with her personal needs." For Harriet, who is from York, this is her gap year. She plans to study law at the University of London, but she sees her work with Shad as invaluable. "It's much more emotionally demanding than I first imagined, but also more rewarding. It might eventually make me want to focus on legal work in this field."

Harriet is mature for her years. She has also had previous experience of working with disabled people and, as someone with a disabled relative, is very keen on Shad's philosophy of maximum independence for service-users. But just as this kind of voluntary work is not for everyone, neither is the relationship the kind that every disabled person wants.

"You need to be someone who is confident about directing your own care, something some people might not be able to do, especially if they've been in hospital for a long time," says Mr Shore. "The first time I applied to get support from Shad, they turned me down. I think they thought I was too immature. I'd been living at my mum's house, and wanted more independence. But the only other option was residential care. I'm really glad I was accepted the second time."

webTitle: Countryside Alliance launches ad campaign

fields.headline: Countryside Alliance unveils ad campaign
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: A pro-hunting lobby group has launched a controversial ad campaign in a bid to drum up popular support, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A pro-hunting lobby group has launched a controversial advertising campaign in an attempt to win popular support for its cause.

The Countryside Alliance is trying to drum up support in rural areas ahead of a demonstration in March.

The ads will run in local papers and shopping centres in towns in rural areas, where the organisation believes it has the most to gain.

One ad focuses on what it believes to be the deliberate misrepresentation and demonisation of people who go hunting with a picture of an attractive young girl alongside the words, "Hi, my name is scum".

The second focuses on the Alliance's belief that the government is destroying the countryside's communities, culture and way of life by over-sanitising it.

In a deliberate play on Pepsi's famous "Lipsmackin'thirstquenchin'" ad, it uses the line "Bureaucratisedpasteurisedshrinkwrappednannifiedsanitised homogenisedstandardisedsterilisedfreezedried...Countryside? It's not too late to act".

"We have chosen these urban areas for our ad campaign because we wish to get across to people in towns that our march is about principles that everyone should be able to support," said Alliance director of communications Nigel Henson.

"Our march is not about playing up any divide between town and country but trying to bridge it."

MPs voted to ban hunting earlier this month and the government hunting bill is now being debated line-by-line at committee stage in the Commons.

The legislation is expected to go to the Lords before Easter when peers will be given the chance to vote on the three options - an outright ban, hunting with regulation, or no change.

The Lords are likely to reject a hunting ban, putting them on a collision course with the Commons. But if a general election is called for May, the bill will have to be reintroduced if Labour wins a second term.

webTitle: Disabled greet volunteer care schemes with mixed feelings

fields.headline: Disabled greet volunteer care schemes with mixed feelings
fields.standfirst: Volunteer-based schemes are a cost effective way of providing community care for people with disabilities, but they are far from perfect, reports Judy Hirst
fields.trailText: Volunteer-based schemes are a cost effective way of providing community care for people with disabilities, but they are far from perfect, reports Judy Hirst
fields.body:
Take a severely disabled person who wants to live independently in their own home. Add a keen volunteer looking for some hands-on work experience. Throw in a bit of government funding, and you have what looks like a neat solution to community care funding difficulties. Or, at least, Gordon Brown seems to think so.

A large chunk of the extra £300m that the chancellor is currently plowing into community volunteering will go towards providing care services. However, as the experience of volunteer-based organisations show, it's an approach that can be fraught with difficulties.

Lambeth support and housing assistance for people with disabilities (Shad) has been providing 24-hour personal care services for disabled adults since 1984, mainly by matching volunteers to service-users on a rotating, short-term basis. The volunteers, usually young and increasingly from overseas, assist with everything from lifting and bathing to shopping, cooking and reading. In return they get free housing association accommodation, a small allowance and often considerable personal satisfaction.

There are similar organisations in the London boroughs of Haringey, Wandsworth and Hounslow, operating with varying degrees of local authority funding. When the system works well, it can offer disabled people, even those profoundly affected by conditions such as cerebral palsy or muscular dystrophy, a degree of dignity and freedom unimaginable in a residential setting. And, unlike statutory home care or live-in services, service-users have a direct say in their choice of "personal assistants" and far more control over what they do.

These are the advantages. The downside is that volunteers are hard to recruit, vet and train, often less reliable than paid staff and generally don't want to stay more than six months. According to Sian Vasey of the National Centre for Independent Living, many disabled people would prefer to recruit and pay for their own personal care workers under the government's recently extended direct payments system.

"Volunteer-based schemes like the ones run by Shad, and Community Service Volunteers, are past their sell-by date. They may be a marvellous experience for the volunteers, but for the service-user they're just not reliable enough, and they let social services off the hook." As a disabled person herself, she believes direct payments are the way forward for users wanting independence and choice. "After all, we don't expect our buses and trains to rely on volunteer drivers."

Hounslow Shad has been slowly drawing similar conclusions, prompted by changes in domiciliary care regulations that make funding for volunteer-based schemes very hard to come by. "Social service care managers want a service they can rely on," says manager Brian James. "Plus, the user-volunteer relationship is open to abuse." Half of its personal assistants are now paid employees, and the proportion is set to rise. But other Shad groups still maintain that volunteering is central to their ethos.

Lambeth Shad director Isabelle Clement says that not all disabled people want to take on the responsibility of employing someone, and that many prefer a young, inexperienced voluntary worker to a professional who "takes over their home". "We don't see our volunteers as being in competition with paid workers," she adds. "After all, they provide a very different service to the statutory authorities - and one that most people wouldn't be getting if we didn't exist."

This, surely, is the nub of the issue. Although Lambeth and other authorities have an uneasy relationship with volunteer-based care providers, where else would they get such value for money? As Wandsworth Shad's manager Alex Iwuoha points out, the scheme currently receives around £300,000 a year from the council towards providing round-the-clock support for 10 service-users: something that would cost half as much again by any other route.

webTitle: Can earthquakes be predicted?

fields.headline: Can earthquakes be predicted?
fields.standfirst:
Earthquake prediction is still more alchemy than science, reports Sarah Left

Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText:
Earthquake prediction is still more alchemy than science, reports Sarah Left
Special report: natural disasters
fields.body:
Western India, El Salvador, Turkey - with tens of thousands of people dead in major earthquakes in the last two years, relatives and friends of those killed must be asking if the devastation could have been avoided.

Earthquake prediction, though, is still more alchemy than science. Scientists have long been able to predict roughly where earthquakes will happen, but they have been less successful in telling us when a major quake will strike.

As Gujarat's chief minister pointed out when criticised for not responding fast enough, an earthquake is not a cyclone. And no warning means no rescue efforts can be deployed until after the event.

If scientists could give governments even a few hours of notice, lives could be saved with advance planning of a rescue operation that could dig out survivors that precious few hours faster. International rescue workers could be on the scene by the time the quake happened, rather than heading for their local airports several hours after the fact.

Even better, notice of a day or more could lead to an evacuation that could cut casualties to virtually zero.

Worldwide each year there are about 18 earthquakes with a magnitude of 7.0 or larger, according to the US Geological survey. Actual numbers since 1900 range from lows of six or seven quakes each year in 1986 and 1990 to a high of 41major earthquakes in 1943, the most seismically active year of the 20th century.

Only one of them has ever been predicted in the level of detail needed to evacuate a city.

Theories that these major earthquakes could be predicted came to nothing until 1975, when the Chinese government acted on the word of scientists and evacuated millions from the city of Haicheng. One day later, a magnitude 7.3 earthquake hit the city. Advance warning had saved thousands of lives.

But the prediction in the Haicheng quake relied on very specific warnings, such as changes in land elevation and ground water levels in the months leading up to the quake. More importantly, a number of foreshocks had shaken the area.

Sadly, most major earthquakes are not so co-operative, and in 1976 China lost a quarter of a million people when a 7.6 magnitude earthquake struck Tangshan with no warning at all. Haicheng remains the only example of a successful evacuation before a major earthquake.

Scientists had predicted the 6.9 magnitude earthquake that killed 63 people in San Francisco in 1989, but not with anything close to the degree of accuracy necessary to evacuate an entire metropolitan area on a specific date. They simply knew that the fault, known as Loma Prieta, had not moved as much as points further north of it, putting immense pressure on the faultline.

The US Geological Survey now only spends about 20% of its budget on earthquake prediction research, focusing instead on mitigating the effects of earthquakes once they strike. Rather than predicting earthquakes, seismologists spend their time trying to understand how earthquakes affect the land and the buildings that stand on it.

This information is the basis of California's strict building codes and the frequent attempts to retrofit older buildings and highways to withstand whatever the state's unstable tectonic plates may have in store for residents.

The results have saved countless lives: when Los Angeles was shaken by a 6.7 magnitude quake in 1994, the retrofitted buildings in West Hollywood performed best, remaining intact rather than crushing their inhabitants.

In contrast, the majority of the 14,000 people killed in the 1999 earthquake in Turkey died after being buried alive in the rubble of sub-standard buildings. Many of the deaths occurred not because the country lacks appropriate building codes, but because they were not enforced.

The safety of buildings is important, but so is the land on which the building sits. Scientists believe that the earth shakes more violently where the ground is softer, meaning homes, offices and infrastructure built on stronger bedrock have a greater chance of remaining intact after a large quake.

That means an earthquake prediction must take into account not only when, where and what magnitude an earthquake will be, but exactly who should be evacuated and to where. In the San Francisco quake, most of the damage happened 50 miles from the epicentre, not simply because San Francisco and Oakland are populated, but because the soft ground around the bay shakes more violently than in surrounding areas.

The Japanese have invested far more time and money than the Americans into earthquake prediction, often at the expense of studying mitigation techniques such as building codes and rescue response. The 1995 Kobe earthquake killed 5,100 people and the Japanese government was widely criticised for its slow response to the disaster.

Since then, the country has invested heavily in preparing for relief operations.

The problem with quake prediction is that it relies on watching a specific, high-risk area in great detail and at great expense. Too often, that leaves seismologists watching the wrong area while a major quake strikes somewhere else. Like Gujarat.

Sadly, most major earthquakes are not so co-operative, and in 1976 China lost a quarter of a million people when a 7.6 magnitude earthquake struck Tangshan with no warning at all. Haicheng remains the only example of a successful evacuation before a major earthquake. Scientists had predicted the 6.9 magnitude earthquake that killed 63 people in San Francisco in 1989, but not with anything close to the degree of accuracy necessary to evacuate an entire metropolitan area on a specific date. They simply knew that the fault, known as Loma Prieta, had not moved as much as points further north of it, putting immense pressure on the faultline. The US Geological Survey now only spends about 20% of its budget on earthquake prediction research, focusing instead on mitigating the effects of earthquakes once they strike. Rather than predicting earthquakes, seismologists spend their time trying to understand how earthquakes affect the land and the buildings that stand on it. This information is the basis of California's strict building codes and the frequent attempts to retrofit older buildings and highways to withstand whatever the state's unstable tectonic plates may have in store for residents. The results have saved countless lives: when Los Angeles was shaken by a 6.7 magnitude quake in 1994, the retrofitted buildings in West Hollywood performed best, remaining intact rather than crushing their inhabitants. In contrast, the majority of the 14,000 people killed in the 1999 earthquake in Turkey died after being buried alive in the rubble of sub-standard buildings. Many of the deaths occurred not because the country lacks appropriate building codes, but because they were not enforced. The safety of buildings is important, but so is the land on which the building sits. Scientists believe that the earth shakes more violently where the ground is softer, meaning homes, offices and infrastructure built on stronger bedrock have a greater chance of remaining intact after a large quake. That means an earthquake prediction must take into account not only when, where and what magnitude an earthquake will be, but exactly who should be evacuated and to where. In the San Francisco quake, most of the damage happened 50 miles from the epicentre, not simply because San Francisco and Oakland are populated, but because the soft ground around the bay shakes more violently than in surrounding areas. The Japanese have invested far more time and money than the Americans into earthquake prediction, often at the expense of studying mitigation techniques such as building codes and rescue response. The 1995 Kobe earthquake killed 5,100 people and the Japanese government was widely criticised for its slow response to the disaster. Since then, the country has invested heavily in preparing for relief operations. The problem with quake prediction is that it relies on watching a specific, high-risk area in great detail and at great expense. Too often, that leaves seismologists watching the wrong area while a major quake strikes somewhere else. Like Gujarat. How can I help? webTitle: Media Monkey

fields.headline: Media Monkey
fields.trailText: • A blow for freedom of speech at the Independent where staff were last week instructed not to send personal emails under the threat of having them monitored by the company. Independent? Not very. Monkey emailed friends at the Indy to find out if this could be true, but no one has yet responded.
fields.body:
 A blow for freedom of speech at the Independent where staff were last week instructed not to send personal emails under the threat of having them monitored by the company. Independent? Not very. Monkey emailed friends at the Indy to find out if this could be true, but no one has yet responded.

 Peter Sissons was in the mood to get a few things off his chest last week. Giving the eulogy at a TV director's retirement party, the 58-year-old Ten O'Clock News presenter attacked the corporation's "ageist" attitude. The BBC was, he argued, too quick to let great talent go to waste. Might it be that Sissons is worried about his own future when Mark "pops" Popescu moves to the Ten from the Six O'Clock News?

 ITV was quick to cry foul when the BBC barred its talent from appearing on the rival network's shows. But, if the latest rumour to reach Monkey is anything to go by, David Liddiment's henchmen are just as fearsome as Lorraine Heggessey's. Ant and Dec, it seems, have been told they can't appear in the celebrity version of Big Brother organised by Channel 4 and the BBC for Comic Relief. Ratings wars are all very well, but can't we call a truce in the name of char-i-dee?

 The BBC rumour mill (which has almost as many staff as John Birt's corporate affairs office) has been working overtime (unpaid, of course) since the Tony Hall succession race kicked off. The latest wild speculation centres on Hall being replaced by his current deputy Richard Sambrook, to be replaced in turn by Newsnight's Sian Kevill. Today editor Rod Liddle would take her place, and 5Live Breakfast editor Ceri Thomas would make the leap to Radio 4. All sounds a bit fanciful to us.

 It's good to see GMTV's Fiona Phillips sticking up for her sisters, deriding nasty Nigel Lythgoe for rejecting Popstars hopeful Claire Freeland because of her size. But Phillips's earnest support for Claire was somewhat undermined by a producer who, without a hint of irony, stuck the breakfast station's own reality TV offering next in the running order - yes, it was time to check on weight-loss progress on Inch-Loss Island.

 E4's glittering launch party last week - which featured a number of scantily dressed twentysomethings who certainly won't be at home watching Generation E - threw up one interesting fact. Apparently the channel's preview tape (a 15-minute loop of the forthcoming attractions) drew more viewers than the largely ignored BBC Choice. Seems like the corporation's exciting plans for BBCs 3 and 4 can't come quickly enough.

 Struck by the visible grief on the faces of the panellists on Newsnight's deconstruction of Peter Mandelson's departure, Monkey phoned the BBC to ask if there had been any complaints. Discussing the tragedy were: Roy Hattersley (loyal), Matthew Taylor (ultra loyal), Tony Lloyd (massively loyal) and former spin doctor, Tim Allan (tremendously loyal). What on earth were they thinking, Monkey asked a BBC news spokesman? "Some viewers did think that there should have been a Tory or someone else on the panel." How many? "A handful. All right, two handfuls." Other complaints that reached Monkey included a perception that Jeremy Vine was smirking...

webTitle: What the Indian papers say

fields.headline: What the Indian papers say
fields.standfirst: India's vibrant anglophone press is hard put to find language powerful enough   to match the disaster, reports Derek Brown
fields.trailText: India's vibrant anglophone press is hard put to find language powerful enough to match the disaster, reports Derek Brown.
fields.body:
The national daily, The Hindu, has a vivid colour piece on the continuing frantic rescue effort, in which occasional miracles are invariably tempered with tragedy: "After several hours of frantic but careful digging through the rubble, the eyes of tense Indian Air Force personnel and policemen suddenly lit up. They heard the faint sobbing of a baby amidst mounds of debris of a building in this town. Hours later, rescuers pulled out Naina Badrasen and her one-and half-year-old daughter Namrata. While Namrata, her pulse weak after spending 50 hours without food and water, was rushed to a nearby hospital, her mother died before rescue workers could reach her."

The Indian Express has a grim prediction that the death toll could rise beyond 30,000. As many as one lakh people (100,000) could still be trapped in the debris. The paper tersely sums up: "Although there was still no clear picture as yet even about the approximate death toll, nearly 7,000 bodies have so far been extricated from the rubble by various rescue teams, even as excavation of bodies in the worst-hit areas of Kutch district like Bhachau, Anjar and Rapar was yet to begin in right earnest. Nearly 12,000 injured people were being treated in various private or government hospitals, dispensaries and tents, an official said here this afternoon. In Kutch district, where thousands of casual workers from Rajasthan, Orissa and other states worked alone on salt farms, the authorities had began to bury the unclaimed bodies for want of any claimants."

The Telegraph, Calcutta in Calcutta highlights the new horror of hunger in the devastation: "With relief reaching slowly, survivors of the quake hunted for food and water in shops that still stood on the ground. "It is a major catastrophe here. The priority is food because shops are being emptied out," said a Red Cross official. Villagers injured in the quake were trekking or piling on to whatever vehicles they could find to get to cities in search of medical help. Some died on the way. Injured people had reached even Ahmedabad, about 10 hours drive from Bhuj, to find hospitals overflowing with the dead and the barely living. A corridor at VS Hospital in Ahmedabad was crammed with bodies."

The Times of India reports that in their desperation, survivors of the earthquake have taken to looting relief supplies: "Having gone without food, water and relief for four days after the earthquake struck Gujarat, survivors of the devastation in Kutch district have started looting vehicles carrying food packets and other relief material even as the over-stretched administration was yet to come to terms with the magnitude of the disaster. Officials in the earthquake control rooms in Ahmedabad and Gandhinagar said there was utter chaos on the roads leading to Bhuj, Bachhau, Rapar and Anjar in Kutch districts where the earthquake victims were pouncing upon vehicles arriving with relief material."

According to the The Pioneer in Delhi, the quake is the worst natural disaster to befall India since independence in 1947, and could derail government plans for radical economic reform. In the immediate future, there are likely to be new taxes in the imminent budget, to pay for reconstruction in Gujarat: "As the calamity's appalling costs begin to become evident, a meeting of senior ministers convened by Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee on Sunday evening began the process of factoring in the damage into the Budget... The meeting, which was the third in the New Year, was expected to focus on widening and accelerating economic reforms. The previous two meetings have concentrated on identifying sectors of the economy where reforms needed a kick-start and on measures on how to incorporate this into the Budget. The meeting on Sunday was completely devoted to the earthquake which has flattened out cities and villages in Kutch and hit one of the nation's most progressive and forward-looking state in the gut."

The Bombay paper, the Afternoon, Bombay, highlights the call of the Maharashtra chief minister Vilasrao Deshmukh for donations to help the neighbouring state of Gujarat: "Addressing an all-party meeting at the state secretariat yesterday, Mr. Deshmukh said it was the moral responsibility of Maharashtra to reach out to its neighbouring state in its time of crisis and all efforts would be made to extend aid in the form of funds, relief material and man power."

The Deccan Chronicle, Hyderabad , in central India, points up the devastating economic loss in the country's second most prosperous state. The paper estimates that at least 5,000 crores of rupees of damage has been caused. (A crore is 10 million, making the figure equivalent to nearly £850m.) And that is only a preliminary estimate: "The State attracts the cream of domestic and multinational investment. Friday's quake has not only caused tremendous loss of life and property, but also damaged infrastructure such as telecommunications, roads, power supplies and railways. The cumulative damage is believed to be in the region of Rs 2,000 crore. CII [Confederation of Indian Industry] chief Tarun Das estimates the loss to be Rs 5,000 crore and if the devastation continues for another week, the loss might go up to Rs 8,000 crore."

The Economic Times in Bombay also looks at the crippling economic burden imposed by the earthquake, and comes up with an even higher figure: "The government has asked the World Bank for $1bn and the Asian Development Bank for $500m to help rebuild the state which has a population of 41.3m people. The Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry put building and construction losses across Gujarat at about Rs 15,000 crore."

webTitle: Risquer sa vie «pour le plaisir»

fields.headline: Risquer sa vie «pour le plaisir»
fields.standfirst: After a woman was shot in a tragic circus accident, Karine Vandenhove asks French students how they feel about people risking their lives to entertain
fields.trailText: After a woman was shot in a tragic circus accident, Karine Vandenhove asks French students how they feel about people risking their lives to entertain
fields.body:
Cible humaine : tel était le métier de Catherine, 39 ans, avant qu'elle ne reçoive une flèche d'arbalète au dessous de l'il. Cela faisait une dizaine d'années qu'elle et son mari présentaient au cirque le numéro intitulé The Grey Arrow (la flèche grise) qui consiste à lancer des couteaux et des flèches sur cible humaine. Exécuté des milliers de fois, ce spectacle était rodé au millimètre. Pourtant, cette fois-ci, la flèche a manqué sa cible, une orange placée sur la tête de cette enfant de la balle qui, chaque jour, bravait la mort. Aujourd'hui, Catherine est dans un état critique. Son mari, le tireur, ne s'en remet pas. Il a failli tuer celle qu'il aime . . . À l'occasion de ce tragique accident, nous avons interrogé trois jeunes Françaises.

Que pensez-vous de l'accident de cirque qui a eu lieu récemment ?

Stéphanie, 18 ans, assistante pour enfants : Je n'y croyais pas. Je pensais que c'était un coup de pub. Souvent, on imagine que ces numéros sont truqués. La preuve que non.

Virginie, 20 ans, lycéenne : Ce sont les risques du métier. La meuf qui fait ça sait à quoi s'en tenir. Elle avait une confiance aveugle en l'homme qui a tiré. Or, un homme n'est jamais infaillible. Le problème, dans ces cas-là, c'est que l'on n'a pas le droit à l'erreur.

Léa, étudiante en droit : C'est vraiment horrible. Pour elle, mais aussi pour le public qui a assisté à la scène. J'aurais pas aimé y être et voir la flèche lui traverser la tête ! Les gens et les enfants surtout, doivent être traumatisés d'avoir vu ça !

Aimez-vous ce genre de spectacles ?

Stéphanie : Ça m'impressionne vraiment beaucoup, tout comme les acrobaties avec du feu. Ces gens sont très forts. Il faut en vouloir, être mordu, et aimer risquer sa vie, souvent pour rien.

Virginie : C'est prenant, fascinant, ça fait monter l'adrénaline, et donne des frissons. Il faut avoir les couilles de faire ce genre de trucs. Heureusement que j'étais pas dans le public, ça m'aurait écÏurée.

Léa : Je n'aime pas ce qui est risqué et ce qui fait peur. Je n'en vois pas l'intérêt.

Pensez-vous que ça vaut la peine de risquer sa vie comme ça ?

Stéphanie : Quand tu aimes ton métier, tu ne comptes pas. Les gens comme les cascadeurs le font pour se surpasser, aller au-delà de leurs limites, et avoir des sensations fortes. Ils ne le font pas que pour le fric. C'est un plaisir, dangereux et excitant à la fois.

Virginie : C'est l'amour du risque. Lors de tels numéros, le public est scotché, on a l'impression que les personnes qui font ça sont invincibles et immortelles. Elles risquent leur vie pour rien. Mais bon, au moins, elles éprouvent des sensations fortes, alors qu'un convoyeur de fonds par exemple, qui risque sa vie tous les jours pour 7 000 F par mois, n'a pas, lui, autant de plaisir et de satisfaction personnelle.

Léa : Ils sont payés pour le faire. À chacun son métier.

Seriez-vous prête à le faire ?

Stéphanie : J'aime goter à tout dans la vie. J'adore les sensations fortes, d'ailleurs j'aimerais sauter en parachute, me retrouver avec des tigres et les diriger, ou marcher sur un fil, avec un filet. D'ailleurs, j'ai déjà essayé de cracher du feu. J'ai même réussi à faire de belles flammes !

Virginie : Jamais de la vie, c'est trop risqué, a n'en vaut pas la peine, c'est pas mon trip de prendre des risques pour rien.

Léa : Je ne suis pas folle à ce point-là ! Pour les gens du cirque, c'est normal, ils ont été élevés comme ça, mais moi, non, je tiens à la vie !

Glossaire/Glossary

l'amour du risque the passion for risk and danger

braver la mort to defy death

à chacun son métier everyone to his trade

avoir une confiance aveugle en quelqu'un to trust someone blindly

avoir les couilles de faire quelque chose (very fam) to have the balls to do something

être écuré to be sickened

un enfant de la balle a child who follows in his father's footsteps (in circus, etc)

état critique critical condition

jamais de la vie ! Out of the question !

être mordu (fig) to be mad about

un numéro de cirque a circus act

quand on aime, on ne compte pas when you love something, the rest doesn't matter

les risques du métier occupational hazards

elle savait à quoi s'en tenir she knew where she stood

webTitle: Wanchope put on the transfer list

fields.headline: Wanchope put on the transfer list
fields.trailText: Manchester City striker Paulo Wanchope has been placed on the transfer list.
fields.body:
Manchester City striker Paulo Wanchope has been placed on the transfer list.

The Costa Rican international was angry at being substituted in the 1-0 FA Cup win over Coventry at Maine Road on Saturday and had words with manager Joe Royle as he made his way down the tunnel.

A meeting between the pair this morning failed to resolve their differences, and Wanchope has now been told he can leave the Premiership relegation strugglers.

"Joe Royle met with the player this morning and feels it is in the best interests of the club that they part company," said chief operating officer Chris Bird.

Wanchope was withdrawn after an ineffective performance against Coventry and replaced by Shaun Goater, who scored the winner in the last minute. As he left the pitch he gesticulated to the coaching staff and brushed past physio Rob Harris.

But at the time Royle poured cold water on the incident and dismissed talk of a prolbem with the player.

webTitle: Trouble for Terim as Lazio slip back into gear

fields.headline: Trouble for Terim as Lazio slip back into gear
fields.trailText: It is a reliable maxim in Italian football that whenever a coach announces he is leaving for pastures new at the end of the season, his side are duty bound to become distracted. Marcello Lippi and Sven-Goran Eriksson led the way in this particular field, and Fatih Terim could well be next.
fields.body:
It is a reliable maxim in Italian football that whenever a coach announces he is leaving for pastures new at the end of the season, his side are duty bound to become distracted. Marcello Lippi and Sven-Goran Eriksson led the way in this particular field, and Fatih Terim could well be next.

The Fiorentina coach had steered his Batigol-free side to an unlikely third position in the Scudetto, before announcing last week he would be saying arrivederci - or more likely Allahaismarladik seeing as he still speaks little Italian - in June. Cue more protests from the volatile Viola fans, who yesterday packed the Artemio Franchi stadium to offer their support.

But despite the vociferous chanting and waving of several large Turkish flags, the Fiorentina players couldn't respond. They were simply busted up by Dino Zoff's resurgent Lazio side, who withstood half-an-hours worth of Rui Costa inspired pressure before running away with the game 4-1.

Goals from Pavel Nedved and Hernan Crespo (2) - who is now, shock-horror, playing like a £36m striker - took the game out of reach early in the second half, and although Enrico Chiesa responded with a late penalty, Lazio had time to score a fourth through Marcelo Salas.

While the result puts pressure on Terim, whose players later blamed fatigue for the defeat, it only confirms Lazio's resurgence under gruff coach Dino Zoff. The champions are unbeaten since the former Italian coach took charge, and he was delighted - well, for him - at yesterday's result.

"Today everything went well," he said. "We played well, we attacked a lot and we scored four goals on a difficult ground. I like this Lazio. We've played well in the last three matches and I think we can reach whatever target we decide to set ourselves."

With Lazio in third place - within striking distance of Roma and Juventus - that target must surely include the Scudetto.

Filippo flips

In Washington the chattering classes debate the merits of George Bush. In London talk centres on Mandelgate II. But in Turin, as always, the discussion is about Alessandro Del Piero.

Once he was the darling of the Stadio Delle Alpi. But this week he was so frustrated at being the third choice striker behind Filippo Inzaghi and David Trezeguet he threatened to ditch his rumoured £100,000-a-week contract with Juve and join an unspecified foreign club at the end of the season.

"Crikey," thought the fans. But such talk cut no ice with coach Carlo Ancelotti, who once again left Del Piero out of his side for the visit of Vicenza. After only 13 minutes however, Del Piero's fortunes changed. Trezeguet hobbled off with an injury, and Juve's golden boy was given his chance to impress.

By and large he took it, getting involved in most of Juve's attacking play. But despite showing some sublime touches during the first half he was outshone by Inzaghi, who scored a hat-trick and set up a goal for Edgar Davids during Juve's 4-0 win.

Afterwards the never-modest Inzaghi had a thinly veiled message for his striking partner, telling Italia Uno's Controcampo sports programme: "I must now be the No 1 choice at Juventus. I am the man scoring goals and I am the best person to play."

Meanwhile Juve president Umberto Agnelli tried to reassure Del Piero that his future lies with the La Vecchia Signora. "Del Piero played really well. I'm confident that he can be just as good a player as he was before his injury," he insisted. But even Del Piero's staunchest fans must have their doubts, despite their man's performance yesterday.

Roma revive

After wheezing like an asthmatic with a cold in recent weeks Roma are back on track. They thrashed Napoli 3-0 with goals from Marco Delvecchio, Francesco Totti and Gabriel Batistuta to stay three points clear of Juventus.

Come rain or shine, win or defeat, Roma coach Fabio Capello never gets too animated however. "I know there is a long way to go yet," was his post-match reaction. "There are still so many matches - and so many difficult matches - to play. We didn't lose courage after last week, which was good, because a defeat in the San Siro against Milan is always possible. But, of course, we are not in raptures after this win."

Napoli coach Emiliano Mondonico was equally pragmatic. "I think that a three-goal gap is real between my team and Roma," he agreed. "Sometimes football respects the respective value of teams and at others the players can balance the technical gap, but unfortunately this didn't happen.

"Nothing has changed for us after today's defeat," he went on. "We are still one point below safety and, realistically, we can't expect to take points off teams as powerful as Roma. But all my players did their best today. We had two good chances during the first half, but we couldn't score. When Roma increased the tempo it was difficult to stop their players."

The best of the rest

Elsewhere in Serie A, Parma won 2-0 at Verona after two goals from Marco Di Vaio, handing Arrigo Saachi his first victory since returning to the Gialloblu.

AC Milan only managed a 1-1 draw away at Brescia, with coach Alberto Zaccheroni using the same excuse as Terim, fatgue, for his players running out of steam (the two sides had met in the Coppa Italia in midweek, so perhaps that had something to do with it).

Not surprisingly Brescia coach Carlo Mazzone - the Big Ron of Italian football - had a different take on the match. "It was a great result against a team who did not come here for a walk in the park but were determined to take away all three points," he said.

At the San Siro, Internazionale's £31m striker Christian Vieri was once again booed by supporters after missing several chances. But Vieri had the last laugh: he scored the winning goal as Inter squeezed past bottom-placed Bari 1-0.

Despite widespread talk of a crisis at the club, Inter's season isn't yet over. Yesterday's win puts them seven points clear of the relegation zone - and more importantly just four points behind Fiorentina, who currently occupy the fourth Champions League spot. With Fatih's side floundering, and with Ronaldo hoping to return before the end of the season, what price the nerazzurri making it into Europe this year?

webTitle: Doctors back change of law on body part removal

fields.headline: Doctors back change of law on body part removal
fields.trailText: Doctors and scientists are backing moves to clarify the law governing consent for the removal of body parts for research, medical education and postmortems. David Batty reports.
fields.body:
Doctors and scientists are backing moves to clarify the law governing consent for the removal of body parts for research, medical education and postmortems.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, is expected to announce changes in the law following the publication of a report on the Alder Hey organs scandals.

Dr Michael Wilks, chairman of the British Medical Association's medical ethics committee, agreed that legal uncertainties clearly needed to be resolved.

He said the Department of Health had recently consulted the BMA's ethics committee about developing new guidance for the profession on consent.

"Doctors have a duty to act within the law but their professional obligations to observe high ethical standards go far beyond the letter of the law," he said.

"Doctors know that obtaining informed consent is a much more complex process than simply obtaining a signature. The discussions between doctor and patient about diagnosis, treatment options, the risk of complications and the prospects of recovery are all part of gaining informed consent. Similarly high standards must apply to discussions with patients or parents about removing organs or tissue."

A spokesman for the Royal College of Pathologists said the law governing consent was ambiguous and out of date.

He said: "The practice of removing organs without consent probably stopped when the first scandal broke but the law needs to be changed to restore public confidence in the profession."

In a speech to patient groups in London, Mr Milburn hinted that sweeping changes in practice and policy would be introduced to ensure patients give informed consent to the use of organs and tissues.

The health secretary acknowledged that the Alder Hey scandal and the independent inquiry into heart operations at the Bristol Royal Infirmary have dented public trust in the health service.

The Alder Hey report, which health officials describe as shocking, is expected to reveal how thousands of organs were removed from dead babies at the Liverpool hospital without their parents' knowledge.

Parents were unaware that by signing consent forms for their children's operations, they were also giving doctors permission to remove and retain organs including the heart, lungs and nervous systems.

Mr Milburn added: "Above all else, for trust to thrive there has to be informed consent. Not a tick in the box 'consent' but consent that is based on discussion and dialogue, where consent is actively sought and positively given.

"The days have gone where the NHS could act as a secret society. It cannot operate behind closed doors. It cannot keep patients in the dark. It has to take patients into its confidence. It has to actively earn the trust of patients in life and it has to actively seek the consent of relatives in death."

Rabbi Julia Neuberger, chief executive of the King's Funds, said Mr Milburn was moving towards creating a more patient-centred NHS.

"The public are increasingly uneasy about the work of doctors and scientists, and about just how effectively they are being regulated. The health secretary is now beginning to deal with these uncertainties," she said.

webTitle: 'Grotesque' breach of trust at Alder Hey

fields.headline: 'Grotesque' breach of trust at Alder Hey
fields.standfirst: Huge scale of storage of children's organs will appal the public
fields.trailText: Huge scale of storage of children's organs will appal the public.
fields.body:
The details of what went on in the name of medical science at Alder Hey hospital in the last couple of decades, published in a report on Tuesday, will appal the public and risk causing serious damage to its already-eroded confidence in doctors and scientists.

The report will tell of the dismemberment of children who died in the Liverpool hospital by the pathologist Dick Van Velzen. What took place, said a source, was "on a scale and in a way that is horrific beyond anything anybody will have seen in this country".

Although the report will point the finger at the Dutch-born pathologist, who is facing a General Medical Council inquiry and is also wanted for questioning by the Canadian authorities about organs found in storage in Canada, others do not escape blame. The report will question why medical staff working with Mr Van Velzen did not blow the whistle on his activities.

The archive of human tissue in Liverpool, spread between Alder Hey children's hospital and the university, where the pathologist held joint posts, is hard to explain in scientific terms and unforgivable in human terms. Whole organ systems and stillborn babies were found preserved, but hardly any research was carried out or even planned. Mr Van Velzen maintains that the build up of body parts was due to a lack of funding to complete cot death research. However, the parents of the children had no idea that they had buried only some of their children's remains, while the rest were stored in bottles.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, has described the report's revelations as "grotesque". In a speech to patients' organisations today, he will say that what went on was a distortion of the doctor-patient relationship and a devastating breach of trust. Mr Milburn will make it clear that changes in the law will be needed, and that if they are not possible before a general election, they should be included in Labour's manifesto.

"For trust to thrive there has to be informed consent, not a tick-in-the-box regime - consent that is based on constructive dialogue and where consent is actively sought and positively given," he will say.

"In this country we can no longer accept the traditional paternalistic attitude of the NHS, that the benefits of medicine, science and research are somehow self-evident regardless of the wishes of patients or their families. There is a simple principle at stake here: the health of the patient belongs to the patient, not to the health service. I want the balance of power in the NHS to shift decisively in favour of the patient, not to pitch patients against doctors but to put the relationship between patients and the health service on a more modern footing.

"That will require changes in practice and changes in policy; changes in medical education and training. I believe it is so fundamental it will also require a change to the law."

Swift and convincing action is considered vital by the government, which fears there may be a violent reaction from parents when they read the full account of the goings-on at Alder Hey.

But ministers will not want the Alder Hey scandals, which they consider an aberration, to tar all the other teaching hospitals in the country. All of them stored organs such as hearts and brains. An audit by the chief medical officer, which will also be published on Tuesday, will show that there are between 40,000 and 50,000 organs in England alone.

Those were collected on the presumption by doctors that parents and relatives of people who died in hospital were happy to have them removed and used for research and teaching. This attitude exposed a gulf of misunderstanding, since the public for the most part has in the past assumed that the reference to the collection of "human tissue" in the autopsy consent form meant only slivers of flesh. Changes in the law will attempt to ensure that full explanations are given to relatives and that consent is truly informed.

The Alder Hey report could have a devastating impact on the public image of the medical profession, which is already considerably damaged by scandals such as the death rates in heart operations on babies at the Bristol Royal Infirmary, the Shipman murders and the botched operations of gynaecologist Rodney Ledward.

There may be calls for faster reform of the General Medical Council, which regulates the profession, although the GMC will point out that the real problem lies with the failures of doctors and managers to pick up bad practice in hospitals and GP surgeries.

Mr Milburn, in his speech today, will warn doctors that they must move faster to reform the profession. The GMC and the British Medical Association, backed by the medical Royal Colleges, are locked in argument over who should run the GMC.

The health secretary will say that the NHS is still a 1940s system operating in a 21st-century world, and call on the GMC, BMA and colleges to discharge their duty to act against bad doctors. But, Mr Milburn will say, "what we can't do and what we will not do is witch-hunt the medical profession."

webTitle: TV ratings January 27-28

fields.headline: Popstars continues to call the tune
fields.trailText: 1.45pm TV overnights: The Popstars ratings juggernaut gathered momentum on Saturday night adding another million viewers. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The Popstars ratings juggernaut continued to gather momentum on Saturday night, adding another million viewers to ITV's early evening audience.

Saturday saw the number of musicbiz wannabes left in the show whittled down from 33 to 10, with cocky Darius Danesh among the cast-offs.

The show had 8.6m and a 39% share, according to unofficial overnights.

That was 1.1m up on the Popstars audience last week and nearly 2m more than its debut in the 6.15-7.15pm Saturday night slot a fortnight ago.

The show's share of 16 to 34-year-olds also continues to climb. On Saturday Popstars pulled in a whopping 51% of this demographic.

ITV director of programmes David Liddiment has reacted swiftly to the success of Popstars, scheduling an extra edition at 8pm on Wednesday and another peaktime edition for Saturday, when the identity of the five Popstars band members will finally be revealed.

However, ITV's other major new reality format, daytime show Public Property, proved less successful in its first week.

Public Property is a real life soap revolving around six participants, who allow the show's viewers to decide what direction their lives take for 12 weeks.

The show, which is stripped daily between 5.05pm and 5.35pm, averaged 1.9m and a 13% share across its first week.

Admittedly it was in a tough slot, sandwiched between The Weakest Link on BBC2 and Channel 4's Pet Rescue, which drew 5m and 2.7m, respectively, across last week.

But the previous week ITV gameshow Family Fortunes averaged 2.9m and a 21% share over five days in the same slot.

Channel 5 reality show The Mole continued its ratings slide between 8pm and 9pm on Friday night.

The Mole dipped to 0.9m and a 4% share, 0.5m below its debut two weeks earlier.
