webTitle: Are earthquakes getting worse?

fields.headline: Are earthquakes getting worse?
fields.standfirst:
With the increasing number of metropolises, earthquakes cause more damage when they hit, writes science editor Tim Radford

Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: Analysis: With the increasing number of metropolises, earthquakes cause more damage when they hit, writes science editor Tim Radford.
fields.body:
There have been five earthquakes so far this year that measured magnitude 7 or more on the Richter scale. Each of these released as much energy as an all-out thermonuclear attack. Three were in almost deserted places. Two, within a fortnight of each other, caused colossal destruction.

On average, seismologists reckon that there should be 18 such earthquakes a year, and one of greater than magnitude 8. But even though the overall toll of disasters is growing, that doesn't mean that the world is a more dangerous place. It chiefly means that there are more victims to hurt, more buildings to destroy.

There are, somewhere or other in the world, 35 earthquakes or so a day. Earthquakes, like volcanoes, are inevitable: they are part of the self-renewal system of the planetary surface, the part that keeps mountains growing even as the wind and rains erode them.

For decades, earthquake scientists and engineers have tried to find ways of predicting them, planning for them, preparing communities for them. They may be in a losing battle. Although the number of earthquakes, on average, is constant, the number of potential victims is not. The planet's population has doubled in one short lifetime, and is still growing at almost 80m a year.

There is a second problem. More than half the planet now lives in cities. So many in this growing population now live in substandard housing, often built on unstable or second-rate land, and rarely inspected by local authorities. If they live in a seismic zone - and billions do - they are potential disaster statistics.

The Earth's crust exists in vast plates which in theory bump and grind together at a rate of about three inches a year. In practice, these tectonic plates stick, give suddenly and - as in San Francisco in 1906 - move up to 15 feet at a time. San Francisco was then a small city, but the destruction was terrible.

Such earthquakes, in today's megacities, are now the disaster expert's nightmare, because there is more fabric to destroy, more services to disrupt, more masonry to move to get at the injured and more risk of debilitation and disease for the survivors.

There is another element to consider: the atmosphere. Earthquakes happen whatever the weather. They don't happen any more frequently. But with global warming, climate experts do expect "extreme" weather events to happen more frequently.

The lesson of the last decade, which included the warmest years ever recorded, is that floods, droughts, tornadoes, hurricanes and avalanches are now taking more lives, and costing more economically, than ever before.

webTitle: US TV mogul in Sky talks

fields.headline: US TV mogul in talks over Sky stake
fields.standfirst: Vivendi: a print-out-and-keep guide
fields.trailText:
10.30am: US cable TV mogul John Malone is in crunch talks about buying a stake in BSkyB, writes Dan Milmo.
Vivendi: a print-out-and-keep guide
fields.body:
US cable TV mogul John Malone is in crunch talks about buying a stake in BSkyB in a complicated move triggered by the collapse of Rupert Murdoch's plans to float Sky Global Networks.

The Denver-based boss of Liberty Media now holds the key to the future of Rupert Murdoch's satellite TV interests and is exploring the possibility of buying the 22.7% BSkyB stake owned by French media giant Vivendi Universal.

The talks follow Vivendi's decision to sell its stake in order to win European Commission approval for its £50bn merger with Seagram.

Mr Malone is already a pivotal figure in News Corporation with a 20% holding in Mr Murdoch's media empire.

Mr Murdoch is running out of options to realise his dream of floating the £27bn satellite TV company after a merger with US operator DirecTV stalled on Friday night.

One option under consideration is a merger of Mr Murdoch's existing TV companies, which include Asian broadcaster Star TV and BSkyB.

But Mr Murdoch is desperate to get his hands on DirecTV - part of the General Motors group - because it is the only satellite operator in the US with more than 9m subscribers.

"It looks like Mr Murdoch will have to choose different options, which will involve News Corporation, DirecTV, John Malone, Liberty Media and Vivendi Universal. They have to organise something," said Marc Loneux, media analyst at Commerzbank.

Mr Loneux added that any enlargement of BSkyB would be scrutinised by a sceptical market.

"The only big asset in Sky Global is BSkyB. They may inject assets into BSkyB, and the market will not like it," he added.

Vivendi Universal could also take Liberty Media's stake in television programming business USA Networks, although a short-term stake in Sky Global is still possible if regulators allow it.

A spokesman for BSkyB said the future of the Vivendi stake was a matter for the respective companies' shareholders.

Mr Murdoch faces some challenging strategic decisions over the next few months, as the failure to link up with DirecTV, the leading satellite broadcaster in the US, will leave Sky Global without a vital US foothold.

Such a gap is likely to scupper any plans for a flotation, leaving him with the lesser option of merging his existing companies.

General Motors admitted at the weekend it was talking to several merger partners, and the recent drop in News Corporation's share price appears to have raised serious doubts about linking up with Mr Murdoch.

Sky Global is seen as Mr Murdoch's attempt to match the recent audacious moves of AOL, Time Warner, Vivendi and Seagram, who have all made bold bids for the global media market.

webTitle: Vivendi

fields.headline: Vivendi: a print-out-and-keep guide
fields.standfirst: Do you glaze over at the mention of the flotation of Rupert Murdoch's Sky Global Networks? Perhaps that's because you don't know enough about the other key players - Liberty Media and France's Vivendi Universal. Read Dan Milmo's print-out-and-keep guide to help improve your understanding of what could be the world's most formidable TV company.
fields.trailText:
What is Liberty Media Group?
It is a US-based cable TV company that also has interests in technology and the internet across Europe, South America and Asia. It is run by John Malone, a highly respected operator, whose no-nonsense-style has earned him the nickname Darth Vader.
fields.body:
What is Liberty Media Group?
It is a US-based cable TV company that also has interests in technology and the internet across Europe, South America and Asia. It is run by John Malone, a highly respected operator, whose no-nonsense-style has earned him the nickname Darth Vader.

Who owns Liberty?
It is 100%-owned by US telecoms giant AT&T but Mr Malone's board has complete independence and Liberty is expected to be spun off from AT&T in the summer.

What does Liberty own?
An awful lot. It has 9% of Time Warner, 49% of the Discovery Channels, 25% of UK cable operator Telewest and 21% of TV programming business USA Networks. Most importantly, Liberty holds 20% of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation.

How did it get involved with NewsCorp?
Mr Murdoch recently bought Liberty's stake in interactive TV guide group Gemstar-TV, and let Mr Malone up his holding in NewsCorp.

How strong is the Murdoch-Malone link?
Mr Murdoch needs strategic allies in the US, which makes 70% of NewsCorp's revenues. But he also needs a friendly buyer for the 22.7% stake in BSkyB, which is being sold by French media giant Vivendi Universal. Mr Malone has the cash - and the ability to execute complicated share swaps - to pull off such a move.

How else can Mr Malone help?
He could team up with Mr Murdoch to buy DirecTV, the much-coveted satellite TV company owned by General Motors. If Mr Murdoch gets hold of DirecTV, he can float his Sky Global Networks satellite broadcast company.

What is Vivendi Universal?
It is a global media company formed by the £50bn merger last year of French company Vivendi and Seagram of Canada. Vivendi was formerly known as Compagnie Generale des Eaux - France's biggest water distribution and treatment company. In the 1980s, it diversified into cable TV and had a significant presence in the UK. Vivendi's water division Vivendi Environnement was spun off in July last year.

What companies does it contain?
Vivendi Universal includes the Universal Studios film studio, the Canal Plus pay-TV channel, the Vizzavi mobile internet service, the Havas advertising company, Universal Music and the Cegetel phone company.

What is the key to Vivendi Universal's success?
Vizzavi, a joint venture with mobile phone operator Vodafone, has a potential customer base of 80m people. When Vivendi's lucrative content is added to the equation, Vizzavi certainly has exciting prospects. However, will next-generation services such as music and TV via mobile phones really catch on?

What are the doubts?
A large number of analysts say the merger has reduced shareholder value and doubt if such a wide-ranging group can be knitted together effectively.

What are its links with Rupert Murdoch?
Vivendi Universal holds a 22.7% stake in BSkyB, which it must sell because of an EU watchdog ruling on the Seagram merger. Jean-Marie Messier, the Vivendi chairman, therefore has a key role to play in the future of Sky Global Networks.

What are the options for Mr Messier?
He wants to keep Mr Murdoch as an ally, so he is likely to sell the stake to a NewsCorp partner, such as John Malone of Liberty Media. Alternatively, he could swap the stake for a holding in Sky Global Networks, although EU regulators might reach for the rulebook.

webTitle: Harman unveils plan to pay parents to stay at home

fields.headline: Harman unveils plan to pay parents to stay at home
fields.trailText: Proposals including paying mothers to stay at home for the first three years of their child's life are expected to be unveiled today.
fields.body:
Proposals including paying mothers to stay at home for the first three years of their child's life are expected to be unveiled today.

Former social security secretary Harriet Harman, who chairs the Childcare Commission, is due to outline the findings of a year-long study into childcare and family support in the UK.

The report is expected to call for an option of "generous family support" for parents and relatives to look after children in the first three years of their lives. Further options to be outlined include a children's centre in every area providing childcare, after school clubs and childminders' networks.

A commission spokeswoman said the report had drawn on surveys of parents, employers and children. "As well as excellent nurseries and childminders, many parents want more choice to care for their own children in their early years," she said. "Providing financial support for this is the only way to extend this choice to many parents."

The spokeswoman added that the report - which backs up the National Childcare Strategy - did not recommend an amount to be paid to families. This has widely been reported as being up to £150 a week.

webTitle: Half of kids now own mobile phones

fields.headline: Half of UK  kids own mobile phones
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Almost half of UK children aged seven to 16 now own a mobile phone, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Almost half of British children aged between seven and 16 now own a mobile phone, according to a new report.

Text messaging has been the key driver of this surge in uptake, with an average of 2.5 messages sent each day, compared with two voice calls per day.

Among children that now own mobile phones, the 14 to 16-year-old age group has the highest penetration, with at least 77% owning one.

The survey, conducted by NOP, reveals that 52% of girls and 44% of boys have their own mobile.

NOP associate director Emma Williamson said part of the attraction for children was the privacy allowed by mobiles.

"Privacy is something that often may not be available to them at school or in the home, so they view SMS texting as the ideal way in which to communicate confidentially with one another," she said.

Current estimates point to two-thirds of the British population - some 40m people - now using a mobile phone.

The impact on BT telephone boxes was revealed today when BT announced it would stop building telephone boxes because too few people were using them.

webTitle: Madrid keep on moving

fields.headline: Madrid keep on moving
fields.standfirst: Sid Lowe reports on a Real bollocking for Valencia, and a ticking off for Tristan
fields.trailText: According to Spanish football daily Marca, Roberto Carlos is a beast. Back in December, the paper turned up at Real Madrid's training ground and measured the Brazilian's dead-ball strikes at 122kph. Unfortunately, there were no speed-guns on hand in the Bernabéu on Wednesday night when Roberto Carlos cracked in another dead ball strike, this time for real, as Madrid beat Real Zaragoza 3-1. If there had been, the Brazilian insisted, "it would have registered a far greater speed - I hit this one a lot harder".
fields.body:
According to Spanish football daily Marca, Roberto Carlos is a beast. Back in December, the paper turned up at Real Madrid's training ground and measured the Brazilian's dead-ball strikes at 122kph. Unfortunately, there were no speed-guns on hand in the Bernabéu on Wednesday night when Roberto Carlos cracked in another dead ball strike, this time for real, as Madrid beat Real Zaragoza 3-1. If there had been, the Brazilian insisted, "it would have registered a far greater speed - I hit this one a lot harder".

Easy to say, but the man with thighs like the Serrano hams that hang from bars all over Spain is probably right - Zaragoza keeper Juanmi admitted afterwards that he didn't have a hope: "It's impossible to even see the ball, he hits it so hard. It's totally unstoppable."

So spare a thought for Valencia defender Jocelyn Angloma, whose cojones were called upon to block a penalty-area-bound strike during Sunday night's top-of-the-table clash at the Mestalla. It may not have been travelling at 122kph, but from point-blank range the Frenchman certainly felt it: down for a good few minutes, Angloma spent the rest of the match clearly suffering and blowing rather heavily.

Not surprisingly, Angloma seemed to be still struggling when substitute Pedro Munitis produced a rare moment of quality on the left to create the only goal of the game for Real Madrid. Fernando Morientes's header was brilliantly saved by Santiago Cañizares, but Raúl was on hand to finish easily.

Valencia's defeat is a huge (probably fatal) blow to their title chances, whereas Madrid have opened up a seven-point lead at the top of the table after Barcelona and Deportivo La Coruña disappointed this weekend.

Stumbles in the pack

La Coruña could be forgiven for being distracted by events off the pitch. Last week the Brazilian Djalminha threatened to take the Spanish FA to court for loss of earnings after they suspended him for two games for having a punch-up with his own team-mate, Víctor. With the row rumbling on, Depor manager Javier Irureta wisely decided not to play the Brazilian against Athletic Bilbao on Saturday.

But this week Irureta had more problems to deal with, as Canal Plus sneakily recorded, and broadcast, Diego Tristán and Fernando slagging off their coach. Fernando quickly rang to beg forgiveness, but there's no news yet from Diego Tristán, who arrived in the summer from Mallorca only to find last year's top scorer Roy Makaay blocking his way.

Makaay was Depor's hero again, responding to Julen Guerreo's opener with two goals. Irureta didn't celebrate the second strike; instead he turned to the bench with what seemed to be harsh words for the subs (including Tristán and Fernando). The Depor coach was even more unhappy when Bilbao secured a draw with a dubious penalty, converted by Aitor Larrazabal, with 20 minutes left.

Barcelona also failed to pick up full points, boring their way to a 0-0 draw in Málaga, where home keeper Pedro Contreras was the star man. Even so, unbeaten in nine league games (15 in total), Barça now look a good bet to finish second or maybe even push Real Madrid to the finish.

It's been a weekend of important results at the bottom, too. John Benjamin Toshack is "happier than I've been for a long time at Real Sociedad" after his side beat Racing Santander 4-1, Osasuna were the victims as Celta finally won (1-0) to end their dismal run, and Zaragoza were hammered 5-0 by cash-strapped Espanyol, whose manager Paco Flores proved he's up to date with yoof culture, man - "I get knocked down, but I get up again," he sang (ok, said) after the game. Numancia's position is looking increasingly perilous after they were beaten 3-0 at Real Oviedo.

This week's big news in the Asturian capital (that's Oviedo, by the way) is that Stanley Collymore is on the way. And while the tabloid hacks and Ray Stubbs reach for their dictionaries to find out what the Spanish is for "last-chance saloon", Oviedo boss Radi Antic has been busy waxing lyrical. "He's a great player and the fans'll love him. It'd be a real luxury for us to be able to call on him," he claimed. "We could be talking about the best signing we've ever made." Oviedo fans are hoping he's right.

Meanwhile Martín Palermo (he of the penchant for missing penalties and wearing drag) still wasn't fit enough to make his league debut for Villarreal, but his new side managed a 1-0 win against Rayo Vallecano, while Valladolid beat Mallorca 2-0 and Alavés ended a terrible run of four games without a win by defeating Las Palmas 1-0.

Real roll on

Finally, with Real Madrid looking likely to win the title for the first time in four years, president Florentino Pérez is back doing what he does best - winding up Barça fans. And what better way to do that than by telling Canal Plus that "it feels like Figo's always been at Madrid". "He has the leadership, companionship and the fighting spirit of a true Real Madrid player," Pérez gloated, before really laying it on thick: "Figo was born to be Real Madrid player." Born to it? So, his arrival at the Bernabéu had nothing to do with greed and blatant electioneering, then?

It didn't stop there, either. Just in case anyone thought Pérez was showing an unhealthy interest in matters purely football, he declared Real Madrid to be "the greatest brand in the world and our bank balance will, no doubt, soon reflect that". How? Well, here comes the really brilliant part - Real Madrid's training ground is set to be redeveloped, becoming "a huge theme park - people will travel from all over the world just to see it". Oh dear, here we go - cue crap jokes about roller-coaster seasons.

webTitle: Scotland gives free elderly care the go-ahead

fields.headline: Scotland gives free elderly care the go-ahead
fields.trailText: Scotland will implement in full the Sutherland report recommendations on free care for the elderly, first minister Henry McLeish said today in an unexpectedly firm declaration. Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
Scotland will implement in full the Sutherland report recommendations on free care for the elderly, first minister Henry McLeish said today in an unexpectedly firm declaration.

The move appears to end confusion over whether last week's decision to "bring forward proposals" on free personal care amounted to a guaranteed acceptance of Sutherland's recommendations.

"We are embracing the principles of Sutherland in full," Mr McLeish said, repeating the phrase for emphasis. He added that implementation of the report's recommendations on personal care for the elderly in residential homes - such as help with bathing, eating and dressing - would start in 2002. He also promised there would be "no backsliding" on the commitment.

The first minister made his comments at a press conference in Glasgow, which was called to present the administration's annual progress report on policy pledges. His statement went far beyond what many had expected after the events of last week, in which a threatened rebellion on the issue by Liberal Democrats in the Scottish parliament was bought off by an ambiguously worded emergency statement from the executive.

There had been speculation that last week's statement was no more than a commitment to study the idea of free personal care and thereby sideline the issue until after the general election and leave open options for a climbdown.

But Mr McLeish said today: "The commitment is there for all to see. We are embarking on a process which will have as its destination the implementation of free personal care. I cannot be more explicit."

He added: "There has been a lot of dancing on pinheads in relation to this. We are embracing the principles of Sutherland in full. In that sense there can be no clearer indication - we mean what we said and we have said what we mean." And he insisted: "There will be no backsliding. Those who have that view are simply wrong."

The decision has put Mr McLeish squarely at odds with Westminster, which has warned that there is "no chance" of implementing the Sutherland report recommendations in England.

The Liberal Democrats now plan to table an ammendment to the health and social care bill, currently going through parliament, which will "keep the door open" for the government in England to adopt Sutherland at a later date.

Mr McLeish's statement came as leading government adviser on long-term care Dr Chair Patel, the chairman of private health provider Westminster Health care, said the government should look at providing free personal care for the elderly in England and Wales.

Dr Patel told the Financial Times that such a move would become affordable as growing home ownership and higher pensions among the elderly meant that in future more people would be caught by the means test and would pay towards personal care.

webTitle: Clashes as 10,000 besiege Indonesian parliament

fields.headline: Clashes as 10,000 besiege Indonesian parliament
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Police fired tear gas and warning shots as thousands of rock-throwing demonstrators stormed the parliament gates in Jakarta today in the largest protest so far against the president, Abdurrahman Wahid.
fields.body:
Police fired tear gas and warning shots as thousands of rock-throwing demonstrators stormed the parliament gates in Jakarta today in the largest protest so far against the president, Abdurrahman Wahid.

Three students were badly beaten by police as running battles broke out on the lawns of the heavily guarded legislature.

The estimated 10,000 protesters had marched through the streets of the capital, demanding that Mr Wahid quit over two corruption scandals.

As the mob broke down the gates, politicians met in a closed session inside the parliament to hear the results of a long-running investigation into the two affairs that have afflicted Mr Wahid's 15-month administration.

Speaking to reporters at the presidential palace, Mr Wahid dismissed the significance of the anti-government demonstration and laughed off demands that he should step down.

Even so, the size and violence of today's rally was reminiscent of protests that led to the ousting of former dictator Suharto in 1998, and his successor, BJ Habibie, in 1999.

Police said around 1,000 supporters of Mr Wahid had also gathered inside the parliamentary compound. However, their support was drowned out by the much larger anti-Wahid demonstration outside.

Ijan, one of the students, who like many Indonesians uses one name, said: "Wahid must resign immediately."

Mr Wahid has come under increasing pressure as his opponents take heart from events in the neighbouring Philippines where Joseph Estrada was forced to quit as president earlier this month after protests and impeachment proceedings.

Analysts warned that today's protest in Jakarta might herald a new wave of violence in Indonesia.

Taufik Abdullah, chairman of the Indonesian Institute of Sciences, said: "The demonstrations will continue. The students are looking at the fall of Estrada. This is just the start."

Last week officials from Mr Wahid's Muslim-based party warned that bloodshed and chaos could erupt if the legislature tried to impeach him.

The investigation into the two scandals represents the biggest political challenge to Mr Wahid since he was elected to office in late 1999 after years of authoritarian rule.

Lawmakers have not yet publicly released their findings. However, many say there is sufficient evidence to implicate Mr Wahid in both scandals, despite the president's repeated denials of any wrongdoing.

It is far from certain, though, whether parliament will pursue the case and initiate lengthy impeachment proceedings.

The investigation into Mr Wahid comes as his popularity remains low due to his inability to fix fundamental problems besetting the world's fourth most populous nation.

Separatist and sectarian violence has killed thousands in several provinces, and the economy remains in crisis.

Authorities also have failed to catch the masterminds of a series of deadly terrorist bombings.

The first scandal centres on Mr Wahid's masseur and one-time business partner, who allegedly used the president's name to dupe the government's main food agency, Bulog, into handing over £2.7m from its employees' pension fund.

Bulog officials say that months earlier Mr Wahid had asked if the fund's money could be channelled into aid projects in Aceh, a province wracked by bloody separatist fighting.

Mr Wahid has admitted he initially considered doing this, but later decided against it. Instead, he accepted £1.3m from the sultan of neighbouring, oil-rich Brunei.

His revelation led to allegations of a second scandal, dubbed "Bruneigate", despite Mr Wahid's insistence that the sultan's money was a personal donation.

webTitle: TV violence on the increase

fields.headline: TV violence on the increase
fields.trailText: 1pm: The portrayal of violence in TV drama increased significantly in 1999 according to new research, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The realistic portrayal of violence in TV drama increased significantly in 1999, according to Broadcasting Standards Commission research.

1999 was the year in which EastEnders fell foul of the BSC for the graphic depiction of Steve Owen's murder of scheming Saskia.

In total, 692 scenes of fictional violence were recorded in 1999 and 68% were regarded as realistic.

This compares with 62% the previous year, according to the BSC.

The number of violent scenes also increased markedly in 1999, up to 1,356 from 1,230 the previous year, according to the BSC.

Much of this increase was put down to coverage of the Kosovo conflict.

News and current affairs accounted for 28% of all depictions of violence on UK terrestrial channels in 1999.

The amount of swearing and bad language on terrestrial TV rose significantly in the 1990s, according to the BSC research.

In 1999, the BSC recorded 2,887 incidents of offensive language, the highest since the regulator began its tracking survey in 1993.

In 1993 there were just over 2,000 incidents of bad language.

Sex was another televised activity on the increase.

The number of scenes in which sexual acts were portrayed rose from 176 in 1998 to 201 in 1999.

But the actual number of programmes containing "significant" incidents of sex, violence or bad language remained relatively small, according to the BSC.

Only 5% of shows were felt to contain a significant amount of violence and 4% had notable levels of strong language.

Only 2.5% featured scenes of explicit sex.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: the expert's view

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Patrick Murray of Blue Sq casts his sharp eye over our punters' bets and decides that, hey, they're not doing too bad after all
fields.trailText: Scott Murray: Sheffield Wednesday to win at Southampton (£5 at 15/2); Tranmere to win at Everton (£5 at 13/2).
fields.body:
Scott Murray: Sheffield Wednesday to win at Southampton (£5 at 15/2); Tranmere to win at Everton (£5 at 13/2).

Could it be? An actual winner? In January? Whatever next, a left footed Englishman?

Yes the marvellous Mr Murray comes to the rescue yet again with the good old value single. I never lost faith in the boy. We all have our little dips in form, our Collymore periods after the honeymoon is over, but class will always tell in the end. Okay so maybe the Collymore metaphor was a mistake but you get the idea.

Everton's pitiful form in recent weeks made them very opposable and the fact that they were playing renowned cup team Tranmere in a local derby (which, like the Cup, tends to be a great leveller) just added to the prospect of an upset. But Everton are a Premiership side and Tranmere languish in the lower reaches of the first division so it was obvious Everton would win - one for all accers as we say in the trade (accers being short for accumulators you see, it's a different world I tell you). But regular readers among you will know that avoiding the obvious is the name of the game, the bookies are liable to artificially shorten the 'sure things' in the knowledge that your average betting shop punter will back them at any price and this often leads to value elsewhere. Tranmere at 13/2 looked cracking value, by backing them all you are saying is that if the teams met 15 times Tranmere would win at least twice; obviously Scott was fortunate that this was one of the 'at least two' times, but in the long run luck shouldn't come into it, if you're backing value you will win. He was less fortunate with his bet on Sheffield Wednesday but that is not to say it wasn't value and that Wednesday wouldn't have won two times out of seventeen.

As for his belittling of the wonderful betting medium that is American Football, nobody's perfect I suppose. Perhaps one day he will see the light, meantime he seems to be doing okay on the good old English version.

Sean Ingle: Most goals tomorrow selection: £5 on Bristol City @ 3/1 and £2 on Sunderland at 12/1.

I certainly reckon these special markets are worth a look (not least because I know the comparatively little time that can go into pricing them up) but given the size of the bookie's margin on such markets they have to get it pretty wrong to offer value.

There was not a lot wrong with Mr Ingle's analysis of the market - indeed the three teams he dismissed out of hand all performed badly and the eventual winner Arsenal (a 6/1 shot) received an honourable mention from Mr I without quite making the grade - and as such one has to think that he might have a fair chance on the market in the long run. Unfortunately his actual picks this time round fell somewhat short, five goals to be precise, of the lofty standard set by the Gunners.

The secret with esoteric markets such as this is to make them your speciality. In this case, for example, one would follow the market week in week out, gaining a good knowledge of how it worked, producing ratings for teams (both as scorers and conceders of goals, at home and away), and then, for the coup de grace, factor in the specifics of the match (injuries, suspensions, past match-ups and so on) in order to produce one's own prices to compare to those on offer. Unfortunately this is not Mr Ingle's style - a little too much like accountancy, I fear.

Oh yeah, and another thing, I notice Mr I only backed his selections to win - with just eight selections the each-way terms of a fifth of the odds if your selection finishes in the first three are actually quite attractive. As it happens had Sean backed both teams each way he would got a fair chunk of his win stake back with one goal being enough, in this case, for a share of third place.

Its all part of the learning curve, Rome wasn't built in a day and all that, I still believe Mr I can turn in a profit by the end of the season, but then I also believe that the mighty Reading will get promoted so perhaps I'm best ignored.

Joe Fortune of the Football Unlimited Punters Collective: Sunderland v Ipswich - half-time draw, full-time Sunderland £5 @ 4/1

I'm not totally convinced by this bet although I certainly think that draw/favourite is almost invariably better value than the favourite/favourite your average punter tends to back (and your average bookmaker tends to artificially shorten as a consequence). Personally I tend to restrict my forays into the half-time/full-time market to moments when there is a very short priced favourite and draw/favourite can often be backed at extremely attractive odds.

This kind of bet is essentially a double - draw at half-time, Sunderland at full-time - so to determine if it's value all we have to do is work out the price of its constituent parts. In this case Blue Square were offering 6/5 on a draw at half-time. A 6/5 6/5 double comes to just under 4/1 so at first glance it looks as though Mr Fortune was getting a shade of value. However one must remember the bookie's margin is part of the prices I quoted - the true prices are probably nearer 5/4 if not 11/8 and a 5/4 5/4 double comes in at just over 4/1.

I don't think Mr Fortune's done a lot wrong here but winners are proving rather elusive of late. Plenty of time to turn it around though, as I seem to say every week.

I seem to got all nerdy and informative this week, but back to the uninformative flippancy next week I shouldn't wonder. And next week hopefully I will be writing about a few wins. Until then happy punting.

Sean Ingle: Most goals tomorrow selection: £5 on Bristol City @ 3/1 and £2 on Sunderland at 12/1. I certainly reckon these special markets are worth a look (not least because I know the comparatively little time that can go into pricing them up) but given the size of the bookie's margin on such markets they have to get it pretty wrong to offer value. There was not a lot wrong with Mr Ingle's analysis of the market - indeed the three teams he dismissed out of hand all performed badly and the eventual winner Arsenal (a 6/1 shot) received an honourable mention from Mr I without quite making the grade - and as such one has to think that he might have a fair chance on the market in the long run. Unfortunately his actual picks this time round fell somewhat short, five goals to be precise, of the lofty standard set by the Gunners. The secret with esoteric markets such as this is to make them your speciality. In this case, for example, one would follow the market week in week out, gaining a good knowledge of how it worked, producing ratings for teams (both as scorers and conceders of goals, at home and away), and then, for the coup de grace, factor in the specifics of the match (injuries, suspensions, past match-ups and so on) in order to produce one's own prices to compare to those on offer. Unfortunately this is not Mr Ingle's style - a little too much like accountancy, I fear. Oh yeah, and another thing, I notice Mr I only backed his selections to win - with just eight selections the each-way terms of a fifth of the odds if your selection finishes in the first three are actually quite attractive. As it happens had Sean backed both teams each way he would got a fair chunk of his win stake back with one goal being enough, in this case, for a share of third place. Its all part of the learning curve, Rome wasn't built in a day and all that, I still believe Mr I can turn in a profit by the end of the season, but then I also believe that the mighty Reading will get promoted so perhaps I'm best ignored. Joe Fortune of the Football Unlimited Punters Collective: Sunderland v Ipswich - half-time draw, full-time Sunderland £5 @ 4/1 I'm not totally convinced by this bet although I certainly think that draw/favourite is almost invariably better value than the favourite/favourite your average punter tends to back (and your average bookmaker tends to artificially shorten as a consequence). Personally I tend to restrict my forays into the half-time/full-time market to moments when there is a very short priced favourite and draw/favourite can often be backed at extremely attractive odds. This kind of bet is essentially a double - draw at half-time, Sunderland at full-time - so to determine if it's value all we have to do is work out the price of its constituent parts. In this case Blue Square were offering 6/5 on a draw at half-time. A 6/5 6/5 double comes to just under 4/1 so at first glance it looks as though Mr Fortune was getting a shade of value. However one must remember the bookie's margin is part of the prices I quoted - the true prices are probably nearer 5/4 if not 11/8 and a 5/4 5/4 double comes in at just over 4/1. I don't think Mr Fortune's done a lot wrong here but winners are proving rather elusive of late. Plenty of time to turn it around though, as I seem to say every week. I seem to got all nerdy and informative this week, but back to the uninformative flippancy next week I shouldn't wonder. And next week hopefully I will be writing about a few wins. Until then happy punting.

webTitle: Emap plans celebrity title

fields.headline: Emap to launch celebrity health title
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Emap is launching a celebrity health and beauty magazine, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Emap is pitching into the celebrity market with a magazine designed to give readers the inside story on the stars' health and beauty regimes.

Celebrity Bodies will launch in late March and compete with Time's InStyle and Conde Nast's Glamour.

It will be aimed at women aged between 25 and 35 who want to learn the health and beauty secrets of the stars.

The magazine will be edited jointly by Olivia Howard and Alison Hall.

Ms Howard said it would be less fashion-heavy than InStyle and Glamour andd would "tailor the editorial so the reader can follow the stars' health and diet routines".

The magazine will have a cover price of £1.50 and a 150,000 print run.

webTitle: Lessons from past disasters go unheeded

fields.headline: Lessons from past disasters go unheeded
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: Earthquakes are inevitable, but death in an earthquake is not. Ground tremors do not kill: collapsing buildings do the killing.
fields.body:
Earthquakes are inevitable, but death in an earthquake is not. Ground tremors do not kill: collapsing buildings do the killing.

Earthquake engineers and seismologists reacted in anger yesterday after the second powerful earthquake in a fortnight brought death to thousands, and grief and despair to tens of thousands more.

People died in El Salvador on January 13 and Gujarat on January 26 because modern buildings - even modern hospitals - fell flat, one floor pancaking on to another as reinforced concrete slabs collapsed like a house of cards.

They died because walls that should have been tied to floors fell outwards, removing all structural support, and bringing the roof down. They died because tall buildings swayed in resonance and shook themselves to bits as the ground danced beneath them.

People died because they lived on or near unstable hillsides; they died because gas pipes burst, and petrol stations caught fire, because water supplies failed and sewage flooded their basements; they died because communications collapsed and the roads were blocked with rubble and help could not get there in time.

They died, the disaster experts say, because it is one thing for national governments to know about earth quake hazard and building safety codes, but another thing for local authorities to enforce them or developers to stick to them.

Thousands died because no one remembers the lessons of past earthquakes.

Ravi Sinha, a civil engineer from Bombay who is preparing to go to Gujarat, said: "We are beginning to relearn the same lessons that were reiterated following the El Salvador event: the governments are not prepared. They directly or indirectly contribute to an increase in death by permitting poor construction quality. It is sickening to see the cycle repeat again and again."

Cinna Lomnitz, a professor of seismology at a university in Mexico City, witnessed that city's terrible earthquake in 1985 and is now heading to examine the damage in San Salvador. He says it is often possible to draw parallels between tragedies.

"Ahmedabad is a city that grew very fast, like Mexico City. The news pictures suggest that Ahmedabad was a second Mexico City; a number of tall buildings collapsed in resonance."

He says engineers are capable of designing buildings to withstand even the most severe earthquake. "Definitely our aim should not and cannot be any less than zero casualties."

Ben Wisner, a researcher at Oberlin College, Ohio, and a member of the International Geographical Union's group on hazards and risks, is campaigning for a worldwide push for safety standards. He is familiar with the architecture in Ahmedabad, and says that it differs little from that in other nearby cities.

"On the one hand, there is an ageing building stock and lack of maintenance. On the other, some new structures may well have been built without proper adherence to codes and not properly inspected," he says. "It is unlikely the percentage of buildings that are earthquake-resistant is any higher in Ahmedabad or Bhuj than it is in Delhi."

In El Salvador on January 13, the country lost 40% of its hospital capacity. In Gujarat, medical facilities also collapsed.

"Authorities know how to protect hospitals," Mr Wisner said. "There is no reason why the civil hospital in Bhuj needed to collapse on patients and staff."

There are around 50,000 detectable earthquakes a year, most of them no more than little rumbles; on average, there are 18 earthquakes of magnitude seven or more every year.

Since January 1 2001, there have been five such tremors: Three - in the Pacific Islands of Vanuatu, near Kodiak Island in Alaska, and on Mindanao in the Philippines - caused little damage; there were few humans around to be hurt. But experts are still counting the dead in the rubble of El Salvador and throughout Gujarat.

webTitle: In brief: Kidman pulls out of thriller after knee injury

fields.headline: Kidman pulls out of thriller after knee injury
fields.standfirst: Plus: The Wedding Planner defies bad reviews to top US box office; Al Pacino and Beverly D'Angelo celebrate birth of twin daughters; Hugh Grant and Cameron Diaz lined up for Wimbledon romance
fields.trailText: Plus: The Wedding Planner defies bad reviews to top US box office; Al Pacino and Beverly D'Angelo celebrate birth of twin daughters; Hugh Grant and Cameron Diaz lined up for Wimbledon romance
fields.body:
 Nicole Kidman has pulled out of David (Fight Club) Fincher's The Panic Room two weeks into production due to a knee injury. The actress first hurt the knee while filming Baz Lurhmann's trouble-hit Moulin Rouge when it was aggravated by her physically demanding role. Her abrupt exit throws the big-budget production into question. Kidman was cast in The Panic Room as a mother struggling to protect her daughter when her home comes under siege from two criminals (Forest Whitaker, Dwight Yoakam).

 Despite a veritable raspberry of bad reviews, the romantic comedy <A HREF=" "http://guardian.imdb.com/Title?0209475">The Wedding Planner leapt straight to the top of the US box office last weekend with initial takings of $14m (£9.58m). Budgeted at a relatively slender $28m (£19.17m), the film stars Jennifer Lopez as the eponymous organiser who falls head over heels for Matthew McConaughey's groom-to-be. The Wedding Singer shunted the inter-racial college outing Save the Last Dance into second place with takings of $10m (£6.84m). Oscar hopefuls Cast Away and Traffic were clinging on at numbers three and four respectively.

 Al Pacino and actress partner Beverly D'Angelo were last night celebrating the birth of twin daughters. Pacino, 60, has an 11-year-old daughter from a previous relationship. He and D'Angelo (best known as Chevy Chase's wife in the National Lampoon's Vacation comedy films) have been together since 1995.

 Hugh Grant and Cameron Diaz are being sized up to co-star in a tennis-themed romance set against the green lawns of Wimbledon. The film is being engineered by Working Title - makers of the ludicrously successful Notting Hill and Billy Elliot - and will presumably star Grant as a diffident Tim Henman type and Diaz as a sexy American tennis ace. Writer Mark Levin yesterday told the Sunday Express that: "We want to do it as soon as possible while Hugh's still young enough to be comfortable with the athleticism of the role." But a spokesman for Working Title cautioned: "It is still very early days."

webTitle: Chris Blackhurst on the Express

fields.headline: Bad days at Blackfriars
fields.standfirst: When Lord Hollick lost interest in the future of the Daily Express those in the middle were the last to know the truth. Chris Blackhurst, until last week deputy editor of the paper, recalls how he and editor Rosie Boycott were kept in the dark - from the day the first rumour surfaced about the sale of the newspaper in the summer of 1999 to the day it was sold in November 2000.
fields.trailText:
Chris Blackhurst, ex-deputy editor of the Express, recalls how he and ex-editor Rosie Boycott were kept in the dark about Lord Hollick's plans for the sale of the paper.
More Express stories
fields.body:
For years I have written about the buying and selling of businesses, usually in that detached tone favoured by the financial community.

A corporate figure (nearly always a man) is interviewed and boasts about his company and its acquisition. He talks about cutting overheads, making assets sweat - in other words, closing plants and sacking people. Or an analyst speaks knowingly about a business losing its focus on core activities. And I lap it up.

Never, until recently, had I been at the other end of such cold reason.

Only now can I appreciate what others have gone through as their firms were broken up and sold. Am I better for it? Certainly. Shouldn't all journalists, analysts, accountants, fund managers, consultants and other know-it-alls be exposed to the experience? Absolutely. Would society benefit if the City had more understanding of what it is like to be the subject of unfeeling logic? Financially, no. But it would be a damned sight more compassionate place in which to work.

When quoted companies make a big move, they do so in the utmost secrecy. They are obsessed, and rightly so, with fears of the news leaking, of the deal being scuppered, of unscrupulous people making a killing, of the Stock Exchange being the last to know. And this was the case with United News and Media (UNM), owner of Express Newspapers, publisher of the Daily Express and Sunday Express, of which I was deputy editor.

Companies that take the stonewall approach fail to realise that senior staff are caught in the middle. You believe or suspect something is up, but don't know for sure. Meanwhile, junior colleagues believe you know what's up and just aren't saying.

For the uninformed senior executive, it is dispiriting and demoralising. You feel useless in a sphere where only days before you seemed to exercise total power. Suddenly, you are running an international news operation and are powerless to say for certain what is happening upstairs. The sale of Express Newspapers was on the cards as early as May 1999, but I learned only on November 22 2000 that the papers had been sold.

We were not told by UNM. We learnt the news from Sky television. Back in April 1998, I had left the job of deputy editor of the Independent with Rosie Boycott, the editor, to take up the task of turning round the Express titles. We were given a mandate to take the papers upmarket, to make them appeal to a younger, progressive audience. We were promised that the vast resources of UNM, a £5bn corporation, would be at our disposal. There would be massive investment. We'd be able to draw on UNM's television and other media interests.

All went well at first. We lost some older readers, wooed in part by promotional overtures from the Daily Mail, but that was predicted. (One commentator forecast we would lose 600,000 readers in six months; in fact, it was 150,000 in almost three years.) UNM, in the person of Lord Hollick, our new chief executive, took a close interest in the papers. Hollick, a big Labour supporter, was a regular at management meetings, where his enthusiasm could be infectious. Marketing plans, expansion and investment proposals were discussed.

Then in May 1999 the tap was abruptly turned off. With hindsight, it was the first sign of a shift in strategy that would ultimately lead to a sale. At the time, UNM's parsimony was attributed to the inherent character of Hollick, a shrewd dealmaker who was cautious by nature, not given to the sweeping visionary brushstrokes of media barons such as Rupert Murdoch and Lord Rothermere.

Hollick hated to spend money. But, to be fair to him, he had no large personal holding to shore up his position. Unlike Murdoch and Rothermere, Hollick was a salaryman, dependent on the goodwill of his external shareholders. Make them a good return, fine. Screw up and you're out.

With us, Hollick was contrary, talking big one minute, lost in petty detail the next. He was enigmatic, fond of playing his cards close to his chest. Once, Boycott and I were summoned to see him about results of research into 'lapsed readers' - who, if we were sticking to our original brief, should not have mattered. We didn't even know the research was being done.

Much was made in the press of Boycott's friendship with Hollick, but she never went to his house for dinner and he failed to attend work functions at her home. They would go for long periods without exchanging a word, and when they did it was often over a trivial complaint. Hollick's temper was fearsome; he was used to getting his own way and executives rarely stood up to him.

Hollick, however, loved owning newspapers. They gave him political and social cachet. He adored ringing up political and football journalists for the latest gossip. If we had a cabinet minister in for lunch, Hollick expected to be invited. Yet he exhibited little interest or feel for the living organism that a newspaper is - how it is put together, what makes it tick.

Hollick's reluctance to spend money did not extend to paying for outside advice. UNM and its many parts were forever being pored over by consultants. It was one such study, I later discovered, that may have prompted the sudden change of policy in May 1999. Unknown to Boycott, PricewaterhouseCoopers had embarked on a crucial study of the Express group. Its sensitivity can be judged by the way it was cloaked in secrecy: in the detailed report that resulted, the project had the code-name Postbox; the Express titles were referred to as Unicorn and their sister publication, the Daily Star, was Comet.

The study's conclusion was stark: although progress had been made, further development required investment that might be difficult to justify for a publicly listed company. For Hollick, who prided himself on doing right by shareholders, this was probably not what he wanted to read. The consultants were saying, in effect, that the Express group needed an owner-proprietor, rather than someone who always had to put shareholders' interests first.

Rumours of the Express papers being on the block first surfaced in early summer of 1999, and the timing, given the date of the PwC report, cannot have been mere coincidence. Hollick's interest began to wane. The weekly meetings with him in the chair were scrapped, and when we did see him, the conversation dwelt on trivia.

After Tony Blair's speech at the Labour party conference in Bournemouth in October 1999, I walked with Hollick to the High Cliff Hotel. He said he was glad for the chance to chat. I thought that at last we might get an indication about future investment. It was not to be. He asked whether I thought he should go to see Barcelona play Arsenal in the Champions League.

Industry gossip said Andrew Neil was hovering in the wings, ready to buy on behalf of the Barclay brothers, and Kleinwort Benson, UNM's banker, was preparing sale details. Pieces started appearing in rival newspapers predicting our disposal. One said City analysts were forecasting a £1 rise in UNM's share price if the Express papers were sold. This gave a strong hint of the pressure Hollick faced. UNM shares at that time were barely above £5. Market capitalisation was about £3bn. The rumour mill said the papers would fetch, at most, £300m - yet here was the City saying we were worth £600m to the share price.

This was always the argument we faced. City analysts, whose work was read by the fund managers who owned the bulk of UNM, thought we were more valuable to the company outside it than within it. One City scribbler even speculated that UNM might be able to raise as much as £1bn by selling us as a provider of content to an internet business, such as Freeserve. UNM had a policy of not commenting on speculative stories. But amid this blizzard of publicity, it meant that assertions went unanswered and claims presented as fact were not denied. It had a curious schizophrenic effect.

Internally, UNM assured us there was no truth in the rumours. Externally, the business and media pundits were having a ball. Staff assumed that the editor and deputy were in the loop - that we were somehow in the thick of whatever was happening, that any decision to sell would involve our agreement. Sadly, nothing could have been further from the truth. We were not told; we were not consulted; we did not know.

A lull ensued. The rumours died down and we resumed business as normal - except it was anything but normal. While talk of imminent sale had receded for the time being, there was little evidence of any substantial new money for the titles. Both the Daily Express and Sunday Express were battling against an onslaught from the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday. The response from our side was lamentable. All the energy went into producing the paper day to day - it was as if the future did not exist.

Journalists are quite unlike other workers. Their trade is information. They are trained observers who like nothing better than gossip. We had 440 pairs of eyes watching us and 440 pairs of ears hanging on every word. Any casual remark, joke or grimace by Boycott was relayed and dissected for any clue to imminent news. We debated whether she should tell staff: 'Look, I hear the rumours, too. But I assure you, I know nothing.' But that was rejected because they would speculate that it was a double bluff.

When we interviewed candidates for jobs, they would invariably ask what lay in store for the papers. Staff would come to us and say they had been approached by another paper about a job. What could we advise? All we could answer was that we hadn't a clue. It was undermining - colleagues we knew and liked found it impossible to believe that a national newspaper editor who was so well informed on other matters and was a board director of the Express subsidiary did not know what the parent company was planning. Nor did her deputy.

The mood changed again early last year. UNM was proposing to merge with Carlton, whose boss, Michael Green, was said to be looking forward to owning papers and to be keen to expand them. Two firms of consultants were appointed to examine the level of cash injection required to boost circulation. It was not much, but it was something. At least dialogue was taking place. We found ourselves in meetings where the talk was of investment and growth. Suddenly, for a period, there was a sense of belonging, that the papers were to remain part of the UNM-Carlton family.

But just as abruptly, the mood changed. Hollick was dealt a savage blow when the Competition Commission ordered UNM to shed its Meridian television holdings as a condition of a merger with Carlton. To Hollick's dismay, Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, accepted the ruling. From what was to be a marriage of equals, the proposed tie-up was hopelessly tilted in Carlton's favour. It was clear the union was off.

Speculation again centred on the future of the newspapers. Granada, seen as a possible buyer of UNM, was apparently letting it be known that it did not want Express Newspapers. It was believed that supremos Gerry Robinson and Charles Allen did not want to risk alienating the City by buying the papers, which many viewed as 'old media' - too expensive and too dangerous to take on. They had seen Hollick having to defend the papers to a sceptical City, and that wasn't going to happen to them.

When UNM announced the sale of its television division to Granada, the writing was on the wall for the Express group. That's what the City thought, what all the media commentators wrote and what the staff believed. But UNM pretended nothing had changed. Hollick's ambition to become a major media player, with the bulk of ITV and other television interests, plus three national newspapers and several consumer magazines, had come to nought. We at the Express titles now found ourselves part of a company intent on a new direction.

What political influence the papers afforded Hollick had vanished. Stories of the Labour peer's rage at the government, which he had loyally supported but which, as he saw it, had not assisted him, made the rounds of the building at Blackfriars. The papers' relationship with their boss had shifted. The feeling grew that he would sell us to any group - especially one opposed to Labour, such as Associated - just to spite the administration that had let him down so badly.

There was also the sense that even had he wanted to keep us, Hollick's hands were tied. Weakened by the collapse of the Carlton merger, he had to be seen to be acting decisively to silence his City critics, many of whom had been badgering for the sale of the Express group and now wanted to see positive signs of a decisive strategy for a new-look UNM.

At the paper, we explored the possibility of a management buyout and, with Boycott's approval, I met a City heavy-hitter. His reaction to the idea was swift: how would the Daily Express avoid the kind of grief the Independent had suffered when The Times started a price war. With no reserves, the Independent could not respond and its circulation fell. Finally, it had to give up its independence and turned to the Mirror Group for help. The buyout expert explained that the City prefers to back businesses that lead their markets. In other words, it hates taking risks - and, whichever way we cut it, we were a risk. He also said Hollick did not have a reputation for 'leaving something behind on the table' so there was little likelihood that profits could be increased by making cuts - another thing the City likes. It was an eye-opener, one that left me applauding anyone brave enough to get involved in a buyout.

Staff assumed, again, that we must have known what was going on. But Boycott had exchanged barely a word with Hollick in the three months before last October's Labour party conference in Brighton, when they had dinner together. I was there, along with other journalists and four government ministers. In the course of a three-hour meal, the subject of the papers never came up. Afterwards, Boycott and I walked with Hollick from the restaurant back to the conference area. He engaged in small talk and we listened. Of the papers, not one word.

What we could not have known was that Hollick was sitting on an offer from the Barclay brothers. That fact emerged days later when the Guardian ran a story revealing that Andrew Neil had bid £7m for Express Newspapers. In newspaper parlance, the report was written 'hard', as fact. Clearly, the Guardian had better lines of communication than we did. Express staff were up in arms. They wanted to know what was going on. We had to stand there like lemons and say we did not know. UNM kept a firm silence. Then there was the shock over the £75m price. Surely we were worth more? Yes, but not much more. Earlier in the year, possibly as a way of smoothing the sale of the papers, Hollick had offloaded the building in a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. That deal netted a reported £69m.

Even so, Neil's offer seemed absurdly low. The papers made a profit and had a total sales of some 2.5 million. But, mad or not, UNM was saying nothing. The silence said it all: after months of debilitating prevarication and speculation, the papers were finally up for sale. The billionaire Hinduja brothers were interested. So was Mohammed al-Fayed. Another potential buyer was David Montgomery, former head of Mirror Group. There were questions against them all. Just how serious were they? Did they really have the cash? What were their plans for the papers?

Officially, UNM was still saying nothing, but news stories began appearing that seemed to carry the imprint of the parent company speaking off the record - in effect, inviting anyone to make a pitch. Internally, we were told zero. Over several weeks, our best sources as to what was going to happen to our business were the Sunday business pages. One week it was the Hinduja brothers, then Associated threw its hat into the ring, then Conrad Black's Hollinger Group. It was a strange feeling, coming into work and wondering whether that unfamiliar limousine parked outside might belong to a new suitor.

And still no official word. To add to the confusion, Hollick agreed to expand the circulation team, resurrecting a recruitment drive. It was mind-boggling. If the papers were being sold, why bother? If they weren't, why not say so? At last, at the end of a management meeting, the human resources director said she had been told by UNM to suspend plans for a personnel initiative. The reason, she was informed, was that UNM felt that with all that was going on it was not a priority. This, believe it or not, was the first time UNM had even indicated that anything might be going on.

fields.bodyText: For years I have written about the buying and selling of businesses, usually in that detached tone favoured by the financial community. A corporate figure (nearly always a man) is interviewed and boasts about his company and its acquisition. He talks about cutting overheads, making assets sweat - in other words, closing plants and sacking people. Or an analyst speaks knowingly about a business losing its focus on core activities. And I lap it up. Never, until recently, had I been at the other end of such cold reason. Only now can I appreciate what others have gone through as their firms were broken up and sold. Am I better for it? Certainly. Shouldn't all journalists, analysts, accountants, fund managers, consultants and other know-it-alls be exposed to the experience? Absolutely. Would society benefit if the City had more understanding of what it is like to be the subject of unfeeling logic? Financially, no. But it would be a damned sight more compassionate place in which to work. When quoted companies make a big move, they do so in the utmost secrecy. They are obsessed, and rightly so, with fears of the news leaking, of the deal being scuppered, of unscrupulous people making a killing, of the Stock Exchange being the last to know. And this was the case with United News and Media (UNM), owner of Express Newspapers, publisher of the Daily Express and Sunday Express, of which I was deputy editor. Companies that take the stonewall approach fail to realise that senior staff are caught in the middle. You believe or suspect something is up, but don't know for sure. Meanwhile, junior colleagues believe you know what's up and just aren't saying. For the uninformed senior executive, it is dispiriting and demoralising. You feel useless in a sphere where only days before you seemed to exercise total power. Suddenly, you are running an international news operation and are powerless to say for certain what is happening upstairs. The sale of Express Newspapers was on the cards as early as May 1999, but I learned only on November 22 2000 that the papers had been sold. We were not told by UNM. We learnt the news from Sky television. Back in April 1998, I had left the job of deputy editor of the Independent with Rosie Boycott, the editor, to take up the task of turning round the Express titles. We were given a mandate to take the papers upmarket, to make them appeal to a younger, progressive audience. We were promised that the vast resources of UNM, a £5bn corporation, would be at our disposal. There would be massive investment. We'd be able to draw on UNM's television and other media interests. All went well at first. We lost some older readers, wooed in part by promotional overtures from the Daily Mail, but that was predicted. (One commentator forecast we would lose 600,000 readers in six months; in fact, it was 150,000 in almost three years.) UNM, in the person of Lord Hollick, our new chief executive, took a close interest in the papers. Hollick, a big Labour supporter, was a regular at management meetings, where his enthusiasm could be infectious. Marketing plans, expansion and investment proposals were discussed. Then in May 1999 the tap was abruptly turned off. With hindsight, it was the first sign of a shift in strategy that would ultimately lead to a sale. At the time, UNM's parsimony was attributed to the inherent character of Hollick, a shrewd dealmaker who was cautious by nature, not given to the sweeping visionary brushstrokes of media barons such as Rupert Murdoch and Lord Rothermere. Hollick hated to spend money. But, to be fair to him, he had no large personal holding to shore up his position. Unlike Murdoch and Rothermere, Hollick was a salaryman, dependent on the goodwill of his external shareholders. Make them a good return, fine. Screw up and you're out. With us, Hollick was contrary, talking big one minute, lost in petty detail the next. He was enigmatic, fond of playing his cards close to his chest. Once, Boycott and I were summoned to see him about results of research into 'lapsed readers' - who, if we were sticking to our original brief, should not have mattered. We didn't even know the research was being done. Much was made in the press of Boycott's friendship with Hollick, but she never went to his house for dinner and he failed to attend work functions at her home. They would go for long periods without exchanging a word, and when they did it was often over a trivial complaint. Hollick's temper was fearsome; he was used to getting his own way and executives rarely stood up to him. Hollick, however, loved owning newspapers. They gave him political and social cachet. He adored ringing up political and football journalists for the latest gossip. If we had a cabinet minister in for lunch, Hollick expected to be invited. Yet he exhibited little interest or feel for the living organism that a newspaper is - how it is put together, what makes it tick. Hollick's reluctance to spend money did not extend to paying for outside advice. UNM and its many parts were forever being pored over by consultants. It was one such study, I later discovered, that may have prompted the sudden change of policy in May 1999. Unknown to Boycott, PricewaterhouseCoopers had embarked on a crucial study of the Express group. Its sensitivity can be judged by the way it was cloaked in secrecy: in the detailed report that resulted, the project had the code-name Postbox; the Express titles were referred to as Unicorn and their sister publication, the Daily Star, was Comet. The study's conclusion was stark: although progress had been made, further development required investment that might be difficult to justify for a publicly listed company. For Hollick, who prided himself on doing right by shareholders, this was probably not what he wanted to read. The consultants were saying, in effect, that the Express group needed an owner-proprietor, rather than someone who always had to put shareholders' interests first. Rumours of the Express papers being on the block first surfaced in early summer of 1999, and the timing, given the date of the PwC report, cannot have been mere coincidence. Hollick's interest began to wane. The weekly meetings with him in the chair were scrapped, and when we did see him, the conversation dwelt on trivia. After Tony Blair's speech at the Labour party conference in Bournemouth in October 1999, I walked with Hollick to the High Cliff Hotel. He said he was glad for the chance to chat. I thought that at last we might get an indication about future investment. It was not to be. He asked whether I thought he should go to see Barcelona play Arsenal in the Champions League. Industry gossip said Andrew Neil was hovering in the wings, ready to buy on behalf of the Barclay brothers, and Kleinwort Benson, UNM's banker, was preparing sale details. Pieces started appearing in rival newspapers predicting our disposal. One said City analysts were forecasting a £1 rise in UNM's share price if the Express papers were sold. This gave a strong hint of the pressure Hollick faced. UNM shares at that time were barely above £5. Market capitalisation was about £3bn. The rumour mill said the papers would fetch, at most, £300m - yet here was the City saying we were worth £600m to the share price. This was always the argument we faced. City analysts, whose work was read by the fund managers who owned the bulk of UNM, thought we were more valuable to the company outside it than within it. One City scribbler even speculated that UNM might be able to raise as much as £1bn by selling us as a provider of content to an internet business, such as Freeserve. UNM had a policy of not commenting on speculative stories. But amid this blizzard of publicity, it meant that assertions went unanswered and claims presented as fact were not denied. It had a curious schizophrenic effect. Internally, UNM assured us there was no truth in the rumours. Externally, the business and media pundits were having a ball. Staff assumed that the editor and deputy were in the loop - that we were somehow in the thick of whatever was happening, that any decision to sell would involve our agreement. Sadly, nothing could have been further from the truth. We were not told; we were not consulted; we did not know. A lull ensued. The rumours died down and we resumed business as normal - except it was anything but normal. While talk of imminent sale had receded for the time being, there was little evidence of any substantial new money for the titles. Both the Daily Express and Sunday Express were battling against an onslaught from the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday. The response from our side was lamentable. All the energy went into producing the paper day to day - it was as if the future did not exist. Journalists are quite unlike other workers. Their trade is information. They are trained observers who like nothing better than gossip. We had 440 pairs of eyes watching us and 440 pairs of ears hanging on every word. Any casual remark, joke or grimace by Boycott was relayed and dissected for any clue to imminent news. We debated whether she should tell staff: 'Look, I hear the rumours, too. But I assure you, I know nothing.' But that was rejected because they would speculate that it was a double bluff. When we interviewed candidates for jobs, they would invariably ask what lay in store for the papers. Staff would come to us and say they had been approached by another paper about a job. What could we advise? All we could answer was that we hadn't a clue. It was undermining - colleagues we knew and liked found it impossible to believe that a national newspaper editor who was so well informed on other matters and was a board director of the Express subsidiary did not know what the parent company was planning. Nor did her deputy. The mood changed again early last year. UNM was proposing to merge with Carlton, whose boss, Michael Green, was said to be looking forward to owning papers and to be keen to expand them. Two firms of consultants were appointed to examine the level of cash injection required to boost circulation. It was not much, but it was something. At least dialogue was taking place. We found ourselves in meetings where the talk was of investment and growth. Suddenly, for a period, there was a sense of belonging, that the papers were to remain part of the UNM-Carlton family. But just as abruptly, the mood changed. Hollick was dealt a savage blow when the Competition Commission ordered UNM to shed its Meridian television holdings as a condition of a merger with Carlton. To Hollick's dismay, Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, accepted the ruling. From what was to be a marriage of equals, the proposed tie-up was hopelessly tilted in Carlton's favour. It was clear the union was off. Speculation again centred on the future of the newspapers. Granada, seen as a possible buyer of UNM, was apparently letting it be known that it did not want Express Newspapers. It was believed that supremos Gerry Robinson and Charles Allen did not want to risk alienating the City by buying the papers, which many viewed as 'old media' - too expensive and too dangerous to take on. They had seen Hollick having to defend the papers to a sceptical City, and that wasn't going to happen to them. When UNM announced the sale of its television division to Granada, the writing was on the wall for the Express group. That's what the City thought, what all the media commentators wrote and what the staff believed. But UNM pretended nothing had changed. Hollick's ambition to become a major media player, with the bulk of ITV and other television interests, plus three national newspapers and several consumer magazines, had come to nought. We at the Express titles now found ourselves part of a company intent on a new direction. What political influence the papers afforded Hollick had vanished. Stories of the Labour peer's rage at the government, which he had loyally supported but which, as he saw it, had not assisted him, made the rounds of the building at Blackfriars. The papers' relationship with their boss had shifted. The feeling grew that he would sell us to any group - especially one opposed to Labour, such as Associated - just to spite the administration that had let him down so badly. There was also the sense that even had he wanted to keep us, Hollick's hands were tied. Weakened by the collapse of the Carlton merger, he had to be seen to be acting decisively to silence his City critics, many of whom had been badgering for the sale of the Express group and now wanted to see positive signs of a decisive strategy for a new-look UNM. At the paper, we explored the possibility of a management buyout and, with Boycott's approval, I met a City heavy-hitter. His reaction to the idea was swift: how would the Daily Express avoid the kind of grief the Independent had suffered when The Times started a price war. With no reserves, the Independent could not respond and its circulation fell. Finally, it had to give up its independence and turned to the Mirror Group for help. The buyout expert explained that the City prefers to back businesses that lead their markets. In other words, it hates taking risks - and, whichever way we cut it, we were a risk. He also said Hollick did not have a reputation for 'leaving something behind on the table' so there was little likelihood that profits could be increased by making cuts - another thing the City likes. It was an eye-opener, one that left me applauding anyone brave enough to get involved in a buyout. Staff assumed, again, that we must have known what was going on. But Boycott had exchanged barely a word with Hollick in the three months before last October's Labour party conference in Brighton, when they had dinner together. I was there, along with other journalists and four government ministers. In the course of a three-hour meal, the subject of the papers never came up. Afterwards, Boycott and I walked with Hollick from the restaurant back to the conference area. He engaged in small talk and we listened. Of the papers, not one word. What we could not have known was that Hollick was sitting on an offer from the Barclay brothers. That fact emerged days later when the Guardian ran a story revealing that Andrew Neil had bid £7m for Express Newspapers. In newspaper parlance, the report was written 'hard', as fact. Clearly, the Guardian had better lines of communication than we did. Express staff were up in arms. They wanted to know what was going on. We had to stand there like lemons and say we did not know. UNM kept a firm silence. Then there was the shock over the £75m price. Surely we were worth more? Yes, but not much more. Earlier in the year, possibly as a way of smoothing the sale of the papers, Hollick had offloaded the building in a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. That deal netted a reported £69m. Even so, Neil's offer seemed absurdly low. The papers made a profit and had a total sales of some 2.5 million. But, mad or not, UNM was saying nothing. The silence said it all: after months of debilitating prevarication and speculation, the papers were finally up for sale. The billionaire Hinduja brothers were interested. So was Mohammed al-Fayed. Another potential buyer was David Montgomery, former head of Mirror Group. There were questions against them all. Just how serious were they? Did they really have the cash? What were their plans for the papers? Officially, UNM was still saying nothing, but news stories began appearing that seemed to carry the imprint of the parent company speaking off the record - in effect, inviting anyone to make a pitch. Internally, we were told zero. Over several weeks, our best sources as to what was going to happen to our business were the Sunday business pages. One week it was the Hinduja brothers, then Associated threw its hat into the ring, then Conrad Black's Hollinger Group. It was a strange feeling, coming into work and wondering whether that unfamiliar limousine parked outside might belong to a new suitor. And still no official word. To add to the confusion, Hollick agreed to expand the circulation team, resurrecting a recruitment drive. It was mind-boggling. If the papers were being sold, why bother? If they weren't, why not say so? At last, at the end of a management meeting, the human resources director said she had been told by UNM to suspend plans for a personnel initiative.
