webTitle: Di Canio takes his chance

fields.headline: Di Canio takes his chance
fields.standfirst: Di Canio: Barthez didn't confuse my brain
fields.trailText: Manchester United were dispatched from the FA Cup here yesterday afternoon on a sea of bubbles of the West Ham kind. A piece of cool finishing by Paolo di Canio 15 minutes from the end of a tie notable more for the quality of its passing than for much incisiveness in front of goal took Harry Redknapp's side to Sunderland in the fifth round.
fields.body:
Manchester United were dispatched from the FA Cup here yesterday afternoon on a sea of bubbles of the West Ham kind. A piece of cool finishing by Paolo di Canio 15 minutes from the end of a tie notable more for the quality of its passing than for much incisiveness in front of goal took Harry Redknapp's side to Sunderland in the fifth round.

For the moment West Ham will be concerned less with their chances of casting a further shadow over the Stadium of Light, where they drew 1-1 in September, than with basking in the afterglow of yesterday's victory for skill, discipline and judgment allied to tactical nous. It was hard to believe that before yesterday they had lost on 11 successive visits to Old Trafford.

Not that their triumph defied credibility. In fact for those who had witnessed the way Liverpool ended Manchester United's two-year-old unbeaten home Premiership record before Christmas there was logic in the result. Redknapp's side outmanoeuvred, even outwitted Sir Alex Ferguson's team in similar areas.

The Manchester United manager accepted defeat graciously enough, praised West Ham's performance and wondered aloud if this might be their season to win the FA Cup. But his complaint that the pitch had been trampled by 26 men in November's Rugby League World Cup - "I can't believe that the biggest club in the world has to stage bloody rugby; it's an utter disgrace" - sounded a little wan in view of the quality of football achieved by West Ham's youthful midfield.

The longer the match progressed the more the ability of Joe Cole, Michael Carrick and Frank Lampard to keep the ball and create space behind Roy Keane and Nicky Butt echoed the way Steven Gerrard and the Liverpool midfield had denied Manchester United possession six weeks earlier. Cole in particular must have impressed Sven-Goran Eriksson, who will shortly be picking his first England squad.

Since Redknapp's lowly Bournemouth team had knocked out Ron Atkinson's Manchester United in the third round in 1984 there was a vague sort of precedent for yesterday's result. Then again West Ham had lost so limply at Old Trafford on New Year's Day that even avoiding another defeat would have been a surprise.

This time Redknapp's players set out to avoid conceding the possession and space they had surrendered so meekly in earlier games. Before half-time and for a period after it, with Cole and Di Canio tied to largely defensive roles and Frédéric Kanouté little more than a token attacking force, the London side barely threatened Fabien Barthez.

That was the period when Manchester United should have taken the initiative, for what few clear chances there were came their way. With Ryan Giggs popping up all over the place it seemed only a matter of time before Teddy Sheringham or Andy Cole would find a way past the visitors' resolute back three, and once it became evident that Shaka Hislop's movements in the West Ham goal were restricted by a knee injury there seemed little possibility of Ferguson's side failing to score.

Yet with Redknapp's midfield falling back to help the defenders, little came through to trouble Hislop, and when Manchester United did create opportunities their shots were off target. "You run risks if you miss chances in a cup tie," said Ferguson, "and that was us today."

Quite so. Four minutes into the second half Sheringham, sent clear by Denis Irwin, beat Hislop with a narrow-angle shot only to see Hannu Tihinen, West Ham's borrowed Finn, clear off the line. Five minutes later Hislop blocked a shot from Andy Cole and Sheringham wafted the rebound over the bar.

With Joe Cole now beginning to run the game and Di Canio resuming a closer acquaintance with Kanouté, the thought that West Ham might win became more than a faint suspicion. Not that it occurred to Barthez, who had had so little to do that when at last he was asked to prevent a goal he more or less did nothing.

The Frenchman had started the match in typically skittish mood, racing out of goal to backheel the ball to Jaap Stam despite Kanouté's lurking presence. But when Kanouté's pass caught the defence square, leaving Di Canio clear and onside, Barthez simply stood still with a hand in the air as if he expected a late flag.

"Perhaps he thought Paolo was going to pick the ball up," quipped Redknapp, remembering the Italian's sporting refusal to score a winner at Goodison Park with the Everton goalkeeper lying injured. No chance. Di Canio scored with sweet simplicity, 9,000 West Ham fans roared while not forgetting to pinch themselves, and for once a day at Old Trafford belonged to another United. It was Manchester United's first defeat in the FA Cup since they lost at Barnsley in a fifth-round replay in 1998.

At the end Gary Neville's attempt to remonstrate with the linesman who had kept his flag down was blocked by the referee Paul Durkin. Neville should have known better, and in any case his team have bigger fish still to fry.

 Ladbrokes took a hammering in east London yesterday, losing thousands of pounds after offering 100-1 on Di Canio scoring the only goal. Mike Dillon of Ladbrokes said: "Our East End shops [were] flooded with £1 and £5 bets on the 100-1 shot."

webTitle: Will Blairism woo Australia's voters?

fields.headline: Will Blairism woo Australia's voters?
fields.standfirst: The opinions of some 1m rural electors will prove crucial in this year's elections, reports Patrick Barkham
fields.trailText: The opinions of some 1m rural electors will prove crucial in this year's elections, reports Patrick Barkham in Sydney.
fields.body:
Whether Australians like it or not, 2001 is going to be the year of the politician. Before the federal government election - most likely to be called by the prime minister, John Howard, in November - voters in four states will go to the polls to elect new state governments.

First up on the electoral calendar are Liberal-held Western Australia on February 10 and Labor-governed Queensland a week later. One of the most intriguing issues will be the choices made by the 1m voters who backed One Nation, the extreme rightwing, anti-immigrant, anti-political establishment party, in the 1998 federal election.

Nationally, Australia's rightwing Liberal party has held power in a coalition with its country cousins, the National party, since voters tired of Paul Keating's lofty reign as Labor prime minister in 1996. Polls currently give Howard's regime a slim advantage over Labor, led by the bulky, experienced former minister Kim Beazley.

But both parties were shaken at the last election by the impact of One Nation, led by Queenslander Pauline Hanson. Hanson, elected to the federal parliament as an independent MP in 1996, became infamous after using her maiden speech to attack welfare for Aborigines and voice fears of being "swamped" by Asians. She established her own party, One Nation, in the spring of 1997.

In the last Queensland state election, in June 1998, One Nation's vote peaked at 22.7%. Since then, it has been downhill almost all the way. Hanson lost her seat in the 1998 federal election as One Nation polled 9% nationally. Her party then spectacularly imploded, beset by fraud allegations and internal rows. All its 11 Queensland MPs quit, becoming independents or coalescing around a breakaway group, the City Country Alliance. In the most recent Queensland polls the party - re-registered just in time for the election - looks set to take just 3-4% of the vote.

One Nation may be a shadow of its short-lived former self, but its supporters remain disaffected, particularly in Australia's vast rural constituencies where people feel neglected by the slick promises of the traditional parties of government based in urbane Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne.

The perception that the mainstream politicians are on the make has only been reinforced by an epic Queensland inquiry into Labor "rorting", where state MPs were found to have defrauded electoral rolls to "stack" their constituencies with supporters, ensuring they became their party's nominated candidate. Three Labor MPs resigned over the inquiry and Labor lost its slim governing majority, which forced Peter Beattie, Queensland's popular premier, into calling the February state election.

The federal parties will be looking to pointers from the Western Australia and Queensland elections as to where Australia's disaffected demographic will go. Most commentators believe their votes will be spread across a wider group of independents and minor "anti-political" parties. This will guarantee the major parties remain in power, although a similar number of voters supporting independents with "One Nation" agendas will also clearly signal the continuing, worrying failure of the political mainstream to win back fed-up rural voters.

Western Australia is also a test case to see how UK-style New Labour policies would fare in Australia. The leader of the Labor opposition, Geoff Gallop, preaches "solutions-driven government". A pragmatic political scientist who has moved steadily rightwards over the years, he endorses the state's controversial mandatory sentencing laws, which can jail people for up to 14 days for a first offence and which are controversially often deployed to jail young Aborigines for petty theft.

He also trades heavily on his old friendship at Oxford University with Tony Blair, flashing about yellowed pictures of the pair from the 1970s. fields.bodyText: Whether Australians like it or not, 2001 is going to be the year of the politician. Before the federal government election - most likely to be called by the prime minister, John Howard, in November - voters in four states will go to the polls to elect new state governments. First up on the electoral calendar are Liberal-held Western Australia on February 10 and Labor-governed Queensland a week later. One of the most intriguing issues will be the choices made by the 1m voters who backed One Nation, the extreme rightwing, anti-immigrant, anti-political establishment party, in the 1998 federal election. Nationally, Australia's rightwing Liberal party has held power in a coalition with its country cousins, the National party, since voters tired of Paul Keating's lofty reign as Labor prime minister in 1996. Polls currently give Howard's regime a slim advantage over Labor, led by the bulky, experienced former minister Kim Beazley. But both parties were shaken at the last election by the impact of One Nation, led by Queenslander Pauline Hanson. Hanson, elected to the federal parliament as an independent MP in 1996, became infamous after using her maiden speech to attack welfare for Aborigines and voice fears of being "swamped" by Asians. She established her own party, One Nation, in the spring of 1997. In the last Queensland state election, in June 1998, One Nation's vote peaked at 22.7%. Since then, it has been downhill almost all the way. Hanson lost her seat in the 1998 federal election as One Nation polled 9% nationally. Her party then spectacularly imploded, beset by fraud allegations and internal rows. All its 11 Queensland MPs quit, becoming independents or coalescing around a breakaway group, the City Country Alliance. In the most recent Queensland polls the party - re-registered just in time for the election - looks set to take just 3-4% of the vote. One Nation may be a shadow of its short-lived former self, but its supporters remain disaffected, particularly in Australia's vast rural constituencies where people feel neglected by the slick promises of the traditional parties of government based in urbane Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne. The perception that the mainstream politicians are on the make has only been reinforced by an epic Queensland inquiry into Labor "rorting", where state MPs were found to have defrauded electoral rolls to "stack" their constituencies with supporters, ensuring they became their party's nominated candidate. Three Labor MPs resigned over the inquiry and Labor lost its slim governing majority, which forced Peter Beattie, Queensland's popular premier, into calling the February state election. The federal parties will be looking to pointers from the Western Australia and Queensland elections as to where Australia's disaffected demographic will go. Most commentators believe their votes will be spread across a wider group of independents and minor "anti-political" parties. This will guarantee the major parties remain in power, although a similar number of voters supporting independents with "One Nation" agendas will also clearly signal the continuing, worrying failure of the political mainstream to win back fed-up rural voters. Western Australia is also a test case to see how UK-style New Labour policies would fare in Australia. The leader of the Labor opposition, Geoff Gallop, preaches "solutions-driven government". A pragmatic political scientist who has moved steadily rightwards over the years, he endorses the state's controversial mandatory sentencing laws, which can jail people for up to 14 days for a first offence and which are controversially often deployed to jail young Aborigines for petty theft. He also trades heavily on his old friendship at Oxford University with Tony Blair, flashing about yellowed pictures of the pair from the 1970s. webTitle: Granada and Carlton bury hatchet over ITV website

fields.headline: Granada and Carlton bury hatchet over ITV website
fields.trailText: 12pm: Granada Media and Carlton Communications are close to agreeing a deal for ITV.co.uk, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Granada Media and Carlton Communications are close to agreeing a deal for ITV.co.uk.

Years after the BBC set up its hugely successful online service, the two companies have finally decided to bury the hatchet and work together in ITV's common interest.

The companies, which own 90% of the commercial network, want to create a single, focused ITV website to give them more clout.

ITV Online will be the first instance of Granada and Carlton co-operating on moves to create a more integrated and efficient ITV operation.

Itv.co.uk was first discussed by Carlton Communications chairman Michael Green in June last year when it was admitted that the ITV companies were lagging behind the BBC in the online arena.

Since then, Granada Broadband has taken on much of the responsibility for getting itv.co.uk off the ground.

However Granada's own internet ventures have been slow to take off. It has delayed the launch of Granada Powerchannel - a TV spin-off that was to have launched last year.

And it is phasing out its G-wizz portal - the home of everything from Coronation Street to London Tonight.

Carlton is widely regarded as having a superior internet presence, largely because it has developed a number of strong web brands, such as Jamba, Popcorn and SimplyFood, while Granada went cold on G-wizz almost immediately following its launch.

Developments on itv.co.uk are already taking shape and the website now features programme listings, news and links to other ITV sites.

Eventually, the plan is to develop the site into a seamless transition between its TV programming and internet services.

However, lack of foresight could prevent the ITV companies from expanding their internet plans overseas.

Itv.com is currently registered to Nick Rosen, a director of the Online Research Agency and a writer for trade magazine Revolution. His ownership of the domain name runs until November 2002.

webTitle: BBC job cuts

fields.headline: BBC to slash up to 40 jobs
fields.standfirst: Special report: The BBC
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Up to 40 jobs are set to be axed by the BBC as part of Greg Dyke's cost-cutting drive, reports Jessica Hodgson.More BBC stories
fields.body:
Up to 40 jobs are set to be axed by the BBC as part of Greg Dyke's cost-cutting drive.

The BBC is to pool its information and archive research staff in a move that will cut 25 jobs.

But over a two-year period, the total job losses could amount to 40.

The Research Reshaping project is designed to concentrate the archive and information departments into a single division.

Job cuts will come purely from the research operations department, which has around 280 staff.

The move is the latest part of Mr Dyke's One BBC strategy, introduced last year.

Over a two-year period starting in April, 20 BBC databases will be collected into a single archive "centre of excellence" at Television Centre.

Programme makers, journalists and managers will be able to access all resources - TV and radio footage and text-based archive material - from a single point.

BBC archive and information staff will be trained in multi-skilling to allow them to cover new areas of research.

This is expected to cost the corporation £360,000.

The BBC has held talks with broadcasting union Bectu, which is "reasonably confident" the planned redundancies can be achieved voluntarily.

But the union warned it would resist any compulsory redundancies.

A spokesman added the union had concerns about the BBC's emphasis on multi-skilling.

"Potentially, it can water down people's specialisms. We want to hear more about how this retraining will work."

The BBC will put the offer of voluntary redundancy to staff this week.

webTitle: The Third Degree

fields.headline: The Third Degree
fields.standfirst: The inside track on the great and the (not always) good
fields.trailText: The inside track on the great and the (not always) good.
fields.body:
We are delighted to inform passengers that the University of Surrey has announces the identity of the world's first professor of airline food, Peter Jones. He's taking off from the Forte chair of hotel management in the school of management studies at the Guildford institution. Apart from in-flight insights he hopes to help improve the university's catering - it conjures up a picture of stewardesses pushing trolleys through lectures just when the customers are nodding off.

For all those fanatics of Inspector Morse, the grumpy police detective who exposed the renowned murderous activities of Oxford University dons until he was killed off last November, we have more bad news. Dexter's creator, Colin Dexter, is in fact a Cambridge man. The Cambridge graduate visited the university last week to help with a crossword being sponsored as part of science week in the Cambridge Evening Post.

What has happened to the Council for Science and Technology, the much vaunted senior science advisory body for the government? Launched by luminaries like Sir Richard Sykes, rector of Imperial College, Cambridge vice-chancellor Sir Alec Broers, and the recently departed chief scientific adviser, Sir Bob May, it last met in June while the three reports it did gather virtual dust on its website.

Slam flunk?Mississippi Valley State University has fired its basketball coach and two other officials after they were discovered arranging for existing students to take entrance tests on behalf of athletes they wanted to recruit to the team.

Are the police about to get a new high profile dog-handler? Education secretary David Blunkett's scheduled speech at Southampton University in March is already being seen as his valedictory - a year after his Greenwich announcement on the future of the higher education sector. Academic heads are now convinced that Blunkett has his heart on Jack Straw's job at the Home Office after the general election. And what will this mean (apart from Lucy helping out with prison patrols?) The biggest obstacle to top-up fees would be gone.

Aspiring teachers seeking information on the internet are met with the disappointing message "The TTA website will return soon." It turns out to be the Tibetan Terriers Association - evidently better known on the internet than the Teacher Training Agency, which perhaps says a lot about the body trying to sort out the current crisis in our classrooms.

Recent history is an appalling record of bloodshed - and that's just what the historians say about eachother. Richard Evans' new edition of In Defence of History out next month glances aside from his main attack on the postmodernist enemy for a sideswipe at Open University professor Arthur Marwick for his "arrogant and unreflective subjectivity" and "gems of homespun wisdom". "The main characteristic of the Marwickian metaphor seems to be its complete absence of identifiable meaning".

A Japanese professor, intrigued by the intense silence in his lectures, switched off the lights to reveal the glow of scores of cellphone monitors. His subsequent survey found two thirds of students admitted receiving or sending text messages on their i-mode phones during classes, and 30% were doing four per lecture on their kei-tais. Universities are now using text messages to chase students up for tuition fees.

The president of Little Big Horn College, Janine Pease-Pretty on Top, has been fired from her job at a meeting of the Crow Tribal Council. She had been criticised for her running of the two-year tribal college founded in 1980 on the Crow Indian Reservation in Montana. Henry Real Bird was named interim president.

Bill Taylor's group investigating whether students should be charged extra fees to help finance universities are having to look over their shoulders. As general election fever hots up, all sorts of proposals for Labour's expected second parliamentary term are being aired. In a Fabian Society report on the reform of private schools, Prof Harry Brighouse argues that extra university fees could yield the money needed to boost spending in state schools.

"People are spending the money before we have even worked out how we might raise it," said a bemused Taylor last week.

The doomsday scenario of course for university heads is that they incite the wrath of the nation for charging fees, only for the money to be syphoned off elsewhere. The group's report will be delivered to vice-chancellors in March, and a conference to discuss the conclusions is organised for early April - a good month before the general election is due.

Stories? Gossip? Contact us:
donald.macleod@theguardian.com
lee.elliotmajor@theguardian.com

webTitle: Gullane buys David and Charles kids' arm for £1.1m

fields.headline: Gullane nets Zippy Dinosaurs for £1.1m
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Gullane Entertainment has acquired the children's books division of David and Charles for £1.1m, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
They were once one of Britain's best-known publishing companies but the disappearance of the firm's name from the credits of Thomas the Tank Engine isn't holding back this children's TV company.

Gullane Entertainment, formerly known as the Britt Allcroft Company, has added Zippy Dinosaurs and Vroom Vroom to its stable of children's characters, which include the Fat Controller and Thomas's carriages Annie and Clarabel.

The kids' favourites are part of the children's books division of David and Charles, which Gullane has snapped up for £1.1m.

"This is a wonderful business run by very talented people, which has an exciting present and future publishing list," said William Harris, chief executive of Gullane.

Gullane has made its success from TV programmes including Sooty and Art Attack, and will push its latest acquisitions onto the small screen.

"The key is getting the rights. This gives Gullane a raft of rights which are convertible into TV programmes and films," said a spokesman for Gullane.

Other David & Charles characters include Tabitha's Terrifically Tough Tooth and Harry and the Bucketful of Dinosaurs.

The company publishes 50 new book titles each year.

webTitle: Q&A: Health and social care bill clause 67

fields.headline: Q&A: Health and social care bill clause 67
fields.standfirst: Fears of diminished patient confidentiality surround clause 67 (formerly clause 59) of the health and social care bill. David Batty explains the background to the clause and its potentially far-reaching impact.
fields.trailText: Fears of diminished patient confidentiality surround clause 67 (formerly clause 59) of the health and social care bill. David Batty explains the background to the clause and its potentially far-reaching impact.
fields.body:
What powers are granted to the health secretary under clause 67?
Clause 67 gives health secretary Alan Milburn the authority to disclose identifiable patient information, such as personal medical records, to third parties for research. This could be done without consent and despite any legal objections. It also enables Mr Milburn to block organisations outside the NHS from using anonymised data for research. Fines of up to £5,000 could be imposed on anyone undertaking research without his permission.

Why does the health secretary want these powers?
The Department of Health says the powers will both safeguard patient information and allow the NHS to compile registers on diseases such as cancer more easily, improving the care available. A spokeswoman said the clause is partly in response to a case where a pharmaceutical company bought prescription information from pharmacists, which was not necessarily in patients' best interests.

What are doctors' and patient groups' fears?
The British Medical Association and the Patients Association believe the powers are "all encompassing" and "totalitarian". They warn the clause would outlaw independent scrutiny of the NHS, as information could be blocked from outside bodies if it was considered of detriment to the NHS. This could prevent academic departments, patient groups and community health councils from publishing reports on NHS standards and treatment, as it would undermine staff morale, they argue. They say this power could also be used to suppress information that might embarrass the government, such as doctors' workloads, hospital waiting times, postcode lotteries of care, the use of human organs and deaths due to hospital-acquired infections. The BMA also warns that the clause would destroy patient confidentiality.

What does that mean?
Clause 67 would overturn the common law of confidentiality, allowing the health secretary to force doctors to hand over medical data that identifies individual patients. Dr Fleur Fisher, chairman of the BMA Foundation for Aids and former head of the BMA's ethics committee, says this would destroy the doctor-patient relationship. She warns that patients would be wary about what they could tell their doctor. Disclosure of mental health diagnoses, genetic abnormalities or sexually transmitted infections could affect patients' careers, insurance and personal lives.

How does this sit with Alan Milburn's pledge to improve transparency in the NHS?
GPs argue that the clause goes against principle 10 of the NHS plan, which states: "The NHS will respect the confidentiality of individual patients and provide open access to information about services, treatment and performance."

Are these fears justified?
A DoH spokeswoman said that any information would be released only if it improved overall patient care. "There would be specific obligations of confidentiality on those persons receiving the information and it would not be available across departments," she said. However, she would not clarify what information might be blocked from outside bodies.

How will the powers be regulated?
A DoH spokeswoman said the regulations would be reviewed annually. But the government's critics warn that the abolition of community health councils means they would be regulated by less independent patient advocates appointed by hospitals. They say this severely limits independent checks on the powers.

What do opposition parties feel about it?
Doctors' and patients' concerns are shared by the Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats. Liberal Democrat health spokesman Paul Burstow, MP, wants the clause withdrawn. "It goes right to the heart of freedom of information and confidentiality. The fact that doctors and patients have not been consulted only makes one suspicious of how these powers will be used," he commented.

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours stand around for ages with their right hand in the air
fields.trailText: All the papers report John Gregory's pursuit of Spanish striker Javi Moreno. The Villa boss wants him to partner Juan Pablo Angel up front, and he was so desperate to watch the £6m-rated Alaves hitman that he left Villa Park ten minutes early on Saturday, missing his side's defeat against Leicester. The Daily Express claims he even left the ground by riding pillion on a motorbike.
fields.body:
All the papers report John Gregory's pursuit of Spanish striker Javi Moreno. The Villa boss wants him to partner Juan Pablo Angel up front, and he was so desperate to watch the £6m-rated Alaves hitman that he left Villa Park ten minutes early on Saturday, missing his side's defeat against Leicester. The Daily Express claims he even left the ground by riding pillion on a motorbike.

Meanwhile Paolo Di Canio has pledged his future to West Ham after his match-winning performance at Old Trafford yesterday. "There is only one way for me to walk away from Upton Park and that is if the club kick me out", he said. "I feel the shirt like a second skin. I am very happy with everybody and I think I'm going to finish my career here. If you don't have a good feeling with the people you have to work with, the chairman and the manager, you have to leave. But now that is not the situation. We played with pride and passion and we deserved to win."

Newcastle have denied that Kieron Dyer will be leaving the club. Teamtalk quote Toon boss Bobby Robson as saying: "We are not even interested in talking about selling Kieron. He's very much the future of the club."

fields.standfirst:
Mandelson's influence had waned to very little long before last week

Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: Mandelson's influence had waned to very little long before last week.
fields.body:
Back in 1871, a supporter of the Paris Commune disguised himself in widows' weeds and took a pot shot at Louis Thiers, the president of the Third Republic. He missed. But although he made no lasting mark on history, he drove the French capital mad for several days. For almost a week, Parisians assumed that every elderly woman who wore a veil had a revolver inside her bodice. Decrepit mourners were stopped on their way to funerals and their wreaths searched for weapons. Children, fearful of being arrested as accessories to attempted murder, refused to go out with their grandmothers.

The world has grown up over the past 130 years. But hysteria still bubbles just below the surface of our society. Five days ago it broke out as newspapers attempted to find new culprits in the Hinduja affair. The damage it did to the government was less a deep wound than an irritating rash, which it was reasonable to assume would soon fade. Then Alistair Campbell began to scratch. With the help of Peter Mandelson, he produced a running sore.

I remember Campbell telling me that his admiration for Alex Ferguson was built on the Manchester United manager's talent for focusing on the main objective. All that mattered was winning. How, I wonder, did the prime minister's press secretary imagine that using a lobby briefing to denounce Mandelson's character weaknesses would serve the greater objective of a Labour victory at the next election?

By writing his unintelligible article for the Sunday Times, Mandelson confirmed the Campbell diagnosis. The retraction of a confession is the mark of an old lag who has run out of excuses. Clearly, something very strange has been going on inside poor Peter's head. A couple of years ago he would have realised that a politician who complains that he has been bullied into admitting misdemeanours of which he is innocent is doomed.

Campbell clearly detected the nervous state before the Sunday Times gibberish was written. But that was no excuse for gratuitously drawing attention to it. In politics, to be cruel is sometimes forgivable. To be counterproductive is not. Once again, Campbell's own character weaknesses - different from Mandelson's but none the less dangerous - have damaged the cause he believed he was serving.

If Mandelson was not finished before the weekend, he is now. Yet there can be no serious complaint about a telephone call to a junior Home Office minister to ask about the Hindujas' passport application. And I would have seen nothing wrong in him expressing support for their attempt to become British. After all, one of the criteria for nationality is "good character". Who better to confirm that they possess it than a secretary of state? The offence, as admitted on Wednesday, was a silly lie about how the message was conveyed. Now Mandelson says that he did not tell the truth about the lie. Either way, it is hardly the conduct of a statesman. But a statement of the facts both confirms the triviality of the whole affair and the still unspoken truth about last week's events. The passing of Peter is not very important.

The pressure of the moment is so great that it is difficult to write about last week's excesses without announcing general support for the howling pack of virtue. If I am incriminated by drawing attention to some of the nonsense that last week's events provoked, I shall accept with good grace that I fall below the high standards that William Hague expects in politicians - David Willetts, for example, who resigned from the government after deceiving a select committee and is now a member of the shadow cabinet.

Painful as Mr Hague's disapproval will be, I cannot pretend that Peter Mandelson's departure has changed the course of Labour party history. Mandelson was undoubtedly the architect of "the project". But the part of that initiative with which he was most intimately associated was being discarded long before last Wednesday. The notion that Labour could be elected only if it abandoned all its traditional values died with Gordon Brown's 2000 spending review; and the obsequies were spoken over the corpse by Tony Blair in Brighton last October. For the first time at a Labour conference, he sounded like a Labour prime minister. Next evening, at a fringe meeting, I heard Mandelson beg the party to accept that the continuous revolution against socialism would go on. Few in the audience believed him.

During the past couple of years, Labour has found its ideological feet. Gordon Brown's version of communitarianism is not altogether to my taste. Its emphasis on rewarding effort sometimes ignores need. But it has more in common with real social democracy than could possibly be claimed for the managerial nihilism of The Blair Revolution, the intellectually shaming description of New Labour philosophy that Mandelson wrote with Roger Liddle. Brown's ideas are now edging their way into the prime minister's speeches. Mandelson's theory that it was essential to ditch socialism was, like him, only briefly fashionable.

After the general election - which last week's events will barely influence - the chancellor's strength can only increase. Because of his management of the economy, he will be discreetly hailed as the architect of victory. The next Labour leader is either Brown or somebody nobody has yet thought of. No sensible punter backs a horse that has yet to enter the race. Mandelson was never in the frame, nor was he likely to train another winner. Brown has lost a distraction, not a competitor.

Mandelson became associated with three great enterprises - entry into the European single currency, alliance with the Liberals and proportional representation. It would be hard to argue that he was able to persuade the prime minister to take early or decisive action on any one of those vital issues. When the time comes they will be decided by pressures beyond the control of even the late secretary of state for Northern Ireland - their effect on the future of the Labour government. Nothing has changed.

It is convenient for commentators and Conservatives to claim otherwise. And it is a tribute to Mandelson's reckless skills that it is possible to pretend that his resignation marks a decisive shift in Labour's prospects and policies. There are no certainties in politics, but the chances of the Mandelson affair having much effect on history are only slightly greater than the risk of the prime minister being shot by a communist disguised as an old lady.

 Peter Preston's column will appear tomorrow.

webTitle: Mandelson and Campbell - how they came to blows

fields.headline: The roundhead and the cavalier - and how they came to blows
fields.standfirst:
Despite their rivalry the two men had been close for years

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: They were the best of friends and now they appear to be not even friends at all.
fields.body:
They were the best of friends and now they appear to be not even friends at all.

Within Downing Street the surprise will be not that Alastair Campbell and Peter Mandelson have fallen out so publicly but that the falling out has taken so long to become public.

Mr Campbell, the Sultan of Spin, and Mr Mandelson, the Svengali of Spin, have been rivals as well as comrades for more than a decade.

While they agreed on many key issues such as the need to transform the Labour party into new Labour with Tony Blair a presidential figure, they also disagreed on key issues from the single currency to a cosier relationship with the Liberal Democrats via electoral reform.

Since 1994 the pair have tussled for Mr Blair's ear in a battle won last week when Mr Mandelson was banished from the inner court of No 10.

As one Blairite MP, who knows both men well, put it: "The first time Peter resigned, Alastair gave him a tearful hug before Peter walked out of the door. This time Alastair opened the door. That says it all."

The tensions rarely surfaced in opposition when they were united in promoting new Labour and Mr Blair, although Mr Campbell used one of his final columns in the now defunct Today newspaper before joining team Blair in 1994 to make a mild dig about Mr Mandelson's inability to write - a dig intended to show he wanted to be boss.

Their friendship stretches back some time and shortly before the 1987 election when the News of the World decided to "out" Mr Mandelson, Mr Campbell and his partner Fiona Millar invited him to spend the Saturday night before publication at their north London home.

When Mr Mandelson stepped down as Labour's director of communications before the 1992 election to stand in Hartlepool, he needed a new income so Mr Campbell fixed him up with a column in the Sunday People. A column Mr Campbell was to ghost for his friend.

When a combination of stress at work and heavy drinking led to Mr Campbell suffering a breakdown during the late 1980s, Mr Mandelson was one of the first to call offering his sympathy and support.

The Westminster rumour mill even has it that Mr Mandelson once did a spot of baby-sitting for his old mate.

The first sign in government of what was to come occurred in November 1997 when the Bernie Ecclestone affair erupted and plunged Mr Blair into his first major sleaze scandal.

Mr Campbell, the prime minister's official press secretary, advised Mr Blair almost immediately to come clean and get all the facts into the open, including an admission it had been a £1m donation.

Mr Mandelson, the prime minister's unofficial counsellor, advised Mr Blair to say as little as possible, keeping the seven-figure sum a secret.

The prime minister took the advice of Mr Mandelson and Mr Campbell was barely able to conceal his anger when the information leaked out anyway and the premier was forced to say sorry.

In the new Labour revolution, Mr Campbell has always been a roundhead to Mandelson's cavalier, the family man who enjoys an early night (except when he is watching football or going to a Britney Spears concert) while Mr Mandelson the social butterfly flutters from one drinks party to another.

He drafted Mr Mandelson's resignation letter in December 1998 after the £373,000 Geoffrey Robinson home loan was disclosed and shed a genuine tear when he had to quit.

Yet Mr Campbell, it has been said by several government special advisers, believes Mr Blair was wrong to bring Mr Mandelson back into the government so quickly after his first resignation.

The relationship between a pair once so close was certainly less close from autumn 1999 when Mr Mandelson returned as Northern Ireland secretary and, after he self-destructed a second time last week.

A former aide to Mr Mandelson admitted: "It is true that relations between Peter and Alastair had been strained since Peter's return but it is also true much of that was on Alastair's side. Relations between Peter and Tony were still very good."

Some claimed that Mr Campbell thought it looked like an indecent haste, leaving the prime minister open to accusations of favouring "Tony's cronies". Others suggested that he had rather liked running the spin show on his own from the inside and feared Mr Mandelson might be a liability.

Significantly, perhaps, relations between Gordon Brown, sworn enemies with Mr Mandelson, and Mr Campbell have improved markedly since the press secretary was fingered three years ago for the "psychological flaws" attack on the chancellor.

Mr Mandelson's long justification published yesterday was commissioned before Mr Campbell's lobby briefing and the former Mirror man almost certainly knew what was coming, whether he had been consulted or not.

His insistence yesterday that he had been quoted out of context, and Mr Mandelson's presence at a family party at Mr Campbell's home on Saturday was proof of their enduring friendship, will raise a few eyebrows in the Labour hierarchy.

Mr Campbell is an experienced operator who knows that in briefings to the Sunday lobby one word out of place, let alone sentence after sentence, can send the wrong signals.

Mr Blair famously remarked that he knew he would have fully transformed the Labour party when it had learned to love Peter Mandelson.

The prime minister may be very disappointed. It seems that Mr Mandelson, whatever the public statements to the contrary, is losing existing friends rather than finding new ones.

webTitle: Leader: Mandelson spinning out of control

fields.headline: Spinning out of control
fields.standfirst:
Will the tapes show who told the truth?

Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson's going was never likely to be the end of it. A state that smells of private influence loses confidence, a precious quality now haemorrhaging as if from an arterial wound.
fields.body:
It is a peculiar civil war where the protagonists attend a party in the middle of the battle, but what has been happening in that field of dreams triangulated by ministers, the media and a sleaze-sick public over the weekend is very peculiar indeed.

Peter Mandelson's going was never likely to be the end of it. The spoor laid by Keith Vaz over several years is turning out to be especially aromatic. The flow charts of the Hinduja connexion head off in all directions, left and right - and if no Liberal Democrats have been invited to the brothers' penthouse in Haymarket, that speaks either of tremendous self-restraint or of their utter irrelevance to a family with a magnetic sense of who the powerful are (with the exception, perhaps, of Sir Edward Heath, whose attractiveness was doubtless ornamental).

Yet by the end of last week, the occasion of Alastair Campbell's now famous briefing of Sunday newspaper correspondents, the main event seemed to be over. The Northern Ireland secretary had gone and a successor installed; the ancillary jobs had been shuffled. Mr Mandelson was to all intents preparing for a long life on the backbenches - chair of the culture committee, perhaps. But then the bomb dropped, or rather Mr Campbell sent up his missile defence as the rogue state prepared to use the Sunday Times to drop the big one on Downing Street and so destroy whatever shred of political reputation he still possessed.

The resulting detonation is not life-threatening for Labour, but the collateral damage is extensive. Did Tony Blair's press secretary say erstwhile bosom buddy Mr Mandelson was mad? Mr Campbell has an easy way of checking the political editors' shorthand note: release the recording. Candour (in this case a mini-disc) has to be the friend of his version and his reputation. The smoke will not clear until there is an authoritative account of another conversation which is highly likely to have been taped, that between Mr Mandelson and Home Office minister Mike O'Brien about the Hinduja passport.

If, per Mr Mandelson, it did not take place, then Mr O'Brien must be suffering from the self-same memory lapse which befell Mr Mandelson last weekend when the row erupted. But any such conversation would have been recorded at both ends. The truth thus lies with David Omand at the Home Office and Richard Wilson at the Cabinet Office. What the permanent secretaries know Sir Anthony Hammond must be told. For the sake of good governance, let alone the Blair government, his report will need to be limpid and exhaustive.

Two things are worth observing in the interim. One is that even the wildest allegations about the Hindujas and their contacts do not show systemic corruption in Britain. That is something else. Yet Mr Campbell is wrong to say the minutiae of procedure are unimportant compared to bread-and-butter policies that affect the public. All that government does depends on the efficacy and honesty of process. Government decisions, however trivial, that are made on the dark stairway in response to influence-peddlars rather than by the book in the open will prove costly.

Favouritism provokes resentment - if the Blairites want to liberalise immigration let new criteria for UK citizenship be stated clearly and applied uniformly. A state that smells of private influence loses confidence, a precious quality now haemorrhaging as if from an arterial wound. A government lacking trust will find itself less and less able to do social democracy's daily tasks.

Mr Campbell has an easy way of checking the political editors' shorthand note: release the recording. Candour (in this case a mini-disc) has to be the friend of his version and his reputation. The smoke will not clear until there is an authoritative account of another conversation which is highly likely to have been taped, that between Mr Mandelson and Home Office minister Mike O'Brien about the Hinduja passport. If, per Mr Mandelson, it did not take place, then Mr O'Brien must be suffering from the self-same memory lapse which befell Mr Mandelson last weekend when the row erupted. But any such conversation would have been recorded at both ends. The truth thus lies with David Omand at the Home Office and Richard Wilson at the Cabinet Office. What the permanent secretaries know Sir Anthony Hammond must be told. For the sake of good governance, let alone the Blair government, his report will need to be limpid and exhaustive. Two things are worth observing in the interim. One is that even the wildest allegations about the Hindujas and their contacts do not show systemic corruption in Britain. That is something else. Yet Mr Campbell is wrong to say the minutiae of procedure are unimportant compared to bread-and-butter policies that affect the public. All that government does depends on the efficacy and honesty of process. Government decisions, however trivial, that are made on the dark stairway in response to influence-peddlars rather than by the book in the open will prove costly. Favouritism provokes resentment - if the Blairites want to liberalise immigration let new criteria for UK citizenship be stated clearly and applied uniformly. A state that smells of private influence loses confidence, a precious quality now haemorrhaging as if from an arterial wound. A government lacking trust will find itself less and less able to do social democracy's daily tasks. webTitle: Cabinet cuts off Mandelson

fields.headline: Cabinet cuts off Mandelson
fields.standfirst:
Straw leads assault as sacked minister promises to clear his name

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Jack Straw yesterday spearheaded a cabinet assault on Peter Mandelson as the government launched a brutal operation to undermine the former Northern Ireland secretary in the wake of his decision to launch a fightback to clear his name.
fields.body:
Jack Straw yesterday spearheaded a cabinet assault on Peter Mandelson as the government launched a brutal operation to undermine the former Northern Ireland secretary in the wake of his decision to launch a fightback to clear his name.

Amid a war of words between the former prime ministerial favourite and Downing Street, the home secretary accused his one time cabinet colleague of departing from the high standards set by the prime minister. "There is no doubt by his own admission that he told an untruth," Mr Straw told ITV's Jonathan Dimbleby programme.

His criticism was echoed in stronger language by the international development secretary Clare Short who famously denounced Mr Mandelson for briefing behind the back of politicians. "Peter Mandelson went last Wednesday because he has got problems telling the truth," Ms Short told The World This Weekend. "Peter Mandelson is over."

Tony Blair who is said to be dismayed by Mr Mandelson's own version of the events which triggered his resignation last Wednesday. In an article in yesterday's Sunday Times, Mr Mandelson said that he had been forced to resign after a "summary exploration of limited available evidence" about his role in the Hindujas' passport application.

The prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, described Mr Mandelson as "slightly detached".

In a briefing for lobby journalists working for the Sunday newspapers, Mr Campbell compared Mr Mandelson's state of mind to that of Ron Davies who was forced to resign after a "moment of madness" on Clapham Commons in 1998.

"Part of the problem, and Peter would accept this, I think, is that there were things that Peter cannot explain and cannot explain to himself," Mr Campbell said. "I think he has been slightly detached."

His remarks, which highlighted the rift between two of the main architects of New Labour, were echoed in stronger terms by Downing Street sources who told the Observer that Mr Mandelson had been "unfocused". "He's been a little bit like that for a while," the source said. "He's fed up with it. He's kind of had enough."

Mr Campbell, whose attack is said to have deeply upset Mr Mandelson, attempted to distance himself from the remarks yesterday. Mr Campbell did not deny the words attributed to him, but said that the interpretation placed on them highlighted the "current media frenzy".

His defence was rejected by all the political editors who attended the lobby briefing on Friday afternoon. Writing in today's Guardian, the Observer's political editor Kamal Ahmed says: "The mood and tone of the briefing was clear. Mandelson was not the man he used to be, politically at least."

Downing Street's attempts to distance itself from Mr Mandelson - even before the Friday briefing - played a hand in convincing him to put his side of the saga on the record. Mr Mandelson highlighted the end of his political alliance with Mr Blair when he wrote of how he lost the will to fight for the first time in his life during his fateful meeting with the prime minister.

"I felt isolated," he wrote. "I knew I hadn't done anything wrong, but I had no time to prove it. I agreed to resign and the prime minister - understandably, given the presentation of the facts - did not try to dissuade me. I should have fought for time to allow a fuller examination of the facts."

Friends of Mr Mandelson, who left the country last night, said that he decided to speak up after civil servants, who worked with him in 1998 when he made the crucial telephone call on behalf of the Hinduja brothers, backed his version of events.

Mr Mandelson insists that the main contact with the home office was made by his officials, though they cannot rule out that he made the contentious phone call to the home office minister Mike O'Brien. It was Mr Mandelson's failure to tell Downing Street about this conversation which led to his downfall.

However, Mr Mandelson's lengthy article only served to tarnish his reputation even further after he admitted that a week before his resignation Mr Straw reminded him of the telephone conversation with Mr O'Brien. He also admitted that he tried to cover up his involvement in the Hindujas' passport application in a written parliamentary answer.

Mr Straw spoke of the importance of politicians telling the truth. "I regard it is of the highest importance that when answering questions to journalists ... but above all to parliament that we should give the whole truth and ensure these answers are as full as possible."

The Tories claimed last night that Downing Street was "locked in open war" with Mr Mandelson in an attempt to "deflect attention away from Mr Blair's direct responsibility for the causes of this mess". He added: "The Blair government, built as it is on spin, lies and deception, is unravelling."

But there were signs that Mr Mandelson and Downing Street may eventually patch up their differences.

Mr Mandelson attended a party at Mr Campbell's north London house on Saturday night to celebrate the birthday of Audrey Millar, the mother of the partner of the prime minister's official spokesman. Mrs Millar is a stalwart of the north London Labour party.

Mr Mandelson and Mr Campbell are said to have read the first editions of the Sunday newspapers late on Saturday night after Mr Campbell tipped him off about what they were likely to contain.

webTitle: Brother deals new blow to Vaz

fields.headline: Brother deals new blow to Vaz
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Pressure was mounting last night on Keith Vaz after it was confirmed that the Europe minister spoke to the billionaire Hinduja brothers about Britain's extradition rules after they were named by the Indian authorities over an arms scandal.
fields.body:
Pressure was mounting last night on Keith Vaz after it was confirmed that the Europe minister spoke to the billionaire Hinduja brothers about Britain's extradition rules after they were named by the Indian authorities over an arms scandal.

In a damaging blow to Mr Vaz, who is fighting for his political life, one of the brothers admitted that he spoke to Mr Vaz last year about his rights as a British citizen in the face of the Indian inquiry.

On BBC1's Breakfast with Frost, Srichand Hinduja said: "We have inquired because he [is] the foreign minister - what is the protection they give to British citizens."

The brothers are being questioned in India by the central bureau of investigation about their alleged involvement in bribes paid during the long-running Bofors arms scandal.

Mr Vaz hinted yesterday that he discussed Britain's extradition rules with the brothers, which may have compromised his position as a minister. "Details concerning extradition procedures are not privileged or secret but are displayed on the Home Office website," he said in a statement. "As I have said before, all my dealings with the Hinduja brothers will be chronicled and given to Sir Anthony Hammond."

Sources close to Mr Vaz went further. "Keith never fixed up a meeting with the specific intention of discussing the issue," the source said. "That does not mean that the issue did not come up at meetings."

The Tories last night seized on the admission. Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, said: "Like so much of this affair it is utterly amazing, if true. If somebody had been named and then asked about their chances of extradition a minister should not answer the question."

The disclosure that Mr Vaz, a Cambridge-educated lawyer, spoke to the Hindujas about extradition is the first confirmation that he discussed sensitive issues with the brothers as a minister.

Mr Vaz has admitted that he made representations on behalf of their applications for passports, but insisted that he did so before he became a minister.

Further evidence of Mr Vaz's extensive contacts with the brothers was revealed yesterday when a former Tory frontbencher said that the Europe minister had acted as if he were their "PPS" - a ministerial bag carrier - before he became a minister.

Christopher Chope, the MP for Christchurch, said he was surprised to receive a call in November 1998 from Mr Vaz after he raised questions in a newspaper about their contribution to the Dome.

Mr Chope, who was then a trade and industry spokesman, said: "The following day Keith contacted me and said the Hindujas were very upset to see their name on the front pages of the newspapers. He arranged for me to see them, which I did within 24 hours. I had a very friendly meeting with SP Hinduja. It was as if Keith was their PPS."

At the time Mr Vaz was a PPS to the attorney general, Sir John Morris. Ms Widdecome said: "It seems as if Mr Vaz was rendering consistent service to the Hindujas."

The prime minister rallied to Mr Vaz's defence, accusing the press of a "feeding frenzy" and insisting that there was nothing wrong in a leading British Asian making representations on behalf of leading Asians who want to become British citizens.

webTitle: JWT boss 'suffered blood clot'

fields.headline: JWT boss 'suffered massive blood clot' on business trip
fields.trailText: 11.15am: JWT chief executive Chris Jones resigned after suffering a massive blood clot, it emerged over the weekend. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
J Walter Thompson chief executive Chris Jones resigned after suffering a massive blood clot on a business trip to Switzerland, it emerged over the weekend.

The New York-based head of one of the world's biggest advertising agencies was travelling to Switzerland when he was struck by so-called "economy class syndrome".

Doctors said Mr Jones was lucky to be alive after his right leg swelled up by six inches. He had to undergo three operations in 30 hours to save his life and then spent two months recuperating in Switzerland before being allowed to return home.

The news sent shock waves through the ad industry. Top advertising executives are spending more and more of their time on planes as clients demand a global service.

Frequent fliers are at an increased risk from the disease, which researchers believe may be brought on by cramped airline seats and inactivity during long-haul flights.

The condition hit the headlines earlier this month after research was published suggesting that deep vein thrombosis costs as many as 2,000 lives every year.

JWT issued a statement two weeks ago saying Mr Jones had resigned for health reasons.

webTitle: 'I think Peter has been slightly detached'

fields.headline: 'I think Peter has been slightly detached'
fields.standfirst:
Resonant phrase that rounded off a week of high political drama

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Resonant phrase that rounded off a week of high political drama.
fields.body:
It is one of those phrases that will sum up the political mood of the times. "Slightly detached" has the same ring of longevity about it as "psychological flaws" or "moment of madness". It will last.

It was said by Alastair Campbell at a briefing of Sunday lobby journalists on Friday afternoon. I was there, along with most of the political editors of the Sunday newspapers. It was a remarkable hour and a quarter.

The week, of course, had been one of high drama. As it drew to a close on Friday the public address system in the press gallery of the Commons sparked into life. "There will be a briefing for the Sunday lobby at 1.30pm at Downing Street." It was 12.30pm.

We trooped over to No 10 and made our way down the stairs to the room where Mr Campbell would meet us. He was 10 minutes late, clasping, as usual, a Burnley FC mug of tea. Behind him was Godric Smith, his deputy.

"Right, what do you want to talk about?" Mr Campbell said as he sat facing us. It is his usual opening line.

There was only one subject. We were all keen to get to the bottom of why, exactly, Peter Mandelson had thought it wise not to tell the truth when first questioned by the Observer over the Hinduja passport applications.

Mr Campbell was willing to talk about it. In fact he had obviously come prepared for a lengthy discussion because after each question he gave long and frank answers - so long in fact that he had to send out for another cup of tea. This was a "two-mug" lobby. That is in stark contrast to some of the meetings when he will go little further than what he tells the daily journalists during the week.

The prime minister's official spokesman went through the week in detail, describing what he thought had been going on and the difficulties he had faced.

We kept returning to the question of why Mr Mandelson acted as he had. Mr Campbell seemed genuinely perplexed and, with no prompting, said: "There are parts of this Peter cannot explain and cannot explain to himself. I think he has been slightly detached."

This was an odd phrase to choose as the last time anyone can remember it being used in a lobby briefing was when Ron Davies resigned after a "moment of madness" on Clapham Common. That was the reason Mr Campbell was questioned about the connection between the two ministers.

He was asked whether Mr Mandelson's state of mind was in any way similar to the state of Mr Davies's in 1998. "I think it was," he replied.

There was an implication throughout the briefing that Mr Mandelson had not been focusing on the political issues in the way that he usually would. And far from simply being connected with this one case, Mr Campbell said that he had noticed it for some time.

What is most surprising about all this is that Mr Campbell is not someone who just breezes into meetings and says the first thing that comes into his head. He chooses his words carefully. When asked, as he often is, whether when he said Y he really meant (usually a more newsworthy) X his response is: "I'll choose the words I use, not you."

On this occasion there was no pushing him towards saying something he did not really want to say. In fact he returned to the subject several times, talking about the stress Mr Mandelson had been under and saying that the former Northern Ireland secretary "wanted to get out of frontline politics". The tone of the briefing was clear: Mr Mandelson was not the man he used to be, politically at least.

I remember chatting to one of my colleagues later that evening. We agreed that the briefing had been remarkable. When Mr Mandelson's article for the Sunday Times was added to the rich mix, there was obviously something serious going on. I do not know whether Mr Mandelson wrote the piece because he had heard about the briefing and decided to respond. But whenever he agreed to the commission, his words could not be in starker contrast to Mr Campbell's.

There was Mr Campbell saying that Mr Mandelson wanted to be out of the spotlight. There was Mr Mandelson revealing that he wanted to be at the centre of it. There was Mr Campbell saying that Mr Mandelson did not seem to have a grasp of the facts. There was Mr Mandelson giving an account of every cough and spit of the affair.

That Mr Campbell has attacked the coverage of the story is not surprising. What else was he going to do? That he said the things he said is also beyond dispute as anyone who listens to a tape of the proceedings would agree. If he had wanted to kill the Downing Street end of the story he could have given us a few bland statements. Mr Campbell never says anything by mistake.

"Slightly detached" has the same ring of longevity about it as "psychological flaws" or "moment of madness". It will last. It was said by Alastair Campbell at a briefing of Sunday lobby journalists on Friday afternoon. I was there, along with most of the political editors of the Sunday newspapers. It was a remarkable hour and a quarter. The week, of course, had been one of high drama. As it drew to a close on Friday the public address system in the press gallery of the Commons sparked into life. "There will be a briefing for the Sunday lobby at 1.30pm at Downing Street." It was 12.30pm. We trooped over to No 10 and made our way down the stairs to the room where Mr Campbell would meet us. He was 10 minutes late, clasping, as usual, a Burnley FC mug of tea. Behind him was Godric Smith, his deputy. "Right, what do you want to talk about?" Mr Campbell said as he sat facing us. It is his usual opening line. There was only one subject. We were all keen to get to the bottom of why, exactly, Peter Mandelson had thought it wise not to tell the truth when first questioned by the Observer over the Hinduja passport applications. Mr Campbell was willing to talk about it. In fact he had obviously come prepared for a lengthy discussion because after each question he gave long and frank answers - so long in fact that he had to send out for another cup of tea. This was a "two-mug" lobby. That is in stark contrast to some of the meetings when he will go little further than what he tells the daily journalists during the week. The prime minister's official spokesman went through the week in detail, describing what he thought had been going on and the difficulties he had faced. We kept returning to the question of why Mr Mandelson acted as he had. Mr Campbell seemed genuinely perplexed and, with no prompting, said: "There are parts of this Peter cannot explain and cannot explain to himself. I think he has been slightly detached." This was an odd phrase to choose as the last time anyone can remember it being used in a lobby briefing was when Ron Davies resigned after a "moment of madness" on Clapham Common. That was the reason Mr Campbell was questioned about the connection between the two ministers. He was asked whether Mr Mandelson's state of mind was in any way similar to the state of Mr Davies's in 1998. "I think it was," he replied. There was an implication throughout the briefing that Mr Mandelson had not been focusing on the political issues in the way that he usually would. And far from simply being connected with this one case, Mr Campbell said that he had noticed it for some time. What is most surprising about all this is that Mr Campbell is not someone who just breezes into meetings and says the first thing that comes into his head. He chooses his words carefully. When asked, as he often is, whether when he said Y he really meant (usually a more newsworthy) X his response is: "I'll choose the words I use, not you." On this occasion there was no pushing him towards saying something he did not really want to say. In fact he returned to the subject several times, talking about the stress Mr Mandelson had been under and saying that the former Northern Ireland secretary "wanted to get out of frontline politics". The tone of the briefing was clear: Mr Mandelson was not the man he used to be, politically at least. I remember chatting to one of my colleagues later that evening. We agreed that the briefing had been remarkable. When Mr Mandelson's article for the Sunday Times was added to the rich mix, there was obviously something serious going on. I do not know whether Mr Mandelson wrote the piece because he had heard about the briefing and decided to respond. But whenever he agreed to the commission, his words could not be in starker contrast to Mr Campbell's. There was Mr Campbell saying that Mr Mandelson wanted to be out of the spotlight. There was Mr Mandelson revealing that he wanted to be at the centre of it. There was Mr Campbell saying that Mr Mandelson did not seem to have a grasp of the facts. There was Mr Mandelson giving an account of every cough and spit of the affair. That Mr Campbell has attacked the coverage of the story is not surprising. What else was he going to do? That he said the things he said is also beyond dispute as anyone who listens to a tape of the proceedings would agree. If he had wanted to kill the Downing Street end of the story he could have given us a few bland statements. Mr Campbell never says anything by mistake. webTitle: Prophets of doom at online news profits

fields.headline: Prophets of doom at online news profits
fields.trailText: Media bosses have have started to wonder whether they will ever make money online, writes Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
Leaning down from the stage, Rupert Murdoch, the head of News Corporation, made it clear that the honeymoon with online news was over. "I just don't see how you can make money out of it."

Since that comment, at an annual meeting last November, many other media bosses have started to wonder whether they will ever make money online. After years of worrying that their business would be eaten up by upstarts staffed by twentysomethings, the new era finds them wondering whether they will ever recoup the millions invested in new staff, new technology and new advertising.

Murdoch actually boasted about the fact that, because he was a late convert to the web, he had frittered away less cash than Walt Disney online. Few other executives have executed such a public volte-face. But most have followed suit both in cutting costs and looking for new ways to make money in the past few months.

The problem for the industry is that online advertising is not generating enough money to cover the cost of offering a free service, and subscriptions are believed to be unworkable for all but a handful of sites.

A report by Forrester, a US research group, earlier this month revealed that of 75 news, entertainment and information sites, 23% were making money. However, the profitable ones tended to be tiny, niche operations with a fee-paying percentage of revenue.

Most media companies have decided that charging for access does not make sense. There are signs that this may be changing, however, as companies return to the business-model drawing board.

Daniel O'Brien, internet analyst at Forrester, is an optimist about the long-term health of online news. "People will figure out how to do subscriptions in the online world," he predicts confidently.

The omens are not good. The Wall Street Journal is the only large newspaper company in the US to charge a subscription for both its online and offline versions. In circulation terms, its strategy has been unusually successful. According to Dow Jones, which owns the newspaper, about 535,000 people were paying to read wsj.com at the end of December, a 44 % increase on the year.

The Journal is able to charge a fee for its online services for good reason. The newspaper, which has 1.8m readers, is required reading for most of corporate America. The $29 (£19.82) subscription fee is nothing when you can claim it on expenses. But even wsj.com is losing money, and is expected to continue doing so until 2002 at the earliest.

In any event, there is abundant evidence that while subscriptions make sense for media groups, consumers are not ready to pay. The Forrester report - called rather optimistically The Content Site Turnaround - also found that only 10% of consumers questioned said they planned to pay for any sort of content, be it news, entertainment or information. The figure represented a decline in the number currently happy to pay for it, suggesting that things could get worse before they get better.

The main attraction of subscriptions, of course, is that they soften the edges of the cyclical advertising market. Online advertising has been hard hit by belt-tightening at large companies and the collapse of the internet sector. The decline has been steep. Last week's figures showed that advertising lineage at the Wall Street Journal fell by 24% in December, after strong gains earlier in the year. Other companies have recorded similar downturns.

In this bleaker environment, companies are being forced to come up with more creative ways to make money. A sign of the times came last week from that doyen of free news services, Yahoo!. Out of the blue, the California-based portal sent investors a list of all its premium services, ranging from the $19.99 service for extra mailbox memory to the $35-a-year charge to maintain a custom web address. Last December, the leading portal also started to charged $50 per individual job posting.

Other US newspapers, such as the Washington Post, have set up mini-malls on their websites in conjunction with online retailers. McClatchy, which owns the Minneapolis Star Tribune, is building websites for local businesses and is also said to be considering the sale of special news software.

There has also been an increase in the use of "interstitial", an ugly word for the ugly practice of using ads that pop onto the screen and have to be clicked away. The practice is supposed to be akin to the advertising leaflets that fall out of newspapers. While it may be less environmentally damaging, it is no less harmful to the nerves of the consumer.

The various experiments going on in the US underline the fact that the holy grail of online profitability is still some way away. Nevertheless many are prepared to join the crusade. Murdoch is unlikely to be donning his shining armour any time soon, however.

webTitle: Hackney staff strike over pay and conditions

fields.headline: Hackney staff strike over pay and conditions
fields.trailText: Thousands of workers at the London borough of Hackney will today start a three-day strike aimed at "paralysing" the council.
fields.body:
Thousands of workers at the London borough of Hackney will today start a three-day strike aimed at "paralysing" the council.

Social workers, housing officers, administrative staff and other employees at the authority are striking until Thursday in an escalating dispute over pay, jobs and conditions.

Unions claim that hundreds of jobs will be lost, pay cut by up to £2,000 and employment conditions worsened under plans to save millions of pounds.

John Page, branch secretary of Unison, said services were being "decimated" and workers "impoverished" because of the council's financial problems: "Lack of financial accountability, incompetent management and malpractice by politicians are the cause of these problems. The residents and the workforce are no longer prepared for the damage."

Hackney currently faces a deficit that the Audit Commission believes could reach £40m by the end of the financial year.

In an attempt to cut costs by £4.5m by March, the council last year announced plans to scrap around 250 positions, with only statutory minimum severance payments. The borough says compulsory redundancies will not be this high, because some staff will relocate within the council.

The unions want to persuade the council not to cut the payments, to drop plans for compulsory redundancies, and to maintain current terms and conditions, which the borough plans to review as part of its savings package.

A Hackney statement today said: "Management has looked to bring staff terms and conditions in Hackney in line with those of its neighbouring boroughs. These changes are being proposed because Hackney cannot afford to run services that are significantly more expensive than elsewhere."

webTitle: Indies rule as Sundance goes back to basics

fields.headline: Indies rule as Sundance goes back to basics
fields.trailText: This year's Sundance Film Festival has honoured a range of uncompromising movies in what is seen as an attempt to return to its independent roots
fields.body:
The Sundance International Film Festival wrapped up on Saturday night by distributing awards to a brace of low-budget and left-field independent productions. This year's festival has attracted criticism for failing to ignite the buying frenzy from major distributors that has been seen in previous years. Others, however, have commended Sundance for resisting what they see as a move towards the mainstream. In its choice of award winners, supporters say, the festival has returned to its original independent roots.

This year's Dramatic Grand Jury Prize went to The Believer (pictured), a troubling, provocative study of American bigotry from writer-director Henry Bean. Based on a true story, The Believer tells the story of Danny Balintas (played by Ryan Gosling), a Jewish kid who comes to revile his heritage as he allies himself with Nazism. Accepting the award, a dazzled Bean admitted that he was surprised his film even made it onto the festival line-up. A Special Jury Prize was also awarded to Sissy Spacek and British actor Tom Wilkinson for their roles as an anguished middle-class couple in the family saga In the Bedroom. The skateboard scene film Dogtown won the Audience Award for Best Documentary.

Meanwhile other festival winners spotlighted an overall fascination with gender issues. "It's a tranny kind of Sundance and we're enjoying that," quipped John Cameron Mitchell, director and star of the transsexual rock opera Hedwig and the Angry Inch. Mitchell was on stage to pick up the Audience Awards for Best Film and Best Director. "I do like a warm hand on my entrance," he told the assembled crowd.

Elsewhere, Southern Comfort, Kate Davis's film about female to male transsexual Robert Eads, took the Grand Jury Prize for Best Documentary. "Sundance has always been on the front line of gay-themed work, but I feel there's a shift going on," said Tom Shepard, director of Scout's Honor, a documentary implicitly attacking institutionalised homophobia within US society. "It's great to see straight people taking a stand. Ultimately these are not just gay/straight issues."
