webTitle: In brief: Cher seeks eternal youth in new film

fields.headline: Cher seeks eternal youth in new film
fields.standfirst: Plus: Ray Park to play Iron Fist; Luke Goss to replace Ewan McGregor in Billy Fury biopic; Kurt Russell to have body double in Basic Instinct 2; legendary French team to work on thriller
fields.trailText: Plus: Ray Park to play Iron Fist; Luke Goss to replace Ewan McGregor in Billy Fury biopic; Kurt Russell to have body double in Basic Instinct 2; legendary French team to work on thriller
fields.body:
 Cher (pictured) is set to star in a film based on the life of a real-life Hungarian countess who bathed in virgins' blood to stay young. Elisabeth Bathory was so desperate to live forever that she had dozens of virgins murdered for their blood, but she eventually died in prison in 1614. Czech director Zdenek Troska wants to start filming the project next winter and intends to cast Gerard Depardieu and Anjelica Houston alongside the 54-year-old star. If the project comes off, it will be the most expensive Czech film ever made with production costs estimated at over $6m (£4.1m).

 Ray Park, who played Ewan McGregor's adversary Darth Maul in The Phantom Menace, has landed the lead role in a new £50m (£34.2m) film about the comic strip character Iron Fist. According to ananova, the Glasgow-born martial arts star will collect £2m (£1.36m) to play Marvel character Danny Rand, a Westerner raised in a secret temple in the Far East who returns to America to avenge his parents' murder. The film is due to go into production next month. A friend of Park's told ananova of Park's joy over this new role: '"It wasn't long ago that Ray was totally broke and wondering if he had made the right decision to be an actor. He was considering becoming a martial arts instructor."

 Ewan McGregor has allegedly been dumped from his role in a forthcoming film about rock legend Billy Fury in favour of ex-Bros twin Luke Goss. The Scottish actor had secured the part in a new biopic of the fifties singer's tragic life until Fury's ex-partner Linda Voice objected to the casting and asked for Goss to step in instead. Voice claimed the Star Wars star lacked the necessary charisma for the role. "Ewan does not look a bit like Billy. The part should be played by a rock 'n' roller. They only want Ewan because he's a big star, but I think it would be very sad if the film did not do justice to Billy. Everything about Luke reminds me of him." Fury, dubbed "the British Elvis Presley," had a string of hits in the 50s and early 60s, but died without a penny in 1983 at the age of 42.

 Kurt Russell is demanding a body double for his steamy sex scenes in Basic Instinct 2, according to reports this afternoon. Russell, who is married to Goldie Hawn, will play a policeman assigned to investigate pulp novelist Catherine Trammell, played by Sharon Stone, but he is not prepared to go as far as Michael Douglas did in the 1992 original. He apparently told a close friend: "I don't mind getting my clothes off if the context is right but I know when to draw the line. There are scenes I shall just opt out of." The producers of the $60m (£41m) film do not seem to be phased by this. A senior source said: "We don't have a problem if Kurt wants to use a body double. These days, through technology, it hardly makes a difference."

 Claude Lelouch, Michel Legrand and Francis Lai, who created the 1960s romantic classic A Man and a Woman, are to work together again on a new film. According to ananova, they will reunite for the thriller, And Now, Ladies and Gentlemen. Lelouch has signed John Malkovich to co-star in the whodunnit and French pop star Patricia Kass will make her soundtrack.

webTitle: Port in despair as fishermen get hooked on heroin

fields.headline: Port in despair as fishermen get hooked on heroin
fields.standfirst: The young men in Fraserburgh's fleet blow their wages on smack, making the Scottish town Britain's drug capital
fields.trailText: The young men in Fraserburgh's fleet blow their wages on smack, making the Scottish town Britain's drug capital
fields.body:
Davie was shivering, drenched from Adidas anorak hood to Reebok trainers with the day-long freezing rain. Standing on the corner at the entrance to some flats, he had been managing to squeeze out the odd word, but the longer we waited, the faster his conversation deteriorated from nervy gibbering to non-existent - as he focused on hissing a stream of expletives.

It was getting on for nine hours since Davie, 21, had had his last injection of heroin and his dealer was 30 minutes late. Another five, painful-to-watch minutes like this, and then the dealer appeared.

Barely older than Davie and dressed almost identically, he started to utter something which might be a greeting, but the client had waited too long for small talk. Inside the dealer's flat, the business was done quickly: £20 for a tin-foil wrap of a tenth of a gramme. Immediately, Davie went to work, cooking up the drug on a spoon over the flame of lighter. Holding the syringe in one trembling hand, he injected into a vein in the other. And the trembling stopped.

We were not sitting in Glasgow, Liverpool or London, and Davie is no deprived no-hope youngster from a sink council estate. Two days after we met, he would be back at his post on a fishing trawler operating out of the North Sea port of Fraserburgh, population 21,000, 40 miles north of Aberdeen and the undisputed drug abuse capital of Britain.

Fraserburgh should reek not just of the sea, but of the affluence it has generated for 400 years. Home to the second-largest fishing fleet in Britain, the harbour is filled with modern trawlers worth up to £200,000 each. Even in these trying days of falling stocks and EU quotas, the men who crew these boats can bring in £30,000 a year, the owners and skippers even more. Look closely around Fraserburgh and the trappings of high income are there: the BMWs and Audis, the gaudy, modern bungalows on the outskirts of town.

'We are in the middle of a bloody disaster,' said Sandy Wisley, a local doctor. 'If this was Glasgow or London, there would be a public outcry, but because we're a tiny place stuck away up here in the top corner, nobody is interested.'

The cold statistics compiled by Wisley at his Finlayson Street surgery are staggering. One in five young men in his practice, which covers 13,000 of the town's population, is a drug addict. About 70 per cent work on the trawlers, or did until they could no longer juggle their habits and their jobs. Wisley is treating more than 230 addicts and claims that two new ones come to him every week. Between February and April 1998, the practice prescribed 3,622 tablets of the opiate substitute dihydrocodeine; in the same period last year, more than 83,000 tablets - known as 'diffs' by users - were prescribed. The current tally is running above 90,000.

In total, there are about 450 heroin users in the town, more than 2 per cent of the population. On average, they consume about £80 of heroin each a day, more than £29,000 a year. Spread over the whole population, from infants to pensioners, that means heroin is costing every single person in Fraserburgh about £800 each a year. Dealers can make £5,000 a week here, but not all of this is profit; a substantial percentage of their income is used by the dealers to feed their own habits. 'It would be a great living if I didn't have to shoot so much up my arm,' said Davie's dealer.

Heroin has taken a heavy toll on Fraserburgh's young population. On 30 December the town achieved the dubious distinction of being home to Scotland's last drugs fatality of 2000. Richard Smith, 24, had been a familiar face in the local drugs scene for years, but on the Saturday before New Year the heroin addict was found dead at a house in the village of St Combs, just outside Fraserburgh. His death was the 140th in the area since 1996, when the scale of the drugs problem began to emerge.

'You come back after 10 days or whatever at sea and you are ready to party,' he says. 'You've got money in your pocket and a bit of time on your hands, so you go a bit wild. I used to get mad pissed, but all around you your mates are taking pills, doing a bit of blow, and you get sucked into it.'

'It is the dealers who are fuelling the market,' said one local user, who refused to be named. 'They started using it themselves, so they are trying to build up a market so they can bring in the gear and take a cut of it for themselves.'

Back in his flat, Davie was already starting to plan his next hit. Within 48 hours, he would be back at sea, taking dihydrocodeine tablets to control his withdrawal symptoms. 'The day I lose my job will be the day I stop using the smack,' he said. Until then, he has his cravings to attend to.

webTitle: January 29 Media Briefing

fields.headline: Today's media stories from the papers
fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN
fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN

Online information service 192.com plans to import 5,000 copies of Richard Tomlinson's M16 book to the UK. P7
The ICA has dropped plans for an ad campaign depicting a spoof baby auction. P7
Civil servants have been told to be more cautious about smearing C4 comedian Mark Thomas in emails, after he requested copies of them under the Data Protection Act. P8
Sex and violence on TV had increased, according to new research from the Broadcasting Standards Commission. P9
Pink Slip parties (parties to cure dot.com blues) have arrived in San Francisco. P13

MEDIA SECTION
Chris Blackhurst, former deputy editor, tells his story of the shenanigans at the Express. P2 Roy Greenslade assesses the chances of Rosie Boycott's successor, Chris Williams. P4 The PR battle Camelot faced when it took on the People's Lottery. P5 Jessica Hodgson interviews the new editor of Loaded, Keith Kendrick. P6 Is current affairs programming still on the BBC agenda? P8 The benefits of publishing rich lists - soaring sales. P10 How the consumer is going to watch interactive TV. P58 PR people need to get on cybersquatting cases. P60

THE FINANCIAL TIMES

Advertisers are up in arms about plans to merge commercial terrestrial TV sales houses. P3
Walt Disney is set to overhaul its loss-making internet operations, likely to mean the abandonment of Go.com and job cuts across the board. P27
Vivendi Universal is planning to withdraw its board director from BSkyB next month, the first step towards a strategic exit. P27
BT is under pressure to clarify its plans for Yell. P27
ONdigital has emerged as frontrunner to win the Premier League pay-per-view contract, beating BSkyB and NTL. P28
Granada Media and Carlton Communications are in talks to pool their internet interests to take full advantage of the ITV.co.uk brand. P29
AOL Time Warner is to lay out its newly merged strategy at an analyst presentation on Wednesday. P32

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL EUROPE

Vivendi has reached an agreement in principle to cede the 55% stake in AOL Compuserve France to AOL. P4

THE TIMES

Sex and violence on TV have reached record levels. P8
A row has broken out between Channel 4 and the Tories over plans to privatise the TV station. P8
Students at St Andrews University have been threatened with expulsion if they leak any information about Prince William to the press. P8

THE INDEPENDENT

Sex, swearing and violence on TV at record levels. P12
BT may abandon Yell float in favour of full demerger. P16

DAILY TELEGRAPH

Betray Prince William to the press and you're out, students at St Andrews University are warned. P3
The experience of serving in a Lancaster bomber during the second world war is being recreated by a £2.5m BBC drama. P9
Granada Media and Carlton are proposing to pool their websites under the ITV.co.uk brand. P27

DAILY MAIL

The former chief exec of J Walter Thompson, Chris Jones, said he almost died after suffering DVT on a long-haul flight. P45

DAILY EXPRESS

Richard Branson is demanding £30m in damages for his failed lottery bid. P1
Carol Vorderman is dating Mirror sports hack Des Kelly. P20

THE SUN

Internet baby couple The Kilshaws are to appear on the Oprah Winfrey show. P9
Footie fans were left fuming last night after the BBC scrapped its FA Cup Match of the Day special. P17

THE MIRROR

The Mirror says it turned down a request to find out who the finalists of Popstars were going to be from 'Darius the Dastardly'. P7
Sex, swearing and violence on TV at record levels. P15

THE STAR

BBC bosses had to pull Match of the Day last night after a row with Sky TV about screening FA games. Instead BBC showed Wildlife on One. P3
Internet baby couple the Kilshaws fly out to appear on the Oprah Winfrey show. P7
Adam Rickitt had admitted his pop career is over and is heading back to Coronation Street. P9

AND FINALLY...

Labour spinmeister Alastair Campbell is talking fast to dig himself out of the latest crisis he dug himself into last week. All papers cover his insistence that he is "friends" with Peter Mandelson. But would a friend really tell journalists that another friend's career was in tatters and publicly question their mental state? The damage has been done and Campbell is squirming.

webTitle: Indian earthquake: 'In half a minute everyone was killed'

fields.headline: 'In half a minute everyone was killed'
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: By 9am most mornings, the market in the unassuming town of Bhachau is a busy place. Last Friday was no exception. Within a minute, as giant tremors ripped through the lane, almost all of them were dead - drowned under a tidal wave of masonry.
fields.body:
By 9am most mornings, the market in the unassuming town of Bhachau is a busy place. Last Friday was no exception. The vegetable seller was putting the finishing touches on his cart, laying out a row of chillies. Mothers were buying shoes for their children. Shopkeepers were chatting and drinking tea. At the primary school, 300 excited small girls were parading to celebrate India's Republic Day. Within a minute, as giant tremors ripped through the lane, almost all of them were dead - drowned under a tidal wave of masonry.

Of all the towns affected by last week's catastrophic earthquake in India, Bhachau has been the most devastated. Before last week some 25,000 people lived here. Rescuers say they can find only 5,000. The rest have simply vanished. Some 90% of the streets have been pulverised. The girls who were waving India flags at the parade have gone largely unmourned: their parents are also dead. "I came to find my mother and father. They are somewhere under the rubble," Dinesh Shah said yesterday, picking through the debris.

And yet amid this infernal carnage there is still scope for miracles: a young couple who were entombed for 50 hours after the quake were dug out alive yesterday from beneath a collapsed five-storey residential block. They were freed by army engineers who arrived only on Saturday evening. "They were trapped in an air pocket so they survived. It was very dicey work but we chiselled them out," said an army major. "They gave a sign saying: 'We are alive'. We made a hole and started talking. We passed them some water. They are in deep shock."

Yesterday I watched as Kalpesh, the husband, dressed in a vest and a lunghi, staggered, Lazarus-like, out of his tomb. His wife, Rekha, still covered in dust, was carried out in tears. The rescuers applauded as they were led to an ambulance, together with a six-year-old boy who had, somehow, survived under the rubble for two days and two nights. But such moments are all too rare.

Despite the fact that large-scale aid was finally rolling into Gujarat yesterday, the authorities' torpid response to the crisis has come too late.

Instead, the living are merely exhuming and burning the dead. Bhachau market is now a medieval vision of nightmare: a circle of Dante's Hell. Volunteers from the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), a right-wing Hindu group, kept the pyres burning all day. There were too many corpses for ceremony: instead the dead were burnt where they were dug up. The town's alleyways were filled with black smoke. Fires smouldered with charred skulls and the sickly-sweet stench of burning flesh.

"In half a minute everybody was killed," Tusha Mehta, an aid worker newly arrived from Bombay, said. "There have been more tremors today. This morning [Sunday] at 6.30am we felt another aftershock." He was right: as I climbed over a pile of debris soon after midday, the ground juddered again. Outside the market's temple, dozens of pairs of adult shoes are scattered amid the rubbish. Their owners lie crushed under 20ft of concrete. The way is strewn with fallen masonry, coconuts, sacks of rice, bangles, and mangled bicycles. At the school, the ponytail of a dead girl with an orange braid pokes out of the rubble.

Fifty miles to the east in Bhuj, the historic town nearest to the earthquake's epicentre, the official responsible for managing the disaster painted a grim picture last night. "We have 10 divisions. Five of them have been massively affected. Half a million people are homeless. The death toll is more than 20,000. In Bhuj alone we have already burned 1,000 corpses. There are an estimated 3,000 people under the debris," Bhuj's collector Kamal Bayani said. "Our main activity now is removal of debris. We have 1,300 soldiers. In the next 24 hours we will have our power back.'

His last forecast seemed hopelessly optimistic. Bhuj has no water or electricity, and there seems little prospect of its getting much of either for several weeks. There is little food, no petrol, and only a makeshift tent for a hospital set up in a park.

While the devas tation is less severe than in Bhachau, most of Bhuj's old city has been destroyed, including the maharajah's 16th-century palace. At the Prince Hotel, where a couple of British tourists survived the quake, the manager Ajay Bora recalled what happened. "We were preparing our bills when suddenly the floor started going doom doom doom," he said.

At night the town is plunged into utter darkness. The stars seem glaringly bright. And the nights are cold - those who have survived the quake are camped outside their houses on makeshift beds. No one wants to go back inside.

The exodus from Bhuj has already begun: by 6am the first people could be seen tramping through the bus station in the hope of escaping. Their prospects are improving: by afternoon all manner of vehicles were heading towards Bhuj, some transporting bulldozers others merely bringing second-hand jumpers.

Further north, in the village of Lodai - the epicentre of the quake - villagers were attempting to rebuild their lives. Twenty three people were killed here. Most of the victims of the tragedy in Lodai, as elsewhere, were the elderly and the young unable to escape. "My parents were killed over there," Shyamgi Rupa said, pointing to a heap of rubble. "When the earthquake happened I looked after my wife and kids. Then I went to find my parents.

"After five hours I recovered my parents' bodies and put them on the fire."

Red Cross appeal

Call 08705 125125 or www.redcrossdonations.org.uk

webTitle: Hopes fade as toll rises to 20,000

fields.headline: Hopes fade as toll rises to 20,000
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: As the death toll from the Indian earthquake continued its inexorable rise yesterday with more than 20,000 people feared dead, the sheer scale of the disaster appeared to be overwhelming the authorities.
fields.body:
As the death toll from the Indian earthquake continued its inexorable rise yesterday with more than 20,000 people feared dead, the sheer scale of the disaster appeared to be overwhelming the authorities. Despite the arrival of dozens of international rescue workers to help the 5,000 Indian troops hunting for survivors of the disaster, many remote villages had yet to be reached by rescue workers.

With more than 500,000 people made homeless by the earthquake, the state government issued an urgent appeal for further shipments of food, shelter and medicines from the international community.

The government in Delhi asked for $1.5bn (about £1bn) from the World Bank and Asian Development Bank to help in the reconstruction.

Relief efforts have been hampered by continuing aftershocks measuring as high as 5.9 on the Richter scale, while damage to major roads has further delayed the distribution of much-needed supplies. According to a spokeswoman for Rapid UK, which makes up the British deployment, along with UK Fire Service and civil defence personnel, finding anybody alive between 48 and 72 hours after an earthquake was akin to a miracle.

"The rush of bodies has really picked up since early morning," said one hospital worker in Ahmedabad. "There are no survivors now, only the dead are being brought in."

A spokeswoman for the Red Cross said the priority was to provide food, blankets and shelter for the homeless.

It said it had already sent 100,000 blankets and 600 tents to the disaster zone, but has launched an urgent appeal for more.

Most gas pipelines, power supply stations and water services were knocked out by the earthquake, and the home minister of Gujarat, Haren Pandya, said people were in desperate need of food, water and petrol.

"Immediately we need 25,000 to 30,000 tents to set up some camps for the homeless," he said.

The Indian air force said that it had 40 cargo planes and military aircraft ferrying engineering equipment, mobile kitchens, food, water, tents, blankets and power generators.

webTitle: The long goodbye

fields.headline: The long goodbye
fields.standfirst: Chris Blackhurst, who resigned as deputy editor of the Express last week, tells the tale of a newspaper up for sale
fields.trailText: Chris Blackhurst, who resigned as deputy editor of the Express last week, tells the tale of a newspaper up for sale.
fields.body:
For years I have written about the buying and selling of businesses, usually in that detached tone favoured by the financial community. A corporate figure (nearly always a man) is interviewed and boasts about his company and its acquisition. He talks about cutting overheads, making assets sweat - in other words, closing plants and sacking people. Or an analyst speaks knowingly about a business losing its focus on core activities. And I lap it up.

Never, until recently, had I been at the other end of such cold reason. Only now can I appreciate what others have gone through. When quoted companies make a big move, they do so in the utmost secrecy. And this was the case with United News and Media (UNM), owner of Express Newspapers, publisher of the Sunday Express and Daily Express, of which I was deputy editor.

Companies that take the stonewall approach fail to realise that senior staff are caught in the middle. You believe or suspect something is up, but don't know for sure. Meanwhile, junior colleagues believe that you know what's up and just aren't saying. For the uninformed senior executive, it is dispiriting and demoralising. You feel useless in a sphere where only days before you seemed to exercise total power. Suddenly, you are running an international news operation and are powerless to say for certain what is happening upstairs. The sale of Express Newspapers was on the cards as early as May 1999, but I learned only on November 22 2000 that the papers had been sold. We were not told by UNM. We learned the news from Sky News.

Back in April 1998, I had left the job of deputy editor of the Independent with Rosie Boycott, the editor, to take up the task of turning round the Express titles. We were given a mandate to take the papers upmarket, to make them appeal to a younger, progressive audience. We were promised that the vast resources of UNM, a £5bn corporation, would be at our disposal. There would be massive investment. We'd be able to draw on UNM's television and other media interests.

All went well at first. We lost some older readers, wooed in part by promotional overtures from the Daily Mail, but that was predicted. (One commentator forecast we would lose 600,000 in six months; in fact, it was 150,000 in almost three years.) UNM, in the person of Lord Hollick, our new chief executive, took a close interest in the papers. Hollick, a big Labour supporter, was a regular at management meetings, where his enthusiasm could be infectious. Marketing plans, expansion and investment proposals were discussed.

Then, in May 1999, the tap was abruptly turned off. With hindsight, it was the first sign of a shift in strategy that would ultimately lead to a sale. At the time, UNM's parsimony was attributed to the inherent character of Hollick, a shrewd dealmaker who was cautious by nature, not given to the sweeping visionary brushstrokes of media barons such as Rupert Murdoch and Lord Rothermere.

Hollick hated to spend money. Unlike Murdoch and Rothermere, he was a salaryman, dependent on the goodwill of his external shareholders.

Much was made in the press of Boycott's friendship with Hollick, but she never went to his house for dinner and he failed to attend work functions at her home. They would go for long periods without exchanging a word, and when they did it was often over a trivial complaint. Hollick's temper was fearsome; he was used to getting his own way and executives rarely stood up to him.

Hollick, however, loved owning newspapers. They gave him political and social cachet. He adored ringing up political and football journalists for the latest gossip. If we had a cabinet minister in for lunch, Hollick expected to be invited. Yet he exhibited little interest in or feel for the living organism that a newspaper is - how it is put together, what makes it tick.

His reluctance to spend money did not extend to paying for outside advice. UNM and its many parts were forever being pored over by consultants. It was one such study, I later discovered, that may have prompted the sudden change of policy in May 1999. Unknown to Boycott, PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) had embarked on a crucial study of the Express group. Its sensitivity can be judged by the way it was cloaked in secrecy: in the detailed report that resulted, the project had the code-name Postbox; the Express titles were referred to as Unicorn and their sister publication, the Daily Star, was Comet.

The study's conclusion was stark: although progress had been made, further development required investment that might be difficult to justify for a publicly listed company. For Hollick, who prided himself on doing right by shareholders, this was probably not what he wanted to read. The consultants were saying, in effect, that the Express group needed an owner-proprietor, rather than someone who always had to put shareholders' interests first.

Rumours of the Express papers being on the block first surfaced in early summer of 1999, and the timing, given the date of the PwC report, cannot have been mere coincidence. Hollick's interest began to wane. The weekly meetings with him in the chair were scrapped, and when we did see him, the conversation dwelt on trivia. After Tony Blair's speech at the Labour party conference in Bournemouth in October 1999, I walked with Hollick to the High Cliff hotel. He said he was glad for the chance to chat.

I thought that at last we might get an indication about future investment. It was not to be. He asked whether I thought he should go to see Barcelona play Arsenal in the Champions League.

Industry gossip said Andrew Neil was hovering in the wings, ready to buy on behalf of the Barclay brothers. Pieces started appearing in rival newspapers predicting our disposal. One said City analysts were forecasting a £1 rise in UNM's share price if the Express papers were sold. This gave a strong hint of the pressure Hollick faced. UNM shares at that time were barely above £5. Market capitalisation was about £3bn. The rumour mill said the papers would fetch, at most, £300m - yet here was the City saying we were worth £600m to the value of share price. This was always the argument we faced. City analysts thought we were more valuable to the company outside it than within it.

UNM had a policy of not commenting on speculative stories. But amid this blizzard of publicity, that meant that assertions went unanswered and claims presented as fact were not denied. Internally, UNM assured us there was no truth in the rumours. Externally, the business and media pundits were having a ball. Staff assumed that the editor and deputy were in the loop. Sadly, nothing could have been further from the truth. We were not told; we were not consulted; we did not know.

A lull ensued. The rumours died down and we resumed business as normal - except it was anything but normal. All the energy went into producing the paper day to day - it was as if the future did not exist.

Journalists are quite unlike other workers. Their trade is information. They are trained observers who like nothing better than gossip. We had 440 pairs of eyes watching us and 440 pairs of ears hanging on every word. Any casual remark, joke or grimace by Boycott was relayed and dissected for any clue to imminent news. We debated whether she should tell staff: "Look, I hear the rumours, too. But I assure you, I know nothing." But that was rejected because they would speculate that it was a double bluff.

When we interviewed candidates for jobs, they would invariably ask what lay in store for the papers. Staff would come to us and say they had been approached by another paper. What could we advise? All we could answer was that we hadn't a clue. It was undermining - colleagues we knew and liked found it impossible to believe that a national newspaper editor who was so well informed on other matters and was a board director of the Express subsidiary did not know what the parent company was planning. Nor did her deputy.

The mood changed again early last year. UNM was proposing to merge with Carlton. Two firms of consultants were appointed to examine the level of cash injection required to boost circulation. It was not much, but it was something. We found ourselves in meetings where the talk was of investment and growth.

But just as abruptly, the mood changed. When it later became clear the merger was off, speculation again centred on the future of the newspapers and when UNM announced the sale of its television division to Granada, the writing was on the wall for the Express group. That's what the City thought, what all the media commentators wrote and what the staff believed. But UNM pretended nothing had changed. Hollick's ambition to become a major media player, with the bulk of ITV and other television interests, plus three national newspapers and several consumer magazines, had come to nought. We at the Express titles now found ourselves part of a company intent on a new direction.

What political influence the papers afforded Hollick had vanished. Stories of the Labour peer's rage at the government, which he had loyally supported but which, as he saw it, had not assisted him, made the rounds of the building at Blackfriars. The papers' relationship with their boss had shifted. The feeling grew that he would sell us to any group - especially one opposed to Labour - just to spite the administration that had let him down so badly.

At the paper, we explored the possibility of a management buyout and, with Boycott's approval, I met a City heavy-hitter. His reaction to the idea was swift: how would the Daily Express avoid the kind of grief the Independent had suffered when the Times started a price war? With no reserves, the Independent could not respond and its circulation fell. Finally, it had to give up its independence and turned to the Mirror Group for help.

The buyout expert explained that the City prefers to back businesses that lead their markets. In other words, it hates taking risks - and, whichever way we cut it, we were a risk. He also said Hollick did not have a reputation for "leaving something behind on the table" so there was little likelihood that profits could be increased by making cuts - another thing the City likes. It was an eye-opener, one that left me applauding anyone brave enough to get involved in a buyout.

Staff assumed, again, that we must have known what was going on. But Boycott had exchanged barely a word with Hollick in the three months before last October's Labour party conference in Brighton, when they had dinner together. I was there, along with other journalists and four government ministers. In the course of a three-hour meal, the subject of the papers never came up.

What we could not have known was that there was an offer from the Barclay brothers which Hollick was sitting on. That fact emerged days later when the Guardian ran a story revealing that Andrew Neil had bid £75m for Express Newspapers. Clearly, the Guardian had better lines of communication than we did.

Express staff were up in arms. They wanted to know what was going on. We had to stand there like lemons and say we did not know. UNM kept a firm silence. Then there was the shock over the £75m price. Surely we were worth more? Yes, but not much more.

Even so, Neil's offer seemed absurdly low. The papers made a profit and had a total sale of some 2.5m. But, mad or not, UNM was saying nothing. The silence said it all: after months of debilitating prevarication and speculation, the papers were finally up for sale. The billionaire Hinduja brothers were interested. So was Mohamed Al Fayed. Another potential buyer was David Montgomery, former head of Mirror Group.

Officially, UNM was still saying nothing, but news stories began appearing that seemed to carry the imprint of the parent company speaking off the record - in effect, inviting anyone to make a pitch. Internally, we were told zero. Over several weeks, our best sources as to what was going to happen to our business were the business pages. One week it was the Hinduja brothers, then Associated threw its hat into the ring, then Conrad Black's Hollinger Group. It was a strange feeling, coming into work and wondering whether that unfamiliar limousine parked outside might belong to a new suitor.

And still no official word. At last, at the end of a management meeting, the human resources director said she had been told by UNM to suspend plans for a personnel initiative. The reason, she was informed, was that UNM felt that with all that was going on, it was not a priority. This, believe it or not, was the first time UNM had even indicated that anything might be going on. It was just one week before the sale of the papers was announced.

As ever, we got our information from the other press. That week's Sunday Times delivered a new name: Richard Desmond, owner-proprietor of the Northern & Shell magazine group. The next day's Financial Times carried a front-page story that Desmond was on the point of securing the newspapers.

That Wednesday will live long in my memory. Another morning of silence from UNM, then at 1pm Sky proclaimed the sale of Express Newspapers as a breaking story. But still no confirmation.

My mobile beeped at 2pm, while I was at the Savoy for the Spectator's Parliamentarian of the Year awards. It was my office: the papers had been sold. Northern & Shell called an afternoon press conference. Boycott was summoned to see Hollick. For the first and only time, he explained to her why the papers had to go - terribly difficult, sorry and all that, hands tied... They said their farewells. Soon afterwards Desmond arrived to say hello.

 Chris Blackhurst was deputy editor of the Daily Express until last Thursday when he and Rosie Boycott resigned.

Officially, UNM was still saying nothing, but news stories began appearing that seemed to carry the imprint of the parent company speaking off the record - in effect, inviting anyone to make a pitch. Internally, we were told zero. Over several weeks, our best sources as to what was going to happen to our business were the business pages. Another morning of silence from UNM, then at 1pm Sky proclaimed the sale of Express Newspapers as a breaking story. But still no confirmation. My mobile beeped at 2pm, while I was at the Savoy for the Spectator's Parliamentarian of the Year awards. It was my office: the papers had been sold. Northern & Shell called an afternoon press conference. Boycott was summoned to see Hollick. For the first and only time, he explained to her why the papers had to go - terribly difficult, sorry and all that, hands tied... They said their farewells. Soon afterwards Desmond arrived to say hello.  Chris Blackhurst was deputy editor of the Daily Express until last Thursday when he and Rosie Boycott resigned. webTitle: Interactive TV

fields.headline: The audience is watching
fields.standfirst: The end of the couch potato could be in sight. You will still be able to sit glued to the screen. But, as  Imogen O'Rorke  explains, interactive TV will allow you to write your own plot
fields.trailText: The end of the couch potato could be in sight. You will still be able to sit glued to the screen. But, as Imogen O'Rorke explains, interactive TV will allow you to write your own plot
fields.body:
So far there have been two approaches to interactive television drama. The depressingly commercial route has been to view it as an unparalleled opportunity for integrated e-commerce within a mass market medium - the ability to click-and-buy the beer in John Goodman's hand in Roseanne, or that sofa in Friends. The other route is to see it as an unparalleled opportunity for new ideas that break the conven tional boundaries of narrative and authorship.

The first, where most effort has been expended to date, is not going to get anyone excited (except ad men and women, retailers and a few network executives), which is why many people in the industry already find the medium a turn-off. The TV production community seems to be split into two camps: those who believe that dramatic narrative should be left to the experts - the rest of us are just there to be passively entertained - and those who passionately believe that audience participation is the future of drama.

The Interactive Fictions conference, organised by scriptwriter Stephen Jeffery-Poulter with academic think-tank New Media Knowledge, was full of the latter faction. Students, media types and industry grey-hairs piled into a small theatre near the University of Westminster campus last Wednesday night to hear what pioneers of the medium had to say about how it works and what it is capable of.

The first bit of bad news for those who are still struggling to get their heads round multi-channel TV is that interactive TV (iTV) has multiple potential platforms: not just digital cable, terrestrial, satellite and broadband ADSL, but games consoles, kiosks, supermarket intranets, not to mention on-the-move mechanisms. In other words, it is not just broadcasters but telcos, ISPs and even retail brands which are interested in getting into it. There is nothing new in commercially branded drama, however. After all, it was soap powder that funded the first "soaps" - radio serials.

One of the drawbacks of the new medium is precisely that it has no constraints. Producers, traditionally bothered only by their budgets and pleasing the right people, now have to think of "self-scheduling" (users arbitrarily switching you off or on), non-linear and multi-layered plot lines subject to vagaries of viewer-voting (see that budget fly out of the window), personalisation (keeping tabs on the viewers' profile) and "cross-genre" developments (integrating chatrooms, email and phone). No wonder so many producers are despondent about iTV.

Never before have the people behind the propaganda machine been so at the mercy of its audience. Simon Rose, founder of IMP corporation, aka Interacta (www.itsyourmovie.com), who made the "world's first" interactive movie Running Time, believes in "democratic drama", which gives the audience the power to influence the fates of the characters, actors and even the producers themselves. The thriller, devised in six-minute episodes, prompts the audience to vote on what happens next. For example, crisis point: there is an intruder in the flat. Should the heroine jump out of the window, open the door to people calling themselves "the police" or go off with the ruggedly handsome stranger?

The production process Rose describes was hectic, however: the episode went live on a Thursday, the voting was processed over the weekend and on Monday the team of 10 would have to write the next day's script, find a location, shoot and then edit on Tuesday and Wednesday. It cost a tenth of the budget that Rose and his partner Simon Beaufoy, director of The Full Monty, were used to, but the crew often went without sleep.

The producers found it was impossible to second-guess the audience. They had just secured a new actress (Valerie Grogan) when the audience killed off her character. When they supplied a salacious lesbian plotline, the prudish audience rejected it. A virtual boardroom was presented to get around the problem of discontinuity, so that the viewers could look back at the portfolio of the characters and read their email correspondence. Running Time got 6m visits in May while it was running.

Rose points out that drama has only been linear since the 20th century. "Storytelling used to be much more interactive, from the oral tradition through to Dickens, whose novel serialisations were influenced by the letters that people wrote him. The idea that there should just be one author is ridiculous." Like the early US film-makers, such as William Castle who sent electric shocks through the audience's seats, Rose wants to make drama a "sit forward" medium.

Gub Neal, chairman of Vox TV and former head of drama at Granada and Channel 4, believes that "democratic drama" (of which Big Brother, being at once a docu-drama, internet experience and gameshow, was arguably the first successful example) has a bold new future. Thrillers and cop shows such as Cracker could work "amazingly well in the medium [imagine a courtroom scenario], but there has to be a competitive element like betting or gaming in order to sustain the audience participation".

The second genre to have emerged is "immersive" or "illusory drama", where the viewer becomes voluntarily immersed in a virtual world. The best exponent of this is Online Caroline (www.onlinecaroline.com) , which appeared to be a window into the private world of a real twentysomething girl: "Watch my webcam, read my emails, be my friend." Caroline even encourages you to give her advice on clothes and boys. If you respond, your relationship with her deepens and you "share" more information about yourself; if you don't reply to her emails, she gets stroppy.

According to its co-creator Tom Harvey, MD of XPT, the audience seemed quite happy to "suspend their disbelief and infiltrate her life as though it were real". When two actors in black balaclavas appeared to be being burgling her flat, her answer phone was deluged with warning messages from concerned viewers. Two people even rang the police. The drama is still going strong. XPT claims an unheard-of 92% retention rate among the audience, and the chatroom is still buzzing.

The BBC Fiction Lab's first experiment with "immersive drama" is to be aired later this year. Called The Block, it creates a virtual tower block environment set anywhere and nowhere, inhabited by virtual characters plus members of the audience, who can take a room in the block and join the community. The characters, scene-setting and "house rules" have been written by two young novelists- cum-techno-culture pundits, Jim Flint and Hari Kunzru, but ultimately it's the audience, as the narrative jury or fiction police, who decide what fate befalls their neighbours. If only it was this simple in life.

The Lab is also exploring what they call "multilevel drama" in The Affair, devised by novelist Emily Perkins, which covers the breakdown of a relationship. The audience can navigate its way through a sequence of events which form the main storyline but at the same time can "mine vertically" through a scene to view it through the eyes of different characters and deepen their understanding (feel like you're missing something? Scroll back to find out what really happened behind the scenes at that party).

Executive producer Richard Fell emphasises that the projects are still all experimental. "We don't know what works yet or what shape they might end up taking," he concedes. But he believes that the medium, far from being banal, could put an end to couch-potatoism by "drawing out the creativity of the audience". He already envisages the "Best of the Block" as a conventional prime-time TV spin-off.

Back to the conference, and panellists Rose, Harvey, Jeffery-Poulter and Jason Kingsley, founder of games publisher Rebellion and teenage inventor of the gamebook, all seem to be in agreement that interactive drama is heading towards the realm of voyeuristic, first-person computer games. Kingsley's description of the God-mimicking process of game authoring - "to create a tool set for people to create their own form of entertainment; to say 'here's the environment, now play!'" - seems a fairly good patent for the drama of the future.

The greatest compliment games masters (or interactive scriptwriters for that matter) can be paid is for fans to write to them and say they are taking a "virtual holiday" inside their cod world, be it Alien Versus Predator, The Block or the fictional game based on Kronenberg's sci-fi classic Existenz.

Perhaps XPT has got there already with its latest project, Mount Kristos. The interactive soap, scheduled for some time this year, allows you to go on holiday with 15 virtual characters and other users and get away with everything you can't do in real life. The plot has yet to be written, but the postcards and the T-shirts are in the post.

webTitle: Panorama and current affairs

fields.headline: Tea, toast and child labour
fields.standfirst: With poor old Panorama pushed back to an unpopular Sunday evening slot, current affairs programmes seem to be the last thing on the BBC's mind. But editors at Panorama and ITV's Tonight promise  Maggie Brown  that it is the next big thing
fields.trailText: With poor old Panorama pushed back to an unpopular Sunday evening slot, current affairs programmes seem to be the last thing on the BBC's mind. But editors at Panorama and ITV's Tonight promise Maggie Brown that it is the next big thing
fields.body:
On Friday Greg Dyke went to the corporation's equivalent of the lion's den, to assure Panorama journalists, led by new editor Mike Robinson, that BBC1 still loves them. He was inviting them to move on from last October's bitterness and gloom at being abruptly dumped on Sunday nights at 10.15pm, which some likened to being removed to die quietly in a hospital's side ward.

Now with a reduced run of three ten-week blocks per year, Panorama will be judged in future by impact; the waves made by ambitious programmes such as last year's naming of the alleged Omagh bombers or the exposé of the use of child labour by Gap and Nike. Impact will be more important than delivering BBC1-sized audiences to controller Lorraine Heggessey.

You could call this new criterion a bit of a cop-out: the waves made by TV programmes are notoriously hard to measure, while Barb audience data is hard fact. And the later a programme's start time, the smaller the audience you can impact upon. Panorama audiences averaged 3.8m in 1999, dropping to 3.6m last autumn. Since the move, viewing figures have been more robust than expected, but still only average 3.3m.

Meanwhile, as Dyke met the troops, celebrations were under way at ITV's populist current affairs strand, Tonight with Trevor McDonald. Pushed back from its 10pm slot to 10.20pm last Thursday because of the restored news, it drew an average 4.8m, 32% of the available audience, thanks to an interview with actor and ex-cocaine addict Danniella Westbrook and items on DNA paternity testing and the burial of Mary, the doomed conjoined twin.

Like Panorama, Tonight has a new editor: David Mannion, 50, a combative former editor of ITV news at ITN: "I'd like, in a year, to convince ITV to run Tonight twice a week," he says, "to make the programme so successful that it's good business to have more current affairs. Current affairs is on the way back, it's being raised from the near dead. People were making programmes for their peer group, for the chattering classes, and lost touch with the audience."

His optimism is echoed elsewhere. Richard Lindley, a former Panorama reporter who is writing a book marking its fiftieth anniversary in 2003, says: "I feel more cheerful about Panorama's survival now than I did before Christmas."

The optimism partly stems from the appointment of Robinson, 44, a universally respected BBC producer of 20 years' standing, a winner of five top industry awards with experience spanning documentaries and editorship of the One O'Clock News. He worked with Martin Bashir (now Tonight's star journalist) on Panorama's biggest coup, Princess Diana's "there are three people in this marriage" interview, and is determinedly upbeat: "Look at the successes, the number of programmes which have had an impact. We had a strong run in the autumn."

A possible merger of BBC current affairs with the documentaries department, which scored a hit with MacIntyre Undercover, is much talked-about, but nothing is in the pipeline at the moment. What Robinson is keen on is cross-fertilisation between the two departments, with positive results for the scripts and camera technique of Panorama programmes. "Events will unfold before camera, instead of people talking about events. We have to make it engaging."

Besides enhanced production values - a return to what Panorama aspired to before Birtist analysis squeezed the life out of BBC current affairs - his manifesto centres on defining the strand's role as scrutinising "the public and private use of power" and on thinking of the audience as "citizens, not consumers". He is looking for a couple of fresh faces to leaven the white, male mix (not Mariella Frostrup - for whom he has "no plans").

"We are always looking at where the next generation of journalists are. The important point is that presenters have authority." The word is that there's a problem finding rising producers who are prepared to commit themselves to the strand in its unglamorous new slot.

The governors' decision to move Panorama happened between Robinson's two interviews for the editorship. Did he think of withdrawing? "No, it's one of the best jobs in TV. I'm accepting for the foreseeable future. It's now a Sunday night show and I'm working very hard to ensure the programme succeeds in the slot I have."

The strand also has an extra £500,000 year to spend on being ambitious and going abroad, bringing the budget close to £5m. "We will punch our weight in future," he promises.

Perhaps surprisingly, something close to a consensus emerges when Robinson and his rival Mannion are asked how current affairs can be reinvented. Although Robinson says that current affairs is "a different journalistic enterprise" to daily news, he is encouraging more senior BBC News correspondents to do topical reports. Five years ago he pulled together Panorama's coverage of the Canary Wharf bomb over a weekend. But "if I commission something now, it takes 6-8 weeks, and by the time it comes out it has dropped out of the news. It is important either to do a programme very quickly, or take time on it." Both agree their programmes should be making news, running stories which the nationals follow up.

There is "no point doing a longer version of the news", says Mannion, his ITN background to the fore: "I want to be ever more responsive and react to current stories. It's a faster-paced world: the Concorde crash, for instance, was off the agenda in four days. I want to be ahead of the game."

Both define current affairs as providing "added value", the chance to strip back stories and look at underlying issues. Mannion rattles off his targets this way: "Big news exclusives, investigations or big issues of the week, exclusive interviews." He is quite unashamed about chasing the same human interest stories as tabloid editors: "They know what people want. Journalism without an audience is pointless."

And is there an audience for a current affairs programme on Sunday evening? Is that the time to worry about police corruption or the past drinking habits of the new US president? Mannion says: "People will watch any day of the week if the subject is interesting."

Robinson says there is no change to Panorama's agenda, and it will be interesting to see what role it is assigned in the forthcoming election. Yesterday's programme, on the exploitation of millions of vulnerable people by loan sharks, used undercover filming. The week before, Gavin Hewitt's profile of George W Bush was timely. Coming soon is an investigation into Railtrack.

Last week the editors were competing for an exclusive interview with Peter Mandelson. Last autumn they battled over the story of the conjoined twins (ITV won).

Robinson says: "Current affairs has an important role in the democratic process. The BBC's commitment is second to none."

It's curious, then, that the key vehicle of that commitment is first reduced to a 30 weeks a year experience, then shunted to the perimeter of prime time. Especially if impact is more important than ratings.

And is there an audience for a current affairs programme on Sunday evening? Is that the time to worry about police corruption or the past drinking habits of the new US president? Mannion says: "People will watch any day of the week if the subject is interesting." Robinson says there is no change to Panorama's agenda, and it will be interesting to see what role it is assigned in the forthcoming election. Yesterday's programme, on the exploitation of millions of vulnerable people by loan sharks, used undercover filming. The week before, Gavin Hewitt's profile of George W Bush was timely. Coming soon is an investigation into Railtrack. Last week the editors were competing for an exclusive interview with Peter Mandelson. Last autumn they battled over the story of the conjoined twins (ITV won). Robinson says: "Current affairs has an important role in the democratic process. The BBC's commitment is second to none." It's curious, then, that the key vehicle of that commitment is first reduced to a 30 weeks a year experience, then shunted to the perimeter of prime time. Especially if impact is more important than ratings.

webTitle: Richard Branson was a fearsome rival to Camelot

fields.headline: Steel balls and villains in the battle of Camelot
fields.standfirst: While she never doubted that her company was the right choice to retain the lottery licence,  Louise White  admits that Richard Branson's consummate PR skills turned his People's Lottery into a fearsome rival
fields.trailText: While she never doubted that her company was the right choice to retain the lottery licence, Louise White admits that Richard Branson's consummate PR skills turned his People's Lottery into a fearsome rival.
fields.body:
I can now admit it. As the director in charge of media strategy at Camelot, I had one thorn in my flesh - Sir Richard Branson.

This was never because I felt that the People's Lottery merited to win the lottery licence, but because of Branson's obvious gift at handling the media. I had faith in the Camelot bid, but knew that whereas the media was obviously never going to win us the licence, there was a danger of it losing it for us. Fat cats versus national hero - this was always going to be one of the greatest communication challenges ever.

With such a skilled communicator as our adversary, our media strategy initially was twofold: to concentrate on the running of a world-class lottery and to ignore the competition. We set about collecting the badges: the world's most efficient lottery; the ISO 9001 award for quality; leading corporate donor; a far-reaching social and ethical audit... and so the list went on. Not, of course, headline stuff, but our proven track record provided a powerful contrast to a consortium with no experience of running the UK national lottery.

The decision publicly to ignore the competition was daring, and at times intensely frustrating for Camelot's 800 staff. There seemed little point, however, in strengthening our competition's publicity agenda and so we firmly stuck to defending and promoting our own strong position.

By August last year, we may not have won the hearts of the nation - most polls still showed the People's Lottery as the popular favourite - but we had won the rational argument among most media opinion-formers. In stark contrast to the fat-cat days, there was no strong tabloid hostility to us. The media generally seemed prepared to accept a possible Camelot victory without making it a major national issue.

Curiously enough, we have Dame Helena Shovelton to thank for helping us achieve the final turnaround in media support. Her "conspicuously unfair decision" in August, to exclude Camelot from the race, gave a new twist to the media campaign. For a start, the fact that we so very nearly lost perversely acted in our favour. Suddenly glowing Camelot epitaphs started to be drafted by journalists. I sensed a certain amount of guilt among some of the media who had criticised us so hard - was Camelot really that bad that it deserved to be kicked out so unfairly? Would the new operator really live up to all the promises made?

Two key strokes of fortune came our way. The first was that the unthinkable happened: a new "villain" entered the lottery saga and Camelot now had the opportunity to be seen as the victim of a blatantly unfair process.

W ith a damning court judgment and the media hungry for fair play, this opportunity was relatively easy to exploit. It required, however, a complete change of approach at Camelot. For the first time, the company very publicly started attacking its regulator. Our strong and gutsy attack took some people by surprise. For many of us at Camelot it was a liberating experience: we had nothing to lose and strongly believed that we had been sorely cheated. There was a roar of approval throughout our offices in Watford when the decision was announced to take the commission to court. For once, the company was seen by staff to be robustly standing up for itself.

The second opportunity was to promote to the full one of our best assets - a "feisty, 5ft nothing blonde" with, in her own words, "balls of steel". Overnight, Camelot's new chief executive, Dianne Thompson, became the people's champion for fair play. At first reluctant to become a media star, she was a natural and quickly rose to the challenge. Although the fight was clearly with our regulator, we were able to use it to question the competition. Suddenly, we relished face to face interviews with the People's Lottery. Here was a woman who struck a chord with the nation and who was a sound, articulate advocate of a well-run organisation.

Ironically, we now had two ingredients which were in many ways more "Bransonesque" than Camelot. Against the odds we had become the underdog and in so doing won widespread public sympathy. Second, we suddenly gained public popularity with a strong individual personality who provided a clear contrast to the past fat-cat image of Camelot.

At the end of the day, however, it was the soundness and quality of the Camelot bid rather than the media that won the licence for us. That, of course, is how it should be and all we ever wanted. I would, though, be the first to admit that the strong media interest in Camelot has been an important driving force behind some of the changes and improvements made to the company over the years. For that we owe thanks to Branson.

On the day that the People's Lottery announced that it would not continue with the fight, Branson sent a fax to Thompson congratulating her on Camelot's success and wishing all the staff well. It was a generous gesture. Hopefully, Camelot can now move on and develop its exciting and radical plans for the second licence term in a more supportive, but still questioning, media climate.

In the end, only time will tell. The National Lottery has graced our front pages for far too long to escape future controversies. This time, however, I shall enjoy watching whatever action unfolds from the security of the sidelines rather than being in the eye of the storm.

 Louise White is the outgoing director of public affairs for Camelot

webTitle: Rich pickings

fields.headline: Rich pickings
fields.standfirst: Publishing a list of the country's wealthiest people is a nice little earner for the Sunday Times and the Mail on Sunday. Each time they do it, sales soar, says  Kevin Cahill.
fields.trailText: Publishing a list of the country's wealthiest people is a nice little earner for the Sunday Times and the Mail on Sunday. Each time they do it, sales soar, says Kevin Cahill.
fields.body:
The season of the rich is upon us, the rich-list season that is. The most expensive editorial projects of the year, the annual counts of the richest people in the country, are huge circulation boosts for the Sunday papers.

Both the Sunday Times and the Mail on Sunday have spent more than £1m on their chronicles of those who own the most this year. First out of the trap was the Mail, which bolted last week - more than six weeks ahead of its more established rival. The Mail's prize was an early slice of the extra sales that a peek at how the other half lives can bring. According to Dr Phil Beresford, rich list editor of the Sunday Times, sales of the paper go up by 14% on rich list day.

Beresford thinks it is this rise that prompted the Mail on Sunday into action. Last year was the Mail's first survey of the 300 richest people in the UK. Despite a promotions budget of more than £700,000 and a research budget of £265,000, the first list was tentative, played it safe and included few entrants who were not also on the Sunday Times's list. The reward was a tantalising 2.3% rise in circulation, about 50,000 copies.

This year the rise was almost 5%, and this time the Mail did what it does best. It told stories of the wealthy instead of listing their loot and used plenty of pictures. The result was a bright, hugely readable colour supplement. Rachel Oldroyd, compiler of the rich report, reckons that the paper has hit its stride.

"We try to tell the story of these people both in words and pictures, and not just provide a list of financial figures. The huge response from readers and from people portrayed in it suggests we have the balance right."

But who likes rich lists? Beresford muses that "people have always been fascinated by their betters, whether financially or socially. Once upon a time it was royalty and the aristocracy. Now it's the rich, who are the modern aristocracy."

His role in rich lists began in Claridge's at lunch with the late Tiny Rowland, buccaneering head of Lonrho, and the Telegraph's city editor, Ivan Fallon. As Beresford tells it, Rowland asked Fallon why he didn't do a UK rich list "like the American one in Forbes". Fallon thought it a great idea, rushed back to the paper and got his team onto it right away.

Two weeks into the research, after a couple of dukes had been phoned and asked to put a price tag on their ancient art and acres, Lord Hartwell, the then proprietor of the Telegraph, got an irate call from one of the same dukes, advising him that if he (His Grace, the Duke of Atholl) appeared in a rich list,Hartwell could forget shooting "grice" across the duke's 147,000 Scottish acres. The Sainsbury family rang Scotland Yard. The Duke of Devonshire told the Sunday Telegraph editor, John Thompson, at the bar in White's club that: "That is not the done thing in the Sunday Telegraph." The year was 1982 and there ended the first UK rich list, destroyed by the dukes.

By 1988, however, Fallon was deputy editor of the Sunday Times and Beresford was industry editor. That year, the original Money magazine had a stab at the 200 richest people in the UK. That was enough for the Sunday Times duo. In circumstances of the utmost secrecy, marooned on an island between business news and the sports section, Beresford and a small team put all their expertise into a definitive list of the UK rich.

No one was phoned. The research was entirely desk-based, arm's-length. The first the entrants knew of their elevation to wealth stardom was when they bought the paper on April 2 1989. Indeed, so tight had been the security that that was also the day that 99% of the Sunday Times staff found out that the paper had a rich list. Sales rose by 14%. The rich list was there to stay, and it has grown from 200 entrants to 1,000.

Neither Beresford, nor his proprietors, will admit the true scale of spending on the ST list, but it is known that the first year research alone cost about £165,000, a sum about which the late Tony Bambridge, managing editor of the ST, was heard to remark, "If we'd know what it cost we'd never have done it".

The first version of any rich list is the most expensive, as the Mail has found - now focused on a combination of research and photography, with an annual spend of around £1m, about £750,000 of which goes on production and marketing. Sunday Times costs are probably in the same region.

There are no real rivals to the two heavyweights. The Observer produces an eclectic and intimate list of the young rich, but has found itself sandwiched between the multimillion-pound promotional budgets of the MoS and the ST. And what about the wealthy? How do they like being on a rich list? The late steel tycoon Jack Walker described the first Sunday Times rich list as "a beggars' and burglars' charter". Peter de Savary, currently working his way back into the list after the recession of the 90s, was wont to make phone calls beginning, "Hi number 65, this is number 44 here". David Sullivan, the porn baron, wrote an irate letter to the Sunday Times, enclosing his accounts and pension fund and declaring himself grossly undervalued in 1990 at £60m. In 1991 he was better pleased at £100m, and the MoS now makes him worth £400m.

Perhaps the greatest moment for the rich lists came in 1993, when the Queen was finally forced to pay tax after years of appearing at the head of the list as a billionairess. The price of success was years of pressure from the Palace to reduce her estimated wealth, on the grounds that most of her assets belong to the state. Last year, she was worth a mere £270m, while the M0S placed her at £480m.

The two rival compilers both have some claim to be producing a work of academic scholarship. Whether or not the rich list can truly be seen as such, the multimillion pound rivalry between the two former historians will continue well beyond the publication in April of the Sunday Times rich list 2001.

 Kevin Cahill is editor of the Eurobusiness Richest 400 Europeans, and Eurobusiness Richest 200 Women in the World. His book Who Owns Britain will be published later this year by Canongate.

webTitle: New Media Diary

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: • Sometimes it's the hardest thing in the world to be a trendy new media type. Particularly when you're invited to a posh dinner party at the last minute and you assume that a ubiquitous black polo neck will be suitable attire. Alas, for Ed Ling, planning director at i-level, that wasn't the case. Ling found his sartorial elegance called into question when he was refused entry to Real Media's Burns Night dinner last Monday. So much for new media casuals. Luckily, help was at hand in the form of an oversized polyester suit, a shiny white shirt and unsightly tie - a far cry from the designer garb usually donned by this irrepressible Nathan Barley contender. Can Ed live this down?

 Sometimes it's the hardest thing in the world to be a trendy new media type. Particularly when you're invited to a posh dinner party at the last minute and you assume that a ubiquitous black polo neck will be suitable attire. Alas, for Ed Ling, planning director at i-level, that wasn't the case. Ling found his sartorial elegance called into question when he was refused entry to Real Media's Burns Night dinner last Monday. So much for new media casuals. Luckily, help was at hand in the form of an oversized polyester suit, a shiny white shirt and unsightly tie - a far cry from the designer garb usually donned by this irrepressible Nathan Barley contender. Can Ed live this down?

 As the paparazzi descended on Peter Mandelson's Notting Hill pad on Wednesday evening, so did a number of giant fish. Yes, giant fish. This had all the hallmarks of a dot.com gimmick. On closer inspection, suspicions were confirmed. The giant fish were branded with Fish4 logos, the classified ads website that is currently running a rather daft TV campaign featuring, yes, you guessed it, some giant fish. Supposedly they were doorstepping Mandy in a bid to get him to sign up to their jobs website... The words "publicity" and "liggers" suddenly spring to mind.

 It's not uncommon to be duped by bizarre websites that are really just fanciful PR gimmicks. Having once been duped by RubberBurner.com, there's no more pulling the wool over my eyes. This time, I'm convinced that the Thyropod project (see angelfire.com/ journal2/thyropod) is yet another viral marketing effort, designed to build intrigue around something that is a surefire bet to emerge as a PlayStation game. Emails encouraging journalists to follow the escapades of one Jack Macintyre and a secret Nato project have been doing the rounds for the past week, but no one has yet written about it. It's all a bit mysterious - and therefore bound to be a PR spoof.

 AltaVista is getting heavy-handed. The much-maligned search engine is now threatening to sue competitors because it transpires that it owns some patents for web searching. Expect a flurry of lawsuits to hit the likes of Yahoo, Google and MSN. Cynics say the timing couldn't have been better. AltaVista has been laying off staff by the bucketload - 424 staff have been axed in four months, but presumably no one in the legal department - and its legal battle with The Free Internet Group is still pending. Clearly it needs the money, but shouldn't it be concentrating on its own troubles rather than gleefully generating more work for its lawyers?

Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com

webTitle: 'Ten years to recoup phone licences' says survey

fields.headline: 'Ten years to recoup phone licences' says survey
fields.trailText: 8.45am UK mobile phone companies paid too much for next-generation licences, according to an industry survey. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
UK mobile phone companies paid too much for next-generation licences and it could take more than 10 years to get their money back, according to an industry survey.

The poll by telecoms consultancy Quotient Communications underlines concerns within an industry that has taken a massive gamble on the success of so-called "3G" mobile phone networks.

"There are lots of risks in 3G, and lots of money is at stake. The amount of licence money means the operators will have to look at innovative ways of getting revenues through different types of services," said Rodney Stewart, managing director of Quotient.

The next-generation networks, which are expected to run from next year, will offer video messaging, music downloads and even television clips.

Quotient interviewed bankers, mobile phone operators and industry regulators, with 86% saying Orange, Vodafone, BT Cellnet, One2One, and the TIW consortium went too far in paying a total of £22.5bn for the licences.

Over 90% of the respondents said it will take more than five years to recoup their investments, with 35% adding it may stretch to more than 10 years.

A spokesman for Vodafone would not reveal the company's timescale for paying back its £5.9bn bill for a UK licence, but added the company was confident that 3G services would be a success.

"Obviously the licence fees in the UK cost quite a bit of money, but we are very confident of making money on that investment from the greater number of data services and products that we will be introducing," said the spokesman.

However, Quotient was alarmed by the fact that only 11% of those questioned believed effective planning of networks was crucial for 3G services to succeed.

Quotient released a survey last year that revealed that more mobile phone transmitters will need to be built for the networks to withstand the increased traffic.

"The message that we are trying to put across is that the design of the networks is a crucial issue. If you do not get the core stuff right, you are going to get unhappy customers no matter what you do," said Mr Stewart.

The survey will add to mounting concerns over the health of the telecoms sector, after banks loaned over £270bn to telecoms operators worldwide last year.

The poll by telecoms consultancy Quotient Communications underlines concerns within an industry that has taken a massive gamble on the success of so-called "3G" mobile phone networks. "There are lots of risks in 3G, and lots of money is at stake. The amount of licence money means the operators will have to look at innovative ways of getting revenues through different types of services," said Rodney Stewart, managing director of Quotient. The next-generation networks, which are expected to run from next year, will offer video messaging, music downloads and even television clips. Quotient interviewed bankers, mobile phone operators and industry regulators, with 86% saying Orange, Vodafone, BT Cellnet, One2One, and the TIW consortium went too far in paying a total of £22.5bn for the licences. Over 90% of the respondents said it will take more than five years to recoup their investments, with 35% adding it may stretch to more than 10 years. A spokesman for Vodafone would not reveal the company's timescale for paying back its £5.9bn bill for a UK licence, but added the company was confident that 3G services would be a success. "Obviously the licence fees in the UK cost quite a bit of money, but we are very confident of making money on that investment from the greater number of data services and products that we will be introducing," said the spokesman. However, Quotient was alarmed by the fact that only 11% of those questioned believed effective planning of networks was crucial for 3G services to succeed. Quotient released a survey last year that revealed that more mobile phone transmitters will need to be built for the networks to withstand the increased traffic. "The message that we are trying to put across is that the design of the networks is a crucial issue. If you do not get the core stuff right, you are going to get unhappy customers no matter what you do," said Mr Stewart. The survey will add to mounting concerns over the health of the telecoms sector, after banks loaned over £270bn to telecoms operators worldwide last year.

webTitle: Blunkett warning on fairer society

fields.headline: Blunkett warning on fairer society
fields.standfirst:
Building up assets for the poorest may hit the better off, minister hints

Special report: Fabian Society conference
fields.trailText: Building up assets for the poorest may hit the better off, minister hints.
fields.body:
If Britain is to become a fairer society the next Labour government must do much more than simply move people from welfare to work. It must give them the chance to build up "capital assets" such as home ownership, bank balances and pensions, David Blunkett warned at the weekend.

The education and employment secretary also hinted that government pledges to do more for "work, families, pensioners and investment" would mean that perks for the better off - such as tax relief and state subsidies for pensions and university fees - cannot be sustained in the old way.

Challenged about tuition fees at a Fabian Society seminar, Mr Blunkett said: "We have for years massively subsidized the better off. You cannot move to alleviate the middle classes from paying something and expect the general taxpayer to pick it up, if you genuinely want to move to a more equal society."

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, used a speech at the conference, co-sponsored by the Guardian, to promise a generation of full employment and an end to child poverty. But he also warned that William Hague's election strategy is "to spread cynicism about politics to defeat the very idea of a progressive public agenda".

"The Conservatives believe their best chance is not to win the country's approval, but to win its apathy," Mr Brown said at the seminar at the London School of Economics. "They are the first opposition in history who hope people do not vote."

The conference was not overshadowed by Peter Mandelson's resignation. The former Northern Ireland secretary was one of several ministers to cancel his appearance, though Keith Vaz also involved in the Hinduja passport row, did attend and defended the government's policy in his role as minister for Europe.

Rattling off the government's achievements in education and welfare reform - including a rise in minimum income guarantee for poor families - Mr Brown admitted that one in six families are still without work. Mr Blunkett adapted his cabinet colleague's arguments about social exclusion to argue that alienation from society and a reluctance to vote is directly connected to people having "no definable stake in the community".

The number of people with no assets had doubled to 10% of the population in the past 25 years and the government was reversing the trend with difficulty. "We don't just want to say 'what a terrible tragedy this is'. It's damned hard work [to reverse the trend] and it makes you unpopular at times. But it's working."

He contrasted a young person growing up in London with a relative from whom they might one day inherit even a modest terraced house with someone else with no such prospects, living in rented accommodation without a bank account or job skills.

Mr Blunkett added that the government is moving to get more people into teaching - always harder when the economy is booming. "No one wants to come into the teaching profession if all they hear from the teaching unions is that it is a lousy job," he added.

The most deft answer of the day came when the environment minister, Michael Meacher, standing in for the former Northern Ireland secretary, was asked: "Are you glad to see the back of Peter Mandelson?" He replied: "Only in the sense that it allows me to be here today."
