webTitle: New Eurostar ads

fields.headline: Malkovich gets on board Eurostar ads
fields.trailText: 8.30am: John Malkovich is being lined up to star in the first of a series of ads for Eurostar, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
John Malkovich is being lined up to star in the first of a series of ads for Eurostar in which celebrities reflect on their ultimate journey.

A multimillion pound campaign launching this spring will present Eurostar as a pleasurable experience that allows the traveller time to sit back and think.

Eurostar's ad agency, TBWA, has approached a number of "offbeat" celebrities, including actors, singers and sports stars, for the campaign, which uses the endline "Enjoy your journey".

One of the main aims of the new advertising drive is to persuade more business travellers to opt for Eurostar. It will be presented as the hassle-free alternative to travelling by plane.

Eurostar already claims to have a 63% share of the London to Paris rail and air travel market.

Eurostar has had little consistency to its advertising since it launched in 1994.

A quirky campaign fronted by French comedian Antoine de Caunes and a philosophising Eric Cantona was followed by a campaign that showed scenes of Paris with the line, "As if by magic Paris arrived".

More recent TV advertising has featured a group of visitors to Paris and Brussels breaking into song in French.

Eurostar appointed TBWA to handle its European advertising account last November in order to develop a more consistent message for the brand.

Previously, Eurostar's advertising had been handled by Young & Rubicam in France and Belgium and by St Luke's in the UK.

webTitle: My New Media

fields.headline: My New Media
fields.standfirst: Martin Baker
fields.trailText: Martin Baker, editorial consultant of my-endowment.com
fields.body:
Favourite sites:

I lived in Paris for seven years and now and then I have a nostalgic look at where I used to live and the bars I frequented, at www.pagesjaunes.fr. Every day without fail I go to teamtalk.com, sports.com and lep.co.uk (the Lancashire Evening Post) where I get reams of drivel about Preston North End. Worlds.com is a gas - it's a 3D interactive chatroom. You can choose characters for yourself. I'm a penguin.

Last online purchase:

I bought some plane tickets to Barbados and I regularly use a site called laterooms.com to see if there are any good deals if I want to go away for a weekend or something.

Most recent technological faux pas:

I'm not looking for the ultimate Palm Pilot - I like to get hold of something that works and then use it for a long time. I managed to kill my old Apple Mac laptop which I had for five years and wrote my first book on - I had to take it to the Apple Mac graveyard.

Main news source on the web:

I go to Bloomberg and FT.com - my former arch competitor, but their archive is second to none. For financial news, I subscribe to breakingviews.com which is good; but it's trying to convert to paid subscribers and, good though it is, it won't be getting my money.

Most persistent spam emailer:

The most annoying is a US credit card company you can spot a mile off: "Information you requested". It's a generic label for "please delete me".

Time spent on the web:

A fair amount. If I'm researching something involving foreign business, I can spend up to a couple of hours a day on it. I'm quite selective and try to work offline as often as possible.

Next boo.com:

The next high profile failure will be lastminute.com for sure. They're talented and vigorous people, but they were very badly advised on the flotation. I hope I'm wrong, but that's what I think.

Least useful site on the web:

Martinbaker.com - it's a picture of a bloke in Leamington Spa sitting in a deckchair. But he got there first.

Which screensaver do you use?

I don't use a screensaver. Oh, yes, hang on, I do. It's a Microsoft one. Looks like wire frames that are trying to have sex . . . Coat Hangers Mating.

Most irritating thing about the web?

Junk mail, inaccuracies, misspellings and really stupid names.

Do you still bother with old media:

Oh yes. Newspaper journalism is very important in certain key areas.

Author and journalist Martin Baker is the former editor of the thestreet.co.uk. He is senior editorial consultant of www.my-endowment.com which launched last week.

webTitle: Meet the man who wants to turn Loaded into a woman-friendly read

fields.headline: Meet the man who wants to turn Loaded into a woman-friendly read
fields.standfirst: He once overturned a Jeep in a minefield, so who better for the top job at the magazine for men who should know better? By Jessica Hodgson
fields.trailText: He once overturned a Jeep in a minefield, so who better for the top job at the magazine for men who should know better? By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
What I want to capture in photographs is an intimate, sensual moment that celebrates the beauty of women. Women are not here to be wanked over," says the new editor of Loaded.

Are we talking about the magazine that headlined an interview with an Australian soap star "Picnic at Banging Cock"? The magazine that celebrated football-pitch streakers with full-page, colour photos of the lovelies in question under the heading "Bitch Invasion"?

"Men and women are not the opposite sex," says Keith Kendrick. "That was then, this is now. We're friends with each other." Kendrick wants more women readers, he thinks Loaded man has grown up and he's even talking about banning nipples from its pages.

But surely grown-up men and adult relationships are to Loaded what salt is to a slug? The magazine that became a Bible for New Lad depended on the feeling that you were reading something you should have grown out of years ago. Loaded's success was an uneasy, knife-edge relationship between humour and offence, titillation and porn, slapstick and puerility. And absolutely key to the mix was what Barbara Ellen described as "wank lite".

Kendrick doesn't agree. "The perception of Loaded is entirely a figment of the media's imagination," he says. "Loaded has never subscribed to laddism. It's always been a magazine aimed at young men who have a great time. But it's always been a very intelligent magazine."

He's right that Loaded has a bit of an image problem. Mike Soutar, who manages the IPC Music and Sport portfolio, admits it: "A lot of people I talk to recently have a low opinion of Loaded readers." This readership has fallen by 8.9%, as part of a year-on-year decline in sales figures of men's magazines. And towards the end of last year, the magazine's founding editor, James Brown, described the men's market as "stale", "pathetic" and "embarrassing".

Cue Kendrick. After the nursery slopes of Manchester weekly newspapers he worked on the Liverpool Echo, the Daily Mail and the Birmingham Post and Mail. It was here that he won both the regional young journalist of the year and the prestigious Stern Fellowship scholarship, which sent him on attachment to the Washington Post. After Washington, he was dispatched to the Gulf, where he says he enjoyed a few months of "boy's own stuff" - culminating in being put under arrest after he and a fellow journalist overturned their jeep in a minefield.

In an incongruous move, he joined IPC's Woman magazine from the Birmingham Evening Post. After three years at Woman he was offered the editorship of Chat magazine in 1997, where he earned his reputation as a turnaround expert, credited with rescuing the magazine from an 11.5% year-on-year decline.

His vision for Loaded has a military ring to it. He says he has a book "as thick as a Bible" of ideas and strategy. "I'm not being employed to caretake this magazine," he says. "I'm being employed because of the vision I've got for it and the changes I want to make. Loaded would not be Loaded without its tone of voice, without its attitude, without its mickey taking. But what we can do is broaden it out to a more mass audience."

A thorough market research exercise is under way, and Kendrick will be asking the editorial team to justify the existence of all the sections. The well-loved Platinum Rogues, "the Premier League of bad behaviour" is probably safe, he says. Whether the "pornalikes" section can survive in a woman-friendly Loaded remains to be seen.

He says his experience in women's magazines taught him the value of the real-life interview; a genre he wants to bring in to Loaded. He also wants more of the tongue-in-cheek "campaigns" which he perfected at Chat, including win a divorce and win a lifetime's supply of cigarettes on national no smoking day.

More controversially, he also wants a strict women-only cover policy. Although its covers have always been laden with beautiful women, Loaded has also had some strong male covers and Brown - in particular - championed the idea that modern male icons could be as big a pull as a woman in a state of semi-undress.

Kendrick subscribes to the received wisdom that a man on the cover is circulation suicide. "I don't think young men want to look at other men," he says. "I think if there is an icon of the moment then that icon could end up on the cover. But I think there are so few men in this country that another man would want to buy a magazine just to read about."

Loaded was founded in 1994 by James Brown and a bunch of his mates - young music and lifestyle journalists who were disillusioned with the glossy smugness of the established men's sector. The original editorial team, notably Martin Deeson, Jon Wilde, Tim Southwell, Mick Bunnage, Rowan Chernin, Pete Stanton and Derek Harbinson, defined the writing that came to be identified with Loaded.

"Loaded was basically a fanzine of a young guy's life," says Brown. "It was a fantastic explosion of what it was like to be a man in his mid-20s." Arguably more than any magazine since 60s style bible Nova, it came to encapsulate a movement. The magazine's launch corresponded with the demise of political correctness.

Phrases like "bunch of arse" and "good work fella" fitted perfectly with the growing confidence of men who had heard themselves say "I'm committed to help women achieve orgasm" once too often. The magazine's editorial staff basically used the magazine as an excuse for a lifestyle. And as luck would have it, Loaded sold an astronomical amount and made money for IPC, so everyone was happy.

Derek Harbinson, who took over from Brown when he was poached to edit Condé Nast's GQ in 1997, agrees. "Loaded was always written by the staff, for the staff. It just so happened that half a million people read it." The degree of editorial creativity Loaded had in the beginning is probably overstated. But yarns of the staff's gonzoid antics, from hanging fishing rods out of the IPC building during an anti-fishing protest (culminating in the police being called by Marie Claire editorial staff) to playing the Sex Pistols' God Save the Queen during the visit of Prince Charles, were actively encouraged by IPC as part of the magazine's brand equity.

Loaded was always about birds and football. But it was also about Pythonesque captions. It was about revisiting the moment when the Blue Peter Japanese sunken garden was destroyed by vandals, both to take the piss out of the BBC and to ask implicitly why this particular incident was such a significant one for a generation weaned on top-down television. It was about a cut-out-and-keep guide to where to get laid in London, underpants indicating a one-night stand, a love-heart for something more lasting.

Like all bright ideas, it spawned a slew of poor imitations. With a couple of notable exceptions these are little more than lifestyle self-help for the man who can't think for himself, with a liberal sprinkling of soft porn to help the medicine go down.

And whither Loaded? Former Loaded staff say Kendrick is a likeable man and a competent editor, with even Brown saying explicitly that he thinks he has a good chance of making a go of the editorship. But for many, the spirit of Loaded has been killed off by the suburban blandness of the rest of the men's market. The fight against political correctness no longer has the same streak of creative rebellion - with champions like Richard Littlejohn and Chris Evans, who needs enemies? And the Godfather, Brown himself, grew up and got married.

"IPC appointing an editor to take it on is a bit like having a follow-up to Pulp Fiction that's not directed by Quentin Tarantino," says Brown. Immodesty aside, he may have a point.

webTitle: Media monitor

fields.headline: Media monitor
fields.trailText: Mandelson Downfall Part Two by John Kampfner
fields.body:
This is a tale of good old-fashioned reporting, an underplayed story and a slow-burning fuse. The Observer got wind of something to do with Peter Mandelson, the Hindujas and passports back in November. Their public policy editor, Antony Barnett, contacted the Liberal Democrat MP, Norman Baker, who put down questions in the House of Commons.

On Thursday night, January 18, Gaby Hinsliff, the paper's chief political correspondent, did what lobby reporters often fail to do, and scoured the trays in the lower press gallery for written answers. There she found Home Office replies to Baker's questions. Even the MP himself hadn't realised they were there. She alerted Barnett, they put together a story, paged Mandelson and then his adviser on Saturday lunchtime, and the rest, as they say, is history.

Hindsight may be a wonderful thing, and most people agree that it was Mandelson's response to the story, more than the facts within it, that led to his immolation. But one question on the minds of old hands in the lobby and at the Observer last week was why the story was put only at the basement of the front page? There was no follow-up inside and no leader article. Some of the other Sunday papers, following it up for later editions, gave it greater prominence. And the Mail on Sunday even changed its lead story.

On Sunday, broadcasters made some reference, but it still wasn't considered particularly hot news. The papers made calls, were given a similar line from Downing Street, and the coverage on Monday was straightforward. The Times gave it two-paragraph treatment on page one. The rest put it inside. Two papers wrote leaders. The Daily Mail warned Mandelson to "ensure this latest embarrassment is his last". But that was as far as it went. The Sun was the first really to sniff (or cause) trouble, proclaiming Mandelson was "not fit to be foreign secretary, a job he covets". The lobby, which hadn't had a meaty story for some time, went into overdrive. Pages were set aside.

This time, it was Mandelson's tall story to Campbell himself that did it. Never Foreign Secretary: Sun

Negative, but no recommendation: Mirror, Mail, Telegraph, Times

No leaders: Guardian, Independent, Financial Times

webTitle: Express's former deputy speaks out

fields.headline: Express editorial chiefs 'kept in the dark' over sale
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Former Express deputy editor Chris Blackhurst has revealed that a critical study of the Express in 1999 led to an 'abrupt' loss of interest by the then proprietor, Lord Hollick, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Blackhurst article in full
fields.body:
Former Express deputy editor Chris Blackhurst has revealed that a critical study of the Express by PricewaterhouseCoopers in 1999 lead to an "abrupt" loss of interest by the then proprietor, Lord Hollick.

Mr Blackhurst talks about the alienation felt by himself and editor Rosie Boycott, who were kept in the dark throughout the long and protracted sale process.

In a swingeing attack in today's MediaGuardian, Mr Blackhurst paints a picture of the Express's former owner, Lord Hollick, as an absentee proprietor who wanted a share in the paper's glory without the investment and nurturing required.

Mr Blackhurst notes that after Lord Hollick bought the newspaper in 1999, there was an initial surge of interest, followed by a period of purdah.

At first he said the new owner kept a keen interest.

"Hollick, a big Labour supporter, was a regular at management meetings, where his enthusiasm could be infectious. Marketing plans, expansion and investment proposals were discussed," he said.

"Then in May 1999 the tap was abruptly turned off. With hindsight, it was the first sign of a shift in strategy that would ultimately lead to a sale."

The report by PricewaterhouseCoopers suggested that the papers needed an owner-proprietor "rather than someone who always had to put shareholders first".

It was this conclusion which, Mr Blackhurst believes, precipitated the eventual sale of the papers to Northern & Shell at the end of last year.

Mr Blackhurst also tells of Lord Hollick's "parsimony", saying he liked the glamour of being involved with running a newspaper but did not relish the involvement.

"He adored ringing up political and football journalists for the latest gossip. If we had a cabinet minister in for lunch, Hollick expected to be invited. Yet he exhibited little interest or feel for the living organism that a newspaper is."

At one point during the Labour party conference in October 1999, Mr Blackhurst felt Lord Hollick was about to take him into his confidence.

"I walked with Hollick to the High Cliff Hotel. He said he was glad for the chance to chat. It was not to be. He asked whether I though he should go to see Barcelona play Arsenal in the Champions League," he said.

webTitle: Debate: Our cities need to change

fields.headline: Our cities need to change - or others will beat us
fields.trailText: The challenge to restructure our cities is perhaps one of the greatest facing the present government.
fields.body:
The challenge to restructure our cities is perhaps one of the greatest facing the present government.

Despite of all the talk of urban renaissance, our cities struggle in comparison with their counterparts throughout Europe. Birmingham, for example, has a level of per capita income only half that of Hamburg, three-quarters that of Antwerp and about the same as that of rapidly growing Barcelona. England's northern cities fare even less well.

Moreover, in other parts of Europe, regional cities tend to be richer than their country as a whole, while in the UK they tend to be poorer.

Among the English regional cities, only Bristol has a per capita income that exceeds the British average by the 20% or more evident in Antwerp, Barcelona and Cologne. While some of the regional German cities are even richer still - for instance Stuttgart - cities such as Sheffield and Liverpool stand out for being markedly poorer than the UK average.

It is not as if our cities and our regions do not have the ambition to succeed - they clearly do. By working through networks such as Eurocities, they can measure themselves against cities in other countries.

Yet government is still unwilling to allow the large cities the freedom to plan for their own futures. Government ties everything up in predetermined packages, stifling innovation and refusing to acknowledge that other European and international cities have a wealth of experience from which we can all learn and benefit.

Local communities are not able to make choices or back innovation through a local taxation system. Debate is often obsessed with whether the annual council tax for Band D property is to rise above £1,000. This attracts lots of news coverage in the regional press, but it means little in itself. It is hardly surprising that local electors are apathetic.

The time has come for a thorough rethink of how our cities raise money. Through good management and design, cities can be seen as good credit risks. Birmingham and other cities are now arranging their finances with credit ratings in mind.

If our cities are to gain access to private capital, certain changes need to be introduced so that they can raise revenue and earmark it for particular purposes.

First, cities need a wider range of tax instruments than they have now. Besides congestion charging and parking taxes, a hotels' tax and more general "development" tax at a local level are possibilities. Business rates which are now set nationally could once again be determined locally.

Second, the method central government uses to distribute money should be changed. The formula is still based primarily on population rather than an assessment of what needs to be done. Liverpool is particularly badly hit by this.

Third, council tax - which is still the main way that a local authority has to raise money - needs an overhaul. It is still quite close to a flat tax, with the bill for a prestige penthouse being just three times that for the smallest bedsit. This makes it both unfair and ineffective as a means of raising money.

Underlying these technical changes there should be a fundamental change in the relationship between local and central government.

On one hand, government needs to release its grip. Too tightly defined central government funding inhibits innovation. The French "contrat de ville" offers one model of what a more arm's length relationship might look like, with five- or 10-year contracts between the centre and local authorities. The flexibility of such a system would allow Whitehall to champion creativity in ways which are unthinkable today.

On the other hand, cities need to recognise the full implications of what the freedom to raise capital would entail. Central government's reluctance to countenance such freedom reflects the legitimate concern that if things go wrong, the Treasury will be left to pick up the bill. If cities are to be free to borrow, they have to be prepared to rule out the option of a rescue by the Treasury. The leaders of regional cities - and their electors - need to proceed in full knowledge of the fact that it will be they who will have to pick up the bill should something go wrong.

Achieving success in comparison with the best in the world, rather than improvement against past performance, is the challenge. If the next government is not up for this there may still be a renaissance in our cities, but our faster developing European competitors will leave us even further behind.

 Peter Kenway is co-director of the New Policy Institute. Andy Howell is deputy leader of Birmingham city council.

webTitle: Brand Aid

fields.headline: Brand Aid
fields.trailText: Benetton by Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
What is it?

The high-street clothes shop whose woollies were made famous by its pictures of snogging priests, dying Aids patients and giant condoms. A favourite among cash-strapped students and anyone who likes brightly coloured sweaters.

So what's the problem?

Oliviero Toscani, the brains behind Benetton's campaigns and advertising's very own shock-jock, unexpectedly quit last year after creating a furore that proved too much even for Benetton. An advertising campaign that featured Death Row convicts caused one controversy too many.

And what is it doing about it?

Benetton's latest ad campaign delivered the ultimate shock by featuring - you've guessed it - clothes. Gone are the "provocative" images of newborn babies and copulating horses. In their place we get smiling models in brightly coloured clothes. "We are not speaking to the world this time, we are speaking to women," says chief Benetton spokesman Federico Sartor enigmatically.

Marketing:

Benetton has taken the unusual step of handing the company's advertising to a group of arts students. Pupils of the Benetton-funded Fabrica arts institute have been asked to come up with ideas on how to promote the world-famous brand.

History:

Chairman Luciano Benetton got into the rag trade in the 1970s, after friends admired the jumpers his sister had knitted for him. The 65-year-old entrepreneur is still going strong with plans for a chain of Benetton megastores in major cities across the world. The company's new, cleaned-up advertising is being seen as more appropriate for its more corporate approach.

What about the competition?

Industry observers have pointed out the remarkable similarity of Benetton's latest campaign to The Gap's ads. Come to mention it, those fresh-faced, multicultural young things dancing around in brightly coloured clothes do seem a little familiar...

webTitle: Collapsing cities

fields.headline: Collapsing cities
fields.standfirst: Whether it's London or the growing megalopolis of Mumbai, the world's urban areas have become crisis zones
fields.trailText: Whether it's London or the growing megalopolis of Mumbai, the world's urban areas have become crisis zones
fields.body:
Blocks of flats collapsed like a pack of cards, the concrete slabs concertinaed among heaps of rubble: these images from the earthquake-hit cities of Bhuj and Ahmedabad illustrate one of our worst nightmares. The 20th century saw both a historically unprecedented rate of urbanisation of the world's population and the terrible vulnerability of human life, when accumulated in such concentrations, to natural or manmade disaster. Human beings have spent the last century building, destroying and rebuilding cities. One of the second world war's most pernicious legacies was to turn the city into modern warfare's main battleground: Dresden, Hiroshima, Leningrad, London's blitz. More recently, it has been Grozny, Belgrade, Sarajevo and Baghdad.

By 2007, more people will live in cities and towns than in the countryside. For the first time in history, human experience will be predominantly urban rather than rural. This shift has been accomplished in the west over the course of 200-odd years, but in developing countries it has taken less than half that. In 1950, Africa's urban population accounted for 15%, Asia's 17%; in 2000 it was 38% and 37% respectively and by 2030 it will be 53% and 55%. The life that revolved around the village, the agricultural seasons and a relationship to nature has been replaced by the shanty town, street-selling, schools and a global consumer culture. This massive social transformation is dislocating billions of people's sense of place, belonging and identity within three or four generations.

So, it is with characteristic surefootedness that the Tate Modern has chosen cities for its first major exhibition, which opens this week. If anyone is to begin to make sense of an urbanised world, Century City is a good starting place; it focuses on distinct periods of cultural creativity in nine cities through the 20th century, from Paris and Vienna to Lagos, Tokyo and finally, Bombay/Mumbai and London in the 90s.

In the foreword to the catalogue, Century City is described as a mission statement for the Tate Modern's future exhibitions programme: picking a theme and exploring it across time, across the globe and across the traditional demarcations, from film and music to visual arts. Some will complain of a global urban buffet, which jumbles up Schiele with Mumbai artist Atul Dodiya's painting on shopfront shutters.

But the search here is for the new connections we need to understand experiences common to all cities. For example, pre-first world war Vienna and 90s Mumbai are in many ways worlds apart but both cities share experiences of rapid growth, chronic housing shortages and struggles with ethnic conflict and national identity. In both, an individualistic introspection and sexual assertion comes into conflict with traditional social conventions.

Mumbai is an appropriate city for the exhibition to end on, because it represents the future. Along with Tokyo, Mexico City and Sao Paulo, it is a megalopolis of more than 20m inhabitants; by 2015 it is predicted to become the second biggest in the world with a population of 26m. Shockingly, as Ashish Rajadhyaksha, one of the curators for the Mumbai section, points out, 50% of the population lives in shanty towns or on the streets and by 2010 that could be as high as 90%. Rajadhyaksha adds that such cities become almost impossible to live in; people can't move for traffic congestion, and they can't breathe, the air is so polluted. The scale of such cities present an awesome challenge to politicians to manage and deliver the public goods - such as transport and sanitation - on which the city depends.

And that task is immeasurably complicated by the process of globalisation that Rajadhyaksha ascribes as the key theme: "The city splits into two experiences - the globalised metropolis of shopping malls, high-rise buildings, a security-conscious elite - and the nativisit, indigenous, anti-English language street level." He believes the conflict between the two has moved from economy where the global has triumphed - "You can't be anti-global if you want to be rich" - to culture and politics, fuelling at its worst, ethnic fundamentalism.

Rajadhyaksha fears that in the polarising inequality, what has been lost is a safe public sphere in the city. You can no longer assume safety as a public good provided by the state, you have to buy your own through bodyguards, security gates and several locks on doors. Security is the biggest growth industry in the world.

All of this is exactly what London needs to be thinking about. British cities have been blighted by the governing classes' rural nostalgia; they're dreaming of escape to a country idyll - which is why the M4 was one of England's first motorways. Nationalism was defined in the 20th century as honey for tea and cricket on the village green, while cities were associated with Blake's "dark satanic mills" and the taint of industry and commerce.

The reality, as Lord Rogers pointed out in the foreword to his urban task force report, is that urban areas account for 90% of the UK population and 91% of economic output. Rogers adds that the neglect of our cities by policymakers is borne out by the survey in which one in four people believe their urban neighbourhoods have got worse. What the British have chosen to overlook is that great cultural creativity almost invariably takes place in cities and that (at their best) cities nurture civic participation and citizenship.

Only in the past few years, after nearly 30 years of neglect, have we begun to think and debate a vision of what our cities should be like, and as Rogers points out, it will take decades to repair the damage. In the 70s the state withdrew, and the market exploited the vacuum, to the impoverishment of public space. A sense of what we've lost and need to revive is evident in Ken Worpole's Here Comes The Sun, a fascinating account of the political idealism that informed urban planning for the first two-thirds of the 20th century. It is full of insight into how public space influences such things as a sense of belonging and of ownership - themes that crop up in Mumbai in Century City.

In the spate of millennial openings last year (Tate Modern, British Museum, the Eye), the assumption of an urban renewal, at least in London, was widespread. It has been no such thing. It was a bid for prestige and status - call it conspicuous civic consumption - in a global competition. The point about the municipal ambitions examined by Worpole is that they were the result of political negotiation and were a physical expression of political ideals.

Public works courtesy of private philanthropists, corporations or the lottery is altogether different; it is the equivalent of Father Christmas, largesse to be enjoyed that can be withdrawn at any time. It is not the fruits either of one's labour or of one's vote. Barcelona's regeneration worked not because of the brilliance of individual buildings but because it was driven by political and community participation. Nothing symbolises London's global ambition and civic impoverishment more graphically than the Eye. A massive symbol of corporate power, it dwarfs the houses of parliament and the buildings in Whitehall that belong to the institutions that ostensibly run the country.

Shockingly, as Ashish Rajadhyaksha, one of the curators for the Mumbai section, points out, 50% of the population lives in shanty towns or on the streets and by 2010 that could be as high as 90%. Rajadhyaksha adds that such cities become almost impossible to live in; people can't move for traffic congestion, and they can't breathe, the air is so polluted. The scale of such cities present an awesome challenge to politicians to manage and deliver the public goods - such as transport and sanitation - on which the city depends. And that task is immeasurably complicated by the process of globalisation that Rajadhyaksha ascribes as the key theme: "The city splits into two experiences - the globalised metropolis of shopping malls, high-rise buildings, a security-conscious elite - and the nativisit, indigenous, anti-English language street level." He believes the conflict between the two has moved from economy where the global has triumphed - "You can't be anti-global if you want to be rich" - to culture and politics, fuelling at its worst, ethnic fundamentalism. Rajadhyaksha fears that in the polarising inequality, what has been lost is a safe public sphere in the city. You can no longer assume safety as a public good provided by the state, you have to buy your own through bodyguards, security gates and several locks on doors. Security is the biggest growth industry in the world. All of this is exactly what London needs to be thinking about. British cities have been blighted by the governing classes' rural nostalgia; they're dreaming of escape to a country idyll - which is why the M4 was one of England's first motorways. Nationalism was defined in the 20th century as honey for tea and cricket on the village green, while cities were associated with Blake's "dark satanic mills" and the taint of industry and commerce. The reality, as Lord Rogers pointed out in the foreword to his urban task force report, is that urban areas account for 90% of the UK population and 91% of economic output. Rogers adds that the neglect of our cities by policymakers is borne out by the survey in which one in four people believe their urban neighbourhoods have got worse. What the British have chosen to overlook is that great cultural creativity almost invariably takes place in cities and that (at their best) cities nurture civic participation and citizenship. Only in the past few years, after nearly 30 years of neglect, have we begun to think and debate a vision of what our cities should be like, and as Rogers points out, it will take decades to repair the damage. In the 70s the state withdrew, and the market exploited the vacuum, to the impoverishment of public space. A sense of what we've lost and need to revive is evident in Ken Worpole's Here Comes The Sun, a fascinating account of the political idealism that informed urban planning for the first two-thirds of the 20th century. It is full of insight into how public space influences such things as a sense of belonging and of ownership - themes that crop up in Mumbai in Century City. In the spate of millennial openings last year (Tate Modern, British Museum, the Eye), the assumption of an urban renewal, at least in London, was widespread. It has been no such thing. It was a bid for prestige and status - call it conspicuous civic consumption - in a global competition. The point about the municipal ambitions examined by Worpole is that they were the result of political negotiation and were a physical expression of political ideals. Public works courtesy of private philanthropists, corporations or the lottery is altogether different; it is the equivalent of Father Christmas, largesse to be enjoyed that can be withdrawn at any time. It is not the fruits either of one's labour or of one's vote. Barcelona's regeneration worked not because of the brilliance of individual buildings but because it was driven by political and community participation. Nothing symbolises London's global ambition and civic impoverishment more graphically than the Eye. A massive symbol of corporate power, it dwarfs the houses of parliament and the buildings in Whitehall that belong to the institutions that ostensibly run the country.

webTitle: Blunkett warning on fairer society

fields.headline: Blunkett warning on fairer society
fields.standfirst: Building up assets for the poorest may hit the better off, minister hints
fields.trailText: Building up assets for the poorest may hit the better off, minister hints.
fields.body:
If Britain is to become a fairer society the next Labour government must do much more than simply move people from welfare to work. It must give them the chance to build up "capital assets" such as home ownership, bank balances and pensions, David Blunkett warned at the weekend.

The education and employment secretary also hinted that government pledges to do more for "work, families, pensioners and investment" would mean that perks for the better off - such as tax relief and state subsidies for pensions and university fees - cannot be sustained in the old way.

Challenged about tuition fees at a Fabian Society seminar, Mr Blunkett said: "We have for years massively subsidized the better off. You cannot move to alleviate the middle classes from paying something and expect the general taxpayer to pick it up, if you genuinely want to move to a more equal society."

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, used a speech at the conference, co-sponsored by the Guardian, to promise a generation of full employment and an end to child poverty. But he also warned that William Hague's election strategy is "to spread cynicism about politics to defeat the very idea of a progressive public agenda".

"The Conservatives believe their best chance is not to win the country's approval, but to win its apathy," Mr Brown said at the seminar at the London School of Economics. "They are the first opposition in history who hope people do not vote."

The conference was not overshadowed by Peter Mandelson's resignation. The former Northern Ireland secretary was one of several ministers to cancel his appearance, though Keith Vaz also involved in the Hinduja passport row, did attend and defended the government's policy in his role as minister for Europe.

Rattling off the government's achievements in education and welfare reform - including a rise in minimum income guarantee for poor families - Mr Brown admitted that one in six families are still without work. Mr Blunkett adapted his cabinet colleague's arguments about social exclusion to argue that alienation from society and a reluctance to vote is directly connected to people having "no definable stake in the community".

The number of people with no assets had doubled to 10% of the population in the past 25 years and the government was reversing the trend with difficulty. "We don't just want to say 'what a terrible tragedy this is'. It's damned hard work [to reverse the trend] and it makes you unpopular at times. But it's working."

He contrasted a young person growing up in London with a relative from whom they might one day inherit even a modest terraced house with someone else with no such prospects, living in rented accommodation without a bank account or job skills.

Mr Blunkett added that the government is moving to get more people into teaching - always harder when the economy is booming. "No one wants to come into the teaching profession if all they hear from the teaching unions is that it is a lousy job," he added.

The most deft answer of the day came when the environment minister, Michael Meacher, standing in for the former Northern Ireland secretary, was asked: "Are you glad to see the back of Peter Mandelson?" He replied: "Only in the sense that it allows me to be here today."

webTitle: Rise in attacks on staff 'blighting NHS'

fields.headline: Rise in attacks on staff 'blighting NHS'
fields.trailText: Physical violence and verbal abuse against NHS staff rose by a fifth in 12 months, according to a study published today.
fields.body:
Physical violence and verbal abuse against NHS staff rose by a fifth in 12 months, according to a study published today.

Hospital trusts are recording more than 500 incidents a year despite increased security measures, including closed circuit television and more security guards.

The journal Health Service Report said only a fifth of trusts it surveyed believed they would meet government targets for a 20% reduction in workplace violence between 1998 and April this year. A third expected to hit the 30% fall by April 2003.

The study's author, Adam Geldman, accepted that staff were encouraged far more than they once were to report incidents, but insisted: "This is a shocking finding. There is no doubt that many frontline NHS staff continue to face a serious risk of being physically assaulted and/or seriously verbally abused while serving the public."

Mr Geldman said his survey of 45 trusts suggested that reported cases had risen from an average of 419 in 1999 to 511 last year.

However, the rise in attacks might be because hospitals were encouraging staff to report complaints more.

One trust said that complaints about violence had quadrupled since it revised its reporting procedures.

The present levels of violence were "a blight on the NHS", said Mr Geldman, although there was strong evidence that many trusts were now responding to government calls to stamp it out.

Carol Bannister, occupational health adviser with the Royal College of Nursing, said: "At least trusts have begun to take some action, although it is also clear that targets, particularly for this year, are not going to be met.

"I am not sure we have seen enough cases of trusts taking serious assaults to court or passing them on to the police."

A government study in 1998 estimated that there were 65,000 violent incidents every year against NHS staff and the Department of Health is to reassess the size of the problem.

It has also warned patients in its new public guide to the NHS that it will not tolerate violence or racial, sexual and verbal harassment from patients or relatives.

An advertising campaign by the London ambulance service warns that people convicted of attacking staff will face imprisonment.

However, a spokeswoman for the Department of Health said that Mr Geldman's survey was quite small and some trusts had managed "huge reductions".

She argued that it was unfair to compare individual trusts' performance against national targets. "We take violence against NHS staff extremely seriously," she added.

webTitle: Analysis: Statistics show immigration beneficial to economy

fields.headline: Statistics show immigration beneficial to economy
fields.standfirst: Despite its illiberalism on asylum seekers, the government has been quietly encouraging other immigration - to the benefit of UK plc
fields.trailText: Despite its illiberalism on asylum seekers, the government has been quietly encouraging other immigration - to the benefit of UK plc
fields.body:
The theme at the Davos economic extravaganza today and tomorrow is again openness. At the conference last year Tony Blair dedicated the 21st century to winning "an open world, an open economy, and an open global society". And open borders? How open is open when the Heathrow immigration officer is demanding the papers of would-be residents whose skin is not quite white?

Despite the illiberalism of its response to the growth in asylum-seeking, the Blair government has quietly been trying to ease the passage of "economic migrants". These are welcome because, sotto voce, they make the UK more diverse. They are really welcome - this is more politically saleable - because the IT and health sectors need them.

The case for migration as put by Barbara Roche, the Home Office minister, is unabashedly utilitarian. Immigration is good for migrants and good for us (and let's draw a veil over the consequences for their home countries). Assisted by the Cabinet Office's performance and innovation unit, her civil servants this week gave her some useful ammunition by doing the immigration sums for the first time*.

The UK's foreign-born population pay 10% more to the state than they get back in benefits and services - equivalent to £2.6bn a year net. They push up the rate of economic growth by a finite but hard-to-calculate amount and, among other things, ensure we get treated when we are ill. Nearly a third of UK doctors and 13% of nurses are non-UK born; half the extra NHS staff employed over the past decade qualified abroad.

Immigration is now at "historically high" levels. Some 150,000 non-EU, non-UK people are expected to arrive in 2001 with a view to long-term residence. The chart shows where migrants come from. Returning UK citizens form the biggest category of long-run settlers, mainly because from 1945 to the 70s the migrant flow went heavily the other way. Of course, many would not consider them to be migrants at all. It has been "New Commonwealth" - non-white - immigration that has excited controversy.

On the value of individual immigrants the report is not entirely clear. If we are applying an economic calculus, that would favour migrants with skills. Or capital: there has always been significant, largely uncontroversial immigration of people of people who can kick a ball or mobilise a million on the back of official permits and schemes.

Labour is making these easier to get though it is unclear whether the government wants permit holders to settle permanently. About 100,000 applications for work permits are expected this year. After four years permit holders are entitled to apply to live in the UK permanently but, in practice, only a fraction do.

Officially, migrants include "working holidaymakers". These are 17- to 27-year-olds from the Commonwealth who are allowed to stay for up to two years. They are not supposed to work in non-professional jobs but do. Most are white, many are Australian, and without them the pubs of the capital would close down. Up to 15,200 mainly eastern Europeans qualify under the seasonal farm workers' scheme.

Getting into the UK if you are in business is relatively plain sailing - though not, it seems, for the Hinduja brothers. There are several business migrant categories - for those establishing a new company, innovating and investing. Only a few hundred a year enter under these schemes.

Students with a university place get in automatically but can be stopped if immigration officers think they intend to stay here after completing their course (12% of applications are refused, rising to 20-25% from parts of Asia and Africa). In 1998, 266,000 students were given permission to stay on after their courses ended for further training or to take jobs.

Students and Antipodeans are not, however, what the tabloid press nor people at large label migrant - often because they refuse to distinguish between new arrivals and British people of black or Asian descent.

Over race, as over the attributes of individual migrants, the Home Office report betrays a certain naivety, perhaps because it was written by civil servants rather than politicians having to deal with racist attitudes at the sharp end. Immigration clearly has never been just about jobs, housing or even cultural enrichment; it is also about identity, race, resentment and (for the right) a potent source of political mobilisation.

Still, it is worth getting the facts of the immigration story straight. Theory says migration increases the labour supply, depressing wages while bumping up returns to capital. (That ought to make free marketeers passionate advocates of open borders. To judge from Tory party history, it has not happened.) In fact, there is no evidence of sectors where migrants have supplanted UK-born labour.

Instead, migrants are doing well enough to suggest they are bringing something valuable to the party. On average, migrants who work earn rather 12% more on average than the UK-born. Migrants are over-represented in the upper reaches of the income league tables. However, the migrant jobless rate is about one percentage point higher than for the UK-born. Levels of entrepreneurship and self-employment appear to be high among migrants. But that finding may be skewed by the fact that some 150,000 French entrepreneurs have moved to the UK since 1995, many to work in information technology.

But if migrants are as beneficial as the evidence suggests why not admit many more of them? Silence from Barbara Roche and the civil servants on numbers. They recommend Whitehall should tidy up the competing jurisdictions of Home Office, employment and trade departments. But the obvious question remains: if 100,000 human imports a year is good for the UK, wouldn't the benefit double at 200,000 a year?

webTitle: Crackdown forces out prostitutes

fields.headline: Crackdown forces out prostitutes
fields.standfirst: Initiative cuts crime but women say it puts them at risk
fields.trailText: Prostitutes are being forced out of their traditional territories in British cities as police crack down on kerb crawlers.
fields.body:
Prostitutes are being forced out of their traditional territories in British cities as police crack down on kerb crawlers.

A campaign launched last summer by Greater Manchester police to name and shame kerb crawlers has been pronounced a huge success in reducing crime.

Today in Liverpool the police are again cracking down on prostitutes and kerb crawlers, who will be automatically prosecuted. But the initiative stops short of naming and shaming.

Other cities take a more tolerant view. The authorities turn a blind eye to prostitutes working in massage parlours in Sheffield and in around 20 saunas in Edinburgh. A tolerance zone had been mooted in Sheffield several years ago, but was abandoned due to a lack of support. Birmingham city council is considering a report which suggests a zone of tolerance, similar to those in the Netherlands.

Inspector Mike Schofield, of Greater Manchester police, said he had no sympathy for those kerb crawlers who had been prosecuted and named and shamed. "We ran a press campaign to warn people and a few said they had seen it," he said.

Police believed the benefits of naming people outweighed an individual's right to anonymity. Inspector Schofield said crime had reduced in the city by around 20% between July and December, since the campaign began.

"We have a lot of anecdotal evidence that if we remove prostitution from an area, then crime goes down," he said. "I have been working in the city for 11 years and each time we target kerb crawlers, there is a reduction in crime. Naming and shaming is the ultimate deterrent."

He said that most of the women had a drug habit and much of the money earned by prostitutes was used to support the drug economy.

"It is an embarrassing crime and the message we want to get across is that people should think of the consequences of their actions."

But prostitutes working in the city claim that the number of clients has fallen by at least half. "I have lost all my regulars," said one of the women. "All my regulars are married men. Before this, everything was fine."

Andrea, who has worked as a prostitute in Manchester for 12 years, said the campaign had made things much more difficult for women.

"We are used to working in a certain area and getting the same punters coming to see us," she said. "We are now being forced into areas where we would not normally work and it is a lot more dangerous.

"It is not as if these people can look out of their balconies and see us working. We are not in residential areas." She said she does not have a drug habit and was forced into prostitution as she has a disabled child and can work only for a couple of hours at night. She hated being labelled a victim because it was her choice to work.

The English Collective of Prostitutes says it is opposed to the naming and shaming of clients because it makes all women more vulnerable to violence.

"It will make it even more difficult for anyone with information to come forward to help with any investigation involving violence against a prostitute," a spokeswoman said."Women will also be put at risk as safe regular clients are driven away and women are forced to move to unfamiliar, often isolated areas, to avoid arrest."

The collective claims that women will have less time to check out clients before jumping in their car, as men are nervous about being picked up by the police.

One man who had been publicly identified said it had been a devastating experience. It had made him feel very lonely and a lack of trust had developed with his wife. "If I am sitting in a traffic jam, I feel that people recognise me," he said. "It was a moral offence. There are many other things you do which you know are wrong, but you still do them."

He said he had considered committing suicide after being named and shamed.

Liverpool police are launching a crackdown on kerb crawlers, after a surge in the number of prostitutes in recent months. There are now around 500 women based there.

Merseyside police say women walking home are being targeted by kerb crawlers as are schoolchildren and students.

Chief Inspector Cliff Walker said: "A similar crackdown on prostitutes last year resulted in 71 men receiving cautions for kerb crawling. This time, anyone caught during the operation will receive an automatic court summons.

"There are a lot of innocent people walking along the street who have been accosted by kerb crawlers. We have found that if we move the prostitutes, we remove a lot of the associated crime problems."

Chief Inspector Cliff Walker said: "A similar crackdown on prostitutes last year resulted in 71 men receiving cautions for kerb crawling. This time, anyone caught during the operation will receive an automatic court summons. "There are a lot of innocent people walking along the street who have been accosted by kerb crawlers. We have found that if we move the prostitutes, we remove a lot of the associated crime problems."

webTitle: Sex and violence on TV rise

fields.headline: Sex and violence on TV rise
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Incidents of bad language, violence and sex have increased to record highs on terrestrial and satellite television, according to a new report.
fields.body:
Incidents of bad language, violence and sex have increased to record highs on terrestrial and satellite television, according to a monitoring report published today.

In its latest sample survey from 1999, the Broadcasting Standards Commission found that although individual incidents had gone up on terrestrial television, there had not been a significant increase in the proportion of programmes which contained violence, bad language or sex.

Much of the increase in violence was accounted for by news and current affairs programmes showing footage from Kosovo.

The number of violent scenes on satellite television equalled the 1997 record.

There were record numbers of nude scenes and of instances of sexual innuendo on terrestrial and satellite television.

But only one in 20 of the programmes monitored by the BSC contained significant violence, one in 25 notable levels of "strong" language, and only one in 40 scenes of explicit sex.

Press Association

webTitle: ICA drops spoof baby auction advert

fields.headline: ICA drops spoof baby auction advert
fields.standfirst:
Special report: babies for sale
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Institute of Contemporary Arts has dropped an expensive advertising campaign depicting a spoof baby auction after fears it would be accused of cashing in, WRITES Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Until a British couple were revealed to have "bought" two babies over the internet, the idea of auctioning children would have seemed fanciful, but unlikely.

Now, such has been the hostile reaction to the Kilshaw case, the Institute of Contemporary Arts has dropped an expensive advertising campaign depicting a spoof baby auction after fears it would be accused of cashing in.

The ICA expressed disappointment yesterday. Its director said that British culture was "over-sensitive", and the British were "not very good at taking wit". But it acknowledged that the series would have opened it up to accusations of tastelessness. If the ICA had not pulled the plug, cinema regulators would probably have blocked it anyway, given the current mood.

In the proposed series of films, which was due to be shown in cinemas around the country, babies would have been shown alongside on-screen reference numbers, with a voice-over encouraging viewers to bid. In one film, the final baby knocks over a beaker of water, which "scatters to create an amazing, artistic image on the stark floor", and a caption is flashed up: "Beat the ICA to the next great thing".

The ICA was initially enthusiastic about the campaign, which was developed by the London-based agency HHCL and Partners before the internet baby scandal broke.

Philip Dodd, the director of the ICA, said HHCL had suggested using a baby auction because of its provocative nature. At the end of the film, it would have been clear that it was the art, not the babies, that was for sale.

"When this [the internet babies] blew up the problem for us was that we would have looked reactive rather than proactive. To come out with something like this, we would have seemed exploitative," said Mr Dodd.

webTitle: Hasbro shuts Atari website

fields.headline: Hackers force Hasbro to shut website
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Games and toys manufacturer Hasbro pulled down its Atari website after it was defaced by hackers, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Games and toys manufacturer Hasbro pulled down its Atari website after it was defaced by hackers.

Hackers were so amazed by Atari.com's lack of security that they taunted the company with graffiti referring to its vulnerability and uploaded soft porn images onto the site.

They then emailed the tech people at Hasbro telling them of the security lapse and encouraging them to rectify it.

After 24 hours had passed and nothing had been done, the initial hackers carried on with their fun.

Eventually, after two days Hasbro's tardy tech team noticed and pulled down the site at 3pm on Thursday afternoon.

According to one web developer that witnessed the offensive, the site was easy to penetrate.

"If you went to www.atari.com/admin you were prompted for a username and password, these were both 'test' (an easy guess) and typing these in allowed you to edit the site, doing things like add and editing products in the shop database for example," said the developer, who wished to remain anonymous.

"I think this raises some interesting issues about a company's responsibility for the security and control of content on their website, especially when they are a recognised toy manufacturer, who I guess don't usually show porn to kids."

Hasbro was unavailable for comment.

webTitle: Channel 5 films Ugly models

fields.headline: Ugly models take to the catwalk in Channel 5 film
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Channel 5 has ordered a documentary about the Ugly model agency, whose clients include TFI Friday's Ugly Bloke Del, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 5 has ordered a documentary about the Ugly model agency, whose clients include former TFI Friday Ugly Bloke Del.

The 60-minute documentary about the London-based talent agency specialising in grotesque and unusual looking people is being made by indie producer Zig Zag Productions.

"Dwarves, people with multiple piercings, gurners, very tall people, very fat people - you name it they've got them," said Danny Fenton, the show's executive producer and Zig Zag managing director.

The documentary has been ordered by Channel 5 senior programme controller Michael Attwell and is due to be transmitted later this year.

Zig Zag is also currently putting the finishing touches to its ITV Spice Girls documentary, which will feature previously unseen footage shot when the group shared a house together before they hit the big time.

The documentary is expected to go out in March, after Popstars has finished its ITV run.

webTitle: Rosie Boycott at the Express

fields.headline: Rosie Boycott: 19 months of turmoil
fields.trailText:
April 1998:
Rosie Boycott resigns as editor of the Independent and Independent on Sunday to edit the Daily Express. Express owner Lord Hollick gives her the mandate to transform the ailing rightwing rag into a leftwing "voice of the new millennium". The Tories think Boycott will become a Labour patsy.
fields.body:
April 1998:
Rosie Boycott resigns as editor of the Independent and Independent on Sunday to edit the Daily Express. Express owner Lord Hollick gives her the mandate to transform the ailing rightwing rag into a leftwing "voice of the new millennium". The Tories think Boycott will become a Labour patsy.

May 1998:
The patsy claims gain credence after Labour is accused of blocking the appointment of Paul Routledge as Express political editor. Alastair Campbell is said to have been "horrified" by the prospect of the off-message hack taking control of the paper's political coverage. Although the appointment is set up by Boycott, commentators point to the fact that Labour pollster Philip Gould co-owns his company with Lord Hollick.

October 1998
"Findusgate" hits Boycott after rotting fish fingers are found hidden in her bathroom. It transpires that former Express hack James Hughes Onslow, who was fired by Boycott, had visited 10 days before saying he was interested in buying her house.

November 1998
Boycott comes under fire for printing a story about Peter Mandelson's "friendship" with a Brazilian student.

January 1999
Amanda Platell, editor of the Express on Sunday, takes the flak for the story and is fired along with associate editor Ian Walker. Platell is now chief press officer for the Tories.

November 1999
Boycott stages a dawn raid on giant rival, the Daily Mail, poaching Alan Titchmarsh. In an even more audacious move, she steals the Daily Mail's star astrologer, Jonathan Cainer, in a staggering £1m deal.

July 2000
Lord Hollick scraps UNM's merger with Carlton Communications. UNM sells its ITV assets to Granada for £1.75bn instead. The Express newspapers are up for sale.

November 2000
Porn publisher and OK! magazine owner Richard Desmond buys the papers for £125m. Boycott loses political editor Anthony Bevins and commentators Stephen Pollard, Mary Kenny and Peter Hitchens.

December 7 2000
Boycott attacks Desmond's "heavy handed" management techniques in a memo widely circulated to staff, after 60 employees are sacked by Desmond.

January 6 2001
Leader writer Stephen Pollard's parting shot is an editorial which contains the hidden message "fuck you, Desmond". Pollard is fired from his new job at the Times before he even starts.

January 25 2001
Boycott bows to the inevitable and quits along with deputy Chris Blackhurst. She writes in a farewell message to staff: "Dear all, We're leaving the Express in the next few minutes and we wanted to say goodbye and many thanks to all our wonderful colleagues. We're hugely proud of what we have all achieved. We know we will see many of you in the future and we wish everyone the very best of luck. Best wishes to you all, Rosie and Chris."

webTitle: Just Williams

fields.headline: Just Williams
fields.standfirst: Rosie Boycott's successor as editor of the Daily Express has an unenviable task, but the fact that Chris Williams is a virtual unknown, seen by some as a laid-back lightweight, makes his job even harder, says  Roy Greenslade
fields.trailText: Rosie Boycott's successor as editor of the Daily Express has an unenviable task, but the fact that Chris Williams is a virtual unknown, seen by some as a laid-back lightweight, makes his job even harder, says Roy Greenslade
fields.body:
Farewell then, Rosie Boycott, and hello Chris Williams. Who? It's easy, and unfair, to make jokes about the new editor of the Daily Express having risen without trace. He doesn't arrive in the job with the high public profile of Boycott or Janet Street-Porter.

He has not made his name as a writer, in the mould of Piers Morgan. He hasn't even won the kind of reputation within the industry, gained on their way up, by the likes of Paul Dacre and Simon Kelner.

Williams is from an altogether different tradition, a man who has risen to the bridge from the engine room, gradually earning the respect of colleagues and executives for his tech nical abilities. It is hardly an unknown route to the top. Until the past dozen years or so, most editors of popular papers emerged from the subbing desk, including the Express's most famous past editor, Arthur Christiansen.

I have known Williams for about 20 years, from the time our paths crossed briefly at the Express, when I quickly realised, to use Fleet Street parlance, that he was a good operator. He could sub fluently, wrote headlines with ease, designed pages without fuss and, most important of all, he could visualise how a story or feature should be projected.

Boycott and her deputy, Chris Blackhurst, always acknowledged his importance to the paper. "They had the ideas and he executed them," said one senior staffer. "He was terrific at the nuts and bolts, at production, at getting the paper out."

Doubtless, Williams would regard this as being damned with faint praise. It suggests that he is "only" a technician and therefore devoid of the ideas - the campaigns, investigations and story hunches - that give every paper its distinctive feel. If Williams is to disprove this insistent criticism from his detractors in the coming months he will need to graft proactive journalistic enterprise on to his undoubted reactive skills.

Now 49, he has recently married, for the second time. He and his wife, Daily Mail sub Judy Bywater, have a five-month-old daughter, Alice. Williams started his career on weekly newspapers in his native Liverpool. A life-long Everton supporter, he had youthful hopes himself of becoming a professional footballer, almost signing for a non-league team.

After two years on Merseyside, he did a similar stint on weeklies in Kent before joining the subs desk at the Press Association in 1971, which included a spell as a parliamentary reporter. Six years later, he went to the Daily Express, then selling 2.4m under the editorship of Derek Jameson.

Four more editors came and went as he rose through the subbing ranks to become features editor, a key role. He was then seduced by a good offer from David English to join the Daily Mail, as assistant features editor, in 1989.

By now Williams was a seasoned executive, confident in his abilities and happy in his skin. He was renowned for his rather laid-back attitude, smiling while others panicked, refusing to shout and scream in time-honoured fashion. At the Mail, this lack of hustle and bustle suggested a lack of commitment. Some senior staff, particularly his later editor, Paul Dacre, were upset by Williams's apparent languor.

They were particularly irritated by his habit of keeping his jacket on in the office because it suggested he wasn't taking the job seriously. One of his best friends on the Mail told me he also walked around the office "as if on an afternoon stroll", which tended to infuriate executives raised to produce a paper in a frenetic atmosphere. "In truth," said another Mail chum, "he could do the job easily, without breaking sweat, and saw no reason to get steamed up."

Fearing that he had gone as far up the Mail hierarchy as possible, he returned to the Express in 1995, becoming one of the former Mail boss Richard Addis's key lieutenants as the paper's number three. When Addis was fired in April 1998 in favour of Boycott, the latter decided to replace every one of Addis's senior team with her own appointees. Williams was given notice but he questioned the decision, and Boycott relented after discovering his good reputation among other production journalists.

As the only senior Addis executive to survive the putsch, he was always regarded by Boycott and Blackhurst as rather semi-detached. There were often rumours of him bad-mouthing Boycott, accusations that were never proved. He took such pains to appear supportive of Boycott that there was barely a cross word between them in three years.

He did not share her news agenda nor her liberal politics. Indeed, though he is reputed to be "a consummate office politician", he has shown almost no interest in Westminster politics or international affairs. When he edited the paper, usually on a Sunday, political staff found it difficult to interest him in their stories. "He's very good on show business and the lighter stuff," said one of his former colleagues. "He can handle serious stories, but it's not what moves him."

He is sometimes mistaken for Max Clifford - they have a similar mass of snowy hair - and several Express journalists expect him to introduce more entertainment. That would probably chime with the aspi rations of the owner, Richard Desmond.

In his negotiations with Desmond, Williams showed that, behind his lackadaisical mask, there is consid erable steel. He refused to accept a position as "acting" editor, demanding the full title instead. It's to be hoped that he has secured a legally watertight contract because - whatever Williams' skills - the future for the paper looks anything but bright.

Sales are falling by the week, and I wouldn't be surprised if the Express finds if difficult to stay above the 1m mark in the next month or so.

As if the chalice isn't poisoned enough, Williams will also soon be expected to make up to 100 of his journalists redundant. That may not happen until March, the deadline for a Department of Trade and Industry referral of Desmond's takeover of Express Newspapers to the competition commission. Williams has certainly got the toughest job in Fleet Street just now.

webTitle: Unilever plans Dove shop chain

fields.headline: Unilever plans Dove-branded shops
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Soap giant Unilever is hatching plans for a chain of beauty shops under the Dove name, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Soap giant Unilever is drawing up plans for a chain of beauty outlets under the Dove brand name.

The move follows the success of its Lynx-branded barber shops.

The first Lynx barber shop was launched last October on London's Oxford Street.

A second shop will open in Kingston-on-Thames this month and the company is looking at further sites across the country.

The innovative move contributed to a revival of the Lynx brand, which now has a 30% share of the male toiletries market.

According to independent industry figures, the Lynx brand was worth £80m last year in the UK alone.

Now, Unilever is planning to replicate its Lynx success with its Dove line of moisturising soaps and skincare products.

The plans are at an early stage but are thought to involve a new health and beauty retail brand.

Taking your brand onto the high street has become the latest marketing tool, with Cadbury and Kenco launching branded cafes.

Women's magazine Cosmopolitan is also hoping to introduce a chain of cafes called Cosmopolitan Life.

A spokesman for Unilever said she was unaware of any such plans.

webTitle: The paydays go on at Equitable

fields.headline: The paydays go on at Equitable
fields.standfirst: As a break-up of the business beckons, Equitable Life's salespeople are still drawing six-figure salaries, despite the crisis facing the insurer's policyholders. David Prosser reports
fields.trailText: Equitable Life, the insurer which closed to new business after a House of Lords legal judgement left it with liabilities of £1.5bn, is stuck with paying its top salesmen six-figure salaries, it has emerged.
fields.body:
Equitable Life, the insurer which closed to new business after a House of Lords legal judgement left it with liabilities of £1.5bn, is stuck with paying its top salesmen six-figure salaries, it has emerged.

Though the sales team is no longer able to bring in new business, the insurer has little choice but to spend yet more cash on retaining them until it can sell off the division.

Equitable's sales team includes some of the highest paid advisers in the financial services sector, partly because the provider has never paid its staff commission. It therefore had to pay salaries which were well above average for the industry.

When the insurer put itself up for sale last summer, it promised to keep paying its salesforce their usual salaries, and promised additional bonuses in February 2002 in order to lock them in until a buyer was found.

However, now that all buyers have pulled out of taking the insurer on as a going concern, Equitable is selling off its constituent businesses, including its asset management and sales teams. The latter are continuing to receive their old salaries because Equitable dares not risk losing salesmen.

Departures would dilute the value of the sales team. Equitable spokesman Nigel Webb argues: 'We put in the retention package because we felt it was important to keep the salesforce together. That's why we have an arrangement in place so that they're maintaining their income.'

Stuart Bayliss, co-ordinator of the Equitable Life Action Group, which has campaigned on behalf of Equitable members, says he believes the payments are acceptable if they help to secure a good price when the insurer disposes of its sales arm.

'I know they're working very hard at selling off the salesforce and I suppose they justify it on that basis,' he says.

The with-profits policyholders hit by Equitable's problems will also lose out - their fund shares in the financial fortunes of the insurer.

In the meantime, with-profits policyholders at the insurer continue to face a difficult decision. Investors with policies close to maturity are unlikely to have time to recover this money from better returns at another provider. The decision is finely balanced for investors with policies some way off maturity too.

Moreover, the pressure on policyholders will increase over time. The longer Equitable is unable to secure agreed disposals of its business, the more likely it is other insurers and fund managers will attempt to poach its best customers - particularly large pension schemes. This could be to the detriment of other customers, including some individual policyholders

webTitle: Whitehall email warning after attack on comedian

fields.headline: Whitehall email warning after attack on comedian
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Civil servants are being warned to be more cautious with their emails following a row over an alleged smear campaign against Channel 4 comedian Mark Thomas, report Rob Evans and David Hencke.
fields.body:
Civil servants are being warned to be more cautious in writing and distributing their emails following a row over an alleged smear campaign against Channel 4 comedian Mark Thomas, a new leaked memo has disclosed.

A senior mandarin admits the discomfort of the Department of Trade and Industry after an internal email had revealed the "damaging news" that Richard Caborn, one of its ministers, had apparently instructed officials to dig up dirt to rubbish Thomas. But Mr Caborn denied that he had sought to smear the radical comedian and instead an unnamed official was reprimanded for misinterpreting the minister's wishes.

In other emails, officials had described Thomas as a "prat" and an "out and out nutter". The string of emails had been released to the comedian after he requested them under the Data Protection Act.

The secret memo, to be aired in Thomas's C4 programme on Wednesday, shows how a nervous Whitehall has reacted to protect itself against the act.

According to the memo, Sir Michael Scholar, the most senior DTI mandarin, and his officials "had tried to find ways to avoid" disclosing the emails to Thomas, but had concluded that they had to divulge them under the act.

Sir Michael sounded a warning to his colleagues at a meeting of top civil servants from each Whitehall department two days after the emails were disclosed in the Guardian.

He told the meeting that Thomas had "evidently" submitted a request to every government department to release their documents on him under the act.

"This made it all the more important to be careful in the way in which we write and share email material within government.

"It is of course a much more informal medium than minuting and letters, akin to telephone conversations, but unlike phone calls is recorded and disclosable [under the act]."

The following day, this warning was circulated widely within the upper echelons of the Ministry of Defence by Kevin Tebbit, the department's permanent secretary, in the leaked memo.

He expected further requests from Thomas and others under the act and wanted to ensure that his staff realised that their emails could be divulged for all to read.
