webTitle: Monday briefing

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: A pre-election tax cutting bonanza appears to be off the agenda as a softening British economy and an acceleration in spending on public services puts the squeeze on the size of the Treasury surplus.
fields.body:
Observer

A pre-election tax cutting bonanza appears to be off the agenda as a softening British economy and an acceleration in spending on public services puts the squeeze on the size of the Treasury surplus.

Although final figures will still hand Gordon Brown a surplus of many billions, its size is expected to be far closer to the existing Treasury predictions of £10bn than the over-optimistic predictions by City analysts at the time of November's pre-Budget report.

Water regulator Philip Fletcher is expected to agree to controversial proposals for restructuring Welsh Water - formerly owned by the multi-utility Hyder - but he is likely to attach onerous conditions to the deal.

Industry and regulatory sources say that Mr Fletcher is sceptical about the proposals and claim his conditions may make the scheme unviable.

Sunday Times

Corporate Britain is on the brink of crisis. The latest statistics about profit warnings show that there has been more than one warning a day since the beginning of the year and this trend is predicted to continue for months to come.

The gloomy outlook comes as Ernst & Young, one of the "big five" accountancy companies, prepares to issue its latest quarterly profits warning statistics. It will reveal that there were nearly 80 profits warnings in the final quarter of 2000, a rise of 70% since the summer.

The plans to merge Abbey National and Bank of Scotland have run into trouble. The two institutions are at loggerheads over the location of the new bank's headquarters. Disquiet over the division of management jobs has also emerged - despite an earlier private agreement on these fundamental issues.

Sunday Telegraph

Sir CK Chow, below, is preparing to step down as chief executive of GKN as part of the engineering group's reorganisation plans. He is planning to become chief executive of Brambles, the Australian industrial services group which has a number of joint ventures with GKN.

Hans Rausing, the former chief executive of Tetra Pak and the richest man in Britain, has emerged from apparent retirement to galvanise the packaging industry he once dominated.

Mr Rausing has taken a controlling interest in EcoLean, the creator of an environmentally friendly packaging material made from plastic and chalk.

BT is preparing to demerge Yell, its directories business, to shareholders as an alternative to its £4bn to £5bn flotation plan. The group is considering proposals to load Yell with up to £1bn in debt - which would be roughly equivalent to the proceeds after tax from floating 25% of the shares on the stock market.

Mail on Sunday

The Post Office is to offer cut-price stakeholder pensions at its 18,000 branches from April. The initiative - due to be announced on February 6 - is a coup for the Post Office, which is still buoyant after a deal with banks to sell no-frills accounts.

IoS

Alchemy, the venture capitalist which last year attempted to buy Rover, is close to losing one of its biggest investors, JP Morgan. The private equity arm of JP Morgan Chase, the American investment bank, has decided to cease investing in Alchemy in a move that will come as a blow to Jon Moulton, the venture capital firm's high profile deal maker.

Sunday Business

BT's biggest investors will this week urge the company to rethink its strategy and opt for a complete break-up. Instead of partial spin-offs of its businesses such as Wireless and Yell, the company will be urged to consider demerging entire operating subsidiaries.

Anxiety is growing among European retailers and bankers that there will be serious problems when euro notes and coins are introduced next January, according to analysts at investment bank Nomura.

BA may buy Air France's Concorde fleet if the French airline decides not to return the supersonic airliner to commercial service.

webTitle: British business growth slows but firms keep calm

fields.headline: Growth slows but firms keep calm
fields.trailText: The outlook for British business is looking increasingly difficult amid mounting worries about the impact of a slowdown in the United States and evidence of falling profitability.
fields.body:
The outlook for British business is looking increasingly difficult amid mounting worries about the impact of a slowdown in the United States and evidence of falling profitability.

But despite the gathering clouds, business confidence remains relatively robust, according to survey evidence published today.

In its latest survey, the Institute of Directors said the economy was still expanding but that growth over the last three quarters had been slower. "The deterioration in the indicators for manufacturing for the fourth quarter was more marked than for the economy as a whole," the IoD said.

The head of the institute's policy unit, Ruth Lea, said that despite the slowdown "most indicators were reasonably favourable". The IoD was "cautiously optimistic" that the US economy would avoid a hard landing. "Meanwhile a growing Euroland and a modestly stronger euro should support growth here," said Ms Lea.

A survey of more than 1,000 managers by Dun & Bradstreet found that business confidence was still high. "With nearly six out of 10 businesses across the country expecting to increase sales and nearly half expecting to increase profits and new orders, economic confidence remains buoyant," according to D&B's senior analyst Philip Mellor.

However, a report published by Ernst & Young, one of the big five accountancy firms, shows profits warnings are on the increase. In the fourth quarter of last year, the report reveals, 77 profits warnings were issued by UK-listed companies, a 4% rise on the previous quarter, which itself had shown a significant 64% rise.

For the fourth quarter in succession, the software and computer services sector generated the largest number of warnings, accounting for 22% of the total.

There was also a rise in the number of repeat warnings, with 21 of last quarter's warning companies already having issued one or more alerts during the course of 2000.

The report also suggests that the effects of the US economic slowdown are starting to be felt by UK companies, with 14% of warning companies citing poor American sales as affecting their profits in the fourth quarter.

Meanwhile business information group Experian said that corporate profitability in Britain was already on the wane. The average return on capital fell to 12.48% in the year to the end of June, compared with a peak of 14.18% in the 12 months to March 1999 - and has fallen for five consecutive quarters.

"This is the longest sustained period of declining profitability since the last recession," said Experian's Peter Brooker.

webTitle: Forced marriage in Pakistan

fields.headline: 'I was sold to a man ... is this Islam?'
fields.standfirst:
Pakistan's military ruler has failed to combat the murder of women who resist forced marriages

Special report: Pakistan
fields.trailText: Pakistan's military ruler has failed to combat the murder of women who resist forced marriages
fields.body:
Shehnaz Akhtar did not want to marry her cousin. But a woman of 25 from a poor family living deep in the Punjabi farmlands of Pakistan is rarely allowed to choose her husband.

This month her parents decided she must marry Tajammul, a relative she knew but did not like, who was willing to pay 20,000 rupees (£250) for their daughter. Shehnaz was forced to sign the marriage certificate, but in secret she wrote a letter begging the high court in Lahore for help.

"In the days before Islam girls were buried alive, now they are sold like sheep and goats," she wrote. "I have been sold to a man I never wanted to live with. What kind of Islam is this?

"I am a very unlucky woman who has been thrown to the wolves. My marriage was cruel and arbitrary."

Exceptionally, Judge Khawaja Sharif agreed, and last week he ordered armed police to take Shehnaz from her family home to a refuge for women. "Marriage cannot be imposed on an adult woman against her free will," he said.

In much of Pakistan, marriage clearly is imposed on women against their will. Those brave enough to complain to the courts or run from their homes are hunted down by their families and forced to return or, all too frequently, murdered to restore a distorted sense of honour. The police usually turn a blind eye.

Honour killings

General Pervez Musharraf, the army chief who seized power 15 months ago, promised to end to these "honour killings." Yet in the past year the number reported in the Punjab alone jumped from 432 to more than 500.

"Women are treated as property and there is a perception that honour stems from the woman in the household," said Kamila Hyat, joint director of the Human Rights Commission of Pakistan.

"Gen Musharraf may genuinely believe this shouldn't happen, but he has shown no clear will to stop it. He needs to change tradition, and tradition is one of the hardest things to change."

Shehnaz is apart from her husband now, but her new life is far from ideal and she remains in considerable danger.

The judge sent her to Dar-ul Aman, a privately owned, rundown refuge in Lahore where 75 women live behind locked, steel gates, unable to leave the compound and in constant fear of their families' vengeance. Shehnaz is not allowed visitors, apart from her lawyer, and she and the other women seem to be mainly confined to their rooms. Husbands, fathers and male cousins gather menacingly by the gate.

"The inmates don't like to leave this institution, because their lives are in danger," said Zubaida Khatoon, who supervises the shelter. "If they leave people may murder them."

Some human rights workers are very concerned about this and seven government-run shelters in Punjab. "They call it a shelter, but it is actually like a prison," Ms Hyat said. More than 700 women have passed through the grey metal gates of Dar-ul Aman in the past year.

Despite some previous court rulings similar to the one in Shehnaz's case, support for women who escape brutal marriages is still limited.

Another victim, Tahira Bibi, believes she can live in safety only if she leaves the country. After her first husband died 15 years ago her parents forced her into three engagements. Each time the selected groom paid her family, once with land and twice with 15,000 rupees (£190) in cash, before her parents broke the engagement off.

Then, at the age of 35, Tahira Bibi fell in love with a school tutor, and married him, against her parents' wishes. "My brother and my cousin kidnapped me and tortured me for two months. They hit me with a stick. Then they forced my husband to sign divorce papers," she said.

Now she lives with 34 women in Dastak, a shelter set up in a secret location in Lahore by Pakistan's most prominent sisters, the human rights workers Hina Jilani and Asma Jehangir.

Beatings

Many of the women need medical care and psychological counselling, but they are free to leave the house by day to work or shop for their children, if they wish.

One woman, Razia, was forced into a marriage when she was 13 and regularly beaten and locked in a room by her husband. "He said if I told anyone he would kill me," she said.

After a beating late one night she broke down, poured kerosene over her head and set herself alight. "I felt that death was better than this life," she said. Her husband quickly divorced her and married again.

Pit your wits against the experts by giving the most accurate forecast in six areas of the economy - growth, interest rates, inflation, unemployment, the current account and the exchange rate.

You should answer the following questions: what will the increase in gross domestic product be in 2001; what will the Bank of England's base lending rate be on December 31; what will the level of inflation - excluding mortgage interest payments - be on December 31; what will the unemployment total as measured by the seasonally adjusted claimant count be on December 2001; what will the UK current account be in 2001 - in pounds not as a percentage of GDP - and what will sterling's value against the euro be on December 31 - that is, how much one euro will buy?

Entries are welcome from all those who fancy themselves as an economics pundit. Previous years have shown that a sixth-former is as likely to win as a City analyst. The prize is £500 worth of book tokens from leading publisher Palgrave. Answers on a postcard to: Guardian Economics Competition, Economics Desk, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

You can also enter via:
Predict the future of the economy

Online entries will also be in the running to win a Palgrave economics dictionary. Guardian competition rules apply, and the deadline for entries is February 1.

webTitle: The grand design of globalisation needs strategy

fields.headline: Opening gambit without strategy
fields.standfirst: Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Everybody in Davos knows that there is a problem with globalisation. Things aren't working out the way they were supposed to when the grand design was outlined at the start of the 90s.
fields.body:
First, the good news. Everybody in Davos knows that there is a problem with globalisation. Things aren't working out the way they were supposed to when the grand design was outlined at the start of the 90s. There's a bit more humility and a greater willingness to accept that those who have been warning about the nasty side-effects of one size fits all integration might have a point.

Klaus Schwab, the man behind the World Economic Forum, neatly summed the state of play when he said there were seven challenges of globalisation, none of which seemed the slightest bit controversial. Schwab's list of problems is worth considering, because it could be considered the modern equivalent of the five giants identified by Beveridge as standing in the way of progress when he was writing his report on the need for a cradle to grave welfare state in 1942.

First on Schwab's list came the need to create conditions for faster growth. Then he cited the need for environmental and social sustainablility, followed by effective international peace keeping, a narrowing of the technological and social gulf between rich and poor, the need for higher standards of health and nutrition, a common understanding of human rights and values and, finally, the safeguarding of cultural identity in an increasingly homogenised world. Or, in the lingo of Beveridge, Want, Pollution, War, Ignorance, Disease, Cruelty and Uniformity.

The immediate riposte to Schwab's list is that this is a case of motherhood and apple pie. But this has not always been so, even in the recent past. The idea that globalisation has no future without greater inclusion, without environmental sustainability and without a concern for the human dimension, was certainly not in evidence in the first few years after the Berlin Wall came down. But life has moved on. The climate is not so benign and the Lyndon Johnson principle is now at work: it's better to have the protestors inside the tent pissing out than on the outside pissing in.

So, that's the good news. What's the bad news? Well, the fact that Davos was turned into a fortress at the weekend is symptomatic of some deeper malaise. Civil society representatives who were invited to take part in the World Economic Forum were rightly concerned about the way in which the Swiss government treated those who sought to express their concerns about globalisation in a peaceful way on the town's streets.

What this means, of course, is that getting the rhetoric right is one thing, changing behaviour is quite another. It's easy to make all the right noises about making globalisation inclusive, but what does this mean when the rich countries of the world are spending $1bn a day subsidising their farmers, with the annual subsidy three times as large as the entire amount spent on aid budgets? Not a lot...

How much credence should we give to those who argue that free trade will work for everyone when the modest if welcome plan by the EU's trade commissioner, Pascal Lamy, to give duty free access to all goods except arms from the 48 poorest countries was met with a barrage of protectionist objections from the big barons of the European sugar industry? Not a great deal. How genuine is the commitment to tackling the epidemic of HIV-Aids in Africa when the big drugs companies use their enormous financial and legal clout to prevent poor countries from manufacturing their own cheap generic cures? You tell me.

Moving from words to action is going to be tough. Playing chess is not simply about knowing that a bishop moves diagonally or that a pawn can move forward two squares on its first move, it is about the overall strategy. Sometimes a tactical retreat paves the way for a strategic advance. The good player also knows when to make a sacrifice.

Those running the global economy appear to lack the grand master strategy. They have all their pieces but don't know how to play the game. The chaotic state of Russia in its first decade after the collapse of communism is largely due to the ill-conceived sequencing of moves, with privatisation and the scrapping of foreign exchange controls leading to larceny and capital flight on a grand scale. The economy halved in size in a decade; male life expectancy dropped by 10 years.

China, by contrast, has followed a more cautious approach, liberalising selectively and at its own pace; more people have been lifted out of poverty in the past 20 years than at any time in human history.

The key to a successful strategy is getting the sequencing right. Higher growth in developing countries is not just a question of them opening their markets and liberalising their capital accounts - indeed, these policies may be more of a hindrance than a help. These should be final moves in the chess game rather than the opening gambits. Instead, they need debt cancellation, better access to the rich markets of the north and an increase in aid.

Yashwant Sinha, the finance minister of India, said that nobody in developing countries challenged the inevitability or the potential benefits of globalisation, but that the rich countries needed to learn some facts of life.

Firstly, it was impossible to achieve globalisation in an unequal world. Secondly, the problems of the environment were not caused by consumption patterns in the south but by the lifestyles of people in the north, and developing countries were unwilling to listen to sermons about sustainability from those doing most of the global polluting. Finally, the west needed to do something about its skewed approach to migration since the system involved poaching the brightest and the best from poor countries and putting up barriers to the rest. According to Mr Sinha, 38% of all doctors in the US are Indians, as are 34% of the scientists at Nasa.

The real question is whether the west, which is so keen on telling poor countries what to do, is capable of change itself. It's easy, at this point, to look at the way the Americans scuppered the climate talks in the Hague last year and give up. Yet, as the debt campaign showed, it is possible to force change even against the most implacable of opponents, provided that economics plays second fiddle to politics.

The renaissance of politics has perhaps been the most important development of the past few years. It is now clear that the future of the planet cannot be entrusted to the divine workings of the market or left in the hands of corporations. There are choices to be made, and they are political choices.

But isn't it a problem that governments tend to listen to the voices of business, rather than civil society? You bet it is. In the shorthand of the modern world, business is seen as dynamic, civil society as conservative. But as Ed Mayo of the New Economics Foundation said in Davos this weekend, nearly all the great leaps forward for mankind have been as a result of pressure from civil society. If governments are looking for creativity, enterprise and innovation, then historically they should look beyond the boardroom.

Unfortunately, recapturing politics may be a long, slow process. The historian Paul Kennedy said that he was now insisting that all his students at Harvard study the great leaders of the past so they would be able to think strategically when they took up their positions at the head of the global elite of the future. This is sensible stuff. Our technical ability to make things and to pollute now far outstrips our ability to understand the processes we have unleashed. The idea that schools should be teaching philosophy and ethics may seem laughable. Actually, if we are to have any hope of a long term future, it is essential.

webTitle: NY mayor calls on BAA to run airports

fields.headline: NY mayor calls on BAA to run airports
fields.trailText: New York's mayor, Rudy Giuliani, has called in BAA, the British airports operator, to help the Big Apple out of a crisis in running JFK and La Guardia, the city's two most prestigious airports.
fields.body:
New York's mayor, Rudy Giuliani, has called in BAA, the British airports operator, to help the Big Apple out of a crisis in running JFK and La Guardia, the city's two most prestigious airports.

BAA confirmed it had been asked by the mayor to provide management advice on the airports. The mayor and the two airports' operators have been locked in a bitter dispute over how they should be run.

The UK firm said that it was still negotiating terms but that no deal was likely to be struck for some months. It said if it secured the deal, it would be bidding for the full management contract when it comes up for renegotiation in 2015. The airports are at present operated by the Port Authority of New York and Jersey, but the mayor has been involved in a legal battle for control that has so far cost the city £150m.

BAA said that if successful, it would have to give up its retail franchise at New York's third airport, Newark.

"This is a very significant contract for us and will place us in the forefront of one of the world's leading airport operators," a spokeswoman said.

The port authority says that it is overseeing a £6bn rebuilding of the three New York airports, including new terminals and a train from the city to JFK.

webTitle: Leadership is more than skin deep

fields.headline: Leadership is more than skin deep
fields.trailText: A woman heading up the London Stock Exchange for the first time shows the world of business is changing. But not quick enough for Hilarie Owen, a management specialist who is to launch the Institute of Leadership on Wednesday.
fields.body:
A woman heading up the London Stock Exchange for the first time shows the world of business is changing. But not quick enough for Hilarie Owen, a management specialist who is to launch the Institute of Leadership on Wednesday.

Ms Owen says British companies are being held back by conservative thinking at senior level but adds that poor leadership is rife throughout the corporate structure.

"The old perception of leadership whereby one person - usually a man - fixes everything until he fails and then is pulled down, needs to change. This is seen in the US, where the average life of a chief executive is two years."

Ms Owen believes that companies should put emphasis on and commit time to finding leadership qualities inside their staff, and move away from hierarchical structures.

Marks & Spencer seems an example of what can go wrong. Its deteriorating financial performance has been linked by some to its authoritarian management patterns.

Ms Owen says: "A staff member was rapped on the knuckles after he tried to change a system. He had noticed that customers were getting annoyed with queuing and did something to help, but without the relevant authority."

Ms Owen believes that Asda's inclusive style is the pattern that should be followed. But apart from a small computer services company in Southampton, 2GL, she struggles to think of British companies which are moving in the right direction.

Staff at 2GL start arriving at 7.30am, not because they have to but because they are enthused by what is going on. They are encouraged to participate in community projects and identify with the goals of the company, she says. Tesco and Royal Bank of Scotland deserve mentions, she says, the latter because of the work being done at its call centre in Bristol. "These can be bad places to work, but the manager won a leadership award because he produced a happy atmosphere where the employees felt valued."

Ms Owen says companies who ignore workforce potential will have to change or pay the price. The recent defection of Asda boss Allan Leighton suggests even the forward-thinking companies have more work to do in this area.

But how will the institute help? It hopes to act as a focal point and a catalyst for change. The non-profit making organisation, where Ms Owen will act as founder and chief executive, expects next month to launch a United Nations-funded initiative as well as working with organisations such as the Institute of Directors on leadership training programmes.

Ms Owen describes herself as "an ordinary Cardiff girl", who in 30 years has gone from impoverished beautician to much sought-after management consultant.

She left a broken home at the age of 16 and studied politics to degree level in Plymouth before going on to work with US computer group IBM.

She has seen the worst impact of autocratic management at close quarters working for the Maxwell Corporation. She has also had a taste of the public sector when helping the Department of Trade and Industry launch its enterprise initiative.

But the big change came in 1991, when she attended a business breakfast given by the team manager of the RAF Red Arrows. "He talked about how formation flying was like driving at 200mph up the motorway, bumper to bumper with eight other cars. I realised the power that came from that level of trust.

"At the end of the talk I thrust my card in his hand and said, 'ring me, I have an idea'. A month later I was making a video and carrying out research on Red Arrows leadership style".

It eventually resulted in a well received book from Ms Owen titled Creating Top Flight Teams. Next month Ms Owen will release her next tome, Unleashing Leaders, which also touches on the issue of trust.

This key point came up again talking to a seminar of top ranking policemen on leadership issues. "I told them if they wanted to move forward they had to trust their staff and trust each other. When I asked the room if they trusted each other now, they all shook their heads." Ms Owen quotes TV chat show host Oprah Winfrey, saying how good it felt to talk openly about her private life. Oprah found her trust was rewarded by journalists warming to this newly exposed humanity.

"Her openness and honesty enabled viewers to relate to the woman," says the author.

Ms Owen herself is not always so trusting it seems - at least in one to one interviews. A request for her age does not go down well.

Nor even a question about what car she drives. She is clearly much more at home on the conference podium or in seminars.

John Weston, a director at the IoD, describes her as "dynamic", and says the work she is doing is "crucial" for British business.

It can be easier at first glance to see the beautician rather than an expert on leadership.

But then that's one of her points. Old stereotypes should be cast aside.

webTitle: Internet service providers examined

fields.headline: The great provider lets us down again
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: If you are an internet business your internet service provider is a "mission-critical" partner. At a basic level, it means that if its service goes down, your service goes down. This week the co-founders of Rools turn their attention to ISPs.
fields.body:
The new economy seems a lot like the old when you are part of it. Last week, we focused on the internet-specific pain suffered in trying to manage domain names. This week, our attention turns to internet service providers.

If you are an internet business your ISP is a "mission-critical" partner. It's the ISP that hosts the site and provides the connection between your expensive hardware and the internet. Revenues and business credibility are hugely dependent on this service. At a basic level, it means that if its service goes down, your service goes down.

Playing it safe, we chose a supplier that is one of the leading providers in Europe. Unfortunately, our system has been unavailable three times, for periods of up to two hours a time, in the last three weeks alone.

Around 1% down time for the period may not sound too bad, but it is significantly below that which we expect and which we want to offer to our own customers. But the most galling factor in the three failures of service is that it has been caused by the same fault on each occasion.

It appears that rather than spend time fixing the underlying fault correctly, the engineers, who may well be overworked, patch it up with a temporary fix. Most ISPs run a queueing system, so that you will rarely have the same engineer working on your problem. This lack of proper service over time means that a temporary fix simply becomes another engineer's problem at a later date.

The level of performance that we have received has been shocking.

It "amuses" one of our business advisers, a senior analyst at a US bank, who is regularly on the receiving end of rather more positive and impressive reviews of company performance and customer satisfaction from the very same ISP.

Can we name and shame our ISP? Our experience, it seems, is not unique, and naming would serve little purpose. Like us, it appears that many of our peers suffer at the hands of their ISP and that poor customer service is common within that sector. The bottom line for us is that there is no guarantee that by switching to another provider we will receive a better level of service.

Meanwhile, we will be seeking a substantial rebate on the costly fees that we pay to our supplier.

It will not have a direct impact on their healthy stock price or sales pitches, but it may help them focus their attention on delivering what they have promised.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of Rools, a service allowing teenagers to shop online

webTitle: Arkansas firm rescued Huntingdon Life Sciences

fields.headline: Little Rock firm with Clinton links rescued HLS
fields.standfirst: US rm extended £10m loan
fields.trailText: A family controlled, Arkansas-based investment firm with close links to the former Clinton administration has emerged as the "secret" rescuer of Huntingdon Life Sciences, the controversial animal testing company.
fields.body:
A family controlled, Arkansas-based investment firm with close links to the former Clinton administration has emerged as the "secret" rescuer of Huntingdon Life Sciences, the controversial animal testing company.

Stephens Group, which has its headquarters in Little Rock, has extended a long term loan of about £10m to Huntingdon, replacing credit facilities cancelled by Royal Bank of Scotland last week.

Huntingdon's chief executive, Brian Cass, yesterday said: "Yes, it is Stephens.

"They've been shareholders for a couple of years and we've got to know them quite well.

"We're obviously delighted that they've shown confidence in the business by offering extra backing."

Although little known in Britain, Stephens Group is one of the biggest US investment firms outside New York.

The company manages funds of more than $1.6bn (£1bn). Over the last 10 years, Stephens' investments have included buying the US's largest operator of nursing homes, a waste incinerator in Massachusetts, local newspapers in Las Vegas and a management company with clients including Burt Reynolds.

The protest group, Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty, recently met executives from Stephens in New York in attempt to persuade the firm to sever its ties with Huntingdon.

Greg Avery, the group's co-ordinator, said: "There will be no more talking with Stephens. It is war against Stephens. We will show we can damage them."

Stephens recently recruited General Wesley Clark, the former supreme commander of Nato, as a consultant on hi-tech investments.

The firm helped Bill Clinton with some last-minute fundraising before his election victory in 1992, and Hillary Clinton has represented the group in legal battles.

Stephens has courted controversy before - the firm was investigated by the Federal Reserve in 1993 over whether it had contravened laws governing the ownership of banks. Stephens subsequently sold its controlling stake in the bank concerned - the Worthing Banking Corporation.

In addition to providing a loan, Stephens has paid back Huntingdon's borrowing of about £10m to two US banks. Mr Cass refused to comment on a report that the Bank of Scotland had written off its £11.6m loan by selling it to Stephens for £1.

Stephens has a policy of active involvement in the management of companies. Mr Cass said: "They have been interested in our business, but never interfering or anything less than supportive."

The Cambridgeshire firm has been besieged by protests since errant employees were filmed mistreating animals three years ago. The company's management has since changed, and has attracted support from the government and the drugs industry.

webTitle: The future of abortion in America

fields.headline: Back to the back alley
fields.standfirst:
Last Monday was George Bush's first day in office. It also just happened to be the 28th anniversary of the Supreme Court ruling that gave American women the right to abortion. Katie Roiphe reports from New York on how the president marked the day

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Last Monday was George Bush's first day in office. It also just happened to be the 28th anniversary of the Supreme Court ruling that gave American women the right to abortion. Katie Roiphe reports from New York on how the president marked the day.
fields.body:
In George Bush's gorgeously written inauguration speech about "a single nation bound by ideals", it was not at all clear that the very next business day, his first executive order would be to block US foreign aid tied to abortion. It was not at all clear that he was going to issue an inflammatory statement, that same day, that "the promises of our Declaration of Independence are not just for the strong, the independent or the healthy. They are for everyone, including unborn children"; a statement that went on to say: "Every person, at every stage and season of life, is created equal in God's image." His first day in office also happened to be the 28th anniversary of Roe v Wade, the historic Supreme Court judgment that enshrined women's right to abortion. By the end of that day, his rhetoric of healing and unity and bipartisanship had melted away.

But why should this come as a surprise? Many people expected the younger George Bush to be not pro-choice - he is a republican, after all - but somewhat laissez-faire on the issue of abortion. And Bush himself has been spectacularly cagey about reproductive rights. During his campaign, he managed to appease the right wing without completely alienating moderates, emphasising his desire to decrease the number of abortions without directly attacking Roe v Wade. He has been deliberately obscure. (Here is where his lack of verbal skill may serve him well. When he doesn't articulate a definite position on a particular subject, it does not raise any alarms.)

We think of Bush as being unsophisticated about expressing himself. Perhaps he is more sophisticated than anyone has given him credit for. Somehow, by a strange combination of his blundering circumlocutions and his artfully written speeches, he has managed, on the subject of abortion, to give everyone the message they wanted to hear.

And then, to confuse matters more, the day before the inauguration, Laura Bush said on NBC news and the Today show that she did not believe Roe v Wave should be reversed. She had hinted at her leanings in this direction during the campaign but never came right out and said it. Though much of the news media treated this as a spontaneous, independent outburst on the part of the next first lady, this opinion cannot have slipped out. It must have been part of a deliberate strategy. The president elect's wife was being used to soften him. To make the many supporters of Roe v Wade feel comfortable. To reassure them that there is a woman on their side in the White House. Never mind that she will be too busy organising her bookshelves to worry about women's rights.

One of the many failures of the Gore campaign - hardly worth dwelling on now - is that the vice-president did not force Bush to make clear his position on abortion. He did not force Bush to say something really chilling, something that would have made it more difficult for women voters to punch their chads. He did not, in any of the debates, or in any other way, corner Bush on this issue which is so important to so many Americans, and which clearly would have given him the advantage.

One of the reasons Bush got elected (in so far as he did get elected) is that the people in America take Roe v Wade so absolutely for granted. Up until only a few days ago, it seemed impossible that, in our lifetime, a woman's right to a safe, legal abortion could vanish; it seemed alarmist, even slightly hysterical, to think that we could go back to the days when women died after back alley abortions. Even many prominent republican women are pro-choice, such as Christie Todd Whitman and Barbara Bush. The country as a whole is behind a woman's right to choose. But the country was also behind Al Gore and that did not stop the Supreme Court.

There is no ambiguity whatsoever on where Bush's nominee for attorney general, John Ashcroft, stands on abortion. He sponsored a human life amendment to the constitution that would outlaw abortion even in cases of rape and incest. And as senator, he voted for the child custody protection act that would have made it a crime for family members to help teenagers cross state lines to have an abortion.

Women are uncomfortable with Ashcroft. So uncomfortable that his 54-year-old wife, Janet Ashcroft, until recently a law professor at Howard University, felt called upon to reveal that she had been attacked by a rapist years before and that her husband's response to her situation "was exactly the way any woman would want him to respond". His behaviour was "perfect". But that perfection has not reassured. In his long, painful confirmation hearing, Ashcroft declared his intention to uphold the law of the land, including Roe v Wade, but that will not stop him chipping away at it with judicial appointments.

And where is the pro-choice movement? During the past decade, the whole issue has become more complicated. As women have begun to take their reproductive rights for granted, the complexities of abortion have risen to the surface. Debates and ruminations have sprung up where previously there were only posterboard slogans. No more wire hangers. Life begins at birth. When this president came into office, the truisms of the pro-choice movement were in the midst of being honestly examined and knocked around.

The black and whiteness the movement had in its inception has become more subtle and sophisticated. We have begun to examine our own assumptions - something feminists are not prone to do. Even fairly middle of the road, party line feminists, such as Naomi Wolf, have confessed doubts about the ethical difficulties of the subject: is a foetus a life? Is abortion a simple medical procedure like removing an appendix?

Changes in medical technology have also altered the terrain of debate. When one sees a sonogram pasted to a refrigerator, or hears of the survival of a very, very premature baby, one gets a clear sense of life before birth. After 28 years of legal protection, the complexities of the issue have begun to be explored; but now suddenly the moral ambiguities may become luxuries we can no longer afford. We may have to go back. No more wire hangers.

webTitle: Global warming dangers 'buried' in new rankings

fields.headline: Global warming dangers 'buried' in new rankings
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: An attempt by the World Economic Forum to rank countries on an environmental scorecard was dismissed as "global misleadership" by a London-based think tank because the index claims that some of the world's most polluting economies are the most environmentally sustainable.
fields.body:
An attempt by the World Economic Forum to rank countries on an environmental scorecard was dismissed as "global misleadership" by a London-based think tank because the index claims that some of the world's most polluting economies are the most environmentally sustainable.

The forum's first full "environmental sustainability index", published over the weekend, is one of the first to classify 122 countries according to their ability to protect the environment while promoting economic growth. With the exception of Belgium, all the industrialised countries are in the top half of the rankings, with the United States in tenth place and Britain sixteenth.

The New Economics Foundation pointed out that they were in the bottom half of a list of 134 countries ranked according to their carbon dioxide emissions, a key component of global warming.

"The US consumes so many finite natural resources that you could fit the whole of China, India, the Russian Federation and Brazil into its ecological footprint and still have room to spare", the foundation added.

Its deputy director, Alex MacGillivray, said: "I've worked on plenty of indexes in my time, but I've never come across such a blatant effort to bury the most important parameter - global warming - in a morass of irrelevant noise. "The forum's index is being presented as a rigorous tool for policymakers."

One of the report's authors, Daniel Esty, who is the director of Yale University's Centre for Environmental Law and Policy, said: "The index represents a first step toward a new approach to pollution control and natural resource management, with the emphasis on data, facts and analytic rigour rather than emotion and rhetoric." However, the forum's study admits that data is scarce, including "shockingly poor country coverage" of environmental indicators, while economic indicators are more readily available at international level.

webTitle: Grassroots policy for the regions

fields.headline: Grassroots policy for the regions
fields.standfirst:
Special report: north-south divide
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown sets out Labour's second-term plans today for a "bottom-up" regional policy designed to stimulate jobs and innovation in an attempt to woo back disgruntled voters in the government's heartlands.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown sets out Labour's second-term plans today for a "bottom-up" regional policy designed to stimulate jobs and innovation in an attempt to woo back disgruntled voters in the government's heartlands.

With the government fearful of a stay-at-home backlash from traditional supporters at the forthcoming election, Mr Brown will use a speech in Manchester to try to rid Labour of its centralising and London-centred image.

Britain's economic success over the past 10 years has been concentrated in the south, but he will stress the need for "regionally balanced growth, which is essential if there is to be opportunity for all in all regions".

Under plans drawn up with the envrionment secretary John Prescott, the Treasury is boosting spending on regeneration over the next few years in return for hitting stringent performance targets and greater local accountability. Regional development agencies will be given £1.2bn this year, rising to £1.7bn in 2003-2004.

"We are ensuring the resources and flexibilities that RDAs need but in return we are demanding strenuous targets be met in skills, innovation, business creation, new technology and employment", Mr Brown will say.

"This is the new regional policy - locally sensitive and locally delivered, local people meeting local needs through local agencies."

Labour believes the relatively poor performance of the regions is a barrier to its goal of returning to full employment in a second term in office.

However, it has turned its back on the old models of regional policy. Instead it wants to pursue a grassroots approach in which decisions are taken locally and where there is local accountability.

webTitle: Musical to commemorate Irish hunger strikers

fields.headline: Musical stage tribute to H-block hunger strikers
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Twenty years on from the 1981 hunger strike in which 10 IRA and INLA inmates died in the Maze prison, republicans plan to commemorate this pivotal period with an innovative musical drama, which will open in west Belfast this year.
fields.body:
The 1981 hunger strike, in which 10 IRA and INLA inmates died in the H-blocks in the Maze prison, changed Northern Ireland's political landscape for ever.

Now, 20 years on, republicans plan to commemorate this pivotal period with an innovative musical drama, which will open in west Belfast this year.

Laurence McKeown, who is writing the script with Brian Campbell, refused food for 70 days before the strike was called off. The prisoners' demands for special status had not been met but their requests were quietly granted over the next few years.

Prisoner 454, now an established author with a PhD, was 19 when he was jailed for life in 1976 on attempted murder and explosives charges. He believes the younger generation can learn from history told by those who lived it.

The play's title, The Laughter of Our Children, comes from a quote - "and our revenge will be the laughter of our children" - by republican icon Bobby Sands, the first of the hunger strikers to die, shortly after he was elected Sinn Fein MP for Fermanagh/South Tyrone.

But it will focus more on the impact the deaths had on the outside world than on the hunger strikers themselves. It looks at eight characters to show how events affected parents, politicians, clergy, and ordinary people.

"It was a watershed, the start of the whole shift within the republican movement from armed struggle to politics, and it had a huge impact, on society here and internationally," explained Mr McKeown.

"The role of women, mothers, wives, sisters, was paramount, and the hunger strike challenged the dominance of the Catholic church," he said. "There are people who never went back to church because the priest wouldn't allow a hunger striker's coffin draped in the Irish tricolour inside the chapel."

Mr McKeown has drawn on his own vivid memories for the play and a film he is also working on. He says the other hunger strikers' families were consulted and have been supportive.

"Once you put your name down, that was it, you'd made your decision. The IRA army council could choose you at any time. Other people were depending on you," he said.

"Yet my first day on hunger strike was a real anti-climax. People were sweeping out my cell for me as if I'd suddenly lost the power of my limbs but I was just an ordinary person like the day before.

"The H-blocks became my whole world, my comrades were my family. We heard all the news on the radio, everything that was happening on the outside, and yet we were detached from it all, preparing to die, the calm in the eye of the storm."

Mr McKeown, who first collaborated on a book about his experiences in 1994, said republicans were initially shocked at emotive writing about the hunger strike, fearing it betrayed weakness, but he felt the opposite was true.

"There is a saying that the victors write history, but it is more true that outsiders usually write history so it was very important for republicans to write their own," he said.

"We were portrayed by our enemies as men of violence who had somehow turned that violence against ourselves. But we were willing to die for what we believed in, and yes, I would do it again.

"The emotion is a sign of strength."

webTitle: Make-or-break move for trade pact

fields.headline: Make-or-break move for trade pact
fields.standfirst:
World trade organisation shrugs off Seattle debacle and revives talks to save multilateral system
Special report: World Trade Organisation
fields.trailText: The world trade organisation is to to spend the next six months paving the way for the launch of a new round of negotiations this autumn in a make or break effort to safeguard the future of the multi-lateral trading system.
fields.body:
The world trade organisation is to to spend the next six months paving the way for the launch of a new round of negotiations this autumn in a make or break effort to safeguard the future of the multi-lateral trading system.

Faced with the threat of protectionism and a splintering of the global economy into rival trading blocs, Mike Moore, the director general of the WTO, said he believed lessons had now been learned from the debacle in Seattle 14 months ago, when attempts to launch a new round collapsed.

"I believe that with focus and flexibility, a new round can be launched at the WTO's ministerial meeting in Qatar in November," Mr Moore said in Davos. "We have a brief period of time but I don't see that as a disadvantage. It should help to concentrate minds."

Mr Moore's comments came as three past leaders of the Geneva-based body, together with leading trade ministers, warned that the future of the multilateral trading system would be in jeopardy unless steps were taken to launch a round quickly.

Pascal Lamy, the EU's trade commissioner, said: "The multilateral trading system has a future but it is a future which will be decided this year."

Mr Lamy said there was a growing fashion for regional trade agreements and a growing risk that the WTO would be turned into a world trade court, with "lawyers and litigators" taking over from trade negotiators. "I believe there is only one answer, and that is to launch a new round this year".

South African trade minister Alec Erwin said: "Don't underestimate the risks of the disintegration of the multilateral trading system. The law of the jungle in trade is very dangerous for weak countries."

In a joint statement released in Davos, Mr Moore's three immediate predecessors - Renato Ruggiero, Peter Sutherland and Arthur Dunkel - said: "We see danger in the present situation. We consider it is time for political and business leaders to pay attention to that danger and make the development of an adequate response a priority. Lack of attention will mean continued drift and, ultimately, increased difficulty in reinvigorating an effective, rules based system."

Mr Moore said he welcomed the support from his predecessors which marks the start of an attempt by the WTO to relaunch itself following a year of licking its wounds after Seattle.

He held a breakfast meeting in Davos with ministers from 25 countries attending the World Economic Forum in an attempt to boost political support for fresh talks which are intended to cover market access for poor countries, lower tariffs, agriculture, competition policy and investment.

"By March I want to be in a position to take stock, and by July I need to know exactly how far we have got, because that will determine the shape of the ministerial meeting in Qatar," Mr Moore said.

"We have got to go into the ministerial 95% of the way to an agreement."

The insistence on "pre-cooking" a draft agreement reflects the WTO's determination to avoid a repeat of Seattle, where fundamental differences divided the organisation's 140 member governments.

However, he believes that the deterioration in the global economic outlook - particularly in the US - has helped to make trade negotiators more willing to compromise their former hardline positions.

With George Bush's presidency only a week old, Mr Moore has yet to meet the new trade team in Washington, but is aware that the attitude taken by the US will be crucial. He is concerned that failure to launch a new multilateral round will lead to Mr Bush concentrating his energies on a regional trading bloc covering north and south America.

However, he is also aware that the US will have to scale down its demands for core labour standards backed by sanctions to become part of future trade deals if developing countries are to agree to the launch of a new round.

"Labour standards are a brick wall," Mr Moore said. "There will be no labour sanctions in the WTO."

Faced with the threat of protectionism and a splintering of the global economy into rival trading blocs, Mike Moore, the director general of the WTO, said he believed lessons had now been learned from the debacle in Seattle 14 months ago, when attempts to launch a new round collapsed. "I believe that with focus and flexibility, a new round can be launched at the WTO's ministerial meeting in Qatar in November," Mr Moore said in Davos. "We have a brief period of time but I don't see that as a disadvantage. It should help to concentrate minds." Mr Moore's comments came as three past leaders of the Geneva-based body, together with leading trade ministers, warned that the future of the multilateral trading system would be in jeopardy unless steps were taken to launch a round quickly. Pascal Lamy, the EU's trade commissioner, said: "The multilateral trading system has a future but it is a future which will be decided this year." Mr Lamy said there was a growing fashion for regional trade agreements and a growing risk that the WTO would be turned into a world trade court, with "lawyers and litigators" taking over from trade negotiators. "I believe there is only one answer, and that is to launch a new round this year". South African trade minister Alec Erwin said: "Don't underestimate the risks of the disintegration of the multilateral trading system. The law of the jungle in trade is very dangerous for weak countries." In a joint statement released in Davos, Mr Moore's three immediate predecessors - Renato Ruggiero, Peter Sutherland and Arthur Dunkel - said: "We see danger in the present situation. We consider it is time for political and business leaders to pay attention to that danger and make the development of an adequate response a priority. Lack of attention will mean continued drift and, ultimately, increased difficulty in reinvigorating an effective, rules based system." Mr Moore said he welcomed the support from his predecessors which marks the start of an attempt by the WTO to relaunch itself following a year of licking its wounds after Seattle. He held a breakfast meeting in Davos with ministers from 25 countries attending the World Economic Forum in an attempt to boost political support for fresh talks which are intended to cover market access for poor countries, lower tariffs, agriculture, competition policy and investment. "By March I want to be in a position to take stock, and by July I need to know exactly how far we have got, because that will determine the shape of the ministerial meeting in Qatar," Mr Moore said. "We have got to go into the ministerial 95% of the way to an agreement." The insistence on "pre-cooking" a draft agreement reflects the WTO's determination to avoid a repeat of Seattle, where fundamental differences divided the organisation's 140 member governments. However, he believes that the deterioration in the global economic outlook - particularly in the US - has helped to make trade negotiators more willing to compromise their former hardline positions. However, he is also aware that the US will have to scale down its demands for core labour standards backed by sanctions to become part of future trade deals if developing countries are to agree to the launch of a new round. "Labour standards are a brick wall," Mr Moore said. "There will be no labour sanctions in the WTO."

webTitle: Remember Jorg Haider?

fields.headline: Remember Jorg Haider?
fields.standfirst:
This week last year - and what happened next

Special report: the Austrian far right in power
fields.trailText: This week last year - and what happened next
fields.body:
The rise of the far-right Freedom party (FPO) in Austria, under the leadership of the yuppie fascist Jörg Haider, thrust the alpine republic into a limelight it was wholly unused to.

The trouble began when the conservative People's party broke a pre-election promise and formed a coalition with the FPO. Austria immediately began paying the price of a government involving Haider - the man who had praised Hitler's policies - as Europe introduced sanctions.

But a glance back on the last year reveals that it has not all been doom and gloom. "Although we don't appreciate what's going on in Austria we do have a lot of fun," was how a young Viennese internet publisher summed it up. Pledging to push through privatisation, deregulation and social welfare reforms, the coalition government adopted the English slogan Speed Kills, meaning those against the changes would be swept aside, rather than the Ginsbergian interpretation. Intellectuals chuckled.

Then came the cuddly elephants. The FPO's Vienna MP Hilmar Kabas denounced President Thomas Klestil as a "lump", meaning "trash", then denied it, saying he had said "hump", or "dump" - words that have no meaning in German. The FPO, ever-skilled at turning things in its favour, began marketing its new mascots, elephants Humpy and Dumpy.

At the end of Feb ruary, Haider resigned as party leader, putting Susanne Riess-Passer (dubbed "the king's cobra") in his place. But throughout the year he has continued to be the FPO's de facto leader, ruling from the southern province of Carinthia where he is governor. Observers say he has now given up all hope of fulfilling his life's dream of becoming chancellor - no foreign leader would ever want to be seen shaking his hand.

Unless of course that leader's name is Gadaffi. Haider the pariah stokes the fire every now and again by taking business trips to Libya and Iraq where he has purchased cheap fuel for the Carinthians. And last week an Austrian paper revealed that he was flown on a "secret mission" to Moscow by the pistol manufacturer Gaston Glock, to look at buying Soviet fighter jets.

He has also cuddled up to the far-right in Italy where he is viewed as a bit of a hero, and was received by the Pope at Christmas when His Holiness apparently lectured him on racial tolerance.

At the end of last year the party came in for the most intense scrutiny, when policemen revealed Haider had paid them to provide him with secret files on his opponents. The sensitive right-winger has also proved himself to be one of the most litigious politicians in Europe, having at any one time 100 law suits against his opponents - including stand-up comedians - on the go.

Elections in Vienna (home to a quarter of the country's eight million citizens) are due in March. It's said to be the first litmus test for the FPO since it entered government. If the opinion polls turn out to be correct, Haider is not going to be a very happy man.

webTitle: Radio pick of the day:

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day:
fields.trailText: The Real Captain Bligh | The Year 1901| Health Matters
fields.body:
As The Real Captain Bligh (11.0am, Radio 4) tries to establish, the tyrannical sadist portrayed on film by Charles Laughton was a gross distortion of history. The 33-year-old naval officer, pictured, deputed by the Admiralty to collect breadfruit in Tahiti and supply it to slaves in the West Indies, certainly had a rough tongue. But he was also superb at his job, as he demonstrated over 41 days by navigating safely to Timor the open boat in which he and 18 of his crew had been dumped by the mutineers.

Robert Lacey, after an earlier description of the world of 1000AD, focuses over the next five days on The Year 1901 (3.45pm, Radio 4). Queen Victoria's death wasn't quite the end of an era: that came with the Great War. But the Edwardians' everyday world still seems light years away. Its continued dependence on the horse generated noise and smells on a scale we could never tolerate now. And youngsters, exploring the countryside on their new, cheap bicycles, quickly managed to widen the accessible gene pool.

In a pronouncement better left as a private thought, the American surgeon-general declared in 1960 that antibiotics had finally conquered infectious disease. In Health Matters (8.05pm, BBC World Service, and 2.05am, Radio 4) Sue Armstrong launches a six-part series on the state of the world's health. Not only are we under attack by superbugs but we a facing a host of new infections.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: War relic kills Iraqi children
fields.body:
War relic kills Iraqi children

Four children were killed when a bomb dropped during the 1991 Gulf war exploded in southern Iraq, the Iraqi News Agency reported yesterday.

Quoting a civil defence source in Dhi qar province, it said two sisters and two brothers under eight were killed by a cluster bomb in the al-Badiya area. It did not say when the incident occurred.
Reuters, Baghdad

Pope names more cardinals

The Pope has named two cardinals whose identity was not made public when they were appointed in 1998, and added five names to the list of new cardinals presented a week ago.

Another 44 cardinals will be named next month, raising the number of cardinals entitled to vote for the Pope's successor to 135.
Philip Willan, Rome

Police prevent Corsica bomb

The French police said they had caught two suspected guerrillas on Saturday night as they prepared to plant a bomb near a government office on the Mediterranean island of Corsica.
Reuters, Ajaccio

webTitle: Country Diary

fields.headline: One fell swoop
fields.standfirst: The Lake District
fields.trailText: The Lake District
fields.body:
From my bedroom window, the other day, I could see the sunshine glistening on the summit snows of High Street, perhaps 12 miles away to the north-west, and easily visualise pleasantly crunching the last mile to the cairn. But now the clouds have come down, and with them the rain, and the most splendid three winter weeks that the Lakeland hills have seen in years has come to an end.

This December to January benison, coming so soon after miserable weeks of almost non-stop rain, has restored our trust in Nature: life was bearable again. The sun shone for most of the time and, in the crisp, pollution-free atmosphere, the views from the fell tops were incredibly clear, with the snowbound Scottish hills often visible. And the snow - the wonderful, powder snow beloved of skiers - not only crunched when you plodded through it but also, most satisfyingly, squeaked - the acid test. It remained on our little side-road and on the tree branches and shrubs, just as it had fallen, for days and weeks.

For 100% perfection, then skiers and climbers, no doubt, would have welcomed a little more snow on the fells and more ice on the crags but, after such an unexpected bonus, outdoors folk were certainly not complaining. Even the wind was kindly, and you felt the downpours and floods had washed the whole of the fell country clean as a whistle.

May I thank those scores of readers who sent me letters and cards to mark my 50th and 90th anniversaries. For the very first time, please forgive me for not answering them all personally - just too big a job.

webTitle: Radio review

fields.headline: Radio review
fields.standfirst: Another day, another medical scandal
fields.trailText: Five Live Report - Fallen Angels | Between The Ears
fields.body:
A new day, and it's a different medical scandal being picked at like a scab on the Today programme. Alder Hey, Shipman, dead bodies stored in chapels with their toes forlornly on display. Given all this, yesterday's Five Live Report - Fallen Angels (Radio 5 Live) on standards of nursing care in Britain's hospitals, had a macabre timeliness about it.

There was a certain Day Today sensationalism to Kim Catcheside's delivery. Nurses used to be our angels, she said - cue a rousing chorus of Robbie singing Angels - "now, they risk a new label: fallen angels".

The personal testimonies, from patients' families and nurses themselves, which would have sounded like scaremongering six months ago, now had a terrible familiarity about them. A woman left on a commode in her ward for half an hour died on it, another woman's soiled nightdress simply had a clean one placed over the top. A widower told of the treatment her husband had received in the days before his death: "He was absolutely neglected. He used to sit in his excrement for hours."

Nurses talked of basic care skills disappearing fast. No one wants to wipe bottoms any more; "they just want to come in, do the job and go home". For all the terror in these tales, the programme ultimately still left us feeling sorry for nurses. It quietly raised the question of who would want to dedicate themselves to messy TLC, given the pay, conditions and other opportunities on offer.

You could tell right away that Lou Stein's mother, Carmen, wasn't in an NHS hospital. "This food is delicious, have some!" she enthused to her son, who was nursing her for terminal cervical cancer. A year after her death, theatre director Stein made a "sound diary" for Radio 3's consistently impressive experimental series, Between The Ears .

My Month With Carmen used a backdrop of sounds (noises from the hospital ward, orchestral music like a heart monitor, the deep hollow sound of assisted breathing) along with actors and Stein himself to make this ordinary story into something different - about the nature of grief and memory rather than death itself.

But it was claustrophobic and sad too, as Stein read his mother's journals about her journey from Puerto Rico to New York - he had known nothing of this. Stein was worried, apparently, that his account would be too schmaltzy. It was anything but, and yet it made the most emotionally draining episode of ER seem like a programme for wimps.

webTitle: Screen grabs

fields.headline: Screen grabs
fields.standfirst: Coming to a box near you
fields.trailText: Coming to a box near you
fields.body:
 Keep an eye out for the return of the excellent Michael Barrymore vehicle, Bob Martin, on February 5. The comedy drama about a neurotic game show host (probably best described as Britain's answer to Larry Sanders) had poor ratings for its first season, despite a warm reception from the critics. One member of the cast, however, has point-blank refused to reveal inside gossip on the making of the new series. Apparently every hilarious behind-the-scenes anecdote they could think of would involve an embarrassing revelation about one or other of the cast's army of supposedly reformed hardened drinkers.

 FilmFour kicks off another Gratuitous Controversy season next month with a Lolita theme night. Bravely, it shuns Stanley Kubrick's deeply dull adaptation of Nabokov's classic in favour of British director Adrian Lynn's even duller one. But it does partly redeem itself with another showing of the underrated Emily Lloyd drama Wish You Were Here, which was of course responsible for introducing Jim Royle to the phrase "up your arse".

 A new book, Semiotics And TV Drama, (published by Luton University Press), has at last addressed that sticky which-was-better-Morse-or-Cracker? problem that's been bothering us all: "Morse clearly deals in naturalistic signs to offer us a conventional message in keeping with the status quo. Cracker, on the other hand, reaccentuates the sign of the detective and is responsible for bringing about a radical reappraisal of the semiotics of Morse." Now you know.

 Good and bad news from veteran actress Celia Imrie. She's to be seen this weekend in the BBC's eagerly awaited Nancy Mitford adaptation, Love in a Cold Climate. The drama is set to be one of the highlights of the television year. The bad news? "There won't be another series of dinnerladies. But Victoria Wood will definitely be doing something else," she says.

webTitle: Simon Nye on office comedies

fields.headline: What a way to make a living
fields.standfirst: We spend our lives in offices - so why do we want to go home and watch more of them? As yet another office sitcom heads for our screens,  Simon Nye , creator of Men Behaving Badly and Beast, explains why
fields.trailText: We spend our lives in offices - so why do we want to go home and watch more of them? As yet another office sitcom heads for our screens, Simon Nye , creator of Men Behaving Badly and Beast, explains why.
fields.body:
So you've heard that Ben Elton's got a massive house and you want to break into the lucrative, not to mention sexually charged world of TV comedy. You've done your research on how to write a sitcom - the Rule of Three, the smash cut, the notion of clowning-as-pain. You've been to watch live recordings of new ITV sitcom Mr Silly, and Channel 4's new interactive sitdotcom Innit. You've studied the comedy architecture of 'Allo 'Allo. Now what the hell do you write about?

The chances are that if you are a psychotherapist, for example, you will set your comedy series among psychotherapists, and call it something with Couch or Shrink in the title. It's good to write about what you know, of course, but the temptation is to shoe-horn an unwieldy, humorous incident from your professional life, involving for example a couch, a mysterious sticky stain and an escaped monkey. But do bear in mind the phrase "You had to be there". No one has ever said to me (and I wish they would), "I'm an accountant/ newsagent/feng shui consultant. We'd be rubbish in a sitcom."

Any setting can work, I'm convinced, if you get the characters and tone right, and can get hold of Ronnie Barker. But it's true that some workplaces are harder to get right than others. Good luck to anyone setting a situation comedy in the office of a Child Abuse Helpline, for instance. And the world of stunt men or midwives in the Outback may lose something in translation to a bunch of plywood scenery in a Shepherds Bush studio. I personally won't rush home to watch a series set in a morgue.

Incidentally, a successful sitcom creates a vacuum around its area of interest. No comedy professionals wrote about hotels with any degree of confidence for 20 years after Fawlty Towers. And a sitcom set among civil servants couldn't get arrested after Yes Minister, thereby frustrating a whole generation of disaffected junior bureaucrats with media ambitions.

More and more comedy series are being set at work. Office Gossip, starring Pauline Quirk, is about to start on BBC1. Bob Martin, set in a TV studio, will return shortly. Beast, the BBC1 sitcom that I write, is set in a vet's practice. Do watch it while you can. In these days of teleworking and short-term contracts, this may be pre-nostalgia for a time when the workplace offered more of a sense of community and permanence. This is one of a number of cod-sociological theories I'll be sharing with you.

One of the more sensible theories about sitcoms (for professional reasons I'll pass over the theory that they're all dreadful and we should sit down and read a good book) is that the best ones are about characters who are trapped. And where are we more trapped than at work? The hierarchies of the workplace were exploited particularly early on, in the likes of Bilko, The Rag Trade, and - may we be forgiven - On The Buses. It would be dangerously pretentious to make the claim that these shows had a genuinely subversive effect on people's attitude to their jobs, but I'll say it anyway.

The question is, after a hard day at work, do viewers really want to come home and watch people having a hard day at work, and pretending it's funny? But the truth is, most people's workplaces are funny. Not necessarily for the incidents ("and then Brian from Docketing came in with his head stuck in the paper towel dispenser..."), but the banter. A big prize will go to the first sitcom that properly conveys the unforced hilarity of the best office conversation, the way Cheers captured the essence of bar room repartee.

The appeal of TV-as-escape is belied by the popularity of soaps, which thrust a monstrously grim version of reality into the nation's face every evening. It's true that the reality is heightened - so few characters, so many mysterious deaths - but the basic gruel of argument, misery and mutual loathing is, perhaps, depressingly authentic.

But comedy may be starting to learn lessons from TV drama, not least because it is generally getting whupped in the ratings. Fifteen million people tune in to the cyn ical, arid Heartbeat, while an airy, subtle sitcom like Kiss Me Kate is lucky to get a third of that. But don't get me started. The Royle Family notwithstanding, viewers want three plots in an episode, and where else are you going to get that kind of action and mobility but at work?

Domestic sitcoms - whose finest hour was the legendary "Heil Honey I'm Home", about a Jewish couple who live next door to Hitler (filmed but never shown) - have always been the staple of British TV. The leisurely, static nature of home life - not to mention the boxy, overlit interiors - is perfect for sitcoms. A neighbour pops round: high-drama! Something falls out of a kitchen cupboard: whoa, slow down there! The apotheosis of the British domestic sitcom, Terry And June, has been mercilessly pilloried for its, shall we say, limited horizons. A more charitable view would be that it was the kabuki of sitcoms, highly stylised and making much of very little. You could even say that, pre-empting Seinfeld, it was a "sitcom about nothing". You'd be foolish to say it, but you could.

Work-based comedy series are more robust. They do, however, have a very troubled relationship with reality. How much like life do you actually want your comedy? Larry Sanders works because, among other things, it looks and sounds hideously authentic. This is partly, it has to be said, because everyone says "fuck" a lot, the way we all do in television. But if you enjoy the characters, then the milieu tends to look genuine, whether it is or not. The glimpses of the media that you get in I'm Alan Partridge seemed completely authentic, although they pushed the boundaries of the absurd. Nor am I convinced that Father Ted is an accurate reflection of Irish clerical life, but it might as well be. And my own series, Is It Legal?, was criticised by Law Student magazine for not depicting the reality of a solicitor's office. No there's a stunning compliment if ever there was one.

So if you ever take time off work to write your sitcom, Shrinking Violet, about a Freudian therapist called... you guessed it, or Bun In The Oven (set in a bakery, owner possibly called Bunn), or Please Mend My Bicycle! (set in a bicycle repair shop), or Morgue's The Merrier, don't expect anyone in your profession to enjoy it. But you can be consoled that you are contributing to a genre that has given us such classics as Doctor Down Under, Mind Your Language and The Flying Nun.
