webTitle: Adrian Mole returns to the screen

fields.headline: Adrian Mole returns to the screen
fields.standfirst: Sue Townsend used the first Adrian Mole books to make razor sharp observations about the 80s. Now, a TV adaptation of her latest instalment takes on the Blair years
fields.trailText: Sue Townsend used the first Adrian Mole books to make razor sharp observations about the 80s. Now, a TV adaptation of her latest instalment takes on the Blair years.
fields.body:
The last time the secret diarist Adrian Mole was televised, he was nervously measuring his penis with his school ruler and applying acne cream to a moonscape face. Returning to the screen in Adrian Mole: The Cappuccino Years (Friday, 9.30pm, BBC1), the damage limitation in the bathroom has spread from gratifyingly smooth cheeks to a dismayingly smooth scalp, displaying the beginnings of middle-aged baldness and, whether or not he's still fretful about its dimensions, his equipment has measured up to the extent of fathering at least one child and possibly two.

When Sue Townsend published The Cappuccino Years as a novel in 1999, the book took its place in a fiction bestseller list dominated by sequels. This sixth volume of Mole's diaries jostled with the further chronicles of Harry Potter, Hannibal Lecter and Bridget Jones. The trick in re-animating a long-running character is the timing of the revivals. There needs to have been time for the person and the world around them to have changed. Mind the gap.

In The Cappuccino Years, Townsend judged the jump to perfection. Mole (Stephen Mangan) is rediscovered on a pivotal day: the eve of the election of the Labour government in 1997. Long established as a hopeless innocent, he is a Blairite true believer. It feels exactly right that Pandora Braithwaite (Helen Baxendale), object of Adrian's fetid sexual fantasies since he first took up his pen as an adolescent, should now, as Dr Braithwaite, be the New Labour candidate in the Leicester constituency where they both grew up. In his characteristic, doleful, sub-Proustian tone, Mole remembers being "the first to insert my hand inside the cup of her white training bra. Hers was the first nipple I ever saw, pink like a hamster's tongue". Equally appropriate is Mole's current job, as chef in Hoi Polloi, a new British restaurant in Soho specialising in offal. He views this as a temporary profession while he waits acceptance by the BBC of The White Van, a "serial killer comedy in 12 parts".

Leicestershire, which represented the grim and dull English Midlands when Townsend started writing, now stands for Middle England, capital of Blair's political kingdom. Jobless for years, Adrian's dad George (Alun Armstrong) stays in bed all day, taking Prozac, but - in an odd slip of topicality - not Viagra, although he is impotent and under treatment: "I'm not having those injections in my dick again." Pauline Mole (Alison Steadman) is sexually restless, drawn to Pandora's father Ivan (James Hazeldine) who, being a New Labour campaign manager, scatters her with rose petals before they commit adultery.

None of this is going to bring down a government, but the targets are the right ones and, while political satire often dates, The cappuccino Years feels sharper on TV than on the page because Townsend's focus is the optimism of those May days.

The point has frequently been made in reviews of the brilliant presidential drama The West Wing (Thursday, 10pm, Channel 4) that American television creates political drama in which the processes of democracy are taken seriously, while British shows about politics are gags and satire. Someone using this generalisation in a TV Studies exam would get full marks, but, within the limits of sit-com, The Cappuccino Years is quietly subversive.

When Pauline tells her unemployed husband, "Tony will get you a job", or David Dimbleby's voice seeps from the Moles' TV set mentioning that this is the largest Labour majority ever, the series captures something of the now painful hopefulness of that election day. You wouldn't, for example, advise Peter Mandelson to fill the spare time he now has by watching this series, unless he wants another reminder of the distance between ambition and reality.

Townsend's lines frequently surprise. Ivan's wife knows he's betraying her when she finds a Kit-Kat wrapper in his pocket. You don't understand this until she later explains that the right-on couple have been "boycotting Rowntrees products since 1979" because of their fears about cocoa beanfarming. After his mother babysits Adrian's son, she hands him back with the warning: "Don't put him on the floor - he's pretending it's the open sea." Trains and cars are things you want to see coming, but the best dialogue hits you from nowhere, and Townsend's frequently does.

A satire of New Labour, The Cappuccino Years also, in one curious way, represents a new BBC. Under John Birt, BBC current affairs presenters were banned from appearing as themselves in comedies and dramas, because of fears that fictionalisation robbed them of authority. For this reason, the headlines were usually read in TV dramas by Pamela Armstron, Jan Leeming, Richard Whitmore, or other former newsreaders. (In the 1993 BBC2 political comedy The Vision Thing, incidentally, the newsreader was played by a then Daily Mirror reporter, Alistair Campbell.) This rule now seems to have lapsed because, in the second episode of The Cappuccino Years, Dr Pandora Braithwaite, now a Blair Babe, is interviewed on the Newsnight set by Jeremy Paxman, who is undone by her brazen sexuality. Paxman exposing Labour MPs as heterosexual on-air - it's about the only thing that doesn't feel accurate in this sparky picture of the Blair Years.

 Adrian Mole: The Cappuccino Years, Friday, 9.30pm, BBC1 (not Scotland)

webTitle: Zanzibar clashes spread to mainland

fields.headline: Zanzibar clashes spread to mainland
fields.trailText: At least 10 people were killed in clashes between police and opposition protesters in Zanzibar yesterday, raising the unconfirmed death toll to 31 in two days of demonstrations against disputed elections.
fields.body:
At least 10 people were killed in clashes between police and opposition protesters in Zanzibar yesterday, raising the unconfirmed death toll to 31 in two days of demonstrations against disputed elections.

Soldiers were rushed in from mainland Tanzania to try to restore calm to Pemba, the smallest of Zanzibar's main islands. More than 100 people were arrested in the mainland capital, Dar es Salaam, and clashes were reported in the western town of Mwanza.

Hundreds of tourists in semi-autonomous Zanzibar spent a second day cooped up in their hotels. The Foreign Office warned British holiday-makers not to visit the islands while the protests continue.

Twenty people are reported to have been killed on Pemba. Three policemen were reported killed there yesterday, after a policeman was beheaded the previous day. Sporadic gunfire could be heard around the island.

"We have 20 people dead, including four policemen," an islander said.

The police said 11 people, including three members of the security forces, had been killed on the main Zanzibar island. More than 100 people are reported to have been injured, most by gunfire.

The clashes began after the police fired on demonstrators calling for fresh polls on Saturday. Elections in October were reduced to chaos by vote-rigging and police intimidation. A Commonwealth observer mission described the polls as a "shambles".

webTitle: Rebels kill 25 from two families in Algeria

fields.headline: Rebels kill 25 from two families in Algeria
fields.trailText: Algerian rebels massacred 25 villagers, including 16 children, at the weekend.
fields.body:
Algerian rebels massacred 25 villagers, including 16 children, at the weekend.

The massacre, the worst in recent months, occurred at El Guetaibia n the Chlef region, 135 miles west of the capital Algiers, between 11pm and midnight on Saturday.

"They cut the throats of 25 people from two extended families," a doctor at the hospital in Chatia said.

Relatives told the hospital that members of the Islamic Armed Group (GIA) were responsible.

Yesterday the security forces were sweeping the area in search of the assailants.

The massacre brought the number of people killed in Algeria to more than 90 this month alone, and more than 100,000 since the Islamic insurgency began in 1992 after the military-dominated government cancelled a general election which a radical Islamic party was about to win.

Last month 250 were killed during the fasting month of Ramadan, when the violence broke out against after the relatively quiet period which followed a government amnesty.

The doctor and staff at the Chatia hospital, where the bodies of the dead were taken, said they were members of the Miloud and Ayad families.

They quoted relatives as saying that armed members of the family fired at the attackers in an unsuccessful attempt to repel them.

"The villagers in the area have been asking the authorities to grant them arms for self-defence since 1997, but they got no answer," a doctor said.

Relatives also told them that the rebels had abducted a girl aged about 20, the doctor added.

Most of the violence this month has been around Chlef and Ain Defla, 85 miles west of Algiers, from the capital, and near Medea, 60 miles to the south, traditionally an area controlled by the GIA.

webTitle: Interview: Dido

fields.headline: What went right?
fields.standfirst: Six months ago Dido was just an unknown hopeful. Now, with a little help from Eminem, she is Britain's hottest singer-songwriter. She talks to  Dave Simpson
fields.trailText: Six months ago Dido was just an unknown hopeful. Now, with a little help from Eminem, she is Britain's hottest singer-songwriter. She talks to Dave Simpson.
fields.body:
Last November 29-year- old Dido Armstrong and her boyfriend Bob were discussing their day at work. Bob had gone to the office and relaxed with a game of football. Dido had ended up locked in a car boot.

"I was actually tied and gagged," she recalls. "It was pretty hairy. I don't like not being able to breathe and the gag hurt my mouth. And I managed to smash my head on the car jack. There was this massive crunch and I just burst into tears."

It was all in a day's work, even if the tears and the head-smashing were not in the contract. She had been locked up for the video of Eminem's controversial smash hit Stan, which had heavily sampled her song Thank You. Since then, Dido's career has gone ballistic. Her No Angel album has sold 2m albums in America and 300,000 here since Christmas, and should hit number one next month. And all this before the Islington girl has even released a single.

"I'm not really sure who's buying it," sighs Dido, whose Beth Orton/ Sinead O'Connor-like songs allude to betrayal and abortion but have little in common with Eminem's rage-filled rap. "I mean, I can't exactly hang outside Virgin and look in people's bags. From my American audiences I suspect it's a mixture of families, couples, lots of guys and [she laughs loudly] a posse of Eminem fans looking a bit puzzled."

So far the British press have been caught on the hop. With Dido away until recently on a much-needed holiday with Bob ("You've got to get your priorities right"), the tabloids have resorted to camping outside her house ("My parents' house too, and I haven't lived there for 14 years") and gleaning what they can from American reports. They have described Dido as a demure, butter-wouldn't-melt English rose from a privileged background who was "turned into a superstar by bad boy Eminem". She finds all this hilarious. "That's so not me!" she squeals, in an accent closer to the Arsenal terraces than posh London convent. Her true story is that of a clued-up woman who took on and defeated everything from her parents to the male-dominated pop industry.

Dido was born on Christmas Day 1971, which is perfect for pop mythology but tough when it comes to birthday presents (she named June 25 her "official" birthday to make up for it). Her father was a publisher, and her mother an unpublished writer who coupled housework with a parallel world of "scary" poetic fantasy. The household was odder in that Mrs Armstrong didn't allow visitors and the family didn't own a television.

"Looking back, I think that's why I did music," says Dido. "I'd get home from school and the house would be so quiet." Upset that her peers played recorder and she didn't, Dido "appropriated" one from the school's lost property cupboard. Against her parents' wishes, she followed her teachers' advice and spent weekends at London's Guildhall College of Music. Music was Dido's only form of expression. She "didn't say a word to anyone" for the first six weeks of primary school and - embarrassed about being named after the Queen of Carthage - learned to make friends by living a bizarre double life as "Claire". Aged nine, she toured Yugoslavia with a recorder orchestra ("Do I have the tapes? Yes, in a fuckin' safe!") but remembers feeling"terribly left out, younger than everybody else, and homesick". By her mid-teens, she was rebelling against music, Westminster School and everything else, and was thrown out of the family home.

Dido lived with friends, working at a literary agency and doing a law degree by night. "That comes in handy now. I totally understand the business, much to the annoyance of the business." Later she immersed herself in club culture, then eased back out when several of her friends ended up in mental hospitals.

"Did I ever dabble? To be honest I was mixed up at the time and drugs scared me," she says. "I'd smoke a bit and get paranoid. I'm too much of a control freak."

In her early 20s, Dido finally realised that she wanted to do music but took to singing, the only thing she hadn't learned. Her older brother, Rollo, was forming the now hugely successful dance band Faithless and Dido wanted in. She hung around the sessions, "playfully manipulating" her brother into letting her sing backing vocals. But her first record wasn't with Faithless. It was Give Me Life by Mr V, in 1994, done with a "horrible" boyfriend, and brings back memories that she still describes as traumatic. Around this time, Dido signed lots of "stitch-up" management contracts she would later get out of, and a publishing deal that coincided with bouts of agoraphobia, panic attacks and depression. webTitle: Barak halts talks until election

fields.headline: Barak halts talks until election
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, broke off peacemaking relations with the Palestinians yesterday in preparation for the prime ministerial election on February 6, which the polls predict he will lose to the hardline Likud leader, Ariel Sharon.
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, broke off peacemaking relations with the Palestinians yesterday in preparation for the prime ministerial election on February 6, which the polls predict he will lose to the hardline Likud leader, Ariel Sharon.

The Palestinian Authority president, Yasser Arafat, delivered a blistering attack on Mr Barak's decision to halt "diplomatic contacts with Arafat and his people" until the country has voted.

Israeli officials said Mr Barak would not have the meeting with Mr Arafat which had been expected to take place in Sweden this week, or any other meeting, until the election was over

Mr Arafat said at the Davos economic summit that Mr Barak's government had waged "a savage and barbaric war" against the Palestinian people for the past four months.

At least 312 Palestinians have been killed in the four months since their intifada erupted. Forty-eight Israelis and 13 Israeli Arabs have been killed in the violence.

Israel's elder statesman, Shimon Peres, also in Davos, appealed to Mr Arafat to put aside the years of bitterness and "walk the last piece of the road for peace". The goal could be reached within weeks, he said.

Mr Barak's office said that although peacemaking contacts would be halted until after February 6, Israeli and Palestinian security officials would continue to hold discussions aimed at "stopping the violence and thwarting terrorism".

The two sides ended five days of talks in the Egyptian resort of Taba on Saturday with a joint statement saying they were closer than ever to an agreement, but the document fell short of Mr Barak's hope of a campaign-boosting breakthrough.

Opinion polls show Mr Barak losing to Mr Sharon by 16 to 18 percentage points.

Mr Sharon, who opposes the territorial concessions offered by Mr Barak, dismissed the joint statement as a danger to the state, and said it would not help Mr Barak to win re-election. He accused Mr Barak of trying to boost his election chances with a piece of paper.

"What we see today, to my regret, are steps that pose a danger to the state of Israel," he told a campaign event in Bat Yam, near Tel Aviv.

Bloodshed continued in the West Bank and Gaza Strip during the talks, and at one point prompted the Israelis to suspend them for two days. Israeli troops and Palestinian police exchanged fire again in the West Bank and Gaza Strip yesterday. Palestinian officials reported at least five wounded in the West Bank.

webTitle: Pink slip parties cure dot.com blues in San Francisco

fields.headline: Pink slip parties cure dot.com blues in San Francisco
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The growing ranks of people made redundant as their e-commerce start-ups grind to a halt are finding solace in the most fashionable parties in the Bay Area of San Francisco.
fields.body:
The ones with the red dots have lost their jobs. Those with green dots may be able to help them. Those with the yellow dots couldn't care less. But the colour to remember at these events is pink.

The Pink Slip party - for those given the pink slips that mean their e-commerce company has no further use for them - has arrived in San Francisco.

The growing ranks of people made redundant as their start-ups grind to a halt are finding solace in the most fashionable parties in the Bay Area.

Next month's event at Club NV in the SoMa (south of Market street) area promises to be the biggest yet, with hundreds of twenty- and thirtysomethings gathering to find comfort and perhaps a new job, too.

Patty Beron, the founder of the parties, said she dreamed up the idea late last year when three friends were laid off and had such a good time in a bar commiserating that they decided to make it an event.

Ms Beron already ran a website called sfgirl.com, which lists everything from social events to housing and job information, and employers were already asking her to point job seekers their way.

What better way to introduce job seeker and employer than at a party, she said. She then posted the event on her site and a new form of partying was born.

"We were amazed at the response," she said, sitting in Haight Street's People's Cafe, which doubles as her office. "We had no idea so many people would come."

Most of the partygoers had been laid off by companies begun in the past few years, renting costly SoMa office space and imagining a fortune was there for the making.

Although such dreams may have faded, the mood is far from morose. "People are very upbeat at the parties, even though they may have lost their jobs. The atmosphere isn't dreary at all," Ms Beron said.

Those sacked are given a red dot to wear, those who can offer jobs a green dot, and those who just want to party - the laid back rather than laid off - get a yellow dot.

Some people have already found work at the parties.

"Some of the recruiters were aggressively walking up to people and saying, 'What are you looking for?' But more often it was more subtle," Ms Beron said, adding that the only ones who did not mix were those who had lost their jobs that day and stood dazed at the bar drinking.

The parties are now held monthly, entry is free, and the bars in which they are held charge redundancy-friendly prices: $2 (£1.35) for a pint of beer or a martini cocktail.

Their success has not gone unnoticed, and they are now backed by two sponsors, one a recruitment agency. Since such companies can spend as much as $10,000 to headhunt an employee, Ms Beron says the parties are good value for sponsors' money.

What's more, by ending at 8pm the parties avoid having too many sacked staff weeping into their beer.

Despite the dismissals - ExciteAtHome paid off 250 workers this week, mainly in the Bay Area - Ms Beron said most people planned to stay in the city and find other work.

For those who head home another site, craigslist.org, aims to help ease their way.

The site has just launched a new section for selling furniture: this week it featured Chinese chairs and Afghan rugs.

If all else fails, Positively Haight Street, opposite the People's Cafe in the former hippie district of Haight-Ashbury, is looking for an assistant to help it sell Bob Dylan cookie jars and Janis Joplin posters to tourists who remember when the city was famous for turning on rather than starting up.

webTitle: Youths pick chic Paris mall for gang rumble

fields.headline: Youths pick chic Paris mall for gang rumble
fields.trailText: Terrified shoppers watched 400 youths armed with baseball bats, knives and pistols fight a two-hour battle in the sleek high-rise Paris suburb of La Defense at the weekend.
fields.body:
Terrified shoppers watched 400 youths armed with baseball bats, knives and pistols fight a two-hour battle in the sleek high-rise Paris suburb of La Defense at the weekend.

"It was horrifying, like the most violent film you've seen," said Simone Corda, 42, who had taken her two young children to the district's huge shopping mall on Saturday afternoon for the last day of the January sales.

"They'd quite clearly chosen the main concourse as their battlegound. It was crowded, there were hundreds of people there in the shopping centre, and right on the square outside the McDonalds they just pulled out axes, knives, hammers, everything. I've never seen such hatred."

A battalion of CRS riot police and 200 local policemen struggled for more than two hours to end the fighting.

Ten gang members were injured, including one who was in a critical condition in hospital last night with a stab wound to the throat.

Nearly two dozen youths were arrested.

A police spokesman said the youths belonged to rival gangs from low-income housing estates in the suburbs of Mantes-la-Jolie and Chanteloup.

The youths had clashed the previous weekend on their home turf, he said, and seemed to have chosen the more dramatic and public setting of La Defense to settle their scores.

"Senseless gang violence is a fast-growing phenomenon in several suburbs, but this is the first time we've seen gangs with enough discipline and organisation to agree to stage a battle on neutral territory," he said. "It is an extremely worrying development."

The number of 13-18 year-olds serving jail sentences in France has doubled to more than 4,250 in the past eight years, and the number in jail for violent crime has almost tripled, to 3,825.

For the past 20 years, murders of adolescents by adolescents have fluctuated from 20 to 40 a year.

A senior local official, Simone Mielle, said the fight began at around 4pm, when the district's big-name chain stores and fountain-filled squares were crammed with bargain hunters.

Mr Mielle said the youths, most aged between 15 and 18, had arrived on public transport and fled the same way as soon as the panicked shopkeepers began lowering their steel shutters - trapping sales staff and shoppers inside - and squads of CRS officers armed with tear gas moved in.

While dozens of police officers waited for the returning youths at Mantes-la-Jolie station until late evening, most of them got off the suburban commuter trains at earlier stations, starting further battles in which six more people were injured and 12 others arrested.

Six French teenagers have died in the past four months as a result of gang violence, which has hitherto been confined to the run-down outer suburbs of Paris and other big cities, such as Marseille, Grenoble and Strasbourg.

In November a quiet, studious 14-year-old boy called Romuald was shot dead a few yards from his flat in the Paris suburb of Courconnes, the mistaken victim of a gang revenge killing.

A 17-year-old, Sami, died from shotgun wounds the following month, prompting Gilbert Conte, the mayor of the northern suburb of Drancy, to demand "urgent national measures to calm the violence which has taken hold of our young people".

Explanations for the surge in violent teenage crime have ranged from the absence of parental control to the growing influence of drugs and the increasing alienation of young Muslims from the mainstream of French society.

Earlier this month Romuald's killers said in court that they had no idea what the rival gangs' original dispute had been about.

webTitle: Florida 'recounts' make Gore winner

fields.headline: Florida 'recounts' make Gore winner
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore, not George Bush, should be sitting in the White House today as the newly elected president of the United States, two new independent probes of the disputed Florida election contest have confirmed.
fields.body:
Al Gore, not George Bush, should be sitting in the White House today as the newly elected president of the United States, two new independent probes of the disputed Florida election contest have confirmed.

The first survey, conducted on behalf of the Washington Post, shows that Mr Gore had a nearly three-to-one majority among 56,000 Florida voters whose November 7 ballot papers were discounted because they contained more than one punched hole.

The second and separate survey, conducted on behalf of the Palm Beach Post, shows that Mr Gore had a majority of 682 votes among the discounted "dimpled" ballots in Palm Beach county.

In each case, if the newly examined votes had been allowed to count in the November election, Mr Gore would have won Florida's 21 electoral college votes by a narrow majority and he, not Mr Bush, would be the president. Instead, Mr Bush officially carried Florida by 537 votes after recounts were stopped.

In spite of the findings, no legal challenge to the Florida result is possible in the light of the US supreme court's 5-4 ruling in December to hand the state to Mr Bush. But the revelations will continue to cast a cloud, to put it mildly, over the democratic legitimacy of Mr Bush's election.

Some 56,000 so-called "overvotes" were examined in the Washington Post survey. All of these ballot papers were ruled to be invalid votes on November 7 because they contained two or more punched holes in the presidential section of the ballot. Twelve Florida counties used voting machines where voting was by punch cards in this way, and eight of them participated in the survey: Broward, Highlands, Hillsborough, Marion, Miami-Dade, Palm Beach, Pasco and Pinellas. None of the ballot papers in the survey formed part of any official count or recount.

The research shows that 45,608 of the 56,000 ballot papers (87% of the total) contained votes for Mr Gore, compared with 17,098 containing votes for Mr Bush (33%). In 1,367 cases, voters punched every hole except that for Mr Bush.

In cases where the voters cast invalid "overvotes" in the presidential election, but then cast valid votes in the US senate contest lower down on the same ballot, 70% voted Democrat, Mr Gore's party, and only 24% voted Republican.

The disproportion was especially dramatic in Palm Beach, whose butterfly ballot paper interleaved two lists of candidates in such a way as to show Mr Gore's name second on the ballot paper, but to require the voter to punch the third hole to record a vote for him.

The survey also clearly implies that some of Florida's voting machines were inadequate and that many voters were confused by the procedure.

The ballots in the survey had been set aside for a possible court-ordered review that never took place.

Of the disputed ballots, some 2,500 had dimples for Mr Gore, while 1,818 had similar marks for Mr Bush. If they had been counted, Mr Gore would have had a net gain of 682 votes. This would have been in addition to a separate net gain of 174 votes from Palm Beach which was disallowed by Florida's secretary of state.

webTitle: Pressure grows on IRA over arms

fields.headline: Pressure grows on IRA over arms
fields.standfirst:
Deal to salvage peace process may be close but hinges on republicans' readiness to destroy weapons

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Deal to salvage peace process may be close but hinges on republicans' readiness to destroy weapons.
fields.body:
The IRA came under new pressure yesterday to get rid of a substantial amount of weapons in return for a significant security scaledown in Northern Ireland and investigations into the killings of several high-profile nationalists.

A deal to salvage the deadlocked political process could be close, but it hinges on whether the Provisionals take one of the most radical steps in their history by agreeing to destroy some guns or seal over a number of their secret arms dumps.

Tony Blair is to hold talks with the Irish premier, Bertie Ahern, in Downing Street on Wednesday night, and while sources played down chances of an immediate announce ment, they are cautiously hopeful that there could be a breakthrough soon afterwards.

"We think we're moving forward but you never know if or when it is going happen, because everything has to fit together at once or it might not happen at all," said a source.

The Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, wants the IRA to make serious moves towards disarmament before he will lift a ban on Sinn Fein's two Stormont government ministers attending cross-border meetings.

Republicans want demilitarisation, particularly in the heavily fortified south Armagh area. They are also deeply unhappy with the current legislation for police reform, which they believe does not go far enough.

Mr Blair spent more than six hours with Sinn Fein leaders in Downing Street last week, and a similar period of time with them at Hillsborough Castle the week before, much longer than with the unionist delegation.

While republicans insist that the negotiations focused mainly on policing and not much progress on the overall situation was made, it is clear that an intense effort is under way to come up with a solution to the arms dilemma.

Mr Trimble said yesterday: "I think the government may have put some proposals to them and I know the Irish government has been putting pressure on them as well. We hope they're going to come back and tell us precisely how they're going to put weapons beyond use in a permanent and verifiable way."

Sean McManus, a Sinn Fein executive member, dismissed Mr Trimble's comments, saying they bore no relationship to the discussions in which his party was involved and that there was still a lot of work to do on all issues surrounding the peace process.

The IRA would never agree to hand over weapons as that would be seen symbolically as surrender, but Mr Trimble said he was unconcerned about the method of decommissioning as long as the guns were rendered permanently unusable.

It is believed the British government could signal the opening gambit in a sequence that could take several months in the run-up to the general election, by agreeing to close army installations in Newtownstewart, Co Tyrone, and Magherafelt, Co Londonderry, as well as up to five of the 14 watchtowers in south Armagh.

The police ombudsman Nuala O'Loan would have her powers dramatically extended, allowing her to launch retrospective investigations into alleged security force collusion in the loyalist murders of Robert Hamill in Portadown and the solicitors Pat Finucane and Rosemary Nelson.

This would help to finally win over the province's largest nationalist party, the SDLP, which is thought to be on the verge of endorsing the policing reform package and nominating representatives to the new police board. But Sinn Fein leaders have yet to convince the majority of grassroots republicans that these gains would make the unprecedented step of concreting over weapons bunkers or pouring chemicals on their guns worthwhile.

The government would also have to tread carefully, weighing up the increasing threat from dissident groups, loyalist and republican, and avoiding the appearance of a trade-off over legal security resources and illegal paramilitary arms.

As ever, timing is everything in Northern Irish politics, and much of this would have to happen as simultaneously and seamlessly as possible so that no party seemed to have given ground first. All sides are aware that the window of opportunity is fast closing with Mr Trimble weighed down by hardliners in his party who want him to quit the power-sharing government unless the IRA makes a meaningful gesture on guns.

webTitle: French say Britain can't be trusted on EU

fields.headline: French say Britain can't be trusted on EU
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's hopes of placing Britain at the heart of Europe suffer a major setback today when the French Europe minister claims that Britain has a "limited conception" of the EU.
fields.byline: John Hooper  in Berlin and  Nicholas Watt
fields.body:
Tony Blair's hopes of placing Britain at the heart of Europe suffer a major setback today when the French Europe minister claims that Britain has a "limited conception" of the EU.

In a stinging rebuke to the prime minister on the day that he arrives in Berlin for talks on the future of the EU, Pierre Moscovici warns Germany against forging links with the British because London's commitment to the European project cannot be trusted.

Against a background of crisis in relations between France and Germany, today's edition of Der Spiegel will report Mr Moscovici, the second in command at the French foreign ministry, as saying: "It is inconceivable [for Germany] to form shifting alliances with, for example, the British, who in certain areas still have a pretty limited conception of the construction of Europe."

His remarks are a withering commentary on Mr Blair's repeated assertions that Britain is playing an active role at the heart of the EU. But they also appear to reflect growing concern in Paris over the state of relations with Berlin and recent overtures by Germany to Britain.

Downing Street last night refused to comment on Mr Moscovici's remarks. No 10 said that Mr Blair would hold talks with the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, tonight as part of his regular contacts with all EU leaders, including the French president Jacques Chirac.

The leaders of France and Germany are to meet in Strasbourg on Wednesday for a crisis summit aimed at reviving their ailing alliance.

But in the run-up to the meeting, the German government's gaze has been trained, not on France, but Britain. Last week, the foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, used an engagement in London to try to reassure Eurosceptics that his vision of a federal Europe would have a prominent place for nation states.

Today, Mr Schröder is to host a dinner for Mr Blair at his private residence in Berlin, just two days before the Franco-German summit. The two men had a similar get-together before Mr Chirac's state visit to Berlin last year.

In his interview, Mr Moscovici calls the Berlin-Paris axis "irreplaceable".

But relations between France and Germany - once the driving force behind European integration - have been deteriorating steadily in recent years. They reached a turning point at last December's Nice summit when the two sides clashed head-on over the balance of power in a Europe whose biggest state is now reunified Germany.

The French succeeded in retaining basic voting parity with Germany in the European council, but conceded for the first time that Germany's demographic weight should be recognised in certain circumstances.

The two countries are also at odds over whether the EU should - as the French, and the British, believe - bypass the Brussels-based institutions when making key decisions.

webTitle: Who really won the cold war?

fields.headline: Who really won the cold war?
fields.trailText: Battle for the Holocaust | Popstars
fields.body:
Not so long ago, I went to Amsterdam with a friend for a long weekend. During our sojourn, we decided to visit Anne Frank's house. "Do you think they have a gift shop?" he asked giddily. I was bemused. He wasn't even on drugs. "Selling what?" I asked.

I was reminded of this moment by Battle for the Holocaust (C4, Sat), a brave and accomplished documentary which charted the development of attitudes towards the Holocaust and challenged orthodox opinions about the whole terrible event. Broadcast to coincide with Holocaust Memorial Day and the 56th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz, this was one of those programmes which messes with your head just when you think you've finally decided what you think about all the Big Issues in the world. "Challenging" doesn't even begin to cover it.

Initially, it looked quite pedestrian, with footage of the Holocaust Education Trust leading a day trip to Auschwitz. "This concept may seem bizarre to some of you," the tour guide admitted, but atrocity tourism is hardly unusual. Then came the archive newsreels of the liberation of death and concentration camps. "There are the bodies and all those guys were dead," swaggered the original voiceover. And then came the talking heads who pieced together how the narrative of the Holocaust was created out of the historical events. They explained how the Holocaust as an Event didn't come into being until some 15 years after the war, and years after Germany had been de-Nazified, rehabilitated and recruited as a western ally against a new enemy - the Soviets. (It was conveniently forgotten that it was the Soviets who liberated Auschwitz in the first place.) "The Nazis won the cold war," argued one commentator. It was hard not to agree with her.

The controversy then became torrential, with Jewish commentators saying things that would have been unthinkable over on BBC2, home of Spielberg's emotionally manipulative effort The Last Days. They railed against the Holocaust Industry and international Jewish organisations who'd effectively "extorted" money from Swiss banks, most of which hadn't reached survivors. They challenged the notion that Jews are morally superior because they're victims, and questioned whether they have a monopoly on suffering. They said things that needed to be said, things that a more emotionally mature world would listen to instead of dismiss as anti-Semitism.

That isn't to say these commentators were completely right, but they raised issues which should be talked about sensibly. In truth, what they said made a lot of sense. From being untouchable in one sense, the Jews/Israelis became untouchable in another. Having survived the Holocaust, the Jews who went on to become Israelis became first martyrs then holy people and, as one commentator pointed out, being victims has led them to think - subconsciously or not - they can victimise. It's difficult to argue with people whose views have been hewn by the appalling experiences they had during the war, people whose entire families, neighbourhoods and communities were wiped out - but courageously, Battle for the Holocaust did just that. Including footage of the Palestinian father and son shot dead last year and the murder of Israeli soldiers meant the programme demonstrated that for every death in the West Bank or wherever, Hitler wins another victory. It made clear that for all the Memorial Days and museums, the lessons of the Holocaust have not been learnt, and that sombre recollections mean nothing when genocide continues worldwide. Easy watching, this was not.

The glorious Popstars (ITV, Sat) continues. Like a minibus crash in Hollyoaks, the carnage on display was magnificent. As the whittling from 33 wannabes to 10 maybes progressed, it became clear that weirdy beardy Darius ("How much love is in this room?") was heading for disappointment, as was James, who danced as if he were on day release. The judges - whose qualifications included looking like Frankenstein's wee brother in a lumberjack shirt and managing a rather rubbish pop act - were upset at letting some of their charges go. They needn't be. Rest assured that those who've been banished will pop up as kids' TV presenters and as third engine from the left in a regional tour of Starlight Express. Everyone's a winner.

webTitle: Films pick of the day:

fields.headline: Films pick of the day:
fields.trailText: Stray Dog | The Game | She-Devil | Entrapment
fields.body:
Stray Dog (Akira Kurosawa, 1949) 6pm, FilmFour
Kurosawa, renowned admirer of the American western, here turns his attention to that other American cinema staple, the crime thriller. It's set almost tangibly in the sweltering summer heat of a rundown postwar Tokyo, where detective Toshiro Mifune is dishonoured by the theft of his gun. His hunt for the thief takes him into the city's underworld, but director Kurosawa makes room for beauty, and for human kindness too, in this compelling early work.

The Game (David Fincher, 1997) 8.05pm, FilmFour
Fincher's follow-up to the repellent but effective Seven is a less violent, but similarly unsettling thriller, pitching a rich investment banker into a Kafkaesque world that's ruled by a mysterious game in which there are no apparent rules - a kind of Mornington Crescent with menace. It's an intriguing premise, and Michael Douglas certainly makes the most of his hero/victim role, with Sean Penn playing the flakey brother who leads him into the mess. All very clever stuff, if lacking an emotional grip.

She-Devil (Susan Seidelman, 1989) 9pm, Living
Roseanne Barr's incarnation as housewife from hell stands her in good stead: plump, dull and abandoned by her husband for slim and elegant romantic novelist Meryl Streep, she gleefully visits umpteen curses upon the smug couple.

Entrapment (Jon Amiel, 1999) 10pm, Sky Premier
Sean Connery finds himself in a slick, glossy, no-expense-spared action movie, with Catherine Zeta-Jones playing a high-class Bond babe. He's a master thief, and she's an officer of the law out to entrap him, but falling for his grey charm.

webTitle: The bright side of the road

fields.headline: The bright side of the road
fields.trailText: Michele Hanson: A ghastly truth has emerged in the past month. I now know that nearly every house in our street is cleaner, tidier, more tasteful and more comfortable than ours. Even the dogs and cats are neater and odourless.
fields.body:
A ghastly truth has emerged in the past month. I now know that nearly every house in our street is cleaner, tidier, more tasteful and more comfortable than ours. Even the dogs and cats are neater and odourless.

I know this because we visited extensively over the festive season. Worse still, my mother knows, too, because I trundled her about partying. A new world opened to her: a clean, smart world of spacious living rooms, fabulous kitchen extensions, charming neighbours, divine snacks. Naturally, she began to compare. Why did our home look like a dark and tiny slum, and everyone else's like a large, airy mansion, if all the houses were exactly the same size?

Last week, while dining out across the road, I met a lady who knew my mother, so I recklessly whizzed her over to our house to visit. My mother was overjoyed, or would have been, if the surprise visit hadn't been tarnished by shame. I'd forgotten that the visitor would see our interior: the cracked paintwork, the washing dangling from radiators, the rumpled throws, the scattered dog chewies.

Who would guess that I devote much of my life to cleaning this Forth Bridge of a house but getting nowhere? I finish the kitchen, the lounge looks a tip; I tidy the lounge, the bathroom is a swamp. Where does all the filth and debris come from?

Until recently, I had Rosemary next door in another slum. Neither of us could conquer the housework. We would stare across the road together, united by domestic failure, looking enviously at the smart houses opposite. But now Rosemary has moved into her new flat. I dragged my mother there for a party. She inspected the new premises carefully. "I can't fault it!" she cried.

What a surprise! My mother can usually find fault if she looks hard, but Rosemary's flat was perfection: lovely new kitchen, no stairs, filth or clutter, not even a cat. But perhaps one day, when her children come to stay, the bits accumulate, the cat returns . . . I live in hope.

Who would guess that I devote much of my life to cleaning this Forth Bridge of a house but getting nowhere? I finish the kitchen, the lounge looks a tip; I tidy the lounge, the bathroom is a swamp. Where does all the filth and debris come from? Until recently, I had Rosemary next door in another slum. Neither of us could conquer the housework. We would stare across the road together, united by domestic failure, looking enviously at the smart houses opposite. But now Rosemary has moved into her new flat. I dragged my mother there for a party. She inspected the new premises carefully. "I can't fault it!" she cried. What a surprise! My mother can usually find fault if she looks hard, but Rosemary's flat was perfection: lovely new kitchen, no stairs, filth or clutter, not even a cat. But perhaps one day, when her children come to stay, the bits accumulate, the cat returns . . . I live in hope.

webTitle: Comment: Inside Europe: Schmoozing in Berlin

fields.headline: Schmoozing in Berlin
fields.trailText: Street-fighting Joschka Fischer may have pulled a couple of punches on his heavily trailed visit to London last week, but his arguments about the future of Europe have not been answered by a government desperate for the issue to go away - for now.
fields.body:
Street-fighting Joschka Fischer may have pulled a couple of punches on his heavily trailed visit to London last week, but his arguments about the future of Europe have not been answered by a government desperate for the issue to go away - for now.

Events - every politician's curse - meant the German foreign minister's timing wasn't great: it was the day, after all, that the most pro-European foreign secretary we never had fell on his sword. Yet Fischer didn't mention the dreaded F-word and he even insisted there would no "superstate", which must have left the Tories feeling a bit like those Romans who were told that the barbarians weren't coming after all.

Still, there's no disguising Anglo-German differences over the way ahead for the union. British Euro-wonks used to dismiss Joschka as expressing personal views or being off-the-wall, and deal directly with Gerhard Schröder's people instead. But then came the chancellor's call for an EU constitution incorporating the charter of fundamental rights (the one Keith Vaz said was no more important than the Beano) - which was hardly designed to make life easier for Downing Street. It is a happy coincidence, then, that Tony Blair is able to take time off from passportgate for a quick schmooze with Schröder in Berlin today.

But what will they say about the great "deeper and wider" debate about the future of Europe they agreed to at Nice? (That was the deal that allowed Schröder to pull a fast one on his least favourite EU colleague, Jacques Chirac. The two meet in Strasbourg this week for some public tinkering under the bonnet of the clapped-out Franco-German motor. Frankly, and happily for Mr Blair, it doesn't look as if it is about to roar back into life.)

Looking ahead to that debate, Blair wants lots of time-consuming consultation, at home and across the union, and little substance, keeping the difficult bits strictly between governments and as close as possible to 2004, when another treaty change is to be discussed. We are talking phone-ins, websites, public meetings and roadshows, with a starring role for Mr Vaz if he survives the curse of Hinduja, and if anyone can work out some simple questions to ask.

The Tories are already sounding off about the terrible dangers ahead. But it is going to happen. How it will all play in the proverbial Dog and Duck is a different matter.

 Irish eyes are distinctly unsmiling after that public rebuke from the European commission over a budget that will pump £1.5bn into an already overheating economy. But with annual growth of almost 10% and unemployment at a record low, Bertie Ahern's government says the motive is envy rather than a justified reminder of the responsibilities of being in euroland. It is striking, too, to see that polls show 70% backing for Charlie McCreevy, the combative finance minister.

Old time Europhiles lament not only that the roars of the Celtic tiger are getting dangerously loud, but also that it has squandered the enormous goodwill it once enjoyed by being so close to Britain - with special reference to Ahern's backing for Blair at Nice over vetoes on tax and social security. So when is Romano Prodi going to make that long-overdue visit to Dublin? No hurry, is the word in Brussels, when he can get to London so easily.

 Chris Patten had a sadly unreported rant in the European parliament the other day - a happy example of acid wit still working even when everything is lost in translation. His target was the unfortunate Geoffrey Van Orden, a Tory MEP who objected to the commission's plans to streamline its appallingly slow aid delivery - and gets his news about the EU from the Daily Telegraph.

The subject was Eurocracy at its leaden worst, with an explanation that the rapid reaction facility (civilian operations for post-conflict situations) had been helpfully renamed the rapid reaction mechanism to avoid confusion with the rapid reaction force - that's the one that isn't a European army.

Patten, by contrast, was refreshingly clear: "If Conservatives like my honourable friend do not approve of this, I have to ask the question, not entirely rhetorically, what the hell will they ever approve of? In the days when I was chairman of the party of which the hon gentleman is a member, we actually believed in trying to speed up the delivery of financial assistance. We actually believed in trying to cut through red tape.

"So I wonder what the hell my honourable friends and his colleagues actually believe in these days?"

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In an article on the former MI6 officer, Richard Tomlinson, page 3, January 24, we said his book was the subject of a high court injunction obtained by MI6 against the Sunday Times. Though the attorney general, on behalf of MI6, did obtain an injunction against the newspaper in 1996, last week's case in the high court was initiated by the Sunday Times, which wanted, and succeeded, in varying the terms of the injunction.

Though the attorney general, on behalf of MI6, did obtain an injunction against the newspaper in 1996, last week's case in the high court was initiated by the Sunday Times, which wanted, and succeeded, in varying the terms of the injunction.

Contrary to what we said in a report, page 1, January 25, Charles Powell (Lord Powell of Bayswater) was never British ambassador in Washington. From 1971-74 he was first secretary and private secretary to the ambassador there.

In our obituary of James Mark, page 24, January 25, we listed Simone Veil among the philosophers he was most interested in. We should have said Simone Weil.

In a report headed Stately silverfish get their chips, page 13, January 26, we mistook the name of Thomas Chippendale's client at Nostell Priory. He was Sir Rowland Winn (not Will).

Michael McNay, whose witness statement was mentioned in a story about the raid on a John Lennon exhibition in 1970, page 11, January 26, was arts editor of the Guardian at the time, not arts correspondent.

Italian department: in our parliamentary sketch, page 1, January 25, we described the singular Alastair Campbell as Tony Blair's consiglieri (plural). The singular noun is consigliere.

webTitle: Obituary: Dave Goodman

fields.headline: Dave Goodman
fields.standfirst: Spanish civil war veteran, educationalist and indefatigable campaigner for pensioners' rights
fields.trailText: Spanish civil war veteran, educationalist and indefatigable campaigner for pensioners' rights.
fields.body:
Dave Goodman, who has died aged 85, was an influential figure in the pensioners' movement, a former Communist party organiser, and a lifelong political activist. He was one of the last surviving members of the International Brigade which fought for the Republicans in the Spanish civil war, and an inspirational adult educator.

Dave's early years were spent in Middlesbrough, where his parents, fleeing the persecution of Jews in the Russian empire, had settled. His father opened a general store and Dave was brought up within a liberal family, one that fostered his lifelong passion for books and education. He attended Middlesbrough high school and, after working for his father, became a travelling salesman.

In 1930 he joined the Young Communist League. This involvement led to his volunteering to fight in Spain in January 1938. After being wounded in the leg, he returned, as commissar, to the fourth company of the British Battalion. He was taken prisoner in the spring of 1938, remaining in captivity - in San Pedro de Cardena concentration camp - for nearly 10 months.

Of his life in the camp, Dave recalled in an interview for the Guardian last November: "It was grim. No windows, just bars. It was cold, even into late spring. There was a stone floor and no bedding. Sanitation was minimal. You'd get a very small loaf of bread once a day, otherwise only beans... People made chess sets from bits of bread and we organised classes. We endeavoured to keep ourselves mentally, as well as physically, alive."

On his return to England, Dave continued to work for the Communist party and was a CP organiser in the 1940s and 1950s in Devon and Cornwall. During the second world war, as with many ex-Brigaders, he was banned from enlisting in the army and blacklisted from war work.

His family had been too poor to enable him to attend university in the 30s, but he became a mature student at 50 and, having graduated in economics from Hull in 1969, worked as a lecturer in trade union studies at Cauldon College in Stoke-on Trent, later becoming warden and tutor-organiser for the Workers' Education Association at the Wedgwood Memorial College, Barlaston (1972-79). There he pioneered a programme of studies including summer schools for North Staffordshire miners and, for the Open University/WEA, on the renaissance and the reformation.

After retiring as warden, he continued organising and teaching adult education programmes. Some reflected his 1930s experiences, such as the successful Spanish civil war summer schools. Others illustrated his new concerns for the rights of older people, as with the programmes he organised for the National Pensioners' Convention. His educational achievements were honoured last year with an honorary doctorate from Staffordshire University.

In the last phase of Dave's life, he invigorated the pensioner movement. His vision of dignity and independence was built around restoring the link between the state pension and earnings. Chairing the North Staffordshire Pensioners' Convention from its inception in 1991, he characteristically paid for the advertisement announcing its first public meeting. This was a tumultuous 300-strong event at the Hanley Museum where Dave and another Brigader-turned-pensioner, Jack Jones, spoke. Through the 1990s he served on the National Council of the Pensioners' Convention.

He was a superbly effective writer. He wrote a Grey Power column in Stoke-on-Trent's paper, The Sentinel, and in his book No Thanks to Lloyd George (1998) he dealt with the development of state pensions. He was active right up to his death, always armed with facts, figures, and rational arguments. A fighter and a tough opponent, Dave Goodman was also a man of great compassion and generosity.

He was married twice. He is survived by his daughter, Carol, and two grandchildren.

 David Goodman, political activist, born February 25 1915; died January 3 2001

webTitle: Obituary: Harry Oster

fields.headline: Harry Oster
fields.standfirst: Musicologist and record producer who popularised the blues
fields.trailText: Musicologist and record producer who popularised the blues.
fields.body:
The folklorist and song collector Harry Oster, who has died aged 77, was well known to blues enthusiasts for his vivid, unstereotypical recordings of African-American rural music. In fact he ranged more widely, across jazz, country and British folksong - interests he promoted both as teacher and as proprietor of a small record company.

Born in Cambridge, Massachusetts, the son of immigrant Russian Jews, he became interested in Yiddish folk song, but soon came to appreciate the whole patchwork of American vernacular music. While teaching at Louisiana State University, a well-received lecture on Old World traditional ballads prompted a colleague to suggest that he apply for a grant to collect local folklore.

"Before long," he recalled, "I found a profusion of unusual material - ancient French ballads, Cajun dance music, Afro-French spirituals... I got the idea that I should issue with my own funds a long-playing record to be called A Sampler of Louisiana Folk Songs." This and succeeding records such as Folk Songs of the Louisiana Acadians, the first LP of Cajun music, appeared under the auspices of the Louisiana Folklore Society, which Oster created with a couple of friends. Later recordings were on his own label, Folk-Lyric.

Oster's greatest discovery came on a trip to the state penitentiary at Angola. He was looking for African-American prison work songs, a genre documented earlier in recordings made for the Library of Congress, but now disappearing as prison farms became mechanised. The tradition in Angola was indeed moribund, but Oster found many impressive blues singers, among them Robert Pete Williams. The singer's intense improvised narratives about prison life and the events that had brought him there, were presented to the world on the 1959 album Angola Prisoner's Blues.

Oster also recorded the New Orleans singer and guitarist Snooks Eaglin, the fiddle-and-guitar duo Butch Cage and Willie Thomas, jazz musicians Billie and DeDe Pierce, old-timey banjoist Snuffy Jenkins and a street musician from Georgia, the Reverend Pearly Brown.

He left Louisiana in 1963 to teach at the University of Iowa, where he remained until his retirement in 1993, working on the American Dictionary of Folklore and pursuing his passion of making and disseminating records. His Folk-Lyric catalogue was acquired by Arhoolie Records and has largely been transferred to CD, and many of his field recordings were heard in 1995 in a BBC Radio 3 series devoted to his life and work.

He is survived by his wife and a son, Aaron.

 Harry Oster, folklorist, born April 17 1923; died January 19 2001.

webTitle: Obituary: Betty Kenward

fields.headline: Betty Kenward
fields.standfirst: Idiosyncratic chronicler of the lives of the champagne set
fields.trailText: Idiosyncratic chronicler of the lives of the champagne set.
fields.body:
Betty Kenward, who has died aged 94, was the undisputed doyenne of professional partygoers. As the author of Jennifer's Diary in Tatler, then Queen and finally Harpers and Queen, she chronicled the social life of English county families at balls, cocktail parties, weddings, royal receptions, race meetings, private views and country house weekends for nearly half a century. Her column consisted of a list of names occasionally preceded by complimentary adjectives, her favourites being "radiant", "exquisite" and "tireless".

She had a phenomenal memory for names, titles and jewellery - "The jewels at this ball were unbelievable in their beauty. The Duchess of Northumberland wore a superb family tiara with her red dress, and her beautiful mother the Duchess of Buccleuch now Mary, Duchess of Buccleuch wore the exquisite Buccleuch emeralds and diamonds. The Duchess of Roxborough, later Mary, Duchess of Roxborough, wore huge diamond bows on her dress and diamond cupid bows in her hair..." Although she attended on average a reception, two cocktail parties and a dinner and dance every day, she never took notes.

Her style was uncritical. She registered her disapproval of a person by omitting to mention them. A young society photographer working for Queen magazine once approached her at a function. "My photographers never speak to me at parties," she informed him acidly. Soon afterwards the young photographer married Princess Margaret and became the Earl of Snowdon, but for years afterwards Jennifer referred to the royal couple as HRH Princess Margaret and her husband.

Her writing style, especially her punctuation, was idiosyncratic. Royal personages were always preceded and followed by semi-colons and the Queen by her own special comma; exclamation marks were preferred to full stops.

Betty's appearance was equally singular. By day she favoured Hardy Amies suits like the Queen's, by night pink taffeta ballgowns. She always wore a four-string pearl choker, hard, geisha-esque makeup, and was heavily powdered with her stiff, bouffant, champagne-coloured hair fastened at the back with a velvet bow.

Despite constant mentions of "dear friends" in her diary she was not a particularly friendly person. This may have been the result of an insecure childhood that she describes without self-pity in her 1992 autobiography, Jennifer's Memoirs. She loved her father, Brian Kemp-Welch, and her twin younger brothers, but she did not get on with her mother, Verena, whom she described as "very pretty but very immoral". At finishing school in Brussels, the 12-year-old Betty was advised by her friend Bunty that they could no longer share a room because Mrs Kemp-Welch was living with a man who was not her husband.

Betty ran away from home at 16 to work in a hat shop in Knightsbridge, and through family connections she met Barbara Cartland and joined the country house and cocktail party set.

In 1932 she married Captain Peter Kenward at St Margaret's, Westminster. Their son Jim was born a year later. But Kenward was a violent alcoholic and they divorced 10 years after. To pay for Jim's education at Winchester, Betty worked in a munitions factory, as a house matron at Eton and on the inquiries desk at Vogue, but even so she was occasionally forced to pawn items of jewellery to pay school fees.

In 1944 she started working for the On and Off Duty in Town and Country column of Tatler, receiving 10 shillings and six pence for her first report of a flower show. In the early days she would stand for hours outside the Ritz to see who came in and went out. The following year the editor changed the column's name to Jennifer's Diary because he said she looked like a Jennifer.

Betty Kenward is often credited as the person who put an end to the tradition of presenting debutantes at court; she confided to a friend of the Queen's that she considered it outdated, vulgar and commercialised. It stopped in 1958.

Her personal style and social standards may have been set in aspic but she recognised before many of her peers that it was more sensible for a young woman to go to university than to look for an eligible husband. The young women who worked on Jennifer's Diary - she had two full-time assistants - did not, however, regard Betty as their champion. They were not allowed to smoke, have red hair, use biros or be Irish. Most of them left after four months.

 Elizabeth Kenward, society columnist, born July 14 1906; died January 24 2001.

This may have been the result of an insecure childhood that she describes without self-pity in her 1992 autobiography, Jennifer's Memoirs. She loved her father, Brian Kemp-Welch, and her twin younger brothers, but she did not get on with her mother, Verena, whom she described as "very pretty but very immoral". At finishing school in Brussels, the 12-year-old Betty was advised by her friend Bunty that they could no longer share a room because Mrs Kemp-Welch was living with a man who was not her husband. Betty ran away from home at 16 to work in a hat shop in Knightsbridge, and through family connections she met Barbara Cartland and joined the country house and cocktail party set. In 1932 she married Captain Peter Kenward at St Margaret's, Westminster. Their son Jim was born a year later. But Kenward was a violent alcoholic and they divorced 10 years after. To pay for Jim's education at Winchester, Betty worked in a munitions factory, as a house matron at Eton and on the inquiries desk at Vogue, but even so she was occasionally forced to pawn items of jewellery to pay school fees. In 1944 she started working for the On and Off Duty in Town and Country column of Tatler, receiving 10 shillings and six pence for her first report of a flower show. In the early days she would stand for hours outside the Ritz to see who came in and went out. The following year the editor changed the column's name to Jennifer's Diary because he said she looked like a Jennifer. Betty Kenward is often credited as the person who put an end to the tradition of presenting debutantes at court; she confided to a friend of the Queen's that she considered it outdated, vulgar and commercialised. It stopped in 1958. Her personal style and social standards may have been set in aspic but she recognised before many of her peers that it was more sensible for a young woman to go to university than to look for an eligible husband. The young women who worked on Jennifer's Diary - she had two full-time assistants - did not, however, regard Betty as their champion. They were not allowed to smoke, have red hair, use biros or be Irish. Most of them left after four months.  Elizabeth Kenward, society columnist, born July 14 1906; died January 24 2001.

webTitle: Obituary: Charles Mérieux

fields.headline: Charles Mérieux
fields.standfirst: Virologist and pioneer of vaccine production
fields.trailText: Virologist and pioneer of vaccine production.
fields.body:
Charles Mérieux, the French virologist who pioneered the large-scale industrial production of vaccines that have saved millions of lives, has died aged 94. He also played a major role in many of the public health initiatives launched by the World Health Organisation in developing countries.

His achievements covered diseases in people and animals. In the late 50s he developed processes for the production of large quantities of the two polio vaccines and made a start on the worldwide eradication of the disease. His organisation, the Institut Mérieux, refined and cultivated vaccines against rabies, rubella, diphtheria, tetanus and other diseases.

Born in Lyon, Charles was the younger of two sons. His father, Marcel Mérieux, was a microbiologist and former assistant to Louis Pasteur, the scientist who made the connection between micro-organisms and disease. This was the foundation of modern bacteriology.

In 1897 Marcel had set up a laboratory to apply Pasteur's ideas to the diagnosis of diphtheria and to prepare serums. He bought 100 acres of land at Marcy l'Etoile, outside Lyon, for pasture for horses used to produce anti-diphtheria serum and for cows that would provide serum against foot-and-mouth disease.

The land is now the site of the world headquarters of the Mérieux organisation, which, after Marcel's death, became a global powerhouse for preventive medicine under Charles's guidance.

Yet Charles had intended to pursue a career in medicine rather than in the family laboratory. While his elder brother, Jean, joined their father with a view to succeeding him in the business, Charles studied medicine. But Jean died from meningitis contracted in the laboratory. Charles agreed to join his father after training in microbiological research at the Institut Pasteur, and inherited the laboratory when his father died in 1937.

During the second world war Mérieux created a blood transfusion centre for the French resistance - his wife delivered the plasma to the fighters on her bicycle - and he produced and distributed protein-rich extracts to feed undernourished children.

After the war he went to the United States to study advances in purifying blood products from transfusions, and other experiments that were the forerunners of biotechnology. He used this knowledge in planning the institute's future, because the French government had banned commercial laboratories from handling human blood products.

On returning to France, Mérieux concentrated on veterinary medicine and created the Institut Français de la Fièvre Aphteuse (the Foot-and-Mouth Institute), where, for the first time, the virus was cultured on an industrial scale. The early method of cultivating foot-and-mouth was to apply it to the tongue of a live cow and harvest the multiplied cells from the resulting pustules. The work was laborious and produced only small amounts of usable virus.

Charles found a more efficient way, by harvesting the cow tongues and using the tissue to form a growth medium that could be used to produce viruses on an industrial scale. When, in the 60s, a foot-and-mouth epidemic threatened livestock in Europe, he organised a "vaccine barrage" to stop its spread. The next step was to apply similar techniques to human health. This began with the large-scale production of the Salk polio vaccine, cultivated on tissue from monkeys' kidneys.

Mérieux went on to collaborate on vaccine projects with other scientists like Hilary Koprowski, a virologist with whom he introduced a new rabies vaccine for humans.

His vigorous approach to public health campaigns was apparent in 1973 when, in response to a meningitis epidemic in Brazil, he built a plant to produce enough vaccine for 90m Brazilians. Later he designed a portable plant that could fit into a Hercules airplane to treat outbreaks on the spot.

Mérieux's interest went beyond research and development and focused on the social and political mechanisms for delivering vaccines to large numbers of people. He believed that it was not enough to manufacture the vaccines without addressing the logistical problems.

In the early 80s he formed a training organisation, Bioforce Développement, to prepare professionals for public health emergencies. He converted a family property into an epidemiological teaching centre, the first course at which was carried out in collaboration with the US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention.

In 1968 controlling interest in Institut Mérieux was sold to Rhone-Poulenc, the French pharmaceutical company; the acquisition was completed in 1994. The Mérieux name has moved into gene therapy through Charles' son Alain, the chairman of Transgene. He is also survived by a daughter, Nicole.

 Charles Mérieux, virologist and vaccine producer, born January 9 1907; died January 18 2001.

webTitle: Letters: No Logo for the Swiss

fields.headline: No Logo for the Swiss
fields.trailText: Planning a winter break in Switzerland? Be careful what you bring as holiday reading. On Friday, members of Bookmarks staff were refused entry at the Swiss border on their way to Zurich to do a bookstall at a conference organised in opposition to the World Economic Forum meeting in Davos (The South rises as Bush fails to show, January 27).
fields.body:
Planning a winter break in Switzerland? Be careful what you bring as holiday reading. On Friday, members of Bookmarks staff were refused entry at the Swiss border on their way to Zurich to do a bookstall at a conference organised in opposition to the World Economic Forum meeting in Davos (The South rises as Bush fails to show, January 27). They had books that the Swiss border guards deemed as too subversive and dangerous to be allowed in while the world's economic leaders were in the country.

The books in question? Captive State by Guardian columnist George Monbiot, and No Logo by Naomi Klein, which came third and first respectively in the Guardian's best-selling books last year. After hours of pressure and outcry here and in Switzerland the authorities finally backed down and the books and booksellers were allowed in.
Judith Orr
Bookmarks bookshop

I read Naomi Klein's book and listened to her talk in central London. It was all beautifully done. But, old Marxist fuddy-duddy that I am, kept asking myself: "Yes, but what is it about? What does she want?" Now I've read her piece (Outflanking the rich and powerful, October 26), all is clear. No need to worry about the destruction of the environment, the attacks on trade union and democratic rights, the fact that a set of zillionaire nutters is now running the White House and the Pentagon on behalf of the biggest of big business. Being outflanked will cause them to collapse like a pack of cards. Why didn't we think of it before?
Cyril Smith
London

webTitle: Letters: New Labour's sorry state

fields.headline: New Labour's sorry state
fields.trailText: Blair, Mandelson and the whole New Labour project were products of defeat (The Hinduja affair, January 27). The 80s left the movement broken and demoralised and created the opportunities that Blair and his allies have exploited.
fields.body:
Blair, Mandelson and the whole New Labour project were products of defeat (The Hinduja affair, January 27). During the 80s, labour, in the widest sense, suffered defeat after defeat on both industrial and political fronts. This left the movement broken and demoralised and created the opportunities that Blair and his allies have exploited.

The policy shifts and evasions of New Labour are becoming increasingly apparent and the false idealism of Blair will be revealed as the illusion it is. Blair, the great democrat, has systematically dismantled the internal democracy of the Labour party and shown nothing but contempt for activists and members. Other sections of the labour movement, cowed by years of defeat, have stood by and watched. Now, the internal checks and balances have gone, is it any wonder that Mandelson and others strut the political stage with such arrogance and disregard for the movement that they supposedly represent?

Blair, the cleanser of the soiled temples of government, has actively led New Labour into the heartlands of wealth and privilege and created a new web of paid-for influence, of backhanded deals and whispered favours. No doubt, the moral climate of the business world is necessarily ambiguous, but when government gets into bed with it, the time has come for all of us to worry. The New Labour enterprise is morally compromised by its closeness to big business and Mandelson's going, welcome though that is, will do little to restore the ideals of labour.
Dr Peter Duff
Sheffield

May I offer the view of a candlestick-maker to those expressed by Mr Butcher and the Rev Baker (Letters, January 26)? Somebody's passport application has been given a gentle nudge forward, which may or may not have hastened the outcome. And we have lost a capable and effective worker for Irish peace. But millions of gallons of ink and tonnes of print and trees have been expended on sanctimonious utterings by all and sundry, with yet more to come.

How could this storm in a teacup ever measure against the years of corruption that flavoured the long years of Tory government? Archer, Aitken, Hamilton et al must be smirking with relish and Schadenfreude.
Dominic Newbould
Milton Keynes, Bucks D.R.A.Newbould@open.ac.uk

Would Hague and his cronies have got their knickers in such a twist if the Indian gentlemen, with their fast-track passports, had been wealthy Canadians, Australians or even white South African Olympic runners?
Andrew Bebb
Liverpool

The BBC played us all manner of songs to accompany the news footage of Peter Mandelson's resignation. As Elton John is trundled out on occasions of national mourning, why not Sorry Seems to Be The Hardest Word?
Daphne Romney
London

We can only be grateful to Hywel Williams for describing the gay subtext to Peter Mandelson's behaviour (It's a gay thing, January 27). There was I thinking it was all about a politician, a dodgy phone-call and a resignation speech; I missed the floppy hair-do, the petulant queenery and risky sex! Now we can truly understand "Pink Wednesday" in terms of "nostrils poised to flare" (whatever that means). Could it be that not only politics attracts chancers of all kinds?
GM McSherry
Clacton-on-Sea, Essex
