webTitle: Letters:Sensitivities that keep the Middle East divided

fields.headline: Sensitivities that keep the Middle East divided
fields.trailText: Elie Wiesel's article is largely a rehash of long-discredited Israeli propaganda, of a sort which is customarily inflicted on American readers but which we are usually spared in the Guardian (Comment, January 25).
fields.body:
Elie Wiesel's article is largely a rehash of long-discredited Israeli propaganda, of a sort which is customarily inflicted on American readers but which we are usually spared in the Guardian (Comment, January 25). He claims that "incited by their leaders, 600,000 Palestinians left the country". Yet all Arab broadcasts were monitored, and 40 years ago Erskine Childers, who had read them, pointed out that not a single Arab broadcast advised Palestinians to leave, though several Israeli broadcasts did. In fact, the Palestinians left because they were driven out by Israel's ruthless ethnic cleansing, comparable to that recently seen in Kosovo.

The claim that Jerusalem is Israel's eternal capital is historical nonsense. Anybody who has been to East Jerusalem knows perfectly well that it is Arab and not remotely Israeli. Wiesel explains that he cannot forget that between 1948 and 1967 Jews were denied access to the Western Wall. Yet he finds it easy to forget that between 1948 and 2001 Palestinians have been denied access not just to a religious site but to their own country.

The Israeli-Arab quarrel would probably have been settled some years ago but for the strength of the American-Israeli lobby and the corruption of American politics. Wiesel's article is yet another demonstration that this lobby is greedier and more extremist than many Israelis.
Lord Gilmour

It seems to me Elie Wiesel chooses to remain silent when he ought to be speaking out and opts to speak out when it would have been preferable to stay silent. I would have hoped that someone who has suffered so much would emerge as a universalistic voice. Alas he chooses to be an ethnocentric tribalist.

The expulsion of the Palestinians and the creation of the refugee problem in 1948 took place before the entry of the Arab armies in war. The ethnic cleansing was the result of the Zionist "plan Dalet", in reaction to the fact that in the Jewish state of the UN partition plan of 1947 there was an Arab majority. The Arab armies never went beyond the territories allocated to the Palestinian Arab state, but the Zionist forces ended up occupying not only the 55% allocated to the Jewish state, but 78% of mandatory Palestine.

Israeli leaders refuse the Palestinians the right of return because they say it will modify the Jewish character of the state. When will they admit and apologise for the historic injustice inflicted upon the Palestinians, driven out of their country precisely so as to insure Jewish numerical predominance and hegemony? Jewish and Israeli insensitivity to the Palestinian ordeal tarnishes and diminishes the respectability of their own claims for recognition, reparation and retribution.
Afif Safieh
Palestinian general delegate to the UK

The Guardian marks the first Holocaust Memorial Day by publishing an advert ("Remembering Nuremberg", January 27) that minimises, relativises, abuses and exploits the memory of the Holocaust. Insulting Jewish sensitivities, on this day of all days, is a strange way for Muslim community leaders to reach out to their Abrahamic cousins.
Jane Koreck
London

webTitle: Letters: Tolerance and evil

fields.headline: Tolerance and evil
fields.trailText: The themes of Holocaust Memorial Day were tolerance and compassion (Leader, January 27).
fields.body:
The themes of Holocaust Memorial Day were tolerance and compassion (Leader, January 27). Strange, then, that the guests of honour included the Chief Rabbi and the Archbishops of Canterbury and Westminster, all well-known supporters of discrimination against homosexuals.
Peter Tatchell
London

If important reminders of the worst of human nature on Holocaust Day threaten to spoil Richard Ainslie's future birthdays (Letters, January 27), may I suggest he celebrates instead sharing his birthday with Mozart, whose every transcendent note conveys the power of the human spirit to triumph over evil.
Alastair Sutherland
Totnes, Devon

Was the William Hague taking part in the Holocaust commemoration the same William Hague that would detain and then return those fleeing persecution in their own countries because some of their claims might be bogus?
Colin Beveridge
University of St Andrews

I was intrigued by your headline about a "Hague prosecutor" (January 26). Is this odious little man about to get his comeuppance?
Edward Gerrard
London

Cathy Bryant (Letters, January 27) recommends a blend of Joyce Grenfell, Delius and Peter Gabriel for the next free CD - presumably a humorous monologue about the First Cuckoo of Spring being dispatched by a blow from a Sledgehammer.
Danny Proudfoot
Northwich, Cheshire

It's all right for you lot. We were looking forward to the Fatboy Slim CD, but some plonker nicked the delivery van with copies of the Weekend section and the CD. There's obviously a demand for it in this neck of the woods.
Cath Staincliffe
Manchester

webTitle: Leader: Philippines' new leader

fields.headline: A presidential coup
fields.standfirst: But Philippines' new leader inherits a mess
fields.trailText: Asked at her first press conference since being appointed president of the Philippines whether an influential general was planning to mount a coup against her, Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo's response was refreshingly direct. "I'll call him up right now and ask," she said.
fields.body:
Asked at her first press conference since being appointed president of the Philippines whether an influential general was planning to mount a coup against her, Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo's response was refreshingly direct. "I'll call him up right now and ask," she said. After an aide reached the general on a mobile phone, with cameras whirring and reporters' pens poised, Mrs Arroyo popped the question to the doubtless rather startled commander. The answer was "no", she announced after a pregnant pause. "He says it's beyond his imagination."

If Mrs Arroyo can bring such aplomb to the many other problems bequeathed by her disgraced predecessor, Joseph Estrada, then things may be looking up for Filipinos. But the list of woes is a long one. Mr Estrada left behind him a hidden budget deficit now recalculated at £3.8bn for this year and a total external debt of £35bn. The economy is in a mess; entrenched poverty is the result and urgent action is required. Mr Estrada's administration, in which Mrs Arroyo served as vice-president, was tainted by rank corruption in the style of Ferdinand Marcos.

So cleaning up the government and the bureaucracy is a priority - as is what to do about her still defiant ex-boss. Staff at the Malacanang palace, picking their way through the dirty crockery and half-gnawed chicken bones of the Estrada era, are still looking for a valuable state-owned art collection. The impeachment hearings were told that the deposed president accumulated a secret £44m bank account awash with kickbacks from illegal gambling syndicates.

All this demands investigation. Mrs Arroyo must also deal with unrest in the southern Philippines, where Muslim rebels belonging to the Moro Islamic Liberation Front are conducting a dogged and bloody secessionist struggle. Her offer of new peace talks, though vastly preferable to Mr Estrada's failed policy of "all-out war", has not so far been taken up.

Stabilising and strengthening the democratic system are perhaps the most basic challenges facing Mrs Arroyo. The daughter of a former president, she hails from the ruling army-church-business elite that has repeatedly let the people down. She seems to enjoy popular support at present, but she lacks the legitimacy that the ballot box confers. Mrs Arroyo has to prove that she is part of the solution, not part of the problem.

If Mrs Arroyo can bring such aplomb to the many other problems bequeathed by her disgraced predecessor, Joseph Estrada, then things may be looking up for Filipinos. But the list of woes is a long one. Mr Estrada left behind him a hidden budget deficit now recalculated at £3.8bn for this year and a total external debt of £35bn. The economy is in a mess; entrenched poverty is the result and urgent action is required. Mr Estrada's administration, in which Mrs Arroyo served as vice-president, was tainted by rank corruption in the style of Ferdinand Marcos. So cleaning up the government and the bureaucracy is a priority - as is what to do about her still defiant ex-boss. Staff at the Malacanang palace, picking their way through the dirty crockery and half-gnawed chicken bones of the Estrada era, are still looking for a valuable state-owned art collection. The impeachment hearings were told that the deposed president accumulated a secret £44m bank account awash with kickbacks from illegal gambling syndicates. All this demands investigation. Mrs Arroyo must also deal with unrest in the southern Philippines, where Muslim rebels belonging to the Moro Islamic Liberation Front are conducting a dogged and bloody secessionist struggle. Her offer of new peace talks, though vastly preferable to Mr Estrada's failed policy of "all-out war", has not so far been taken up. Stabilising and strengthening the democratic system are perhaps the most basic challenges facing Mrs Arroyo. The daughter of a former president, she hails from the ruling army-church-business elite that has repeatedly let the people down. She seems to enjoy popular support at present, but she lacks the legitimacy that the ballot box confers. Mrs Arroyo has to prove that she is part of the solution, not part of the problem.

webTitle: Leader: No house room for political dissidents

fields.headline: Constructive dismissal
fields.standfirst:
No house room for political dissidents

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: However much Alastair Campbell may dispute press accounts of how he assessed Peter Mandelson's recent condition, there is no doubt at all that he did speak of him as having become "slightly  detached ".
fields.body:
However much Alastair Campbell may dispute press accounts of how he assessed Peter Mandelson's recent condition, there is no doubt at all that he did speak of him as having become "slightly detached ". This word has a history. Margaret Thatcher's press spokesman, Bernard Ingham, famously described her maverick minister John Biffen as "semi-detached" shortly before she sacked him. Inevitably now the practice will spread and politicians will come to be assessed on a sliding scale which is precisely the reverse of that used by estate agents selling houses. With them, detached comes top of the list and mid-terrace last (except perhaps in Georgian Bath and such up-market addresses as Belgravia).

From now on, the highest praise in the press secretary's book will be to hail a minister as "completely mid-terrace" - firmly locked in on both sides. David Blunkett, for instance, who keeps out of feuds and is in general thought to have done an excellent job at education and employment, belongs in that category. So does Jack Straw. Some of their cabinet colleagues, though, are rather more end-of-terrace - those such as Clare Short, who pride themselves on speaking their minds, even if it sometimes causes embarrassment. Ann Widdecombe, for the way she does her own things about drugs or hunting, is an end-of-terrace performer, while Michael Portillo, since he entered his caring and sensitive phase, has become so consistently e-o-t that he now counts as semi-detached.

As this categorisation becomes more general, other sub-divisions will come in. Mr Campbell will say of some errant colleague at one of those briefings which do not take place: "I'm afraid he's becoming a bit of a bungalow" or: "We feel there's a bit of a conservatory problem there." Of some other, it may be said: "He [or she] offers generous accommodation." But that, of course, is exactly what keeps getting ministers into trouble.

webTitle: Letters: Russia defends its role in Chechnya

fields.headline: Russia defends its role in Chechnya
fields.trailText: I feel compelled to express my disgust at the anti-Russian outburst in your editorial on Chechnya (January 24). Your newspaper's deeply held prejudice against my country is well-known.
fields.body:
I feel compelled to express my disgust at the anti-Russian outburst in your editorial on Chechnya (January 24). Your newspaper's deeply held prejudice against my country is well-known.

Definite progress has been achieved in Chechnya over past months. Representatives of the Council of Europe recognise that, though, of course, a lot is still to be done to achieve normalcy.

It was not our choice to act in Chechnya. Military action was imposed on us by those bent on exporting their ideology and violent ways to other parts of Russia. The situation is the last thing people in Russia want - but they know that it is what it takes to deal effectively with a threat of that intensity.

You claim to know better than the Russian people, disregarding the fact that Russia is a free and democratic country. For you, President Putin's steady approval rating in the opinion polls of well over 60% means nothing, which I find utterly arrogant if not racist.

Disengagement is not an option. We have had no choice but to protect the legitimate rights and lives of our citizens as well as foreigners who were kidnapped, enslaved, held to ransom, tortured and murdered.
Alexander M Kramarenko
Chargé d'affaires, embassy of the Russian Federation

Thank you for your strong opinion on the situation in Chechnya, which has fought long and hard and deserves to be independent. Russian security forces and death squads should get out; they have no right to terrorise Chechen people any longer. There is no reason for the further presence of any Russian forces on the Chechen soil; the only task for them should be defusing the 500,000 land mines they planted - almost a mine per head of the civilian population - left there after two failed military campaigns. The mass extermination of Chechen citizens is an example of genocide. Chechens have suffered abominable treatment at the hands of regular troops and mercenaries alike.

Aslan Maskadov, the democratically elected president, should be restored to power and allowed to live and work in Chechnya without fear from the FSB, as the KGB now styles itself.
Anya Lauchlan
Redhill, Surrey

webTitle: Analysis: Statistics show immigration beneficial to economy

fields.headline: Welcome to Britain
fields.standfirst:
Despite its illiberalism on asylum seekers, the government has been quietly encouraging other immigration - to the benefit of UK plc

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Despite its illiberalism on asylum seekers, the government has been quietly encouraging other immigration - to the benefit of UK plc.
fields.body:
The theme at the Davos economic extravaganza today and tomorrow is again openness. At the conference last year Tony Blair dedicated the 21st century to winning "an open world, an open economy, and an open global society". And open borders? How open is open when the Heathrow immigration officer is demanding the papers of would-be residents whose skin is not quite white?

Despite the illiberalism of its response to the growth in asylum-seeking, the Blair government has quietly been trying to ease the passage of "economic migrants". These are welcome because, sotto voce, they make the UK more diverse. They are really welcome - this is more politically saleable - because the IT and health sectors need them.

The case for migration as put by Barbara Roche, the Home Office minister, is unabashedly utilitarian. Immigration is good for migrants and good for us (and let's draw a veil over the consequences for their home countries). Assisted by the Cabinet Office's performance and innovation unit, her civil servants this week gave her some useful ammunition by doing the immigration sums for the first time*.

The UK's foreign-born population pay 10% more to the state than they get back in benefits and services - equivalent to £2.6bn a year net. They push up the rate of economic growth by a finite but hard-to-calculate amount and, among other things, ensure we get treated when we are ill. Nearly a third of UK doctors and 13% of nurses are non-UK born; half the extra NHS staff employed over the past decade qualified abroad.

Immigration is now at "historically high" levels. Some 150,000 non-EU, non-UK people are expected to arrive in 2001 with a view to long-term residence. The chart shows where migrants come from. Returning UK citizens form the biggest category of long-run settlers, mainly because from 1945 to the 70s the migrant flow went heavily the other way. Of course, many would not consider them to be migrants at all. It has been "New Commonwealth" - non-white - immigration that has excited controversy.

On the value of individual immigrants the report is not entirely clear. If we are applying an economic calculus, that would favour migrants with skills. Or capital: there has always been significant, largely uncontroversial immigration of people of people who can kick a ball or mobilise a million on the back of official permits and schemes.

Labour is making these easier to get though it is unclear whether the government wants permit holders to settle permanently. About 100,000 applications for work permits are expected this year. After four years permit holders are entitled to apply to live in the UK permanently but, in practice, only a fraction do.

Officially, migrants include "working holidaymakers". These are 17- to 27-year-olds from the Commonwealth who are allowed to stay for up to two years. They are not supposed to work in non-professional jobs but do. Most are white, many are Australian, and without them the pubs of the capital would close down. Up to 15,200 mainly eastern Europeans qualify under the seasonal farm workers' scheme.

Getting into the UK if you are in business is relatively plain sailing - though not, it seems, for the Hinduja brothers. There are several business migrant categories - for those establishing a new company, innovating and investing. Only a few hundred a year enter under these schemes.

Students with a university place get in automatically but can be stopped if immigration officers think they intend to stay here after completing their course (12% of applications are refused, rising to 20-25% from parts of Asia and Africa). In 1998, 266,000 students were given permission to stay on after their courses ended for further training or to take jobs.

Students and Antipodeans are not, however, what the tabloid press nor people at large label migrant - often because they refuse to distinguish between new arrivals and British people of black or Asian descent.

Over race, as over the attributes of individual migrants, the Home Office report betrays a certain naivety, perhaps because it was written by civil servants rather than politicians having to deal with racist attitudes at the sharp end. Immigration clearly has never been just about jobs, housing or even cultural enrichment; it is also about identity, race, resentment and (for the right) a potent source of political mobilisation.

Still, it is worth getting the facts of the immigration story straight. Theory says migration increases the labour supply, depressing wages while bumping up returns to capital. (That ought to make free marketeers passionate advocates of open borders. To judge from Tory party history, it has not happened.) In fact, there is no evidence of sectors where migrants have supplanted UK-born labour.

Instead, migrants are doing well enough to suggest they are bringing something valuable to the party. On average, migrants who work earn rather 12% more on average than the UK-born. Migrants are over-represented in the upper reaches of the income league tables. However, the migrant jobless rate is about one percentage point higher than for the UK-born. Levels of entrepreneurship and self-employment appear to be high among migrants. But that finding may be skewed by the fact that some 150,000 French entrepreneurs have moved to the UK since 1995, many to work in information technology.

But if migrants are as beneficial as the evidence suggests why not admit many more of them? Silence from Barbara Roche and the civil servants on numbers. They recommend Whitehall should tidy up the competing jurisdictions of Home Office, employment and trade departments. But the obvious question remains: if 100,000 human imports a year is good for the UK, wouldn't the benefit double at 200,000 a year?

webTitle: Moor guide drops explosive toilet tip

fields.headline: Moor guide drops explosive toilet tip
fields.trailText: To avoid blotting the Dartmoor landscape the park authority has suggested thoughtful campers should dig their own latrines. But the Ministry of Defence warned that this could lead to holidaymakers blowing themselves up.
fields.body:
Dartmoor offers few options for those caught short by a call of nature. To avoid blotting the landscape, the park authority helpfully suggested, the thoughtful camper should dig their own latrine.

But the Ministry of Defence warned that this could lead to holidaymakers blowing themselves up.

Dartmoor national park authority has now scrapped a proposed guide containing this toilet tip after the army pointed out that unexploded shells, many a legacy of training for D-day, litter the West Country wilderness.

Although there are now only three live firing ranges on Dartmoor, the army has used almost every part of the moor for live ammunition training.

John Weir, of the park authority, said it had decided not to go ahead with the guide after the MoD pointed out that digging on the moor was in breach of bylaws.

"We decided not to launch the guide, but would ask people to use their common sense," he said.

The military have their own methods of avoiding "collateral damage" to the landscape.

Soldiers are sometimes required to bag their deposits, while large bodies of troops either use portable toilets or resort to metal detectors to sniff out the safest spots for digging.

More than three million people visit Dartmoor every year and the Dartmoor Preservation Association has called the scrapping of the guide a "damning indictment" of the dangers of military training.

The association's chief executive, John Bainbridge, said: "By the army's own admission, it would take them 100 years to clear up the moor of ordnance, even if they stopped using it tomorrow.

"It's a sad state of affairs. Some of these shells date back years, but many are recent. We feel they should clear up after themselves, just like everyone else."

webTitle: Former spy signs British book deal

fields.headline: Former spy signs British book deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: A British publisher plans to produce a paperback edition of The Big Breach, by the MI6 renegade Richard Tomlinson, in a move which deals a blow to the Official Secrets Act.
fields.body:
A British publisher plans to produce a paperback edition of The Big Breach, by the MI6 renegade Richard Tomlinson, in a move which deals a blow to the Official Secrets Act.

Mainstream Publishing, based in Edinburgh, was said yesterday to have signed a deal to produce the first British edition of Mr Tomlinson's book next month.

Meanwhile, an online information service, 192.com, plans to import 5,000 copies of the hardback version published in Russia into Britain tomorrow.

Alastair Crawford, 192's chief executive, said: "We just don't see why Russians should have this information first. There is no way Russians should be able to read our secrets when we can't."

Mainstream, which describes itself on its website as the largest independent publishing firm in Scotland, could not be contacted yesterday.

It is unclear how government lawyers acting on behalf of MI6 will react to this latest episode in the Tomlinson saga. The contents of the book, which the Sunday Times is serialising, have been widely reported in the British press and the government will not want to get embroiled in a legal battle reminiscent of the Thatcher administration's failed attempt to suppress Spycatcher, the memoirs of a former MI5 officer, Peter Wright.

The government could claim copyright to the book's contents in a civil action and also charge the publishers and distributors with benefiting from the crime of Mr Tomlinson's breach of confidence. It could also seek to extradite Mr Tomlinson from Italy to face a second prosecution under the Official Secrets Act.

Whitehall sources claim that Serge Korovin, the Russian publisher of The Big Breach, has close links with Russian intelligence services. His real name, they say, is Kirill Tchaschin.

They are also suggesting that some of the material in the book - notably about MI6's disastrous attempt to recruit Platon Obukhov, a Russian diplomat arrested in 1996 - was inserted by the Russian intelligence services.

Oleg Gordievsky, the KGB defector and former MI6 agent, savaged Mr Tomlinson and the Sunday Times in an article in yesterday's Sunday Telegraph.

"By working hand in glove with Tomlinson, the Sunday Times has been working with his backers, FSB (The Russian security service) - those fine supporters of free speech," wrote Mr Gordievsky.

He added: "The Sunday Times editor knows that Tomlinson is a traitor now effectively working for a hostile intelligence service ... Tomlinson is a new kind of traitor: one not motivated by ideology or by moral commitment, nor even by cash, but simply by spite."

Mr Tomlinson in his book accused Dominic Lawson, the Sunday Telegraph's editor, of allowing MI6 agents to use the Spectator as journalistic cover when Mr Lawson was editor of the magazine in the early 1990s. Mr Lawson has denied the claim.

webTitle: Sec's tips:

fields.headline: Sec's tips:
fields.standfirst: 18. Presentation
fields.trailText: 18. Presentation
fields.body:
Keeping the admin team enthralled with stories of the weekend's antics may raise your standing among workmates, but it doesn't qualify you to make a professional presentation in front of the whole company. So when your turn comes, make sure you do your homework.

* Preparation is all. Know your audience, the amount of time you've got, the room and kit available, and whether your presentation risks covering similar ground to another speaker.

* Never underestimate preparation time. Back-of-envelope presentations should be left to the most practised gurus - lesser mortals should not be tempted to "wing" it. One statistic says it takes two hours to prepare half an hour of your talk (including visuals, handouts, etc).

* Think about the visuals you need, when you need them, and the most appropriate equipment. Recent research showed overhead projectors were still top on presenters' lists, followed by the trusty flipchart, although PowerPoint is very common now.

* Write out notes on small cards with headings, bullet points and when you will be showing each visual. Tie or tape cards together so if you drop them, they stay in order.

* Have a run-through using all the equipment, and time it. Get a friend to listen and help you iron out any glitches.

* On the day, take some deep breaths before you start, and slow your speech down. To take emphasis off you initially, put a startling fact up on screen, or ask the audience a question .

* Share eye contact with people all around the room, and try to keep a variable tone to your voice. Have some water handy for any throat tickles.

* Part of your impact comes from how you look, so make sure you are appropriately dressed. Keep hands still, and away from your face and hair.

* Have a question spot at the end. If you get a tricky one, buy time by repeating the question for the audience. If you're still in trouble, throw it open to the floor to gather answers. Failing that, say you have some information on that subject in your office and you'll come back to them. (And make sure you do!)

* And remember, the most common presentation experience is that as soon as you've finished, you realise that you really enjoyed it, and want to do it all over again!
fields.bodyText: Keeping the admin team enthralled with stories of the weekend's antics may raise your standing among workmates, but it doesn't qualify you to make a professional presentation in front of the whole company. So when your turn comes, make sure you do your homework. * Preparation is all. Know your audience, the amount of time you've got, the room and kit available, and whether your presentation risks covering similar ground to another speaker. * Never underestimate preparation time. Back-of-envelope presentations should be left to the most practised gurus - lesser mortals should not be tempted to "wing" it. One statistic says it takes two hours to prepare half an hour of your talk (including visuals, handouts, etc). * Think about the visuals you need, when you need them, and the most appropriate equipment. Recent research showed overhead projectors were still top on presenters' lists, followed by the trusty flipchart, although PowerPoint is very common now. * Write out notes on small cards with headings, bullet points and when you will be showing each visual. Tie or tape cards together so if you drop them, they stay in order. * Have a run-through using all the equipment, and time it. Get a friend to listen and help you iron out any glitches. * On the day, take some deep breaths before you start, and slow your speech down. To take emphasis off you initially, put a startling fact up on screen, or ask the audience a question . * Share eye contact with people all around the room, and try to keep a variable tone to your voice. Have some water handy for any throat tickles. * Part of your impact comes from how you look, so make sure you are appropriately dressed. Keep hands still, and away from your face and hair. * Have a question spot at the end. If you get a tricky one, buy time by repeating the question for the audience. webTitle: WPM

fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: * Ever got annoyed with the incessant need for stamp-licking in today's offices? Ever thought how much time you could save if you could just put stamp straight to envelope, rather than going to all the trouble of a detour via the mouth? No, WPM hasn't either. But that hasn't stopped Royal Mail launching a no-need-to-lick, self-adhesive stamp from today, January 29.
fields.body:
* Ever got annoyed with the incessant need for stamp-licking in today's offices? Ever thought how much time you could save if you could just put stamp straight to envelope, rather than going to all the trouble of a detour via the mouth? No, WPM hasn't either. But that hasn't stopped Royal Mail launching a no-need-to-lick, self-adhesive stamp from today, January 29.

Matthew Gibbs, stamp product manager for Royal Mail (and a man clearly feeling the need to justify his job) has voiced his enthusiasm for the invention. "Small business customers using 100 stamps a week could save a whole working day in a year by switching over to self-adhesive stamps; as the new stamps are quicker to stick for businesses than conventional gummed stamps." A surprising, if slightly stupid, contender, then, for the recurring question of "Where does the time go?"

* More (and arguably better) time-saving techniques can be found at our website of the week, venuefinder.com. The new website for meeting and event organisers helps you save time and money in your search for the perfect venue for your conference, meeting, event, seminar, product launch, training session or big, fat leaving party.

There are more than 6,250 listings of meeting venues in the British Isles, which are being continually updated. Hotels, conference centres, castles, museums, racecourses and all sorts of unusual venues are also listed. For last minute requirements or bargain-hunting, the site has special offers and late availability search, by county or region. A unique feature of the site allows users to take themselves through a selection of virtual reality tours of many of the venues - allowing the user to "walk" through committee rooms, executive suites and have a general nosy at posh buildings they couldn't ordinarily afford to breathe near.

* WPM was delighted to hear news that sultry singer Dido, who recently shot to fame as co-vocalist on Eminem's Stan, used to be a secretary. Treading a more conventional path after leaving school, Dido Armstrong was, for five years, an assistant to Carole Blake of literary agents Blake Friedmann. All this brings hope to the equally talented and doubly sultry WPM, who has yet to be spotted from behind her mountain of paperwork as the superstar of the future, despite many an authentic rendition of Will the Real Slim Shady Please Stand Up? and Who Let the Dogs Out? Convinced she is the next Britney, WPM has resolved to sing louder and more obnoxiously until someone recognises this raw, unhidden talent.

* Praise be to that bastion of equal opportunities, the Italian judge. News reaches this very politically correct corner of Europe that we are being too uptight with our sexual harassment laws. No longer, say the Italians, should we see patting the female behind as some sort of pervy penchant of the office letch. No, no. Instead Rome's Supreme Court has ruled that a "dead hand" lingering on a female employee's thigh or buttock is not molesting, so long as it is not accompanied by suggestive remarks.

Now that that is cleared up, WPM looks forward to upcoming clarifications on the working laws of our Italian cousins. No doubt in future scenarios it will be fine to swipe the inner thigh of one's secretary or stroke the nipple of the office assistant, so long as the caressers keeps their mouths shut in the process.

webTitle: Briton murdered in Thailand by former wife

fields.headline: Briton murdered in Thailand by former wife
fields.trailText: A British man was murdered in western Thailand by his Thai former wife and her new husband after he asked to sleep with her while on a weekend trip together, the senior investigator in the case said yesterday.
fields.body:
A British man was murdered in western Thailand by his Thai former wife and her new husband after he asked to sleep with her while on a weekend trip together, the senior investigator in the case said yesterday.

Lieutenant Colonel Pree Cha Jitsopit said Sriprai Hormkaen, 38, and her husband Samarn Ruengwari, 40, confessed to killing Michael Witt, 52, of Wokingham, near Reading, at the River Kwai Inn in Kanchanaburi province because she was allegedly scared that he might rape and kill her.

"The only motivation appears to be that the victim wanted a reunion with his former wife," Col Jitsopit said yesterday.

He said police were not looking for any other suspects.

Mr Witt had lived with Ms Sriprai for six years before separating last year. They ran a bar in the tourist resort of Pattaya in southern Thailand. Col Jitsopit said the couple, who had no children, broke up after the business failed.

Col Jitsopit said the three checked into the hotel on Friday night, went out to dinner and returned about 11pm.

"The woman told us that she then went into the victim's room and he [Witt] said he would kill her and her new husband if she did not reunion [sic] with him."

Ms Sriprai allegedly then rushed back to her own room and told her husband that they had to kill Mr Witt immediately. They, according to Col Jitsopit, returned to Mr Witt's room at about 12.30am and attacked him. "They covered him in a blanket, smothered him with a pillow and also hit him many times on the chest," the officer said.

Local media reported that strands of a woman's hair and traces of cement were found on the victim's body but Col Jitsopit could not confirm this.

The investigator said the couple tried to cover up the crime by doing nothing until the middle of the afternoon and then asked a housekeeper to open Mr Witt's room. "They said they had not seen him all day and were worried about him," he said. The couple initially denied any knowledge of the crime and even showed police the hotel safety deposit box where Mr Witt had asked her to store his watch and £2,200.

But under police questioning Ms Sriprai reportedly confessed and Mr Samarn followed her lead.

The couple were taken back to the hotel yesterday to re-enact the crime.

A spokeswoman at the British Foreign Office said police had told the embassy in Bangkok that a British man had been killed in Kanchanaburi province and embassy staff were investigating.

webTitle: Explanation raises new questions

fields.headline: Explanation raises new questions
fields.standfirst:
Mandelson's defence Lengthy article for Sunday newspaper admits that Straw reminded him of fatal conversation

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson appears to have forgotten Denis Healey's wise piece of advice to politicians in trouble: when you are in a hole, stop digging.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson appears to have forgotten Denis Healey's wise piece of advice to politicians in trouble: when you are in a hole, stop digging. Wounded by the way in which he has been portrayed as a liar in Downing Street, he yesterday published his version of last week's events, which has served only to weaken his position further.

In a lengthy article in the Sunday Times, Mr Mandelson admits that his initial instinct was to ask the Home Office to keep his name out of the parliamentary written reply about the Hindujas' passport application which led to his downfall.

More damagingly, Mr Mandelson admits that the home secretary, Jack Straw, reminded him of his phone conversation with the home office minister, Mike O'Brien, a week before his resignation. Mr Mandelson's failure to recall this conversation was the "killer fact" which prompted Tony Blair to dispense with his ally.

Far from paving the way for Mr Mandelson's rehabilitation, his account raises questions about his judgment. Mr Mandelson decided to submit his thoughts for publication on Saturday after brooding over the clinical way in which he was removed from office by Mr Blair on Wednesday. Two factors convinced Mr Mandelson to fight back publicly.

In the four days since his resignation, he had decided that he was slain in a "kangaroo court" in which he was never given a proper chance to put his side. He contacted his former civil servants at the Cabinet Office at the time of the crucial calls in 1998. They backed up his version that they, rather than Mr Mandelson, had placed the calls to the Home Office.

"I decided then and there to start fighting back," Mr Mandelson wrote in the article, which was published with the help of his old friend, the millionaire novelist Robert Harris. "I know I have a mountain to climb before reversing this error, but I know I have to start somewhere."

Sadly for Mr Mandelson, he is unlikely ever to reach the summit because his version of events barely stands up to scrutiny. He damages himself by admitting that his initial instinct, when the Home Office contacted him about the parliamentary question, was to cover up his role.

The question asked what representations had been made on behalf of the Hindujas by Mr Mandelson and by the Europe minister, Keith Vaz. Adopting a Clintonesque approach, Mr Mandelson wrote: "Without any deep or long thought I said to my Northern Ireland private secretary that, as I did not make any representations to get anyone a passport, was it necessary to involve me in the answer?

Killer fact

"That was a mistake. I had done nothing wrong... The instructions I gave ... about responding to this question were not terribly clear, but the upshot was that I was reluctant to agree to a parliamentary answer that could be used mischievously to misinterpret my role.

"I stated that my contact with the Home Office had been casual and fleeting and I did not see why my involvement needed to feature. The Home Office responded that it wouldn't be possible to answer the questions in this way and that they would have to refer to the contact."

Friends tried to play down the significance of Mr Mandelson's attempts to wriggle out of answering a parliamentary question, saying ministers receive hundreds of such questions. However, to admit in print - in an article designed to restore his reputation - that he wanted to mislead parliament is a devastating indictment.

Mr Mandelson's account of his conversation with Mr O'Brien is a mess. He wrote that his former civil servants backed up his account that they had made the contacts, but then he admitted: "Of course, nobody could say categorically that such a call [with Mr O'Brien] had not taken place."

He also indicates a remarkably cavalier attitude to Mr Straw, who warned Mr Mandelson a week before his resignation that the Home Office had a record of a conversation with Mr O'Brien.

Devastating

"I did not think about this or its significance, as my recollection was focused entirely on the involvement of my private office; and, as I had no memory of any such phone conversation, I failed to attach importance to Jack's reference to it," he wrote.

Mr Mandelson's admission that he had been recently reminded of the call removes any excuse he had for failing to mention this. Yet he went on to write that when Mr O'Brien recalled the conversation - in the light of Mr Mandelson's claim that contacts had been made through officials - this "did not jog my memory".

With such evidence against him, Mr Mandelson has concocted a convoluted explanation for why he failed to mention the call. Writing of his Channel 4 interview, in which he was asked why he had forgotten the original conversation, Mr Mandelson said: "I responded that 'I didn't forget anything.' By this I meant that I didn't deliberately forget to mention it, rather that I didn't actually recall it."

Such an elaborate defence is said to have appalled Downing Street. Beyond Mr Mandelson's attempts to justify his actions, there is a final factor which guarantees his exile. He has claimed his memory may have been hazy because of the burden of the peace process.

In the article, however, Mr Mandelson admitted that he found time to spend last weekend in Versailles making a speech beyond his brief on foreign policy. When the seminar ended he stayed in Paris, dictating his fatal statement from a museum.

webTitle: Yves Saint Laurent attends rival menswear show

fields.headline: Slimane gets rival's approval
fields.trailText: The reclusive Yves Saint Laurent shocked the fashion world yesterday when he attended the menswear show of a rival fashion house.
fields.body:
The reclusive Yves Saint Laurent shocked the fashion world yesterday when he attended the menswear show of a rival fashion house.

Saint Laurent opted to watch the first Dior menswear show created by Hedi Slimane, but he did not attend the YSL presentation by Tom Ford the evening before.

The 64-year-old designer, flanked yesterday by his business partner, Pierre Berge, actress Catherine Deneuve and Dior's creative force John Galliano, had not attended another designer's show for at least 10 years. Mr Slimane resigned from YSL last March when it was bought by Gucci Group NV. Ford, who is behind the Gucci men's and women's ready-to-wear lines had announced that he would be taking the mantle of the YSL men's line for the autumn/winter 2001 season onwards.

Saint Laurent began his career as a replacement to Christian Dior nearly half a century ago, leaving Dior after a disagreement with the company which then spurred him on to originate his own line. With that history in mind it was even more remarkable that Saint Laurent, who is now only responsible for couture at YSL, appeared at such a high-profile event hosted by his former employer.

The collection that Slimane delivered ran rings around Ford's first catwalk presentation for YSL shown on Saturday night. That lacked variety, sensitivity and personality.

Slimane, using a colour palette of dove grey, black, pink and cyan blue, carved away the boxy silhouettes that had been the signature at Dior Menswear (previously designed by Patrick Lavoix) for many seasons, to create slimline suits and coats.

Draped fluid shirts with the sleeves slashed away were left unbuttoned to the navel. Silver-grey floral tributes attached to the body by fine strands of silk or leather ribbon, delicate prints trapped under a film of glistening clear sequins and fine perforated leather tuxedos prompted the 33-year-old designer's audience to give a deserved and rarely witnessed standing ovation.

webTitle: Iran's 'rogue agents' get death sentence

fields.headline: Iran's 'rogue agents' get death sentence
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: Three Iranian secret agents have been sentenced to death by the military court and 12 others jailed for terms up to life for killing four secular dissidents. The sentences confirm the belief that the murders were part of a broad campaign of terror.
fields.body:
Three Iranian secret agents have been sentenced to death by the military court and 12 others jailed for terms up to life for killing four secular dissidents. The sentences confirm the belief that the murders were part of a broad campaign of terror.

Judge Mohammad Reza Aqiqi passed the sentences for the murder of two elderly nationalists, Darioush and Parvaneh Forouhar, and two writers, Mohammad Mokhtari and Mohammad Jafar Pouyandeh, in 1998. The murders shocked Iranians at home and abroad.

Among the five given life terms for ordering the murders were two former directors of the intelligence ministry, Mostafa Kazemi and Mehrdad Alikhani, according to the 17-page verdict made public on Saturday. Seven got lesser jail terms and three defendants, all intelligence operatives, were acquitted.

Reformers want to know why more senior figures were untouched.

"How come a petty operational agent of a government institution, who was only carrying out an order by a superior ... receives a harsher sentence than that of his commander?" the Islamic Iran Participation Front asked.

Its criticisms were carried by the state news agency, Irna.

Judge Aqiqi said Kazemi and Alikhani had prepared a hit list of up to 40 intended victims. This seems to support the view long held in Iran's reformist camp that the four murders were part of a planned drive by conservatives to stifle dissent.

Reformers maintain that they were among 80 murders in more than 10 years. Two investigative journalists and a former vice-president said the responsibility went much higher, involving senior clerics, state officials and the former president Ali Hashemi Rafsanjani. These allegations have all been denied.

It is unlikely that the verdicts will lead to revelations about other culprits or victims: the hearing was held behind closed doors and the judiciary vowed to prosecute anyone making "unauthorised revelations" about the case.

The intelligence ministry says the men were rogue agents who eliminated enemies of the regime on orders from immediate superiors, without the knowledge of those higher up.

The right wing was quick top say the case was closed. "The judge's verdict is the last word. Criticism of the judge, his verdict or the judiciary must not take place," said the conservative daily Resalat.

President Mohammad Khaami has vowed to work for a society based on the rule of law. When the intelligence service admitted in January 1999 that its agents were responsible for the murders, the minister in charge, Qorbanali Dorri Najafabadi, was forced to resign.

But there are many unanswered questions in the affair. One concerns the death of the most senior government agent arrested in connection with the killings, identified as the deputy intelligence minister, called either Saeed Emami or Saeed Eslami. He died in custody after drinking hair remover. Many are sceptical of the coroner's verdict of suicide.

This seems to support the view long held in Iran's reformist camp that the four murders were part of a planned drive by conservatives to stifle dissent. Reformers maintain that they were among 80 murders in more than 10 years. Two investigative journalists and a former vice-president said the responsibility went much higher, involving senior clerics, state officials and the former president Ali Hashemi Rafsanjani. These allegations have all been denied. It is unlikely that the verdicts will lead to revelations about other culprits or victims: the hearing was held behind closed doors and the judiciary vowed to prosecute anyone making "unauthorised revelations" about the case. The intelligence ministry says the men were rogue agents who eliminated enemies of the regime on orders from immediate superiors, without the knowledge of those higher up. The right wing was quick top say the case was closed. "The judge's verdict is the last word. Criticism of the judge, his verdict or the judiciary must not take place," said the conservative daily Resalat. President Mohammad Khaami has vowed to work for a society based on the rule of law. When the intelligence service admitted in January 1999 that its agents were responsible for the murders, the minister in charge, Qorbanali Dorri Najafabadi, was forced to resign. But there are many unanswered questions in the affair. One concerns the death of the most senior government agent arrested in connection with the killings, identified as the deputy intelligence minister, called either Saeed Emami or Saeed Eslami. He died in custody after drinking hair remover. Many are sceptical of the coroner's verdict of suicide.

webTitle: Exile wants to lead Peru, again

fields.headline: Exile wants to lead Peru, again
fields.standfirst: Alan Garcia is unperturbed by the chaos of his first presidency was chaotic, but he's having another go
fields.trailText: Alan Garcia is unperturbed by the chaos of his first presidency was chaotic, but he's having another go.
fields.body:
After nearly nine years in political exile, the former Peruvian president Alan Garcia, returned home at the weekend to launch a presidential campaign for election in April in a country worn down by a year of corruption scandals and political crises.

Speaking emotionally to a rally of 20,000 people in San Martin Square in central Lima, he promised to lead a government of "bread and freedom for all Peruvians".

Mr Garcia, who governed Peru from 1985 to 1990, showed he had lost none of his skill at oratory nor his populist touch in almost 10 years of exile in Colombia and Paris.

He promised there would be cheap credit for farmers, railed against the excessive phone and electricity bills ordinary people have to pay to the privatised utility companies, and called the tax authority, the Sunat, a "Nazi police".

Peruvians are sharply divided about Mr Garcia. Elected in a 1985 landslide by the traditional centre-left Apra party, he won approval ratings of more than 90% as the country's youngest president at 35. But his popularity sank as guerrilla violence spiralled upwards and the economy downwards.

Many people remember him mainly for food shortages, power blackouts and hyperinflation, which reached 7,000%. The finance system was thrown into disarray when he tried to limit foreign debt payments to 10% of export earnings and attempted, unsuccessfully, to nationalise the banks. In a national opinion poll this month 65% of those questioned said they would never vote for him.

Even so, 3,000 supporters turned out at Lima international airport on Saturday to greet him off a commercial flight from Bogota. A band played party songs and many supporters wore headbands reading "The Apra never dies" or "Alan's coming back".

Malvina Correa, who works in a soup kitchen in the city of Callao, was one of those celebrating.

"Alan will give us work," she said. "When he was in government there were food queues but there was work too, while under the Chino [Fujimori] we got nothing."

Mr Garcia fled Peru in April 1992 when the man who had succeeded him as president two years before, Alberto Fujimori, tightened his grip on power by carrying out a so-called "auto-coup" with the backing of the army: congress was closed, supreme court judges were sacked and some political opponents jailed.

Mr Garcia hid in a water tank until he could make his way to the Colombian embassy, where he was given asylum.

After a corruption scandal broke in September, Mr Fujimori fled to Japan late last year. His right-hand man, the former spy chief Vladimiro Montesinos, is also on the run. The Swiss have found more than $70m (£48m) in accounts linked to him.

Mr Garcia faced corruption charges himself, but arrest warrants were lifted last week after judges ruled that they had expired under the statute of limitations.

Mr Garcia denied all the corruption charges.

Considered a wild-card in the 2001 presidential election, Mr Garcia is on about 10% in opinion polls, vying for second place with two others behind the leading candidate, Alejandro Toledo of the Peru Posible movement, on 32%.

He could make it to a second round. Paradoxically, he has improved Mr Toledo's chances by making him look far less radical by comparison.

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
'Whip attack' on hunt protester
Connery voted top film actor
Organic food prices to fall
fields.body:
'Whip attack' on hunt protester

A 58-year-old woman demonstrator was allegedly struck with a riding whip while filming the Old Surrey, Burstow and West Kent Fox Hounds hunt in Cowden, Kent, on Saturday. A huntsman, 38, was yesterday bailed by police investigating the incident.

About 25 animal rights supporters gathered at the hunt's kennels in East Grinstead, West Sussex, yesterday to protest against the alleged attack.

Connery voted top film actor

Sir Sean Connery has been ranked above figures like Sir Anthony Hopkins and Sir Alec Guinness as the greatest British movie actor in a poll of more than 10,000 people by the Orange Film Survey. Julie Walters was voted the most popular British actress.

Organic food prices to fall

Record sales of organic food over Christmas have prompted a fall in prices for February promotions, says the supermarket chain Tesco. Sales in organic food have risen by more than 70% in just over a year.

Children get phone bug

Nearly half of all children aged seven-16 own mobile phones, text messaging their friends rather than keeping them for emergencies, according to a survey by the NOP Research Group.

Winner takes all

One ticket won the £7.3m National Lottery jackpot on Saturday. The winning numbers were 4, 12, 15, 39, 45 and 47 and the bonus ball was 22. No ticket won the Lottery Extra draw, where the numbers were 5, 6, 13, 15, 22 and 37. One ticket won the £250,000 Thunderball top prize. The winning numbers were 8, 10, 20, 22, 31 and the Thunderball was 7.

fields.headline: Sport pick of the day
fields.trailText: World Alpine Skiing Championship
fields.body: World Alpine Skiing Championship British Eurosport, Somehow sport magically becomes more interesting as soon as the words "world championship" are tacked on the end. While downhill skiers normally face an uphill battle for recognition, the presence of 7,000 media personnel in St Anton, Austria for the next two weeks should change that. Expect the home nation, whose skiers are having a great season, to catch the eye - but not in today's women's Super-G, in which France's Regine Cavagnoud starts as favourite.

webTitle: Drama pick of the day

fields.headline: Drama pick of the day
fields.trailText: Ally McBeal
fields.body: Ally McBeal 9pm, E4 Things have gone off the McBoil this week. After the dancing babies, the writers seem to want to make this more soap than bubblebath, with Ally's internal monologue replacing her hallucinations with Al Green. Is the show in danger of becoming what its critics have always crowed it was - slushy, and indulgent? Even the normally excellent support feel as if they're losing grip - Cage doing a standard defence of a woman accused of sexual harassment, Ling hardly anywhere to be seen, and a mute Robert Downey Jr watching from the sidelines.

webTitle: Architectural wonders and blunders

fields.headline: Wonders and blunders
fields.standfirst: 1: Stephen Bayley
fields.trailText: 1: Stephen Bayley
fields.body:
Wonder: Walsall Art Gallery
Blunder: Mock Tudor house, Chelsea Embankment

There's a morality about "good" buildings, a simple test that can be easily applied. It's this: "Are things better now?" Decent architecture always improves its neighbourhood, makes people enjoy opportunities and ideas which were hitherto obscure or denied. This version of "good" building can take many forms, but there is one thing truly good buildings share: none of them are ever bogus. So, of recent work, there's one outstanding candidate: the new Art Gallery in Walsall is a masterpiece of building design, fantastically refreshing and stimulating in a sometimes weary and cynical world. The architects Caruso St John - together, incidentally, with the gallery's own director - show just what can be achieved with guts and conviction. A simple, honest, generously proportioned, well- detailed handsome building revives a belief, all but extinct in Game Show Britain, that intelligent modern architecture can refresh the body and the spirit of unhealthy, exhausted cities.

A similar amount of money produced one of the nastiest buildings in Britain, a vainglorious and preposterous Tudor farce on London's Chelsea Embankment. A folly born of the vanity of financier Christopher Moran, here is sick building syndrome in all its flatulent and insulting pageantry. The money has been spent, but the grotesque, feeble and sickly concept remains shuttered and incomplete. Dull archaeology and a heavy wallet may be reliable supports for a wobbly ego, but they do not necessarily make good buildings.

It's a lie and so it's immoral. It has made Chelsea worse, not better. Calculating the values of the lost opportunities on this superb site would be heartbreaking. In contrast to Walsall, this bloated folly diminishes one of the loveliest parts of London. So that's bad.

webTitle: The return of Egypt's fabled library

fields.headline: The sequel
fields.standfirst: 400,000 books, 4,600 granite panels and 2,000 seats...  Jonathan Glancey on the return of Egypt's fabled library
fields.trailText: 400,000 books, 4,600 granite panels and 2,000 seats... Jonathan Glancey on the return of Egypt's fabled library
fields.body:
You can spend all your money on roads and on housing and on the poor, but in the end you simply find yourself needing more money. Real civilisation always starts in the mind." This noble, if controversial statement made by Professor Mohsen Zahran, architect, city planner and head of the nearly complete £120m Alexandria Library lies at the heart of the decision made 11 years ago to rebuild, in modern guise, the most famous library of all time in one of the world's poorest countries. That was the legendary library founded by Alexander the Great and built by his Greek general, Ptolemy I, King of Egypt and his son Ptolemy II, Shelley's Ozymandias.

A showcase of classical learning, the Alexandrian library was originally housed in the Mouseion, an arts and science complex that included laboratories and conservatories, as well as a zoo and the library itself. At its height in the third century BC, the library was said to have housed some 700,000 papyrus manuscripts. Its librarians, among them Archimedes and the astronomer Aristarchus, had collected the works of, among very many others, Plato, Aristotle, Thucydides, Sophocles, Euripides, Hippocrates and Euclid, often when these authors were still at work. As well as storing books, the library acted as a publishing house copying manuscripts for distribution throughout the ancient world. It aimed to house every book, and thus, "all the knowledge in the [known] world".

Some ambition. But then Alexandria, founded in 322BC, was one of the greatest cities of the classical world. It remained the capital of Egypt until 969AD, although its decline had set in several hundred years before. The library and its fabulous collection was burned several times: accidentally during Julius Caesar's siege of the city in 48BC (it was rebuilt by Mark Anthony who made a gift of 200,000 manuscripts to Cleopatra), in 272AD by order of the Emperor Aurelian, in 391 by Christians enraged by the cult of Seraphis and the pagan books held in the library, and finally, or so it is said, by the Caliph Omar (or Umar) in 638. "If the writings of the Greeks agree with the Koran they are useless and need not be preserved," Omar is meant to have said. "If they disagree they are pernicious and ought to be destroyed." They were used as fuel to heat the city's 4,000 public baths for six months. Of course, this might just have been anti-Arab propaganda.

This still goes on in new ways. The new library was first announced in 1989 when the Oslo-based practice Snohetta won an open international competition for its design. It has been described by the Economist as a white elephant, and has been mocked for lacking books - and for a collections policy that seems at best random and at worst desperate. Some authors have already been excluded because of Islamic censorship laws. The shelves can hold up to 8m books, although the library will open with just 400,000. Saddam Hussein gave generously to the library fund before invading Kuwait.

Zahran, however, insists that the library is meant to build up its collections over the next 20 years. The building itself - a giant, angled cylinder set behind a great circular wall of inscribed Aswan granite and seeming to rise from the sea - has been likened to a giant colander clashing with a crashed flying saucer.

Yet the design is elegant, imposing and, as far as any architecture can be, quite timeless. It has been easy to mock Alexandria's ambition to become a cultural hub once more. Certainly, the city is no longer the vital junction box, connecting Europe, Asia and Africa, that it was 2,000 years ago. Yet if Bilbao can make hay with its Frank Gehry-designed Guggenheim Museum, why can't Alexandria revel in the splendour of its ambitious new library?

Despite so many weasel words, the building is imposing. The only partly glazed, 160m diameter slanting roof of the main library and seven-tiered, 2,000-seat reading room is a dramatic sight as construction nears completion. Tilted towards the sea, it has been designed to angle sunlight - at optimum levels throughout the year - down to the desks and shelves set on tiers of galleried floors beneath it. The roof is studded with patterns of green and blue glass and promises delightful plays of coloured light across the oak floors and custom- designed steel and timber furniture.

Daylight might be carefully filtered into the depths of the library, a third of which is below ground, but sunlight will flare off its roof at the beginning and end of each day, recalling the way in which the sun appeared to play monumental and deeply significant games - to the ancient Egyptians, at least - with the once shining, limestone-clad pyramids. The height of the building, 31m, is exactly half that of the first great pyramid, at Sakkara. The geometry of the library has been derived in part from a study of ancient Egyptian monuments and in part by that of the bay itself.

The library is reached via an arrow-like walkway from the street that whistles past a new planetarium in the guise of an 18m black concrete sphere, banded with blue lights that give it a startling and appropriately sci-fi appearance by night. The walkway pierces the library walls that, with a little styling by artist Jorun Sannes, are composed of 4,600 granite panels inscribed with calligraphy, lettering and braille drawn from around the world.

Inside, the great roof is supported by fluted columns rising up to 21m high. It promises to be an impressive sight. For Kjetil Thorsen, one of the architects who has led the design of the project from its inception in 1989, when he was just 31, it should be a vindication of a building that must have seemed little more than a pipe dream for many years.

Yet the big question remains: is the library really going to be the great seat of learning and research it is meant to be, or will it be more of a tourist attraction? Censorship is another problem: who can take a library seriously if it sets out limiting knowledge, especially if it is the spiritual successor to Alexander's depot of "all human knowledge"?

As for the tourist factor, there is nothing wrong with this. The pyramids have long lost their religious purpose (if not their spiritual potency), but they continue to captivate the eyes and wallets of travellers. In Bavaria, Ludwig II was castigated for his lavish expenditure on fairy-tale palaces, yet today Neuschwanstein is Germany's top tourist attraction and a moneyspinner.

The Bibliotheca Alexandrina is a brave, dramatic building, refreshingly free from fashionable architectural conceits. But whether its history will be written, finally, by some future Shelley remains to be seen.

webTitle: Classical review: Sinfonia 21/ Brabbins

fields.headline: Sinfonia 21/ Brabbins
fields.standfirst:
Great Hall
Imperial College
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Great Hall
Imperial College
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Canadian composer Claude Vivier was murdered in Paris in 1983, at the age of 35. His remarkable output has only recently begun to establish itself in contemporary music programmes, and two of his works - Trois Airs pour un Opéra Imaginaire for soprano and ensemble, and Et Je Reverrai cette Ville Etrange for six players - were given UK premieres by Sinfonia 21 and Martyn Brabbins.

There is something morbidly mythical about a brilliant artist cut down in his prime. But Vivier's music speaks of different myths. Et Je Reverrai consists of five melodies that the ensemble plays in unison, each short section separated by the sound of a gong. This sparse simplicity of structure, combined with the eastern inflections and echoes of plainchant in the melodies themselves, created an atmosphere of arcane ritual. Yet Vivier's vision of timelessness is wholly synthetic and invented. It is like entering a world both disturbingly strange anddisarmingly familiar.

The Trois airs pour un Opéra Imaginaire, sung by soprano Eileen Hulse, develop the vividness of Vivier's dream world. Hulse performed in a mysterious language that Vivier created, and her role was as much textural as soloistic. Her voice frequently submerged beneath the opulent instrumental parts, Hulse seemed to be taking part in an obscure, private drama. But there was a shimmering clarity in Vivier's instrumental writing, as the players relished their luminous quarter-tones and lush harmonies.

Two works by the Dane Hans Abrahamsen also explored a world of heightened reality. Morchenbilder - Fairytale Pictures - borrows its title from a piece by Schumann, and Abrahamsen's music brought a realm of fleeting fantasy to life. Winternacht was a melancholy investigation. Out of an apparent tranquillity loomed grotesque figures: a threatening trumpet line, an insistent violin melody and an obstinate piano solo.

The world premiere of Richard Causton's arrangements of two movements from Guillaume de Machaut's Messe de Notre Dame completed the programme. Causton created a decorous reimagination of the 14th-century masterpiece. Splitting his ensemble into two groups, he experimented with timbral and antiphonal effects, while maintaining all of Machaut's original pitches and rhythms. Although there were beautiful moments in the halo of string sonority he added to Sanctus, it was difficult to tell what, beyond an obvious reverence, Causton's true feelings were for Machaut's music.
fields.bodyText: Canadian composer Claude Vivier was murdered in Paris in 1983, at the age of 35. His remarkable output has only recently begun to establish itself in contemporary music programmes, and two of his works - Trois Airs pour un Opéra Imaginaire for soprano and ensemble, and Et Je Reverrai cette Ville Etrange for six players - were given UK premieres by Sinfonia 21 and Martyn Brabbins. There is something morbidly mythical about a brilliant artist cut down in his prime. But Vivier's music speaks of different myths. Et Je Reverrai consists of five melodies that the ensemble plays in unison, each short section separated by the sound of a gong. This sparse simplicity of structure, combined with the eastern inflections and echoes of plainchant in the melodies themselves, created an atmosphere of arcane ritual. Yet Vivier's vision of timelessness is wholly synthetic and invented. It is like entering a world both disturbingly strange anddisarmingly familiar. The Trois airs pour un Opéra Imaginaire, sung by soprano Eileen Hulse, develop the vividness of Vivier's dream world. Hulse performed in a mysterious language that Vivier created, and her role was as much textural as soloistic. Her voice frequently submerged beneath the opulent instrumental parts, Hulse seemed to be taking part in an obscure, private drama. But there was a shimmering clarity in Vivier's instrumental writing, as the players relished their luminous quarter-tones and lush harmonies. Two works by the Dane Hans Abrahamsen also explored a world of heightened reality. Morchenbilder - Fairytale Pictures - borrows its title from a piece by Schumann, and Abrahamsen's music brought a realm of fleeting fantasy to life. Winternacht was a melancholy investigation. Out of an apparent tranquillity loomed grotesque figures: a threatening trumpet line, an insistent violin melody and an obstinate piano solo. The world premiere of Richard Causton's arrangements of two movements from Guillaume de Machaut's Messe de Notre Dame completed the programme. Causton created a decorous reimagination of the 14th-century masterpiece. Splitting his ensemble into two groups, he experimented with timbral and antiphonal effects, while maintaining all of Machaut's original pitches and rhythms. Although there were beautiful moments in the halo of string sonority he added to Sanctus, it was difficult to tell what, beyond an obvious reverence, Causton's true feelings were for Machaut's music.

webTitle: Iceland man vows to keep fighting

fields.headline: Iceland man vows to keep fighting
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Iceland's chairman, Malcolm Walker, has returned from holiday in a defiant mood and intends to fight calls for his resignation over his controversial £13.5m sale of shares just before Christmas.
fields.body:
Iceland's chairman, Malcolm Walker, has returned from holiday in a defiant mood and intends to fight calls for his resignation over his controversial £13.5m sale of shares just before Christmas.

Denying weekend press reports that Mr Walker was preparing to quit the frozen food chain, an Iceland spokesman said: "He believes he has done nothing wrong, and he has obeyed all the rules, so why should he resign?"

However, Mr Walker may step back to a non-executive role earlier than anticipated. He was expected to scale down his job in March, but the timing of his move will be discussed at a board meeting early this week.

The company will announce exactly when the change will be effective alongside an update on its recent merger with Booker, scheduled to be published by Wednesday.

Mr Walker, 54, sold 4m shares at 339p on December 20. Last Monday, the company revealed its sales had slumped in the four weeks to December 28, sending the price plunging as low as 200p.

Several institutional investors are reported to have requested urgent meetings with the company for an explanation for these events. Mr Walker was forced to cut short his holiday in the Maldives to face his critics.

Iceland's spokesman said the company was unaware that its Christmas performance had been disappointing until the week of January 15 , just days before its trading statement. He said Mr Walker's transaction in December was cleared by the board and was handled by Iceland's usual stockbrokers.

Mr Walker founded Iceland by selling peas and fish fingers from a tray in Oswestry, Shropshire, in 1970. He still has a holding of some 1.6m shares in the company.

His share sale came a week after the company appointed a new chief executive, former Wickes DIY boss Bill Grimsey. Colleagues say Mr Walker had been waiting for a new chief executive to arrive to allow him to prepare for his semi-retirement. They say his sale of shares was intended to fund new ventures when he goes non-executive.

Iceland's merger update on Wednesday is likely to be disappointing. Sources say it could reveal that the company is struggling to meet its target of making £20m cost savings by March, and a further £30m by spring 2002.

webTitle: New rules to ease banking charges

fields.headline: New rules to ease banking charges
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Proposed new rules for current accounts and credit cards designed to drive down charges and outlaw small-print traps are expected to be announced by the Treasury this week.
fields.body:
Proposed new rules for current accounts and credit cards designed to drive down charges and outlaw small-print traps are expected to be announced by the Treasury this week.

As part of its campaign to make it easier for people to obtain value for money financial products, it will announce voluntary minimum standards which will lay down requirements on the charges people pay and the terms they have to agree.

The Treasury has already introduced so-called Cat standards - charges, access and terms - for individual savings accounts and mortgages, and aims to tackle current accounts, credit cards and, eventually, personal loans and general insurance.

Ministers could insist that Cat-marked current accounts do not impose monthly fees on authorised overdrafts and do not exceed a specified maximum overdraft rate. On credit cards it is likely they will set limits on small print fees such as late payment charges and penalties for exceeding the credit limit.

The new regime forms part of the government's response to last year's Cruickshank review of high street banks, which claimed the industry was overcharging the public by up to £5bn a year.

The proposals for Cat standards for accounts and cards will be put out for consultation, and the hope is that the new regime will be in place by the end of this year.

Barclays, Lloyds TSB, HSBC and NatWest hold almost 70% of current accounts and have come under fire over poor rates of interest, overdraft costs and cash machine charges. Some observers reckon a ban on authorised overdraft monthly usage fees is likely. In the case of Barclays and Lloyds TSB, the fee is £5, but other players do not impose a charge.

The Treasury also wants to make it easier for the UK's 23m credit card holders to know what they are being charged, and to compare their rates with other providers.

webTitle: Waiters sought in credit card inquiry

fields.headline: Waiters sought in credit card inquiry
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: City detectives are hunting two waiters, believed to be working at top London restaurants, in connection with an investigation into the country's most sophisticated credit card fraud.
fields.body:
City detectives are hunting two waiters, believed to be working at top London restaurants, in connection with an investigation into the country's most sophisticated credit card fraud.

The two men, who were known as Sorin Lasculescu and Ivan Guzun at the time of their arrest last year, are both on the run after jumping bail.

The scam, sources estimate, would have eventually cost banks up to £5m. Two Russians, Vladimir Stroguine and Alexandre Tanov, have already been convicted of conspiracy to defraud and will be sentenced next week.

During their hearing, Southwark Crown Court heard the pair used a network of waiters and barmen across London to download information from credit cards, through a process known as "skimming", on machines clipped to their belts. The information was then used to make counterfeit cards which were sold for £300 each.

Lasculescu, a 30-year-old Romanian, was previously employed at City eaterie Caravaggio. He left prior to his arrest and was believed to be living in east London but, after being charged with conspiracy to defraud, he was given bail and has not been seen since.

Guzun, a Moldovan in his early 30s, was arrested and quizzed by police in connection with the inquiry. He was released on bail without charge but his whereabouts are unknown. Police believe he has also used the name of Norwegian Tom Ronny Gundersen, and that both men, who have many years of experience as waiters, could still be operating in the London area.
