webTitle: Office hours: Don't ask the experts

fields.headline: Don't ask the experts
fields.standfirst:
Those we consider most qualified to get things right usually get them wrong. Bill Saunders suggests we trust our own judgement instead

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The office - like everywhere else, these days - is governed by experts. Can you open and shut your window? Do you use a PC or a Mac? Whether you can or do is down to somebody else's decision. Somebody who claims to be far more qualified on the subject than you.
fields.body:
The office - like everywhere else, these days - is governed by experts. Can you open and shut your window? Do you use a PC or a Mac? Whether you can or do is down to somebody else's decision. Somebody who claims to be far more qualified on the subject than you.

But experts are not always as infallible as they like to claim - as supermarket chain Iceland has realised. Last week, the company admitted that its policy of all organic produce was a flop with the public - contrary to what the experts had predicted. At the same time, it was revealed that virtually all the big fund managers underperformed on the stock market last year. In an even bigger blunder, it turned out that the immigration service had wrongly held a British man in prison for a year as an illegal immigrant. Mr Chukwulebuka Ajaelu had to produce DNA samples to prove who he was. All the while, the experts were sure he was wrong.

Even titled "experts" are subject to human error, and recent evidence suggests that experts, in every field, have more off-days than on-days. According to Nick Chater, director of the Institute of Applied Cognitive Science at the University of Warwick, when expert judgments can be measured against mechanical systems of prediction, their suggestions simply do not match up.

Chater became interested in the fallibility of experts when he was conducting research on behalf of a financial institution eager to know what motivated its customers. He was specifically looking into the psychology of what made customers make investment decisions. When he compared the outcomes of the decisions of uninformed individuals with experienced, "expert" investors, no noticeable difference emerged.

Further investigation revealed that this phenomenon is well known to psychologists. Chater found more than 100 studies stretching back nearly 50 years, detailing the same results. Experts, in every field, are more likely to be wrong than right.

Chater points to the "large body of well-attested knowledge" as to why we should trust him - an expert in cognitive psychology himself - on this one. "This research has recorded how people make decisions, where they are likely to go wrong, and at least some valuable suggestions about how decision-making can be improved."

With that kind of promise, business managers immediately became interested. Earlier this month, when Chater and a colleague, Koen Lamberts, offered a presentation on expertise and improved decision-making to businesses, it was so oversubscribed that a second session had to be organised for the same day.

So what does cause experts' judgment to go awry? According to Chater, a major influence is over-confidence. This fault is not confined to experts - it's common to human nature. One study found that for a series of questions where people assessed their performance as 80% correct, the actual results panned out at 65%. Perversely, the more ignorant we are on an issue, the more confident we become.

"Decisions of all kinds, including big decisions, are routinely being made with a powerful, but illusory, sense of control and understanding," says Chater. And they go through thanks to the weaknesses of what he calls "group think".

The old proverb has it that two heads are better than one. Not according to the psychologists. They say groups of experts do demonstrably worse than individuals but they go about their affairs with a great deal more confidence. While differences of opinion may emerge, a much more subtle process is at work. "People are 'soaking up' views from other members of the group, which can strengthen their own views; and this is a mutually reinforcing process," says Chater.

Many famously disastrous decisions have emerged from insular and tightknit groups. So what can be done to make experts work better? Chater suggests we have faith in our own, independent thoughts and views, for a start. Mostly, though, his advice is to accept the experts' error-prone ways as we take their views on board. Unfortunately, human nature has a preference for big decisions being made by human beings. So the more important the decision to be made, the more likely it is to be taken by the most fallible method.

"Indeed, perhaps the most important lesson from the study of real-world human decision-making," says Chater, "is realising just how difficult the task of forecasting the future, and attempting to control it, really is."

webTitle: Opera review: The Rhinegold

fields.headline: Ring of great promise from ENO
fields.standfirst:
The Rhinegold
London Coliseum
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
The Rhinegold
London Coliseum
Rating: *****
fields.body:
The outside of the Coliseum is decked in scaffolding but it has all disappeared from the auditorium. The Italian season has been and gone, and with it the permanent set; the English National Opera's thoughts are now turning to the next major project - a Ring cycle that will be completed in four years.

Each of the works in the tetralogy will be performed in concert before the whole thing is staged by Phyllida Lloyd. The four performances of The Rhinegold that have just begun will be followed by The Valkyrie in a year's time, and the whole cycle will be given in concert in autumn 2002.

The company's previous Ring, conducted in the 1970s by Reginald Goodall and verging on mythic status, was always going to be a tough act to follow, and it's right that ENO should approach its successor with prudence. To underline the totally fresh start, they have commissioned a new English translation from Jeremy Sams, rather than go back to the Andrew Porter version that served the old production so faithfully. This first sample of Sams's text promises well indeed - direct, unfussy and not too colloquial, it nicely reflects the internal rhymes and alliterations of Wagner's original. The thrilling performance under Paul Daniel got an amazingly high proportion of the words across, and suggested that the cast are already growing into their roles.

These are more than just concert performances, though. The orchestra is in the pit, with percussions and harps spilling over on to the stage; the singers deliver from a raised platform between them. There's basic lighting, some atmospheric smoke and signifying costumes - Wotan has his eyepatch and greatcoat; Alberich sports a donkey-jacket, spectacles and natty hat. The words are delivered kabuki-style towards the audience rather than another character. It is powerful and generates far more dramatic intensity than the last Wagner seen in London, the Royal Opera's woeful Tristan three months ago.

With minor exceptions the singers have been expertly chosen. If Matthew Best's Wotan - already familiar from Scottish Opera's ongoing cycle - comes across more as a bullying gangland godfather than a god, that extra dimension may well come later; there's no doubting he has the vocal resources to round things out. Andrew Shore's Alberich - knotted, intense, and physically imposing - is inspired casting, as is Susan Parry's insistent Fricka; the prospect of her big scene in Valkyrie is something to relish. Loge is a gift of a role for a performer of Thomas Randle's stage presence, and he gives it real sardonic edge. As played by Mark Richardson and Stephen Richardson,Fasolt and Fafner become real characters, with real emotions for once. There is a nicely contrasting trio of Rhinemaidens (Linda Richardson, Christine Rice, Rebecca de Pont Davies), a luscious sounding Erda (Patricia Bardon) and surely the tallest dwarf ever in John Graham Hall's lucid Mime.

The orchestral playing, lumpy at first, settled down well, and by the end of the second scene the dramatic trajectory was fixed. After that, Daniel made sure the tension never faltered.

 Further performances tomorrow, Friday and February 6. Box office: 020-7632 8300.

webTitle: Avoid being wrong-footed

fields.headline: Avoid being wrong-footed
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: * Accept imprecision from experts. If they say a final figure could be between 4m and 20m, accept the extremes of that range and do not force them into a pointless precise figure that you are then stuck with.
fields.body:
* Accept imprecision from experts. If they say a final figure could be between 4m and 20m, accept the extremes of that range and do not force them into a pointless precise figure that you are then stuck with.

* Break away from "group think" and encourage a range of opinions by experts acting outside and independently of a group decision-making process.

* If reality proves different from expectation, adjust expectations and give pull-out decisions to those outside the group to stop the original decision-makers digging themselves in even deeper.

* Change the blame culture. Praise, or at least support, people who have walked away from something that has not worked rather than hanging on until the grim end.

webTitle: Better insurance consumer protection is on the way

fields.headline: Better insurance consumer protection is on the way
fields.trailText: The Office of Fair Trading has approved a controversial move that could reduce the number of people allowed to sell general insurance, which covers areas such as motor, home and travel cover.
fields.body:
The Office of Fair Trading has approved a controversial move that could reduce the number of people allowed to sell general insurance, which covers areas such as motor, home and travel cover.

The announcement made by the OFT was on behalf of the General Insurance Standards Council, an authority set up last year to regulate insurance selling.

The GISC wants everyone who provides insurance - both direct insurers and brokers - to be registered with it and abide by a code of conduct covering areas such as training, consumer advice and maintaining professional standards. Insurance companies who sell through brokers must now agree only to deal with those who are GISC members.

The OFT has now given this move the green light and everyone selling insurance will now be expected to sign up. To date, insurance companies which already have strong regulation in place have been far more willing to join.

The element of compulsion places pressure on those with less specialist knowledge who are currently selling insurance such as such as vets, solicitors and travel agents. They will need to register and make sure their product knowledge and selling standards are up to scratch. They will also need to pay GISC fees and prove they are solvent.

Although some have argued that forcing membership was anti-competitive, the GISC is delighted with the OFT's decision. Chairman, Anthony Howland Jackson said: "This represents a milestone in the development of GISC and I am particularly pleased that it also recognises our rules as transparent, non-discriminatory and based on objective standards."

He added the main purpose of the GISC was to make sure that general insurance customers are treated fairly and properly by establishing, monitoring and enforcing standards of good practice.

The move has also been welcomed by the National Consumer Council. It said: "This will be a welcome end to the confusing system of having several different regulators, which has left noticeable gaps in terms of consumer protection."

The move also looks set to improve the current system of consumer complaints for general insurance. Currently, the GISC can only sort out complaints about its own members. But, since it has only been established a short time, many of those selling insurance falls outside of its remit. With all brokers now likely to join, it will have a far broader scope.

They will need to register and make sure their product knowledge and selling standards are up to scratch. They will also need to pay GISC fees and prove they are solvent. Although some have argued that forcing membership was anti-competitive, the GISC is delighted with the OFT's decision. Chairman, Anthony Howland Jackson said: "This represents a milestone in the development of GISC and I am particularly pleased that it also recognises our rules as transparent, non-discriminatory and based on objective standards." He added the main purpose of the GISC was to make sure that general insurance customers are treated fairly and properly by establishing, monitoring and enforcing standards of good practice. The move has also been welcomed by the National Consumer Council. It said: "This will be a welcome end to the confusing system of having several different regulators, which has left noticeable gaps in terms of consumer protection." The move also looks set to improve the current system of consumer complaints for general insurance. Currently, the GISC can only sort out complaints about its own members. But, since it has only been established a short time, many of those selling insurance falls outside of its remit. With all brokers now likely to join, it will have a far broader scope.

webTitle: Pick of the week

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: The Russian Formalists take on cyber cinema, jazzy music and computer cruelty, the dark side of the Scottish countryside
fields.trailText: The Russian Formalists take on cyber cinema, jazzy music and computer cruelty, the dark side of the Scottish countryside
fields.body:
To Be Continued
(www.atomfilms.com)
Eighty years ago, the Russian Formalists discovered the theory of 'relational editing', which is just a smart way of saying that audiences construct a film's narrative meaning through a montage of different shots. Bear that in mind when you're sampling this cunning short, which layers three separately tense vignettes (involving a runaway child, an illicitly copulating couple and an over-cooked breakfast egg) to great effect. Director Linus Tunstrom brings his stories (and his viewers) to boiling point in a mere five minutes and still manages to pull off a surprise in the final scenes. (KS)
 View the film

Qrime
(www.sundanceonlinefilmfestival.org)
We're going for a second bite at the Sundance cherry, out of sheer delight at a site on which Star Wars fan films are nowhere present. Also because they are currently offering Qrime, an arresting three-colour animation which really understands how to make the web work for art film. Whether you've got a broadband pipe wider than the Channel Tunnel or a sluggish 28k modem, you'll feel the impact of Motomichi Nakamura's meditation on violence down the ages. Using a chunky retro computer aesthetic combined with a startling sound mix of jazzy music and muttered quotations, he creates his own little quick-loading theatre of cruelty. So good, you'll watch it twice. (KS)
 View the film

Joyride
(www.britshorts.com)
Despite its name, the recently launched Britshorts.com is actually a Europe-wide showcase for high quality short film on the web. Proving to be one of its early success stories is Joyride, an exhilarating ten-minute drive through the dark side of the Scottish countryside. Two unnamed assailants abduct a cable repairman in the middle of the night. Tied up in the boot of their car, he uses his ingenuity and courage to fabricate his escape. Dark, but not gratuitously so, this is a stylish and pacy film noir for the digital age. (SD)
 View the film

webTitle: Jazz review: Nikki Yeoh/ Cleveland Watkiss

fields.headline: Jazz with a jest at the Spitz
fields.standfirst:
Nikki Yeoh/ Cleveland Watkiss
The Spitz
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Nikki Yeoh/ Cleveland Watkiss
The Spitz
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
When forces as dynamic and inventive as DJ-vocalist Cleveland Watkiss and pianist Nikki Yeoh get together for a jam based on their travels and experiences, you can bet your last rupee the Rough Guide will be nowhere in sight.

Last year Yeoh was seen with the classical cellist Matthew Barley; recently she has been checking out Cuban masters. Watkiss, progressing from reggae into electronics, is just as hard to pin down. The two were together as part of the Serious Sampler series, which experiments with unlikely musical bedfellows.

A funny moment early in the set came when Yeoh tried to set up a rhythm on wood blocks for the DJ's sound sampler. After two failed attempts, Watkiss gave the machine a talking-to. "This is your final warning," he growled. The machine clicked into action.

Later, when a child screamed as he was taken off to bed by his parents, Watkiss amusingly took up the cry, then developed the vibe into another inventive number, ringing with middle-eastern tinges and glassy, waspish sounds, including harpsichord tones on piano. From there, the medley was whipped through a gale of sea changes, from Jabba the Hutt intonation from Watkiss to a dark piano shuffle and high melodic sweetness.

The set brimmed with textures working in fricative contrast. When Watkiss sang straight, it was enchanting but flat compared with his car horn squeaks, a wonderful bit of muted trumpet keening and cartoon scat-talk including a Scooby Doo "Huh?".

He also tackled Yeoh's own fiendish Mutual Serenade. "I wrote this tune 10 years ago. No one else would even look at it because it's got all kinds of weird intervals," she told us. Watkiss made a commendable stab at seesawing through the augmented fourths while Yeoh kneaded out stubborn knots of notes, producing a piece both intriguing and uncomfortable.

Throughout, the pair collaborated through jest as much as music. "I'll do the jazz bit and talk to the audience," Yeoh announced. "These aren't jazz people," countered Watkiss. "Well, it's all music at the end of the day," she grinned.

A new-style gospel piece saw moments from Green Chimneys and the theme from Love Story threaded into the mix, and in the last tune Yeoh shut and thumped the lid of her piano to launch the audience into a clapping rhythm.

In true idiosyncratic style, they returned after a storm of applause not for an encore but to "thank God and spread some love - take it home to your mum, your dad, your cat, your dog".

webTitle: The inside track: Drinking at work

fields.headline: The inside track
fields.standfirst:
Drinking at work

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Drinking at work
fields.body:
Sometimes the rules on alcohol and work are very clear cut. On the railways, nobody has been allowed to mix the two since the 19th century. In the closing days of British Rail, three clerks went out one lunchtime to have half a glass of beer because one of them was due to retire that afternoon. None of the men had anything do with trains, or even the public. But all three were sacked when they returned to their desks, including the man who was to retire. Rules, in this instance, were rules.

There are no records of anyone being sacked for being sober on the job, but there is no doubt that abstinence has blighted some careers. Drinking is a very inclusive activity, but there are many good reasons for not participating, ranging from religious conviction, to pregnancy, and, indeed, alcoholism. Give up cigarettes and the heaviest smoker will wheeze "congratulations", but decline a drink and you may do more damage to your career than you would if you were sick on the carpet.

Drinking at work is less fashionable than it once was, though it still pervades. Most employers accept that a day's paintballing is good for team-building, but a night in the local pub is better - and cheaper, as the employees pay.

Such informal team-building can be exclusive, however. Alcohol aside, not everyone has the time to attend. Managing the effects of over-indulgence is by no means straightforward either. There is a well-known example from the alcohol industry itself of a piss-up, not in a brewery, but in a hotel owned by a brewery. Sadly, the evening ended in a fist fight and the following morning there were some sackings.

This gave the employment tribunal much to think about. Were the employees at work, since they were on company premises and the company was the host? Eventually the tribunal concluded that as the hospitality was free, it was the brewery's responsibility that the employees misbehaved. No doubt the then celebrating employees drank to that.

webTitle: Theatre review:  The Secret Rapture

fields.headline: Welcome Hare revival on the Thatcherite psyche
fields.standfirst:
The Secret Rapture
Playhouse
Salisbury
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
The Secret Rapture
Playhouse
Salisbury
Rating: ***
fields.body:
What keeps a play alive? Often, I suspect, it is something unresolved or contradictory in its content. By strict logic David Hare's The Secret Rapture, first seen in 1988 and dealing with the psychology of Thatcherism, should by now be a bit passé. But in Joanna Read's highly welcome Salisbury revival you feel the play survives precisely because Hare is working out his own complex feelings about the interaction between public policy and private behaviour.

Hare presents us with two sisters brought together by the death of their bookselling Gloucestershire father. Marion, a junior minister in Thatcher's government, is brisk, focused and irritated by emotional mess. Isobel, who runs a commercial design firm with her lover, is humane, altruistic and full of a rather testing moral integrity. The problem the two sisters inherit is their youthful stepmother, Katherine - a relentlessly dependent ex-alcoholic full of a blackmailing helplessness. Who is to take her on? Inevitably it is Isobel, who, through her own instinctive charity, eventually loses everything she values.

In one sense, the play has an historical fascination: it reminds us of the greed, intolerance and curious vanity of the Thatcher years when anyone who didn't subscribe to the prevailing ethos was seen as some kind of deviant. In one of the best scenes Marion and her Christian businessman husband display a blithe incredulity at Isobel's ingratitude over the asset-stripping of her firm. But what makes Hare a good dramatist is that his political convictions are often at odds with his moral inquisitiveness. The final scene implies that the Thatcherite Marion, far from being a monster, is capable of redemption. And there is something prickly and disturbing about Isobel's undoubted goodness, which acts on everyone else like an ethical X-ray machine. In short, you don't always quite know where you stand.

My one cavil about Read's Salisbury production is that it sometimes irons out Hare's moral ambivalence and latent romanticism. Helene Kvale's Marion, while physically dashing, is a little too hysterically testy for comfort. The final transcendent moments are muffed, so that I wasn't sure whether Isobel was returning to earth as a ghostly visitant or arriving prematurely for the curtain call. Elsewhere Niamh Daly's Isobel has exactly the right quality of disquieting virtue and there is first-rate support from Louise Yates as the attention-demanding, witch-like Katherine, Richard Bacon as Isobel's devoted, marginalised lover and Simon Coury as Marion's devout husband, who unavailingly tries to reconcile Christianity and naked capitalism. But that is just one of the escalating contradictions that keeps Hare's play about private and public values theatrically alive.

 Until February 10. Box office: 01722-320333.

webTitle: Art review: Homes for the Soul

fields.headline: Homes for the Soul
fields.standfirst:
Henry Moore Institute
Leeds
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Henry Moore Institute
Leeds
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Homes For The Soul is subtitled Micro-Architecture in Medieval and Contemporary Art, and it is a theme worthy of the most imaginative cultural researcher or gallery curator. Some of the best thematic shows are based on just such unthought-of cultural comparisons, and there is the germ of a fascinating exhibition in the making here. Yet with only 21 tiny exhibits, crammed into the Institute's claustrophobic backroom, it is disappointingly tentative.

The medieval exhibits include bronze and copper censers, lead pilgrim badges and an exquisitely crafted chrismatory (a container for blessed oil). The miniature architectural elements of these objects elude to special sites of religious worship or pilgrimage. In the Middle Ages such micro-churches and cathedrals must have provided iconic refuge for souls constantly threatened with the distractions of physical hardship and the temptations of the flesh. They are virtual homes for that elusive and vulnerable spiritual essence.

As is to be expected, the contemporary sculptural mini-buildings have much more varied and ambiguous imaginary functions. So why bring these two disparate groups of works together? What's the point of the show? It is left to visitors to make up their own mind, and quite rightly so, but many might, like me, feel discouraged by the suspiciously stuffy air of a not very well thought through doctoral thesis.

Donald Rodney presents a minuscule house made from squares of his own skin pinned together. The translucent sculpture, suspended in an outsized glass frame, suggests just how small a threatened self can feel.

The intimate personal tone of Rodney's work is surprisingly missing from most of the other contemporary works. Thomas Schütte's Model for a Museum is a gold-sprayed cardboard mausoleum. Alex Hartley's crystal-clear modernist block contains a photograph of the deserted interior of a white cube gallery.

We live in a world in which the gadgetry of the new technologies is getting more and more compact. The expansionist tendencies of modernism have long passed. Also, our sense of personal and private space is shrinking to a perhaps unprecedented degree. One of these days some artist will do something extraordinarily timely and culturally relevant with the miniature, but he or she is nowhere in evidence here.

 Until March 18. Details: 0113-246 7467.

webTitle: Office Hours: Shaken but not stirred

fields.headline: Shaken but not stirred
fields.standfirst:
British businesses may have been hit by floods, petrol shortages and train delays, but they've done little to prepare for future crises. Kate Hilpern on the challenge to company complacency

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: British businesses may have been hit by floods, petrol shortages and train delays, but they've done little to prepare for future crises. Kate Hilpern on the challenge to company complacency.
fields.body:
Have you ever found there's no chance of getting to work because there's no fuel left at the local petrol station? Or that you're late because only a third of trains in your area are running? Or that when you do finally arrive at the office your health is in jeopardy because the latest floods have turned it into a danger trap? Employees in the UK are likely to have been affected by at least one of these national crises, according to the Institute of Management (IoM). What's more, it has warned British companies to do something about their response to such problems - or face severe consequences.

"Though badly shaken, UK businesses have not been stirred into action to confront emergencies like these in the future," states its new report. "If business leaders continue to ignore voluntary codes on assessing risk, they will face the heavy and costly hand of the law. The current government review on company law is seeking to include recommendations that will bring risk management within the scope of directors' legal duties."

So what are dutiful managers to do? Drive the trains themselves? Sell petroleum to their secretaries on the black market? Do a sun dance around the desk to send the rain away? "Their obligations don't reach quite that far," says Petra Cook, head of policy at IoM. "We're simply pointing out that risks to business - as well as dangers to staff - caused directly by employers' reactions to emergencies can be prevented."

Acceptance that lateness or absence isn't the member of staff's fault is one solution, she says, since failure to do so will almost certainly make them want to quit their job. Consider the flood waters in Kent and Sussex. While they may have subsided, they have left behind a dispute between the local branch of the Communication Workers Union (CWU) and the Royal Mail that could prompt industrial action. After all, the union says that postal workers who couldn't get to work because of flooding - or who needed time off work to bale out their waterlogged homes - were asked to take the time as either holiday or unpaid leave. "It is absolutely heartless to add to the woes of these people," says John Keggie, CWU general secretary.

Recruitment consultants including Office Angels claim it is particularly common for secretaries to get an ear-bashing from their manager when they can't get their car through the snow, or fail to purchase the last few litres of petrol in town. "An increased reliance on support staff means they are sorely missed when absent," explains a spokesperson. "Yet their status - which, in some companies remains low - means that rather than being told this, they are reprimanded."

Abigail Reiss, a 29-year-old PA, has left two posts for this very reason. "It's a job-seekers' market for secretaries right now," she explains. "There was no way I was going to hang around and take the blame for natural disasters when I knew I could walk into another job."

Some companies are believed not only to be putting their business in danger as a result of stringent rules on absence levels - but the staff themselves. Among the latest "anti-absence" strategies is paying staff not to stay away and providing a figure for the number of "acceptable" days off. "At best, it is a Dickensian way of managing people and at worst, it puts them at risk by making them attempt to travel when there are dangers involved," says John Richmond, a business psychologist specialising in absenteeism.

Particularly at risk during times of disaster are the fast increasing numbers of support staff who drive company cars. Whether they're used for getting to work or travelling during the working day, the statistics are grave: two-thirds of all company-owned vehicles are involved in some kind of accident each year - a far higher figure than for owner- drivers. Of course, these accidents aren't all a result of streets turning into rivers and tiredness caused by ensuing traffic jams. Nevertheless, many are a result of staff feeling obliged to use their cars, irrespective of conditions.

In 1999, two directors of a transport company were convicted for being indirectly responsible for a fatal accident in which one of their drivers fell asleep at the wheel. The message is clear: employers must carry out full risk assessments if they want to avoid the risk of prosecution. "Nobody would dream of giving an employee a potentially lethal piece of machinery to operate without providing training or warnings," James Sutherland, chairman of the Fleet Driver Training Association, recently told People Management magazine. "Yet how many companies are prepared to hand out the car keys without a second thought?"

Michelle Jones, a 24-year-old administration assistant, left her job as a result of the rail crisis late last year. "I liked the job, but I couldn't hack the journey. It went from being 30 minutes to 90 for several weeks. I opted for a post nearer to home," she says.

Although it is impossible to blame the employer in this case, the IoM says companies have responsibilities here, too. "In an age of advanced communication, a vast number of PAs and secretaries can feasibly work from home," explains Ms Cook. "If employers enabled secretaries to do this in times of national disaster, the risks to everyone involved would be a lot less."

Andrew Oswald, professor of economics at the University of Warwick, agrees. "Our latest survey found that workers in the UK are among the most unhappy in the developed world and that among the explanations for that is "commuting time". In other words, those who commute long distances are a lot less contented and a lot more likely to resign."

In fact, several studies show that employers should not consider the move to allow secretaries to work from home as an unfortunate reaction to emergency, but as a positive move. Flexible workers have repeatedly been found to be 60% more efficient than their office-based counterparts.

"I have a computer, a phone, access to email and am able to do my job as well as in the office," says Laura Williams, a 32-year-old PA. "The people I deal with over the telephone do not know whether I'm sitting in the office in Waterloo or on my kitchen table in my home in Kilburn."

Temporarily working from home can, according to the IoM, even be a life-saver for secretaries. "It sounds dramatic, but natural disasters such as storms or flooding increasingly affect office buildings," explains Cook. "If a PA, for instance, enters the office in the morning and turns on a light and fuses herself, her life will be at risk. If, on the other hand, the employer carries out a risk assessment first, danger is avoided. There are endless examples."

Making this need more urgent still is the fact that employers who fail to confront the possibility of such injuries and deaths may soon find themselves in trouble. Not only will the offence fall under legislation that may be brought in on risk management, but more seriously, it will be affected by the proposed new offence of "corporate killing".

This legislation, which is part of the government's commitment to improving health and safety at work, would make directors personally responsible for causing injuries and deaths through gross breaches of health and safety law.

At present, a company can be found guilty of manslaughter only if the prosecution can show a single individual was directly to blame. This means that while more than 3,000 people have been killed in the workplace in the past decade - many following national disasters - there have been only three successful prosecutions. When it comes to serious injuries at work, the figures are even more worrying - out of nearly 24,000 reported each year, only 11% are even investigated by the Health and Safety Executive or authorities such as councils. Barely one in 100 lead to prosecutions.

The TUC, which has pushed hard for the reform, claims: "It's high time that serious failings of organisations causing death should result in long prison sentences for those responsible."

National upheaval is not only becoming more common; it is becoming less surprising. News of floods next month or the month after would hardly raise eyebrows in some folk. But what must become surprising, the IoM insists, is any member of staff who is forced by an employer to suffer as a result.
fields.bodyText: Have you ever found there's no chance of getting to work because there's no fuel left at the local petrol station? Or that you're late because only a third of trains in your area are running? Or that when you do finally arrive at the office your health is in jeopardy because the latest floods have turned it into a danger trap? Employees in the UK are likely to have been affected by at least one of these national crises, according to the Institute of Management (IoM). What's more, it has warned British companies to do something about their response to such problems - or face severe consequences. "Though badly shaken, UK businesses have not been stirred into action to confront emergencies like these in the future," states its new report. "If business leaders continue to ignore voluntary codes on assessing risk, they will face the heavy and costly hand of the law. The current government review on company law is seeking to include recommendations that will bring risk management within the scope of directors' legal duties." So what are dutiful managers to do? Drive the trains themselves? Sell petroleum to their secretaries on the black market? Do a sun dance around the desk to send the rain away? "Their obligations don't reach quite that far," says Petra Cook, head of policy at IoM. "We're simply pointing out that risks to business - as well as dangers to staff - caused directly by employers' reactions to emergencies can be prevented." Acceptance that lateness or absence isn't the member of staff's fault is one solution, she says, since failure to do so will almost certainly make them want to quit their job. Consider the flood waters in Kent and Sussex. While they may have subsided, they have left behind a dispute between the local branch of the Communication Workers Union (CWU) and the Royal Mail that could prompt industrial action. After all, the union says that postal workers who couldn't get to work because of flooding - or who needed time off work to bale out their waterlogged homes - were asked to take the time as either holiday or unpaid leave. "It is absolutely heartless to add to the woes of these people," says John Keggie, CWU general secretary. Recruitment consultants including Office Angels claim it is particularly common for secretaries to get an ear-bashing from their manager when they can't get their car through the snow, or fail to purchase the last few litres of petrol in town. "An increased reliance on support staff means they are sorely missed when absent," explains a spokesperson. "Yet their status - which, in some companies remains low - means that rather than being told this, they are reprimanded." Abigail Reiss, a 29-year-old PA, has left two posts for this very reason. "It's a job-seekers' market for secretaries right now," she explains. "There was no way I was going to hang around and take the blame for natural disasters when I knew I could walk into another job." Some companies are believed not only to be putting their business in danger as a result of stringent rules on absence levels - but the staff themselves. Among the latest "anti-absence" strategies is paying staff not to stay away and providing a figure for the number of "acceptable" days off. "At best, it is a Dickensian way of managing people and at worst, it puts them at risk by making them attempt to travel when there are dangers involved," says John Richmond, a business psychologist specialising in absenteeism. Particularly at risk during times of disaster are the fast increasing numbers of support staff who drive company cars. Whether they're used for getting to work or travelling during the working day, the statistics are grave: two-thirds of all company-owned vehicles are involved in some kind of accident each year - a far higher figure than for owner- drivers. Of course, these accidents aren't all a result of streets turning into rivers and tiredness caused by ensuing traffic jams. Nevertheless, many are a result of staff feeling obliged to use their cars, irrespective of conditions. In 1999, two directors of a transport company were convicted for being indirectly responsible for a fatal accident in which one of their drivers fell asleep at the wheel. The message is clear: employers must carry out full risk assessments if they want to avoid the risk of prosecution. "Nobody would dream of giving an employee a potentially lethal piece of machinery to operate without providing training or warnings," James Sutherland, chairman of the Fleet Driver Training Association, recently told People Management magazine. "Yet how many companies are prepared to hand out the car keys without a second thought?" Michelle Jones, a 24-year-old administration assistant, left her job as a result of the rail crisis late last year. "I liked the job, but I couldn't hack the journey. It went from being 30 minutes to 90 for several weeks. I opted for a post nearer to home," she says. Although it is impossible to blame the employer in this case, the IoM says companies have responsibilities here, too. "In an age of advanced communication, a vast number of PAs and secretaries can feasibly work from home," explains Ms Cook. "If employers enabled secretaries to do this in times of national disaster, the risks to everyone involved would be a lot less." Andrew Oswald, professor of economics at the University of Warwick, agrees. "Our latest survey found that workers in the UK are among the most unhappy in the developed world and that among the explanations for that is "commuting time". In other words, those who commute long distances are a lot less contented and a lot more likely to resign." In fact, several studies show that employers should not consider the move to allow secretaries to work from home as an unfortunate reaction to emergency, but as a positive move. Flexible workers have repeatedly been found to be 60% more efficient than their office-based counterparts. "I have a computer, a phone, access to email and am able to do my job as well as in the office," says Laura Williams, a 32-year-old PA. "The people I deal with over the telephone do not know whether I'm sitting in the office in Waterloo or on my kitchen table in my home in Kilburn." Temporarily working from home can, according to the IoM, even be a life-saver for secretaries. "It sounds dramatic, but natural disasters such as storms or flooding increasingly affect office buildings," explains Cook. "If a PA, for instance, enters the office in the morning and turns on a light and fuses herself, her life will be at risk. If, on the other hand, the employer carries out a risk assessment first, danger is avoided. There are endless examples." Making this need more urgent still is the fact that employers who fail to confront the possibility of such injuries and deaths may soon find themselves in trouble. Not only will the offence fall under legislation that may be brought in on risk management, but more seriously, it will be affected by the proposed new offence of "corporate killing". This legislation, which is part of the government's commitment to improving health and safety at work, would make directors personally responsible for causing injuries and deaths through gross breaches of health and safety law. At present, a company can be found guilty of manslaughter only if the prosecution can show a single individual was directly to blame. This means that while more than 3,000 people have been killed in the workplace in the past decade - many following national disasters - there have been only three successful prosecutions. When it comes to serious injuries at work, the figures are even more worrying - out of nearly 24,000 reported each year, only 11% are even investigated by the Health and Safety Executive or authorities such as councils. Barely one in 100 lead to prosecutions. The TUC, which has pushed hard for the reform, claims: "It's high time that serious failings of organisations causing death should result in long prison sentences for those responsible." National upheaval is not only becoming more common; it is becoming less surprising. News of floods next month or the month after would hardly raise eyebrows in some folk. But what must become surprising, the IoM insists, is any member of staff who is forced by an employer to suffer as a result.

webTitle: Theatre review: Misconceptions

fields.headline: Misconceptions
fields.standfirst:
Octagon
Bolton
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Octagon
Bolton
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The original title of David Lewis's play was Sperm Wars. Why this had to change is unclear - perhaps people don't want sperm on the posters in Bolton - but it indicates better the biological nature of Lewis's acerbic comedy for a quartet of actors plus a supporting cast of thousands of the little blighters. Tinkering with the title just leads one to suspect that Misconceptions has been misconceived.

The fertile theme is infertility, as experienced by an intellectually overstimulated, middle-class couple who aren't growing any younger or any fonder of each other. Matthew, a biology lecturer with an enormous ego and tiny sperm count, has been attempting for years to impregnate his wife by arithmetic. Suspicious of doctors, he has taken up fertility treatment as a hobby. His trendy London flat is stuffed with box files full of calculations based on menstrual cycles and temperature charts - the baby itself having apparently become reduced to a small piece of algebra in a knotty equation.

His wife, Linda, has a problem with this - until solace arrives in the obliging form of Barry, an accountant Matthew has nominated as sperm donor. How Barry chooses to make his monthly deposit fuels the emotional centre of the comedy.

The play is determined to grapple with big ideas, from which it emerges slightly the worse off. It tries too hard to demonstrate biological determinism, and this shoehorns the characters into unwieldy philosophical arguments that strive for the ring of truth but often sound only the dull clunk of contrivance.

Though well served by committed, fluent acting, Simon Stallworthy's production batters the point home. Sperm motifs and DNA spirals embellish Dawn Allsopp's set, while in-utero video footage pulsates between scene changes. It's hard to imagine how much more explicit the theme could be made, short of issuing the men in the audience with sample bottles to fill.

The real difficulty is a situation that prevents you warming to the characters. You can't help feeling that a man who invites a colleague round to masturbate for his wife must be a bit of a tosser himself. Such an ill-formed scheme was always going to come to a sticky end.

 Until February 17. Box office: 01204-520661.
